献给约瑟夫·亨利克·斯科特

For Joseph Henryk Scott

介绍

INTRODUCTION

2011年4月初，加州大学伯克利分校的进化生物学家迈克尔·艾森登录亚马逊网站，想为他的实验室买一本备用书。他想买彼得·劳伦斯的《苍蝇的诞生》，这本书讲述了苍蝇从单细胞卵发育成嗡嗡作响的飞行昆虫的过程。这本1992年出版的书虽然已经绝版，但仍然受到学者和研究生的欢迎。艾森以前通常要花35到40美元买一本二手书。但在4月8日这一天，有两家亚马逊老牌卖家以远超他预期的价格出售这本书的全新未使用版本：1,730,045美元和2,198,177美元。

IN EARLY APRIL 2011, MICHAEL EISEN, an evolutionary biologist at the University of California at Berkeley, logged on to Amazon.com to buy an extra book for his lab. He was after The Making of a Fly, by Peter Lawrence, about the genetic development of a fly from a single-celled egg to a buzzing, flying insect. The 1992 book, though out of print, remains popular with academics and graduate students. Eisen was used to paying $35 to $40 for a used copy. But on this day, April 8, there were two established Amazon sellers offering new, unused copies of the book for quite a bit more than he wanted to spend: $1,730,045 and $2,198,177.

艾森以为这个价格是个错误或玩笑；他猜测，没人会给这本书定这么高的价格，就连作者本人也不会。第二天，他再次查看亚马逊网站，发现这本书的价格非但没有恢复正常，反而涨到了2,194,443美元和2,788,233美元。第三天，价格又涨到了2,783,493美元和3,536,675美元。价格持续上涨持续了两周，在4月18日达到峰值23,698,655.93美元。而且买家还得支付3.99美元的运费。第二天，也就是4月19日，这本书的价格下跌，稳定在106美元。

Eisen assumed the price was a mistake or a joke; nobody, not even the author, he speculated, would put such a value on the book. He checked back on Amazon the next day to find that, rather than returning to normal, the prices for the book had risen to $2,194,443 and $2,788,233. On the third day, the prices ascended to $2,783,493 and $3,536,675. The escalation continued for two weeks, with the price peaking on April 18 at $23,698,655.93. And a buyer still had to foot a $3.99 shipping bill. The next day, on April 19, the prices for the book fell, settling at $106.

但亚马逊为何要以近2400万美元的价格出售一本关于苍蝇遗传学的神秘书籍？这本书突然在亿万富翁收藏家之间热销了吗？它真的蕴含着寻宝的线索吗？它真的成了书籍界的“1869年拉菲罗斯柴尔德酒庄”吗？事实上，事情的真相是，为两家在亚马逊上销售数千本书的卖家定价的无人监督算法卷入了一场价格战。其中一个卖家的算法被设定为略高于竞争对手的价格。而第二个算法则不断提高自己的价格，使其更接近价格更高的卖家，这促使第一个算法再次提价。如此反复，直到这些书的价格变得像曼哈顿的顶层公寓一样昂贵。直到有人介入并推翻了系统，情况才恢复正常。如果这个故事只是个例，那么它只是一个关于算法失灵的无伤大雅的轶事。然而，大约一年前，发生了一件远比这更离奇的事情。

But why had Amazon been selling an arcane book on fly genetics for nearly $24 million? Had it suddenly become hot with billionaire collectors? Did it contain clues to find treasure? Had it become the 1869 Château Lafite Rothschild of books? What had actually happened, in fact, was that the unsupervised algorithms that priced books for the sellers, both of whom sold thousands of titles on Amazon, got into something of a price war. One of the sellers’ algorithms had been programmed to price the book slightly higher than the competitor’s price. The second algorithm, in turn, always increased its price to be closer to that of the higher seller, prompting the first algorithm to respond with another price hike. And on it went until the books were as expensive as Manhattan penthouses. Things didn’t return to normal until a human being stepped in and overrode the system. If this tale were an outlier, it would be a harmless anecdote about algorithms gone bad. Almost a year earlier, though, something far stranger had taken place.

2010年5月6日清晨，全球股市因希腊局势动荡而进一步下跌。抗议政府削减开支的暴徒席卷了雅典。许多人担心希腊将出现债务违约，这将使人们对全球经济衰退的担忧更加合理。到纽约上午10点左右，美国股市已下跌2.5%，这已经是极其糟糕的一天了。

Early in the day on May 6, 2010, the world’s stock markets were aggravated lower by unsettling developments in Greece, where rioters protesting government spending cuts had engulfed Athens. Many feared that Greece would default on its debts, which would legitimatize fears of a global depression. By midmorning in New York, the American stock markets had retreated 2.5 percent, already an exceedingly bad day.

但事情很快就变得难以解释。

But things soon swerved from bad to inexplicable.

东海岸时间下午2点42分，股市开始震荡，随后暴跌。仅仅三百秒后，下午2点47分，道琼斯指数就下跌了998.5点，轻松创下历史上最大的单日跌幅。追踪全球最受关注的股票指数——道琼斯工业平均指数的屏幕，看起来像是被一个恶作剧者黑了一样。近1万亿美元的财富化为乌有。

At 2:42 p.m. on the East Coast, the markets began to shudder before dropping into a free fall. By 2:47 p.m.—a mere three hundred seconds later—the Dow was down 998.5 points, easily the largest single-day drop in history. Screens tracking the Dow Jones Industrial Average, the most followed stock index in the world, looked like they’d been hacked by a practical joker. Nearly $1 trillion of wealth fell into the electronic ether.

CNBC对这五分钟的报道，一开始是主持人和嘉宾们轻松聊起希腊骚乱。当时道琼斯指数下跌了200点，就像当天大部分时间一样。当主持人艾琳·伯内特请来明星评论员吉姆·克莱默时，道琼斯指数下跌了350点。当道琼斯指数下跌500点时，克莱默——他可是个活力十足的人——平静地低语道：“事情开始变得有趣了。”

CNBC’s coverage of this five-minute span started with anchors and guests breezily chatting about riots in Greece. The Dow at that moment was down 200 points, as it had been most of the day. When anchor Erin Burnett brought on star commentator Jim Cramer, the Dow sat 350 points down. When it went 500 points down, Cramer, who is an animated man if he’s anything, calmly muttered, “Things are getting interesting.”

不到三分钟，观众就听到伯内特的声音打断了希腊新闻的报道，说道琼斯指数现在下跌了800点。伯内特语气中带着难以置信，她呼叫纽约证券交易所现场的CNBC记者斯科特·瓦普纳：“斯科特，大家在说什么？现在道琼斯指数已经下跌了800点。”

Within three minutes, viewers heard Burnett’s voice breaking into Greece coverage to say the Dow was now down 800 points. Burnett, with disbelief flecking her words, paged CNBC reporter Scott Wapner on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange: “Scott, what are people saying? Now you’re down 800.”

“当我问他们这里到底发生了什么事……我不知道，”瓦普纳磕磕巴巴地回答道。“他们害怕。这是投降。这是典型的投降。”

“When I asked them what the heck was going on down here . . . I don’t know,” Wapner replied, stumbling to find his words. “There is fear. This is capitulation. This is classic capitulation.”

随后，CNBC 又回到克莱默的节目。尽管道琼斯指数在三分钟内下跌了近 1000 点，但他依然保持着异常平静的神情。“我刚坐下，”克莱默说，他指的是自己刚到节目现场，“那已经是 500 点之前的事了。”

CNBC then went back to Cramer, who remained oddly serene, even though the Dow, in a span of three minutes, had fallen nearly 1,000 points. “I just sat down,” Cramer said, referring to his arrival on the set, “and that was five hundred points ago.”

主持人伯内特随后提到了宝洁公司。这家蓝筹股在几分钟内就从62美元暴跌25%，跌至47美元。这让克莱默的沉着冷静彻底崩塌。

Burnett, the anchor, then brought up Procter & Gamble, whose blue-chip stock, in a span of minutes, dove 25 percent from $62 to $47. This brought an end to Cramer’s stoicism.

“不可能。这不是真实价格，”克雷默恼怒地喊道。然后，他愤愤不平地吼道：“好吧，去买宝洁吧。”他转过身，直视着镜头，恳求观众们：“现在就去买。去买！”

“It can’t be there. That is not a real price,” Cramer proclaimed exasperatedly. Then, indignantly, he barked, “Okay, just go buy Procter.” He wheeled to look directly at the camera, imploring viewers, “Go buy it right now. Just go buy it!”

专业人士听从了这番建议。正如克莱默察觉到股市迅速跌得过低一样，其他人也意识到了这一点。道琼斯指数跌至谷底，下跌998.5点后，便开始以与下跌时一样快的速度快速回升。事实上，市场上涨的速度比下跌的速度还要快。不到一分钟，道琼斯指数——通常一天内很少能上涨300点——就飙升了300点。光是想想就让所有旁观者都感到困惑。

The pros heeded that exact advice. Just as Cramer sensed that stocks had quickly gotten way too cheap, so did others. After the Dow hit its nadir, down 998.5 points, it began racing back up just as swiftly as it had fallen. The market rose faster, in fact, than it had gone down. Within a minute, the Dow, which rarely moves 300 points in a whole day, shot up that exact amount. The mere thought of it confounded everybody watching.

位于伊利诺伊州埃文斯顿、管理着70亿美元资产的大型对冲基金Magnetar Capital的高管们听到一阵骚动后，纷纷从办公室冲出，奔向公司的交易大厅。“这里所有人都开始大喊，‘买，买，买’，”Magnetar的一位交易员说道。“不管你交易什么，只要买就行。”

At Magnetar Capital, a large hedge fund in Evanston, Illinois, that manages $7 billion, senior executives rushed out of their offices to the firm’s trading floor after hearing a commotion. “Everybody down here just started yelling, ‘Buy, buy, buy,’” says a Magnetar trader. “It didn’t matter what you were trading—just buy.”

在东海岸的第一纽约证券公司，交易大厅里的情况与马格内塔的交易大厅如出一辙。超过120名交易员争相成交，喊着一个简单的词：“买入”。

On the East Coast, at First New York Securities, the trading floor echoed that of Magnetar’s. More than 120 traders jockeyed to get orders filled, yelling one simple word: “Buy.”

“我的第一反应是，‘好吧，这肯定是个错误，我该怎么利用它？’”第一纽约交易主管汤姆·多尼诺说道。“我干这行25年了，从来没见过这样的事。”

“My first reaction was, ‘Okay, so this is an error, how do I take advantage of it?” says Tom Donino, head of trading at First New York. “I’ve been doing this for twenty-five years and I’ve never seen anything like that in my life.”

一些股价暴跌至1美分（例如0.01美元），导致价值数十亿美元的公司变得一文不值，但几秒钟后又反弹至30美元或40美元。其他股票则大幅上涨。苹果股价一度飙升至10万美元（此前约为250美元）。市场陷入剧烈动荡，无人知晓原因。无论问题是什么，都不可能全部归咎于一笔巨大的错误订单或一个流氓交易员。市场波动来得如此猛烈，以至于一些交易员和市场观察员，或许是在上厕所，或许是在喝咖啡，完全错过了。

Some share prices crashed to one penny—as in $0.01—rendering billion-dollar companies worthless, only to bounce back to $30 or $40 in a few seconds. Other stocks swung wildly up. At one point, Apple traded at $100,000 a share (up from about $250). The market had been gripped with violent turbulence and nobody knew why. Whatever the problem, it couldn’t all be dumped on one giant erroneous order or a single rogue trader. The action came so furiously that some traders and market watchers, perhaps on a bathroom break or lost in a cup of coffee, missed it completely.

回到CNBC的演播室，伯内特和克雷默目睹道琼斯指数在不到三分钟的时间内反弹了500点。尽管股市从未出现过如此剧烈的波动，但克雷默对此却显得异常无动于衷。

Back at CNBC’s studios, Burnett and Cramer watched as the Dow recovered 500 points in less than three minutes. Cramer remained strangely unimpressed by the spectacle, although such violent swings had never before taken place on the stock market.

“机器显然坏了，系统显然坏了，”克莱默说道，语气中带着一丝厌恶。

“The machine obviously broke, the system obviously broke,” Cramer said, a touch of disgust in his voice.

伯内特的新闻素养让她更加激动。“但事实是，在经历了这一切之后，这种事竟然真的发生了，这真是一个惊人的故事，”她感叹道。

Burnett’s journalistic fiber had her more excited. “But the fact that after all this, that that could have just happened, is an absolutely stupendous story,” she exclaimed.

“我觉得这是一个很棒的故事，”克莱默平静地说。“这是从未讲述过的最精彩的故事。你永远不会知道这里发生了什么。”

“I think it’s a great story,” Cramer said flatly. “It’s the greatest story never told. You’ll never know what happened here.”

克莱默说得没错。截至撰写本文时，对于所谓的“闪电崩盘”的确切根源，人们仍未达成共识。一些人指责堪萨斯城的一位基金经理，他的算法过快抛售了价值40亿美元的股票期货，并引发其他算法也纷纷效仿。另一些人则指责一群身份不明的交易员，他们合谋使用协同算法，导致股市瞬间暴跌。另一些人则认为，这只是一场老式的恐慌，与1929年全球经历的恐慌并无二致。然而，可以肯定的是，如果不是算法——它们独立于人类，下单和完成交易只需不到一秒钟——主宰着市场，市场不可能波动如此之快。但算法确实主宰着市场。

Cramer wasn’t wrong. As of this writing, there is still no consensus on the exact root of what became known as the Flash Crash. Some of the blame was directed at a Kansas City money manager whose algorithm sold off $4 billion worth of stock futures too quickly, sparking other algorithms to do the same. Some blame an unknown group of traders who conspired to send things down all at once through the use of coordinated algorithms. Some believe it was simply an old-fashioned panic, not unlike what the world witnessed in 1929. What’s for certain, however, is that the market couldn’t have moved so far so fast if algorithms, which act independently of humans and require less than a second to place and complete a trade, didn’t own the market. But they do.

算法通常按照设计运行，悄无声息地交易股票，或者像亚马逊那样，根据供求关系为书籍定价。但如果无人监管，算法可能会做出一些奇怪的事情。随着我们越来越多地将世界置于算法的控制之下，我们可能会忘记究竟是谁——或者是什么——在幕后操纵。这一事实悄然潜入世界，直到闪电崩盘将我们惊醒。

Algorithms normally behave as they’re designed, quietly trading stocks or, in the case of Amazon, pricing books according to supply and demand. But left unsupervised, algorithms can and will do strange things. As we put more and more of our world under the control of algorithms, we can lose track of who—or what—is pulling the strings. This is a fact that had sneaked up on the world until the Flash Crash shook us awake.

算法借着“闪电崩盘”之门进入了晚间新闻，但并未就此消失。很快，它们就出现在约会、购物、娱乐、医疗等所有你能想到的领域。“闪电崩盘”只不过是一个更大趋势的预兆：算法正在接管一切。

Algorithms entered evening newscasts through the door of the Flash Crash, but they didn’t leave. They soon showed up in stories about dating, shopping, entertainment, medicine—everything imaginable. The Flash Crash had merely been an augur for a bigger trend: algorithms are taking over everything.

当网络上或机器内部的某个过程自动发生时，通常会伴随一个简洁的解释：“这是一种算法。”算法的经典定义是，该设备是一系列指令，可根据手头的信息引导用户获得特定的答案或输出。

When a process on the Web or inside a machine happens automatically, a pithy explanation often comes with it: “It’s an algorithm.” The classical definition of an algorithm says the device is a list of instructions that leads its user to a particular answer or output based on the information at hand.

比如，我们可以编写一个算法来确定早上上班穿什么夹克。输入：温度、有雨、有雪、风速、计划步行的距离和步速、有阳光还是有云。输入：25 华氏度、小雪、20 英里/小时的风速、有云，以及步行两个街区，可能会输出：比如说，你的羽绒 Gore-Tex 派克大衣。这很可能就是你会自己从衣柜里翻出来的那件外套，但算法的入侵始于简单的任务。这些算法的运作方式很像决策树，其中，复杂问题的解决需要考虑大量变量，可以分解为一长串二进制选择。每条必需的数据都会将过程推向另一个选择或节点，从而更接近于产生输出。

One could, for instance, write an algorithm for determining what jacket to wear to work in the morning. Inputs: temperature, presence of rain, presence of snow, wind speed, distance and pace you plan to walk, sun or cloud cover. An input of 25 degrees, light snow, 20 mph wind, cloud cover, and a short walk of two blocks might produce an output of, say, your down-filled Gore-Tex parka. That’s likely the coat you would have plucked from the closet on your own, but the invasion of algorithms starts with simple tasks. These algorithms operate much like decision trees, wherein the resolution to a complex problem, requiring consideration of a large set of variables, can be broken down to a long string of binary choices. Each piece of required data pushes the process to another choice, or node, and closer to producing an output.

然而，这种对算法的粗略定义，并不能充分体现它们在计算机的帮助下所构建的庞大网络。在本书中，我经常将多个相互关联的、旨在执行一项任务的算法称为机器人。这些机器人拥有成千上万的输入、因素和功能。其中最复杂的机器人就像你大脑中神经元的放电：它们根据需要不断运转，动态变化，并且能够自我改进。

This rudimentary definition of algorithms, however, gives little justice to the colossal webs they have become thanks to computers. In this book, I often refer to multiple linked algorithms all aimed at performing one task as bots. These bots feature thousands of inputs, factors, and functions. The most complicated among them are like neurons firing in your brain: they spin up and spin down based on need, they’re dynamic, and they’re capable of self-improvement.

数学使所有这些算法成为可能，它们已经侵入并几乎主宰了我们的生活。几个世纪以来，数学是我们观察世界的工具。如今，它已成为我们塑造地球、生活乃至文化的有力工具。

Math makes possible all of these algorithms that have come to invade and almost run our lives. For centuries, math was something we drew on in making observations about our world. Now it is a potent tool we use to shape our planet, our lives, and even our culture.

随着算法及其背后的数学成为华尔街的标准，其他一些不太受关注的领域吸引了数学家、工程师和物理学家的关注——华尔街后来将这群人称为“量化分析师”（Quant，以量化分析师命名）。这些量化分析师和程序员如今在新兴行业中寻找算法可能取代旧范式的软肋，并在此过程中赚取巨额利润。

As algorithms and the math behind them became the standard on Wall Street, other less-affected fields drew the attention of mathematicians, engineers, and physicists—a group Wall Street came to call quants (after quantitative analyst). These quants and programmers now scout new industries for soft spots where algorithms might render old paradigms extinct, and in the process make mountains of money.

算法的边界每天都在被进一步拓展。它们在越来越多的行业中取代了人类，而且它们往往在这方面做得很好。它们比我们更快，更便宜，而且，当一切正常运转时，它们犯的错误也比我们少得多。但随着算法获得力量和独立性，可能会带来意想不到的后果。或许，潘多拉——一个利用算法来学习用户音乐品味的网络电台——的名字就恰如其分。根据希腊神话，潘多拉是地球上第一个女人，她得到了一个美丽的盒子，宙斯警告她不要打开。但她还是打开了盒子，将邪恶释放到了整个地球。盒子里只剩下一样东西：希望。

The bounds of algorithms get pushed further each day. They’ve displaced humans in a growing number of industries, something they often do well. They’re faster than us, they’re cheaper than us, and, when things work as they should, they make far fewer mistakes than we do. But as algorithms acquire power and independence, there can be unexpected consequences. Perhaps Pandora, the Internet radio outlet that uses algorithms to learn users’ musical tastes, is aptly named. According to Greek mythology, Pandora, the first woman on earth, was given a beautiful box that Zeus warned her not to open. She opened it anyway, releasing evil across the planet. Only one thing remained inside: hope.

虽然有很多理由担心即将到来的算法时代，但正如潘多拉告诉我们的那样，也有很多理由充满希望。算法将为我们的世界带来无数的改进，当然，比如更优质的广播，以及更优质的客户服务电话、更便捷的周五晚餐约会、更优质的中情局情报，以及在癌症致命之前更好地发现它的方法。

While there are many reasons to worry about the impending age of algorithms, there are also, as Pandora instructs us, plenty of reasons for hope. Algorithms will enable myriad improvements to our world, like better radio, of course, along with better customer service calls, better Friday dinner dates, better CIA intelligence, and better ways to sniff out cancer before it can kill.

一些算法的根源可以追溯到人工智能领域。它们可能不像电影《2001：太空漫游》 （1968 年）中的机器Hal 9000（启发式编程的AL算法计算机）那样智能和具有自我意识，但算法可以进化。它们观察、实验和学习——所有这些都独立于它们的人类创造者。利用机器学习和神经网络等先进的计算机科学技术，算法甚至可以根据观察结果创建新的和改进的算法。算法已经创作出如贝多芬般动人的交响乐，以高级法律合伙人的娴熟技巧筛选法律术语，比医生更准确地诊断病人，以经验丰富的记者流畅的笔触撰写新闻报道，并在城市高速公路上驾驶车辆，其控制能力远超人类。

Some algorithms’ roots trace to the field of artificial intelligence. They may not be intelligent and self-aware like Hal 9000 (Heuristically programmed ALgorithmic computer), the machine from the movie 2001: A Space Odyssey (1968), but algorithms can evolve. They observe, experiment, and learn—all independently of their human creators. Using advanced computer science techniques such as machine learning and neural networking, algorithms can even create new and improved algorithms based on observed results. Algorithms have already written symphonies as moving as those composed by Beethoven, picked through legalese with the deftness of a senior law partner, diagnosed patients with more accuracy than a doctor, written news articles with the smooth hand of a seasoned reporter, and driven vehicles on urban highways with far better control than a human.

那么，我们作为人类的职责，我们的职业将会变成什么样？算法也将在这方面拥有发言权。我们曾经指责其他国家窃取的工作，如今正被一堆堆不为人知的计算机代码抢走。如今社会上最向上流动的人，正是那些能够操纵代码、创建算法的人，这些算法能够在海量数据中穿梭，识别数百万张面孔，并执行几年前还无法想象的任务，这绝非巧合。

And what will become of our duties as humans, our employment? Algorithms will have a say here too. Jobs we once blamed other countries for stealing are now being snatched away by faceless piles of computer code. It’s no coincidence that the most upwardly mobile people in society right now are those who can manipulate code to create algorithms that can sprint through oceans of data, recognize millions of faces, and perform tasks that just a few years ago seemed unthinkable.

黑客：新帝国的缔造者

HACKERS: THE NEW EMPIRE BUILDERS

现代词典中对“黑客”一词的定义似乎有两种截然不同的解读。对某些人来说，黑客行为本身就意味着犯罪——程序员入侵本应被禁止访问的电子财产。20世纪80年代对黑客的描述往往是一群打字飞快的歹徒，闯入政府的秘密数据库、银行以及各种不属于他们的地方。

There seem to be two divergent definitions of the term hacker floating about the modern lexicon. To some, hacking has come to mean something inherently criminal—a programmer traversing electronic property meant to be off-limits. Depictions of hackers from the 1980s portrayed fast-typing miscreants breaking into secret government data hoards, banks, and all sorts of places they didn’t belong.

然而，在现代科技界，这个词的含义并非坏事，而是好的。我在本书中使用的定义正是如此。用硅谷的术语来说，黑客是指那些能够灵巧地编写计算机代码的人，他们能够轻松地将白板上的概念转化为算法，从而做出艰难的决策、交易股票、驾驶汽车、筛选大学申请者，或者与世界上最优秀的人打扑克。

Within the modern tech world, however, the word carries good connotations rather than bad. This is the definition I use in this book. A hacker in the parlance of Silicon Valley is somebody who writes computer code with a deft hand, easily translating concepts from the whiteboard into algorithms that can make hard decisions, trade stocks, drive cars, sort college applicants, or play poker with the best humans in the world.

算法是我们故事的核心，但正是黑客编写的代码让算法成为可能；正是代码赋予了算法生命力，并使其能够影响数百万人。算法背后的代码可能长达数千行，将数学函数与用户输入（例如“是/否”判断或实时数据挖掘）关联起来。入侵中等难度的程序——比如一个标准网站或一个自动电子邮件程序——是全球数百万人掌握的技能。而入侵创新的程序，构思并编写出能够解决人类问题的优雅算法，则需要非凡的天赋。

Algorithms are at the center of our story, but it’s hackers’ code that makes them possible; it’s what gives them life and the ability to affect millions of people. The code behind the algorithm can be thousands of lines long, linking mathematical functions to user inputs such as yes/no decisions or the real-time mining of data. To hack something of moderate difficulty—a standard Web site, say, or an automated e-mail program—is a skill possessed by millions of people across the world. To hack something innovative, to conceive and write an elegant algorithm that solves human problems, takes special talent.

我以一种迂回的方式接触到了算法革命的故事。自2002年工程师生涯的最后几个月，我用C语言（一种计算机语言）编写了一些简单的算法后，我就再也没有写过任何有意义的代码。2003年，我追寻着写作的渴望，投身新闻业。我的第一份工作是在《芝加哥论坛报》，在那里，我作为一名新闻编辑室的普通员工，追踪着各种各样的新闻，从火灾到谋杀，再到商业新闻。机缘巧合之下，我在《福布斯》杂志芝加哥分社找到了一份工作。科技成了我自然而然关注的焦点，我花了大量时间在全国各地寻找新的公司和范例来写作。

I came to this story of algorithmic revolution in a roundabout way. I haven’t written meaningful code since 2002 when I composed simple algorithms in C, a computer language, during my last months working as an engineer. In 2003, I followed an itch to write and went into journalism. My first job was with the Chicago Tribune, where as a newsroom grunt I chased all manner of things from fires to murders to business stories. Serendipity landed me a job in the Chicago bureau of Forbes magazine. Tech became my natural focus and I spent much of my time sniffing about the country for new companies and paradigms to write about.

与年轻的创业者和工程师共度如此多的时光令人振奋。我遇到过很多人，他们放弃了稳定的工作或职业道路，试图创立自己的公司和产品。不知何故，我也受到了影响。多年来，我一直在构思创业点子。2010年秋天，我和朋友莱利·斯科特（Riley Scott）构思了一个看似可行的方案。这个想法最终变成了Aisle50，一个提供食品杂货优惠的网站，消费者可以在去商店购物之前购买。在创建Aisle50的同时，我们申请并被硅谷的Y Combinator（孵化器）接纳，该孵化器通过资金、指导和投资者联系，帮助初创企业起步。

Spending so much time with young entrepreneurs and engineers can be invigorating. I met a lot of people who left stable jobs or career paths to try to build companies and products all their own. At some point, I became affected. For years, I threw around startup ideas. In the fall of 2010, I conjured something with my friend Riley Scott that seemed like it could work. The idea eventually became Aisle50, a Web site that offers deals on grocery items for consumers to purchase before they head to the store. While building Aisle50, we applied and were accepted to be part of Silicon Valley’s Y Combinator, which helps startups get off the ground with funding, mentorship, and connections to investors.

我在 Y Combinator 的同事中，很大一部分人在十四岁时就开始学习编程。到了大学（通常是精英大学），他们已经可以写出数千行代码，开发出一个稳定应用程序的核心，或者在几个小时内完成一个原创的网站设计。2011 年夏天，我在那里待了三个月，了解到马克·扎克伯格是如何诞生的：并非​​源于智力和技术的爆发，而是源于多年盯着电脑屏幕，对代码的理解如同经验丰富的文字编辑对成语、标点符号和风格的直觉。

A good percentage of my cohort at Y Combinator picked up programming by the time they were fourteen years old. When they reached college, often an elite university, they could already string together thousands of lines of code, create the guts of a stable application, or bolt up an original Web site design in a matter of hours. During the three months I spent there in the summer of 2011, I learned how Mark Zuckerbergs are created: not from spontaneous explosions of intellect and technology, but from years and years of staring at a computer screen, getting to know code as intuitively as a seasoned copy editor knows idioms, punctuation, and style.

这些代码设计师和算法编写者是这一代杰出的企业家。新帝国的缔造者不再来自商学院——他们来自工程和计算机科学实验室，在那里，他们熬夜苦读编程作业，磨练出构建创新算法和推动其发展所需的黑客技能。在某些情况下，这些算法构建者很早就离开了大学，或者根本不去上学；他们在十五、十六、十七岁时就学到了足够的知识，知道如何构建他们所设想的东西。

These stylists of code and writers of algorithms are the preeminent entrepreneurs of this generation. The builders of new empires no longer come from business school—they come from engineering and computer science labs, where long nights of staring at coding assignments result in the hacking skills required to build innovative algorithms and the companies they can propel. In some cases, these algorithm builders leave college early or don’t bother to go at all; they learned enough when they were fifteen, sixteen, and seventeen to know how to build what they envision.

如今，人们在年轻时学习编程的途径多种多样。无数的网络社区和聊天室专门用于编写代码和构建算法。我所在的Y Combinator团队旗下的一家公司Codecademy，突然想到了一个非常受欢迎的点子——一个设计精良的在线编程学习网站——它在上线后的两周内就吸引了超过20万用户。上线仅六个月后，Codecademy就与白宫达成合作，共同推广计算机编程。这就是我们生活的新现实：一个拥有复杂算法构想工具的21岁年轻人，可以与美国总统建立合作关系。

There now exist all sorts of paths for people to learn programming at young ages. Countless Web communities and chat rooms are dedicated solely to the writing of code and the construction of algorithms. One company from my Y Combinator group, Codecademy, hit upon an idea so popular—a well-designed site for learning how to program online—that it drew more than 200,000 users in its first two weeks after launching. Just six months after launch, Codecademy landed a partnership with the White House to promote computer programming. This is the new reality we live in: a twenty-one-year-old with the tools to conceive complex algorithms can form a partnership with the president of the United States.

Y Combinator 只是一场运动的缩影，这场运动通常由年轻人推动，旨在将算法融入我们所做的一切。在过去的几十年里，这批革命者引领了算法的发展，这些算法可以解决问题、赚钱，并彻底取代人类的工作。本书将讲述我们如何走到今天，以及未来将如何发展。

Y Combinator is just a microcosm of a movement, often pushed forward by youth, that is putting algorithms inside everything we do. During the last couple of decades, this class of revolutionaries has led the way in fashioning algorithms that solve problems, make money, and, in sweeping fashion, take jobs away from people. This book is about how we got here and how things will continue to unfold.

如今，即使与五年前相比，有志于开发机器人的人所能获得的资源也令人震惊。构建创新算法并非易事，但难度正在日益降低。正因如此，那些能够创造这些机器人的人——那些数学、科学和黑客领域的顶尖人才——都对未来充满希望。比尔·盖茨在华盛顿大学实验室里偷偷摸摸地利用业余时间使用电脑的传说不会再发生，因为没有必要。如今，获取科技资源变得轻而易举。

The resources available to aspiring bot builders today, even compared with those from just five years ago, are astounding. Building innovative algorithms isn’t easy. But it gets less difficult every day. For this reason, the people with the ability to create these bots—the best math, science, and hacker minds—look out upon a promising future. The apocryphal story of Bill Gates finding computer time by finagling his way into labs at the University of Washington during odd hours is something that won’t be repeated because it won’t be necessary. Access to technology now comes easily.

2009年末，我开始写这本书的时候，我的关注点和报道内容都完全围绕着华尔街的算法。后来，我和朋友比尔·贝内特（Bill Bennett）共进午餐，他是西北大学凯洛格管理学院的教授。我告诉他，我正在写关于算法如何接管股市的文章。比尔觉得这没什么问题。但当他的目光越过腰果鸡丁，望向街对面对冲基金Magnetar所在的大楼时，却说了一句后来成为本书主线的话。“真正的故事，”他说，“是它们将如何接管一切。”

When I started working on this book in late 2009, my focus and my reporting revolved solely around algorithms on Wall Street. Then I had lunch with Bill Bennett, a friend and a professor at Northwestern’s Kellogg School of Management. I told him I was writing about how algorithms had taken over our stock markets. Bill thought that was fine. But as he looked past his plate of cashew chicken and across the street at the building that houses Magnetar, the hedge fund, he said something that would steer this book. “The real story,” he said, “is how they will take over everything.”

比尔说得对。这个故事始于华尔街。从那里开始，它就会传遍世界各地。

Bill was right. This story only begins on Wall Street. From there, it goes everywhere.

1

1

华尔街，第一张多米诺骨牌

WALL STREET, THE FIRST DOMINO

1987年初的一天，一位在纳斯达克股票市场工作的男子——姑且叫他琼斯吧——出现在世贸中心大厅。他找到自己楼层对应的电梯，按下了上行按钮。他正在例行拜访纳斯达克增长最快的客户之一。琼斯知道会发生什么。华尔街的股票交易员都差不多：一群白人男性，毕业于常春藤盟校，渴望利润。其实没什么可看的。

ON A DAY IN EARLY 1987, a man who worked for the Nasdaq stock market—let’s call him Jones—showed up in the lobby of the World Trade Center. He found the appropriate elevator bank for his floor and pressed the up button. He was making a routine visit to one of the Nasdaq’s fastest-growing customers. Jones knew what to expect. One Wall Street stock-swapping crew is the same as the next: a small lake of white male faces backed by Ivy League educations and appetites for profit. Nothing to see, really.

他沿着走廊走向办公套房的前门，做好了迎接即将到来的雄性激素和混乱的准备。交易大厅和那些把人塞进装满飞舞钞票的玻璃盒子里的游戏节目没什么两样——只不过在交易大厅里，有些飞舞的钞票是输的。熟练的玩家可以在保持疯狂节奏的同时，辨别出赢的钞票和输的钞票。

As he walked down the hallway toward the office suite’s front door, he braced himself for the testosterone and chaos that awaited him. Trading floors aren’t anomalous from game shows that stuff a person in a glass box full of blowing money—except that in the case of a trading floor some of the fluttering bills are losers. The deft players can discern winning bills from losing ones while maintaining a frenzied pace.

接待员迎接了他，然后退到另一个房间去迎接主人。她回来时，一位身材矮小、衣冠楚楚、满头银发的男子陪着她。托马斯·彼得菲的蓝眼睛热情地迎接琼斯。他说话带有口音。

A receptionist greeted him and retreated to another room to fetch his host. When she returned, a short, dapper man with a full head of silvering hair accompanied her. Thomas Peterffy’s blues eyes warmly greeted Jones. He spoke with an accent.

琼斯不可能想到彼得菲后来会成为身价超过50亿美元、美国首富之一的人。当时，他只是华尔街的一位新贵。但他的交易量一直在攀升，利润也一路飙升。琼斯一直很好奇，像彼得菲这样的人是如何找到持续跑赢大盘的方法的。他雇佣了最精明的人才吗？他拥有更优秀的研究部门吗？他是否承担了巨大的风险，最终却幸运地获得了成功？

Jones couldn’t have known that Peterffy would later become a man worth more than $5 billion, one of the richest people in America. He was still at that point a Wall Street upstart. But his trading volume had been streaming upward, and so had his profits. Jones was always curious as to how people like Peterffy figured out ways to beat the market so consistently. Had he hired the sharpest people? Did he have a better research department? Was he taking giant risks and getting lucky?

琼斯不知道的是，彼得菲根本不是交易员。他是一名计算机程序员。他进行交易并非靠衡量交易大厅里交易员的表情、市场动量，或者他认为的经济趋势会引领股市走向。他编写代码，数千行计算机语言——Fortran、C 和 Lisp——所有这些语言都构建了算法，使彼得菲的交易业务成为华尔街最优秀的交易业务之一，尽管规模仍然很小。他是华尔街新一代交易员中的佼佼者。

What Jones didn’t know was that Peterffy wasn’t a trader at all. He was a computer programmer. He didn’t make trades by measuring the feelings of faces in the pit, the momentum of the market, or where he thought economic trends were leading stocks. He wrote code, thousands of lines of computer language—Fortran, C, and Lisp—all of it building algorithms that made Peterffy’s trading operation one of the best on the Street, albeit still small. He was chief among a new breed on Wall Street.

当彼得菲带头走进交易大厅时，琼斯感到一阵困惑。他看得越多——却发现没什么东西——就越是不知所措。他原以为房间里会一片喧闹：电话铃声阵阵，打印机轰鸣，交易员们一边在纳斯达克终端上输入买卖指令，一边互相喊叫。但琼斯什么也没看到。事实上，他只看到一台纳斯达克终端。他知道彼得菲的交易量有多大——而且很大。这怎么可能？是谁在做这些交易？

As Peterffy led the way onto his trading floor, Jones grew confused. The more he saw—and there wasn’t much to see—the more flummoxed he became. He had expected a room bursting with commotion: phones ringing, printers cranking, and traders shouting to one another as they entered buy and sell orders into their Nasdaq terminals. But Jones saw none of this. In fact, he saw only one Nasdaq terminal. He knew the volumes that Peterffy did—and they were big. How was this possible? Who was making all those trades?

“剩下的行动呢？”琼斯问道。“你们的交易员呢？”

“Where is the rest of the operation?” Jones demanded. “Where are your traders?”

“就是这个，都在这里，”彼得菲指着房间里唯一一台纳斯达克终端旁的一台 IBM 电脑说道。“我们所有操作都用这台电脑。”纳斯达克的机器和 IBM 之间电线缠结，IBM 存储着决定交易内容、时间和金额的代码。这位纳斯达克员工并没有意识到，他已经走进了世界上第一个全自动算法交易系统。彼得菲的装置不像过去的其他系统那样，只是建议交易什么。它也不是简单地输出交易指令，然后由人工操作。计算机通过秘密入侵交易终端，做出所有决策并执行所有交易。无需人工干预。然而，它的交易伙伴却是 100% 的人类——而他们却被彻底击败了。

“This is it, it’s all right here,” Peterffy said, pointing at an IBM computer squatting next to the sole Nasdaq terminal in the room. “We do it all from this.” A tangle of wires ran between the Nasdaq machine and the IBM, which hosted code that dictated what, when, and how much to trade. The Nasdaq employee didn’t realize it, but he had walked in on the first fully automated algorithmic trading system in the world. Peterffy’s setup didn’t merely suggest what to trade, as other systems had in the past. It didn’t simply pump out trades that humans would later carry out. The computer, by way of a surreptitious hack into the trading terminal, made all of the decisions and executed all of the trades. No humans necessary. Its trading partners, though, were 100 percent human—and they were getting drubbed.

借助来自纳斯达克终端的被黑客入侵的数据馈送，彼得菲的代码能够调查市场并发出买卖盘，从而轻松捕捉买家买入价和卖家卖出价之间的价差。这种价差被称为价差，当时纳斯达克部分股票的价差可能超过每股25美分。因此，执行两笔1000股的订单——一笔买入价为19.75美元，另一笔卖出价为20美元——几乎无风险地获得了250美元的利润。

With the hacked data feed coming from the Nasdaq terminal, Peterffy’s code was able to survey the market and issue bids and asks that could easily capture the difference between the prevailing price at which buyers would buy and sellers would sell. That difference, called the spread, could grow past 25 cents a share on some Nasdaq stocks at that time, so executing a pair of 1,000-share orders—one to buy at $19.75 and one to sell at $20.00—resulted in a near-riskless $250 profit.

由于彼得菲使用机器执行交易，因此风险更低。当时，对于不断维持买入或卖出股票报价的做市商来说，主要风险之一是市场波动后留下过时的报价。大多数做市商的速度取决于他们的交易员，交易员必须在电脑屏幕上读取新价格，消化这些信息，决定如何调整价格，然后取消订单并在纳斯达克键盘上输入新价格。交易员可能仅仅因为吃了太多金枪鱼三明治或与同事开怀大笑就落后市场几步。彼得菲的电脑不需要午餐。它与市场的波动同步，降低了很大一部分市场风险，而这是人类根本无法做到的。

The trades were even less risky for Peterffy because he utilized machines to execute them. One of the main dangers at that time to market makers, who constantly maintain offers to buy or sell a stock, was leaving stale quotes up after a market shift. Most market makers could only be as fast as their traders, who had to read new prices on a computer screen, assimilate that information, make a decision on how to change their prices, and then cancel orders and type new prices into their Nasdaq keyboards. A trader could fall a few steps behind the market just by taking too many bites of a tuna sandwich or having a chuckle with a colleague. Peterffy’s computer didn’t need a lunch. It stepped in tandem with the market’s zigs and zags, mitigating a high percentage of his market risk, something a human simply couldn’t do.

彼得菲的行动标志着华尔街的新曙光，程序员、工程师和数学家发起了一场为期二十年的入侵，其中算法和自动化（有时极其复杂且几乎智能）将取代人类成为我们金融市场的主导力量。

Peterffy’s operation marked a new dawn on Wall Street, as programmers, engineers, and mathematicians mounted a two-decade invasion in which algorithms and automation, sometimes incredibly complex and almost intelligent, would supplant humans as the dominant force in our financial markets.

琼斯目瞪口呆。彼得菲看到的是创新，而琼斯看到的却是有人用临时搭建的终端机破坏规则。

Jones stood agape. Where Peterffy saw innovation, Jones saw somebody breaking the rules with a jury-rigged terminal.

“你不能这样做，”琼斯说。

“You can’t do this,” Jones said.

纳斯达克没有交易大厅；所有交易都通过电话或计算机网络进行，用户在专用纳斯达克终端的键盘上输入订单，计算机网络接收订单。彼得菲将原本要送往终端的数据线接驳起来，将分叉的一端焊接到一块电路板上。这块电路板是由他的程序员和物理学家团队从零开始打造的，并嵌入到IBM PC主板上。IBM PC运行着彼得菲自己编写的软件。当PC从纳斯达克数据线接头处获取数据时，它的算法会分析市场并快速做出交易决策，然后将这些交易信息通过一团乱麻的线路反馈到纳斯达克终端的内部。直到那一刻，彼得菲才得知自己已经入侵了纳斯达克。

The Nasdaq had no trading floor; all of its trades took place over the phone or on its computer network that took users’ orders as they entered them on the keyboard of a dedicated Nasdaq terminal. Peterffy had taken the incoming data wire meant for the terminal and spliced it, soldering the split end into a circuit board that his team of programmers and physicists had built from scratch and embedded into the motherboard of an IBM PC. The IBM ran software that Peterffy wrote himself. As the PC got data from the Nasdaq wire splice, its algorithms analyzed the market and made quick trading decisions, firing these trades back through a tangle of wires that wound their way into the innards of the Nasdaq terminal. Peterffy, unbeknownst to anybody until that moment, had hacked the Nasdaq.

纳斯达克根本不需要知道这个装置，这个疯狂科学家的实验室，竟然进入了市场。其他交易员会不会安心地知道自己是在与IBM的算法较量，而不是与其他凭直觉行事的赌徒较量呢？纳斯达克不想知道。

The Nasdaq didn’t need word of this contraption, this mad scientist’s laboratory, reaching the market. Would other traders be comfortable knowing they were matching wits with algorithms powered by an IBM rather than other gut-following gamblers? The Nasdaq didn’t want to find out.

“终端需要与 IBM 断开连接，所有订单都需要通过键盘逐一输入——就像我们的其他客户一样，”琼斯说。

“The terminal needs to be disconnected from this IBM and all orders need to go through the keyboard, typed one by one—just like the rest of our customers,” Jones said.

琼斯走了。彼得菲站在办公室里，盘算着他的生意可能就此终结。纳斯达克给了他一周时间来执行检查员的指令。想到要拆掉机器，彼得菲就感到一阵心痛。他几乎没兴趣去找交易员，哪怕是年轻又便宜的交易员，让他们坐在椅子上，把订单输入纳斯达克终端。他花了好几年的时间才从他的操作中剔除人为因素及其反复无常的怪念头。要重新把人、他们的错误、他们的懒惰，以及（在这种情况下）最重要的——他们缓慢的打字速度重新投入到流程中，并期望获得同样的结果，将非常困难。他的操作将在一夜之间失去大部分效率。一定有更好的选择。

Jones left. Peterffy stood in his office contemplating what might be the end of his business. The Nasdaq had given him a week to comply with the inspector’s edict. The thought of dismantling his machine wrenched Peterffy. He had little interest in going out and finding traders, even young and cheap ones, to sit in chairs and punch orders into Nasdaq terminals. It had taken him years to wring the human element and its capricious whims out of his operation. It would be difficult to reinject people, their errors, their laziness, and, most important in this case, their slow typing back into the process and expect the same results. His operation was going to lose most of its efficiency overnight. There had to be a better option.

那天晚上，在他位于上东区的公寓里，临睡前，一个解决方案在他脑海中浮现。这并非易事，但却提供了可能性。彼得菲认为，他可以不接触纳斯达克终端，直接获取信息。无需接线，无需连接电路板，什么都不需要。但该怎么做呢？他问他的工程师和物理学家团队，能否制造一个像摄像头一样的设备，直接从屏幕上读取数据，然后将这些信息转换成电子比特，发送到等待的IBM PC。答案是肯定的。

Before he went to sleep that night in his Upper East Side apartment, a solution came together in his head. It wouldn’t be easy, but it offered possibilities. Peterffy thought he could pull information from the Nasdaq terminal without touching the machine. No spliced wires, no attached circuit boards, none of that. But how to do it? He asked his crew of engineers and physicists if they could build something that read data straight off the screen, like a camera, and then translated that information into electronic bits and sent it to the waiting IBM PC. The answer was yes.

但数据传送只是问题的一半。如果没有一队人守在纳斯达克终端前，彼得菲该如何执行交易？他不能像以前那样把数据电汇回机器。不行，交易必须通过键盘进行，就像纳斯达克要求的那样。彼得菲有了一个主意，一个疯狂的主意。但这样真的可行吗？

But the data feed was only half the problem. How would Peterffy execute his trades without having a team of people sit at Nasdaq terminals? He could not send a wire back into the machines as he had done before. No, the trades had to go through the keyboard, just as the Nasdaq had ordered. Peterffy had an idea, a crazy idea. But could such a thing work?

在紧张忙碌的一周里，彼得菲和他最优秀的工程师们焊接金属、编写代码、焊接电线。他们在纳斯达克终端机的正面安装了一个巨大的菲涅尔透镜，以放大屏幕上的文字。在距离镜头一英尺的地方放置了一个摄像头。摄像头通过一根电线连接到设备旁边的一台电脑。短短几天内，彼得菲和他的程序员就编写出了能够解码摄像头传来的视频数据的软件。这些数据可以通过软件接入彼得菲现有的算法中，这些算法曾经使用来自纳斯达克终端机的直接线路。

During a frantic week, Peterffy and his best engineers welded metal, wrote code, and soldered wires. They affixed a large Fresnel lens to the face of the Nasdaq terminal to enlarge the screen’s text. A camera was placed a foot from the lens. From the camera, a wire led to a computer sitting adjacent to the apparatus. In just a few days, Peterffy and his programmers wrote software that would decode the visual data streaming in from the camera. From there, the data could be plugged into Peterffy’s existing algorithms that once used the direct wire from the Nasdaq terminal.

现在，一根新的电线从IBM电脑里出来了，它没有滑进纳斯达克终端的外壳，而是撞上了悬在终端键盘上方的一堆金属杆、活塞和杠杆。如果说摄像头和屏幕阅读装置看起来有些奇怪，那么这套系统简直是奇葩至极。它让人想起工业革命时期精巧的机械织布机。这台设备是一台从零开始制造的自动打字机。随着计算机发出指令，机器的金属杆会断断续续地敲击终端的键盘。指令一个接一个地飞出，三十秒内就有数十条指令被录入。

A new wire now came out of the IBM and, instead of slithering into the case of the Nasdaq terminal, ran into a nest of metal rods, pistons, and levers hovering above the terminal’s keyboard. If the camera and screen-reading rig appeared odd, this piece of the system was downright bizarre. It evoked the intricate mechanical looms of the Industrial Revolution. The device was an automated typing machine, built from scratch. As orders came from the computer, the machine’s rods rapped the terminal’s keys in staccato bursts. Orders flew out one after another, with dozens logged in under thirty seconds.

纳斯达克规定交易记录必须录入，但没有具体说明由谁来录入。彼得菲的团队创造了一个交易和打字的机器人。他们花了六天时间。他遵守了法律条文，但无论如何，都违反了法律的精神。但这并没有让他太担心。华尔街充斥着漏洞、变通方法和后门，为最有创造力的骗子提供了便利。

The Nasdaq said trades had to be typed, but they didn’t specify who had to type them. Peterffy’s team had created a trading—and typing—cyborg. And it had taken them six days. He had obeyed the letter of the law, but had, by any definition, violated its spirit. But that didn’t worry him much. Wall Street is nothing if not a den of loopholes, work-arounds, and back doors that favor the most inventive of finaglers.

纳斯达克的检查员一周后如约而至。彼得菲在电梯口迎接他，并带他穿过走廊，来到交易室。一阵稳定的叮当声从门上传来。原本寂静无声的地方，此刻却喧闹起来，就像交易大厅里应有的那样。彼得菲领着琼斯穿过门，挥舞着手指着他的作品。纳斯达克的检查员沉浸在这仿佛是儒勒·凡尔纳笔下描绘的场景之中。

The Nasdaq inspector returned a week later, as promised. Peterffy met him at the elevator and led him down the hallway to his trading room. A steady clinking emanated from the door. Where once had been silence, there now arose a racket, just as it should be on a trading floor. Peterffy led Jones through the door and, with a flourish, gestured to his creation. The Nasdaq man drank in a scene that could have been conjured by Jules Verne.

“这是什么？”男人问道。

“What is this?” the man said.

彼得菲解释说，他的机器就像纳斯达克要求的那样，通过键盘输入交易，一次一个。就在这时，市场活跃起来，机器也随之活跃起来。彼得菲的程序开始快速交易，打字机像机关枪一样齐射。源源不断的订单让机器疯狂地敲击键盘，制造出一片混乱的噪音，让人无法交谈。每当似乎出现短暂的平静，机器就会发出更多的订单，填补短暂的寂静。整个操作是华尔街灵活头脑为世界带来的又一次奇妙的规避规则的手段。

Peterffy explained that his machine put in the trades just like the Nasdaq requested—by keyboard input, one at a time. Just at that moment, the market came to life, as did the machine. Peterffy’s program began trading so rapidly that the typing apparatus fired like a machine gun. The continuous stream of orders caused the machine to mash the keyboard furiously, creating a chaotic din that made conversation impossible. Each time it seemed a lull had set in, the machine would fire out more orders, refilling the fleeting silence. The whole operation was yet another marvelous rule bypass brought to the world by the flexible minds on Wall Street.

“他一点也不喜欢这样，”彼得菲回忆道。

“He did not like this one bit,” Peterffy recalls.

彼得菲觉得自己此时也没什么可失去的了，于是提议在这个装置里放一个人体模型，让这个模型敲击琴键。他半开玩笑地说，但他确实会这么做。琼斯的脸依然紧绷着。

Feeling he had nothing to lose at this point, Peterffy offered to build a mannequin into the contraption and make the doll strike the keys. He was half joking, but he would have done it. Jones’s face remained tight.

琼斯摇头，彼得菲愁眉苦脸。他打造了世界上最快的交易机器，现在却完全预料到要把它拆开。纳斯达克的人焦躁了几分钟后，一言不发地大步走出了彼得菲的办公室。彼得菲做好了最坏的打算：纳斯达克下令禁止他的技术进入市场。但琼斯再也没有回来，彼得菲担心的那个电话也从未打来。彼得菲的生意安然无恙，几年前起步资金不足10万美元的彼得菲，在1987年赚了2500万美元。

As the man shook his head, Peterffy grimaced. He had built the fastest trading machine in the world and he now fully expected to have to take it apart. After stewing for several minutes, the Nasdaq man stalked out of Peterffy’s offices wordlessly. Peterffy prepared for the worst: a fiat from the Nasdaq that would ban his technology from the market. But Jones never came back, and the phone call Peterffy feared never came. His operation left intact, Peterffy, who had begun with less than $100,000 several years before, made $25 million in 1987.

1987年，彼得菲在华尔街还是一条小鱼，但他却是新一批市场参与者中的领头羊之一。这些参与者不仅精通编写复杂代码、焊接半导体芯片，还能运用数学知识应对错综复杂的市场结构。彼得菲所做的理论简单，但执行起来却很复杂：他汲取了最聪明交易员的智慧，并找到了一种用一系列算法来表达这些智慧的方法。他的程序涵盖了精明的人类交易员在决策过程中会考虑的所有因素。但计算机进行计算、核对价格并最终做出交易决策所需的时间却要短得多。

Peterffy was still a Wall Street minnow in 1987, but he was one of the lead fish in a new pack of market players who were as adept writing complex code, soldering semiconductor chips, and employing math as they were negotiating labyrinthine market structures. What Peterffy had done was simple in theory and complicated in execution: he had taken the brains of the smartest traders and found a way to express those smarts in a series of algorithms. His programming included all the elements that a crack human trader weighed in making a decision. But the computer took far less time to do the math, check the prices, and pull the trigger.

或许还有其他人会运用软件、代码和快速的计算机来击败市场，但彼得菲的创新——从敲击键盘的活塞到被黑客入侵的数据馈送——引发了这场革命。如今，60% 的交易都是由计算机执行的，几乎没有或根本没有人工的实时监控。彼得菲编织的故事在华尔街独树一帜。他并非一位有先见之明地雇佣程序员来巩固自己统治地位的大交易员。他也不是一位自学编程以在业内占据优势的华尔街玩家。彼得菲的独特之处在于，早在他理解股票期权的运作方式或不同公司股票如何同步波动之前，他就是一名程序员——而且是一名优秀的程序员。

There would be others to wield software, code, and swift computers to beat the market, but Peterffy’s innovations, from keyboard-hammering pistons to hacked data feeds, sparked this revolution. Today, 60 percent of all trades are executed by computers with little or no real-time oversight from humans. The story Peterffy weaved is unique on Wall Street. He wasn’t a big-shot trader who presciently hired programmers to further his dominance. Nor was he a Wall Street player who taught himself coding to gain an advantage over the rest of the field. What made Peterffy unique was that he was a programmer—and a good one—long before he ever understood how a stock option worked or how shares of different companies often move in tandem.

彼得菲运用他的编程技能、对数学的理解以及对复杂代码编写的精通，创建了分层算法，颠覆了一个对他来说全新的领域：华尔街的交易大厅。这种颠覆性的黑客范式在二十世纪后期和二十一世纪初，在世界各地上演：一位精通计算机代码和算法的工程师对一个新领域产生兴趣，发展专业知识，并通过运用计算机科学和模仿人类前辈的代码片段，颠覆行业、公司、标准和旧有的规则。创造能够模仿、超越并最终取代人类的算法的能力，是未来一百年最重要的技能。随着能够做到这一点的人不断增多，工作岗位将会消失，生活将会改变，行业将会重生。这已经发生，并且还将继续。与任何趋势一样，这种趋势追随金钱。这就是为什么它始于华尔街，这在很大程度上要归功于一位匈牙利移民。

Using his programming skills, his understanding of math, and his mastery of writing complex code, Peterffy created layered algorithms to disrupt a field new to him: the trading floors of Wall Street. This disruptive hacker paradigm has played out across varying parts of our world during the latter years of the twentieth century and opening of the twenty-first: a deft engineer of computer code and algorithms takes an interest in a new field, develops expertise, and, by applying computer science and clips of code that mimic their human forerunners, topples industries, companies, standards, and the old guard. The ability to create algorithms that imitate, better, and eventually replace humans is the paramount skill of the next one hundred years. As the people who can do this multiply, jobs will disappear, lives will change, and industries will be reborn. It’s already happened, and it will continue. And as with any trend, this one follows the money. That’s why it began on Wall Street, in no small part thanks to a Hungarian immigrant.

成为一名黑客的艰辛历程

THE MAKING OF A HACKER, THE HARD WAY

托马斯·彼得菲或许是这段持续三十年的算法接管史中最重要的人物之一，但他并非出生在一个触手可及的世界，而是出生在人类历史上最血腥的战争之声中。1944年，彼得菲在布达佩斯一家医院的地下室里出生，当时正值一场空袭。二战后，受苏联支持的共产党占领了匈牙利，彼得菲的父亲逃离了那里，彼得菲由母亲和祖父母抚养长大。他回忆起童年的恐惧：亲人失踪、半夜搬家，以及饥饿、冰冻甚至更糟的威胁。

Thomas Peterffy may have become one of the most important figures in this thirty-year tale of creeping algorithmic takeovers, but he was born not into a world of access but into the sounds of the bloodiest war in human history. Delivered in the basement of a Budapest hospital during a 1944 bombing raid, Peterffy was raised by his mother and grandparents after his father fled the Soviet-backed communists who took over Hungary following World War II. He remembers a childhood of fear, of relatives disappearing, of moves in the middle of the night, and of the constant threat of starvation, freezing, or worse.

彼得菲在高中时发现了资本主义，当时他以500%的溢价向学生出售走私的Juicy Fruit口香糖。十三岁时，他组织了几组男孩，他们会在废弃的建筑物和瓦砾堆中搜寻任何可以捡到的金属。他与年龄是他三四倍的人进行易货交易，找到最划算的废品价格，然后将所得分成几份。后来，他勤奋地将精力转向邮票买卖。这种不规则的市场——有些邮票在某个地方的售价比在另一个地方更高——让他着迷。他发现了套利，即利用价格差异悬殊的类似资产市场获利。套利者在价格较低的地方买入，在价格较高的地方卖出——这种策略以更快的形式构成了许多现代高速交易业务的支柱。

Peterffy discovered capitalism in high school, when he sold smuggled sticks of Juicy Fruit gum to students at a 500 percent markup. At thirteen, he organized several crews of boys who would raid abandoned buildings and rubble heaps for any metal that could be scavenged. He bartered with men three or four times his age and found the best prices for his scrap, splitting the proceeds among his crews. He later turned his industrious focus to stamp buying, selling, and trading. The irregular market, in which some stamps sold for more in one place than they did in another, enthralled him. He had discovered arbitrage, where one takes advantage of similar asset markets with disparate prices. An arbitrageur buys where the price is lower and sells where the price is higher—a strategy that, in far faster form, comprises the backbone of many modern high-speed trading operations.

高中毕业后，彼得菲在一所测量师技术学校学习高等几何，他的长远目标是考上大学并获得土木工程学位。但他的学业在1965年中断了。当时，21岁的他获得了一张短期签证，去西德探望一些远房亲戚。在美国化的德国，他抓住了这个机会，申请了美国移民许可，并最终获得了批准。登上飞往纽约的飞机时，这位年轻的匈牙利人对华尔街几乎一无所知，更不用说他即将征服华尔街的计算机和算法了。

After graduating high school, Peterffy studied advanced geometry in a technical school for surveyors, with a long-term goal of college and a degree in civil engineering. But his education was derailed in 1965 when, at twenty-one, he got a short-term visa to visit some distant relatives in West Germany. He seized this opportunity in Americanized Germany to apply for a U.S. immigration permit, which he eventually received. Boarding a plane to New York, the young Hungarian had little concept of Wall Street, let alone the computers and algorithms with which he’d conquer it.

他在上东区租了一套两居​​室的公寓，寄宿在一位因酗酒和玩弄女性而被教会逐出教会的僧侣家。这位僧侣曾一度邀请彼得菲加入他的生意，担任匈牙利移民的非正式公证人。凭借纽约市日益壮大的匈牙利移民网络，彼得菲最终找到了一套新公寓，并在一家土木工程公司找到了一份起草图纸的工作。

He found lodging in a two-room apartment on the Upper East Side with a monk who had been excommunicated by the church for drinking and womanizing. The monk brought Peterffy into his business for a time as an unofficial notary public for Hungarian immigrants. Through the growing Hungarian immigrant network in New York City, Peterffy eventually found a new apartment and a job drafting plans at a civil engineering firm.

到了20世纪60年代中期，计算机才刚刚开始进入小型企业的视野。这些盒装机器很快就涌入了那些充满善意的企业主的办公室，他们相信利用计算能力可以为他们带来更多客户和更高的效率。然而，计算机的盛行却遭遇了真正懂得如何编程的人才的匮乏。许多购买计算机的人发现，尽管计算机声名鹊起，但使用起来却并不轻松，这让他们感到困惑。它很费劲。因此，当时购买的许多计算机都积满了灰尘，闲置不用，被束之高阁。

By the mid-1960s, computers had just begun to fall within reach of small businesses. The boxy machines soon flooded the offices of well-intentioned business owners who believed harnessing computing power would bring them more clients and more efficiency. But the grand arrival of computers in these places was met with a dearth of people who actually knew how to program them. Many computer buyers felt stymied when they discovered that, for all the fanfare, using a computer was hardly liberating. It was difficult. For that reason, many of the machines purchased during this era collected dust, unused and relegated to closets and back rooms.

1964年，彼得菲的公司购置了第一台计算机，当时公司里没人懂编程。彼得菲自告奋勇。他仔细研读了英文手册，开始学习编程。他创建了一些简单的算法，可以执行勾股定理，用正弦和余弦函数确定角度，还能帮助工程师计算连接道路的半径和坡度。到1966年，他已经为公司建立了一个程序库，而每周的薪水只有65美元。对他来说，学习编程比学习用英语交谈更容易。他表现出色。

When Peterffy’s firm bought its first computer in 1964, nobody at the engineering company knew how to program it. Peterffy volunteered. He pored over the English manuals and began to pick up coding. He created simple algorithms executing the Pythagorean theorem, ones that determined angles using sine and cosine functions, and others that helped engineers prescribe the radii and slopes of joining roads. By 1966, he had built the firm a library of programs while collecting sixty-five dollars a week in salary. Picking up programming was easier for him than learning how to converse in English. He excelled.

就像现在一样，20世纪60年代末的优秀计算机程序员并不缺工作。编写代码为彼得菲提供了一条通往更高薪水和更好工作的清晰道路。他的第一个机会出现在1967年，当时他离开工程公司，前往Aranyi Associates公司任职，这家公司帮助华尔街客户建立计算机系统。这份工作同样是通过本地网络获得的；该公司的老板亚诺什·阿兰伊（Janos Aranyi）是一位匈牙利移民。

Just as is the case now, good computer programmers in the late 1960s didn’t want for jobs. Writing code offered Peterffy a clear path to more money and better work. His first opportunity came in 1967 when he left the engineering company for a position at Aranyi Associates, a firm that helped its Wall Street clients set up computer systems. The job, again, came through native networking; the firm’s owner, Janos Aranyi, was a Hungarian immigrant.

在华尔街，彼得菲面临着我们称之为算法故事的零阶段，也就是说，算法机器人在人们生活的这个时代，或在华尔街，没有立足之地。那是一个由人类选择和人类策略执行的世界。交易员在交易大厅做出决定，基于他对市场走向的预测、他口袋里已有的证券，或者在很多情况下，一种模糊的直觉。他向另一个人发出交易信号，后者在笔记本上记录交易。这就是当时的世界。

On Wall Street, Peterffy confronted what we’ll call phase zero of the algorithm story, which is to say that algorithmic bots had no place in this era of people’s lives or on Wall Street. It was a world of human choices and human strategy executed by humans. A trader made a decision on the floor based on where he believed the market was headed, the securities he already had in his pocket, or, in many cases, an ambiguous gut feeling. He signaled his trade to another human, who took note of the transaction in a notebook. This was the world.

在他的第一份金融工作中，彼得菲开发了算法，使投资者和交易员能够轻松地同时比较证券的不同特征和价值。作为一名移民，他无所事事，凭借着这种专注的精神，他成为了一名令人敬畏的程序员，而当时华尔街的程序员寥寥无几，甚至几乎没有。

In his first finance job, Peterffy built algorithms allowing investors and traders to easily compare securities’ different characteristics and values all at once. Bearing down with an intensity that came from being an immigrant with little else on which to focus, he made himself into a formidable programmer at a time when there existed few—and almost none of them on Wall Street.

在 Aranyi 工作三年后，彼得菲凭借其计算机技能获得了纽约市场最知名的人物之一亨利·贾雷茨基 (Henry Jarecki) 博士的一份有趣的工作机会。贾雷茨基博士是一位精神病学家，他对商品交易很感兴趣，并在 20 世纪 60 年代创建了一家大型贵金属交易公司，并以贾雷茨基最初合作过的一家拥有三百年历史的伦敦公司 Mocatta & Goldsmid 命名，该公司以 Mocatta 集团命名。1亚雷茨基创办彼得菲公司的年薪是2万美元，奖金是4000美元——相当于2012年的14.5万美元，对于一个几年前刚和一位被逐出教会的僧侣合租一套没有暖气的公寓的人来说，这笔钱还算不错。彼得菲对金属市场很有直觉，随着他的编程技能变得不可或缺，他在Mocatta迅速晋升。

After three years with Aranyi, Peterffy’s computer skills landed him an interesting job offer with one of the best-known players in New York’s markets: Dr. Henry Jarecki, a psychiatrist who had taken a fancy to trading commodities and during the 1960s built a large precious metals trading company that took the name of Mocatta Group, after Mocatta & Goldsmid, a three-hundred-year-old London firm with which Jarecki had originally partnered.1 Jarecki started Peterffy with a $20,000 salary and a $4,000 bonus—about the equivalent of $145,000 in 2012 and good money for somebody a few years removed from sharing an unheated apartment with an excommunicated monk. Peterffy found the metals market intuitive and moved up quickly at Mocatta as his programming skill became indispensable.

改变华尔街的算法

THE ALGORITHM THAT CHANGED WALL STREET

1969年，彼得菲与杰雷茨基合作，推出了华尔街最早的所谓“黑匣子”之一。黑匣子会吸收市场数据，仔细分析，然后向用户发出指令，在本例中是买入还是卖出。算法进行交易决策（实际上，任何决策）的计算，都是基于模型、函数和决策树构建的，这些模型、函数和决策树最初主要基于人类做出类似决策的方式。如果Mocatta的交易员通常在周五抛售黄金，因为他们注意到其他交易员在周末前看涨，那么这种偏好就被直接写入了程序中。但也有可能，当金价在过去四天连续下跌时，Mocatta的交易员忽略了周五的卖出规则。这种情况也会通过一系列相互关联的算法写入计算机程序中。

With Jarecki in 1969, Peterffy introduced one of Wall Street’s first so-called black boxes, which inhale market data, chew on it, then issue an instruction to their user, in this case whether to buy or sell. The calculus of an algorithm making trading decisions—really, any decisions—is built out of models, functions, and decision trees that at first are largely based on how humans make similar decisions. If Mocatta’s traders usually dumped gold on Friday because they noticed that other traders got bullish before the weekend, then such preferences were written directly into the program. But it was also possible that Mocatta traders ignored their Friday selling rule when gold had been down the previous four days in a row. This condition too would be written into the computer program through a series of linked algorithms.

1969年，Mocatta的交易员通过电话拨号或在交易大厅里大声喊叫进行实际交易，但买入或卖出的决定直接来自彼得菲编写的代码。尽管彼得菲已经非常优秀，但有一个黑匣子一直困扰着他。贾雷茨基曾要求他设计一种算法，能够精确地确定期权的正确价格。期权的价格和其他任何东西一样，除了交易大厅里交易员反复无常的突发奇想之外，不遵循任何特定的规则。彼得菲花了几个月的时间研究这个问题，但几乎没有什么成果。

In 1969, Mocatta traders dialing on phones or shouting in pits made the actual trades, but the decision to buy or sell came straight from code Peterffy wrote. As good as Peterffy had become, there was one black box that had eluded him. Jarecki had asked him to come up with an algorithm that could peg exactly the correct price for options, whose prices, like anything else, obeyed no particular set of rules other than the vacillating whims of traders in the pit. Peterffy had spent months on the problem and produced little of use.

期权赋予在到期日之前以设定价格买卖特定证券的权利。如果IBM股票的交易价格为100美元，而交易员确信其股价将在下个月飙升，他可能会购买一份看涨期权，赋予他在未来两个月内以100美元买入该股票的权利。看涨期权的价格可能仅为10美元，因此比购买IBM股票便宜得多；看涨期权的下行风险也有限——交易员最多可能损失的仅仅是期权价格，即10美元。出售看涨期权的交易员通常自己持有一些IBM股票，并通过卖出看涨期权套期保值，从而获利。如果股价飙升至110美元，他将不得不以100美元的价格卖出手中的股票。相反，看跌期权赋予交易员在未来以设定价格卖出股票的权利。因此，买入一份以100美元卖出IBM股票的看跌期权是一种看跌押注，因为只有当IBM股价下跌时，这种押注才会成功。买入看涨期权是看涨的。

An option confers the right to buy or sell a given security at a set price before an expiration date. If IBM is trading at $100 and a trader is convinced it will shoot up during the next month, he might buy a call option that gives him the right to buy the stock at $100 during the next two months. The call option might only cost $10, so it’s quite a bit cheaper than buying shares of IBM; a call option’s downside is also limited—the most a trader might lose is simply the price of the option, or $10. The trader who sells the call option usually holds some IBM himself and is hedging against a dip by selling the call and pocketing that cash. He will have to surrender his shares for $100 if, say, the price shoots up to $110. Put options, conversely, give one the right to sell a stock at a set price in the future. So buying a put to sell IBM at $100 is a bearish bet, because it only succeeds if the price of IBM falls. Buying a call is bullish.

20世纪70年代初，期权交易刚刚开始频繁易手。Mocatta是引领这一潮流的公司之一。Jarecki和Peterffy得出结论，期权定价主要包含三个因素：期权允许买入或卖出股票的价格（称为执行价格）；到期日；以及股票或金属的波动性。例如，价格波动剧烈的证券的期权价格应该更高，因为更有可能出现极端的执行价格。其他因素也很重要，例如当时的无风险利率，它会迫使看涨期权的价格上涨，而看跌期权的价格下跌。Peterffy需要一种优雅的算法来表达所有这些因素，并正确地加权每个因素。这是一个复杂的数学问题，他发现几乎不可能解决。他经历了沮丧和灵感的交替。

In the early 1970s, options had just begun to change hands with frequency. Mocatta was one of the firms leading the way. Jarecki and Peterffy had come to the conclusion that there were three main ingredients to pricing an option: the price that the option allowed one to buy or sell the stock for—called the strike price; the expiration date; and the volatility of the stock or metal. For instance, the options for a security whose price can swing wildly should be more expensive, because it’s more likely that extreme strike prices will be hit. Other ingredients matter too, such as the prevailing risk-free interest rate, which forces the price of call options up and the price of put options down. Peterffy needed a way to express all of this in one elegant algorithm that rightly weighted each factor. It was a complicated math problem that he found nearly impossible to solve. He cycled through spurts of dejection and inspiration.

彼得菲花了一年多时间研究这个问题，设计出一种微分方程算法，巧妙地权衡了所有因素。他回测了该算法，看看它在过去是否能够盈利，但当时商品期权的数据集非常有限。当时计算机还无法熟练地处理这类问题，更重要的是，期权市场也还没有多少历史。因此，Mocatta 做了它唯一能做的事情：开始利用算法进行交易。它确实赚了钱。当时的期权市场规模远不及如今，所以该算法无法赚取数十亿美元的利润，但这却为 Mocatta 的交易员带来了巨大的优势。该公司的大多数交易员都不知道他们的交易指令来自哪里；他们只知道自己的交易几乎总是有效。这是算法接管的第一阶段：一台配备了人类编写的算法的计算机，分析输入并向人类发出指令。

After working on the problem for more than a year, Peterffy devised an algorithm of differential equations that cleverly weighted all of the ingredients. He back-tested the algorithm to see if it would have made money in the past, but the data sets for commodities options at that point in history were limited. This was before computers handled such things adeptly and, more important, before the options market had much history. So Mocatta did the only thing it could: it started trading with the algorithm. It made money. The options markets weren’t the giant realms they are today, so the algorithm wasn’t able to harvest billions of dollars, but it gave Mocatta’s traders a big edge. Most of the company’s pit people didn’t know where their trade orders came from; they knew only that their trades almost always worked. This is phase one of an algorithmic takeover: a computer, equipped with human-composed algorithms, analyzes inputs and issues marching orders to humans.

两人将算法投入使用大约一年后，华尔街上空响起了一声惊雷。1973年，芝加哥大学两位教授菲舍尔·布莱克和迈伦·斯科尔斯发表了一篇论文，其中包含了后来被称为布莱克-斯科尔斯公式的理论，该公式可以精确地告诉用户期权的价值。基于布莱克-斯科尔斯公式的算法在数十年的时间里重塑了华尔街，并将一群志同道合的人——数学家和工程师——带到了金融界的前线。与彼得菲的方案非常相似的布莱克-斯科尔斯方案，让迈伦·斯科尔斯于1997年获得了诺贝尔奖（布莱克于1995年去世）。

About a year after the men had put their algorithm to work, a thunderclap sounded above Wall Street. In 1973 Fischer Black and Myron Scholes, both professors at the University of Chicago, published a paper that included what would become known as the Black-Scholes formula, which told its users exactly how much an option was worth. Algorithms based on Black-Scholes would over the course of decades reshape Wall Street and bring a flock of like-minded men—mathematicians and engineers—to the front lines of the financial world. The Black-Scholes solution, quite similar to Peterffy’s, earned Myron Scholes a Nobel Prize in 1997 (Black had died in 1995).

变革并非一朝一夕之功。布莱克-斯科尔斯公式，一个偏微分方程，非常出色。但大多数交易员并不研读学术期刊。即使他们研读，运用这个公式也并非易事；需要相当的数学技能才能掌握。了解布莱克-斯科尔斯公式的人寥寥无几，知道匈牙利人编写了一个类似的算法，几乎每笔交易都能盈利的人就更少了。彼得菲和贾雷茨基对此讳莫如深。

Change didn’t happen overnight. The Black-Scholes formula, a partial differential equation, was brilliant. But most traders didn’t peruse academic journals. Even if they did, employing the formula wasn’t simple; it took significant math skills to wield. As few people as there were who understood Black-Scholes, even fewer knew that a Hungarian had written a similar algorithm that made money on almost every trade. Peterffy and Jarecki kept it quiet.

2010年，在芝加哥的一场正式晚宴上，精神抖擞的贾雷基瞥见斯科尔斯正端着鸡尾酒，悠闲地交谈着。贾雷基走到这位诺贝尔奖得主面前。“你知道吗，我们的诺贝尔奖还在你手里，”贾雷基对斯科尔斯说。这句话引得斯科尔斯苦笑一声。“他一点也不觉得好笑，”贾雷基说。

At a 2010 black-tie banquet in Chicago, a spry Jarecki spotted Scholes across the room nursing a cocktail and lightly conversing. Jarecki made his way over to the Nobel laureate. “You know, you still have our Nobel Prize,” Jarecki said to Scholes. The remark elicited a dry grimace. “He was not amused,” Jarecki says.

对于理解该公式的交易员来说，布莱克-斯科尔斯公式提供了一种计算期权交易准确价格的方法。这就像一张市场小抄。任何能够准确计算布莱克-斯科尔斯公式中每个因素并将其实时应用于期权价格的人都能赚钱。使用该公式的交易员会卖出价格高于公式规定的期权，并买入价格低于其合理价格的期权。只要反复操作，持有足够多的证券，几乎可以保证获得丰厚的利润。

For traders who understood it, Black-Scholes gave them a way to calculate the exact price at which options should be traded. It was like having a cheat sheet for the market. There was money to be made by anybody who could accurately calculate each factor within the Black-Scholes formula and apply it to options prices in real time. Traders using the formula would sell options that were priced higher than the formula stipulated and buy ones that were priced lower than their fair price. Do this enough times with enough securities and a healthy profit was virtually guaranteed.

1980 年成为华尔街黑客：完美地点，完美时机

TO BE A WALL STREET HACKER IN 1980: PERFECT PLACE, PERFECT TIME

20世纪70年代末，华尔街迎来了黑客时代的曙光，算法开始超越人类，这一趋势如今已席卷全球各个角落的金融市场。华尔街开始从美国挖走越来越多的顶尖数学和科学人才，让他们参与编程和设计交易算法。在布莱克-斯科尔斯定价模型（Black-Scholes）占据市场主导地位之前，一直有少量工程师和数学家缓慢地涌入曼哈顿下城，但数量稀少。

The late 1970s marked the faint dawn of the hacker era on Wall Street, when algorithms began to step in front of humans, a trend that has come to dominate all financial markets in every corner of the world. Wall Street began to peel away an increasing share of the best math and science minds in the United States and put them to work programming and conceiving trading algorithms. Before Black-Scholes got hold of the market, there had always been a slow trickle of engineers and mathematicians into lower Manhattan, but they were rare.

麻省理工学院、哈佛大学和其他精英大学的工程与科学殿堂成了招聘人员争夺筹码的地方。华尔街总是潜伏在那里，带着金钱、魅力和奖金的承诺四处游荡。金融业最终不仅成功地从研究型大学和科技公司挖走了有前途的年轻人才，还成功地从科技和学术界的显赫职位上挖走了经验丰富的资深工程师和科学家。

The engineering and science halls at MIT, Harvard, and other elite universities became places where recruiters wrestled for leverage. Wall Street would always be there, around the corner, skulking about with its promises of cash, glamour, and bonuses. The financial industry would eventually succeed not only in pulling away promising young talent from research universities and tech companies but also in luring accomplished and veteran engineers and scientists from cushy positions of prominence in tech and academia.

华尔街为何如此渴求这些人才？为了速度。那些率先抓住良机的人才能获胜——而计算机算法在同类交易中也总能胜过人类。在 20 世纪 70 年代末，能够以代码形式表达算法并非一项常见技能。正因如此，彼得菲，一位拥有 15 年编程经验和 10 年市场经验的异类，发现自己与世界上任何一个人一样，都拥有引领华尔街未来变革的完美位置。

Why did Wall Street want all of this talent? For speed. Those who are first in to a good trade win—and algorithms running on computers will always beat a human looking for the same kinds of trades. Being able to express algorithms in the form of code in the late 1970s was not a common skill. This is why Peterffy, an outlier with his fifteen years of coding experience and ten years of plying the markets, found himself in as perfect a position as anybody in the world to lead the coming changes on Wall Street.

编写了期权算法后，彼得菲开始组建自己的编程部门，随着期权在市场上的效用不断扩大，他招募了更多程序员。凭借贾雷茨基的交易智慧和彼得菲对算法的精通，Mocatta 开始盈利数百万美元，并成为全球最强大的大宗商品交易商之一。随着 Mocatta 的发展，彼得菲的黑客大军也日益壮大。到 1975 年，他们雇佣了 50 名程序员，使公司成为华尔街为数不多的编程知识支柱之一。

Having written the options algorithm, Peterffy began to build his programming department, bringing on more coders as their utility expanded in the market. Mocatta, through Jarecki’s trade smarts and Peterffy’s mastery of algorithms, began to make millions of dollars and became one of the most powerful commodities traders in the world. As Mocatta grew, so did Peterffy’s hacker army. By 1975, they employed fifty programmers, making the company one of the few mainstays of programming knowledge on Wall Street.

这些程序员都在做什么呢？他们中的大多数人都在帮助彼得菲将他和贾雷茨基构思的交易算法转换成计算机可以执行的代码。随着算法变得越来越复杂，需要更好的代码和更多的程序员。

What were all of these programmers doing? Most of them were helping Peterffy put trading algorithms, conceived by himself and Jarecki, into code that could be executed by a computer. As the algorithms grew more complicated, better code and more programmers were needed.

算法可以从简单的事情开始。比如说，洗衣服的算法。输入可以简单到 (1) 衣物重量和 (2) 衣物面料类型。算法会接收重量输入，如果重量低于一磅，就将洗衣机的水位调低。然后，如果衣物面料是“棉”，算法会将洗衣机的水温设置为热水洗涤，冷水漂洗。不同的重量和面料会从算法中得出不同的洗涤程序。但是，如果算法还必须根据衣物的颜色、污渍、预浸需求、烘干时间和洗涤剂类型来选择合适的洗涤方案，那会怎样呢？编写这样的算法对于任何一位计算机科学专业的大二学生来说都是可以理解的，但它仍然比第一个仅输入重量和面料的算法要困难得多，层次也更复杂。人类可以轻松地处理一堆需要多次洗涤和多次需求的衣物，而无需费脑筋；然而，编写一个具有同样功能的计算机算法则需要技巧。突然之间，基于输入的可能解决方案就有数百种。为了确保算法正常工作，必须考虑并正确分类每一种解决方案。

Algorithms can start as simple things. Take one for, say, doing the laundry. The inputs could be as simple as (1) the weight of the laundry and (2) the type of fabric. The algorithm would take the weight input and, if it were below one pound, set the washing machine’s water level to low. It would then take the fabric input of “cotton” and set the machine’s water temperature to hot for the wash and cold for the rinse. Different weights and fabrics would elicit different washing programs from the algorithm. But what if the algorithm had to also pick the exact right wash according to the laundry’s colors, stains, presoak needs, drying time, and detergent types? Composing such an algorithm is well within the reach of any sophomore-year computer science student, but is still multitudes more difficult and layered than the first algorithm whose only inputs are weight and fabric. Humans can easily dispatch a load of laundry with multiple washes and needs without stretching their brains; writing a computer algorithm with the same capabilities, though, takes skill. All of a sudden, there are hundreds of possible solutions based on inputs. Each one has to be accounted for and rightly categorized for the algorithm to work correctly.

这样，算法就可以看作是由一个接一个的二元决策组成的巨型决策树。我们做的几乎所有事情，从开车到交易股票到挑选配偶，都可以分解为基于二元输入的一串二元决策。洗好的衣服里有红色衣物吗？没有。有黑色衣物吗？有。它们是尼龙的吗？没有。它们是棉的吗？不是。它们是丝绸的吗？是的。这些黑色丝绸衣物上是否有污渍？是的。是咖啡渍吗？不是。是蛋黄酱渍吗？不是。是奶酪酱渍吗？是的。等等。对于复杂的主题，这些二元决策树可以增长到数百万甚至数十亿个节点。算法的树可以接受输入并将它们运行到方程式和公式中，然后将这些答案作为进一步的输入，从而创建具有重复层和令人难以置信的细节的长字符串。三百年前，德国数学家戈特弗里德·莱布尼茨就对这个主题提出了理论，即生命可以分解为一系列二元决策，而这远早于半导体的出现，半导体无法为运行算法的机器提供动力。

In this way, algorithms can be looked at as giant decision trees composed of one binary decision after another. Almost everything we do, from driving a car to trading a stock to picking a spouse, can be broken down to a string of binary decisions based on binary input. Is there a red item in the laundry? No. Are there black items? Yes. Are they nylon? No. Are they cotton? No. Are they silk? Yes. Do these black silk items have an existing stain? Yes. Is it a stain from coffee? No. Is it a stain from mayonnaise? No. Is it a stain from cheese sauce? Yes. And so on. These binary decision trees can grow to millions or even billions of nodes for complicated subjects. The algorithm’s tree may take inputs and run them through equations and formulas, then take those answers as further inputs, creating long strings with repetitive layers and mind-boggling detail. The German mathematician Gottfried Leibniz theorized on this exact subject three hundred years ago—that life could be broken down into a long series of binary decisions—long before there existed semiconductors to facilitate machines that could run algorithms.

彼得菲的算法逐渐发展成蜘蛛状矩阵，包含数百个输入、变量以及相关的微分方程和积分。将这些内容转化为计算机代码需要一位真正的大师和一个庞大的团队。在曼哈顿的Mocatta总部，彼得菲的程序员们在电脑屏幕前工作，读取电传打字机传来的市场数据。然后，程序员们将数据手动输入到他们的电脑中，电脑的算法会发出价格，供Mocatta在纽约商品交易所的大厅报价。程序员们会与市中心交易大厅附近的工作人员通话，以算法发出的速度大声报出报价，Mocatta的工作人员会用手势将价格信号传递给场内交易员。这算不上高速交易，但这是市场首次由算法持续主导。而对彼得菲来说最棒的是：市场上的其他人几乎不知道他的数据从何而来。

Peterffy’s algorithms grew to be spidery matrices with hundreds of inputs, variables, and dependent differential equations and integrals. Putting such things into computer code took a true master and a large team. At Mocatta’s headquarters in Manhattan, Peterffy’s programmers worked at computer screens and read market data as it came in on Teletype machines. The programmers then typed the data by hand into their computers, whose algorithms issued prices for Mocatta to quote on the New York Commodities Exchange floor. The programmers, speaking to clerks near the floor action downtown, would bark out quotes as fast as the algorithm issued them, and Mocatta’s clerks would signal the prices to their pit traders with hand gestures. It was hardly high-speed trading, but it was the first time markets were consistently dictated by an algorithm. And the best part for Peterffy: the rest of the market had little idea where he got his numbers from.

彼得菲最初进入华尔街时或许只是个缺乏市场头脑的黑客，但他的交易直觉——在砍口香糖棒、追逐废金属和典当邮票时培养起来——却日渐敏锐​​。贾雷茨基注意到了这一点。他开始在莫卡塔做出任何重大决策或交易时向彼得菲寻求建议。一位同事记得，贾雷茨基每次参加重要会议时，彼得菲都会陪在他身边。2

He might have entered Wall Street as a hacker with little market sense, but Peterffy’s trading instincts—born while chopping up chewing gum sticks, chasing scrap metal, and pawning stamps—became sharpened. Jarecki noticed. He came to lean on Peterffy for advice on any significant decisions or trades that Mocatta made. One coworker remembers Jarecki never entering an important meeting without Peterffy at his side.2

到1976年，彼得菲的黑客团队已发展到80人。这是当时世界上最大的金融编程团队。彼得菲不仅证明了自己是一位敏捷的代码编写者，而且还是一位能够管理形形色色、有时才华横溢的科学人才的优秀管理者——这是一种罕见而细致入微的技能。

By 1976, Peterffy’s hacker force had grown to eighty. It was the largest financial programming operation in the world. Peterffy had proven himself not only a nimble writer of code but also a capable manager of disparate and sometimes brilliant scientific personalities—a rare and nuanced skill.

即使Mocatta发展壮大，其业务仍然主要集中在大宗商品领域。彼得菲想把他的算法带到股票期权交易场，但贾雷茨基却想继续专注于金属。股票期权市场主要由来自证券交易所的交易员主导，而一家公司的价值是由交易场里的人们决定的——这理所当然。许多不可量化的因素会影响股价，例如商誉、增长前景、迫在眉睫的诉讼以及竞争；因此，没有确定股价的神奇公式。然而，期权价格应该纯粹反映概率和统计数据。只有包括彼得菲在内的极少数人知道这一点。对于那些理解数学的人来说，机会就像河流一样涌来。

Even as Mocatta grew, its business remained mostly in commodities. Peterffy wanted to bring his algorithms to the stock options pits, but Jarecki wanted to remain focused on metals. The markets for stock options were dominated by traders who had come from the stock exchanges, where a company’s value was determined by men in the pits—and rightly so. There are a number of nonquantifiable elements affecting stock prices, such as goodwill, growth prospects, looming lawsuits, and competition; for that reason, there’s no magic formula for determining the price of a stock. Option prices, however, should be pure reflections of probability and statistics. Only a very select few, including Peterffy, knew this. For those who understood the math, opportunity ran like a river.

20世纪70年代末，芝加哥期权交易所（CBOE）逐渐成熟，彼得菲认为这是股票期权市场即将爆发的迹象。1976年，他前往芝加哥考察CBOE。当时，一些期权的买卖价差高达两三美元。“交易员们只是随便编造了这些价格，然后就直接抛售出去了，”他说。

When the Chicago Board Options Exchange became well established by the late 1970s, Peterffy took it as a sign that the stock options market was about to explode. In 1976, he traveled to Chicago to check out the CBOE. The bid-ask spreads on some of the options were as much as two and three dollars. “The traders just made these prices up and threw them out there,” he says.

随着股票期权的蓬勃发展，彼得菲并不满足于只专注于大宗商品。彼得菲知道，黄金和白银市场及其相关期权的交易量不足以让他在华尔街积累真正的财富。他还希望获得莫卡塔公司（Mocatta）的部分股权，尽管他声称贾雷基曾承诺过这一点，但最终却未能如愿。贾雷基否认自己曾达成过任何此类协议。

With the burgeoning possibilities of stock options, Peterffy wasn’t satisfied sticking to commodities. Volume on the gold and silver markets and their related options, Peterffy knew, weren’t sufficient to build a true Wall Street fortune. He was also thwarted in his desire for a piece of ownership at Mocatta, which he says Jarecki had promised him. Jarecki denies ever making any such agreement.

1977年，彼得菲花了2000美元买了他的第一台家用电脑——一台Olivetti。在Mocatta工作了几天后，他又花上几个晚上为这台意大利机器编写算法程序，为进军股票期权市场的那一天做准备。

In 1977, Peterffy spent $2,000 on his first home computer, an Olivetti. After putting in days at Mocatta, he spent nights programming his Italian machine with algorithms, preparing for the day he would storm the market for stock options.

最初的算法交易者

THE ORIGINAL ALGORITHMIC TRADER

由于不可能成为Mocatta的部分所有者，彼得菲认为他已经榨干了自己在Mocatta任职期间所能榨干的一切。于是，在1977年，他带着20万美元的积蓄，放弃了稳定的工作，在美国证券交易所购买了一个席位，当时该交易所刚刚开始提供期权交易服务。这个席位花了他3.6万美元，剩下的16.4万美元可以用来交易。

With no possibility of becoming a part owner at Mocatta, Peterffy decided he had squeezed all he could from his tenure there. So in 1977, with $200,000 in savings, he left the stability of employment and bought a seat on the American Stock Exchange, which had just begun to trade options. The seat cost him $36,000, leaving him $164,000 to trade with.

在加入美国证券交易所（AMEX）的第一天之前，彼得菲每天在电脑前忙碌十八个小时，调整算法，制作表格，指导他在场内买卖期权。他锁定了几十家他认为期权定价错误率更高的公司。对于每家公司，他都制作了一系列表格，列出该公司股票不同价格下的期权价值。随着股价全天波动，彼得菲计划快速查阅这些表格，确定股票期权的合理价格，并据此进行买卖。这些表格就是他算法的纸质体现。

Leading up to his first day at the AMEX, Peterffy toiled at his computer for eighteen hours a day, tweaking his algorithms and producing sheets to guide his buying and selling of options on the floor. He homed in on a few dozen companies whose options he believed were more often mispriced than others. For each company, he made a series of sheets listing option values for different prices of the company’s stock. As stock prices fluctuated throughout the day, Peterffy planned to quickly consult his sheets, determine the fair price of the stock’s options, and buy or sell accordingly. The sheets were the paper manifestation of his algorithms.

彼得菲把所有文件都打包成一个三孔活页夹，作为他在交易大厅的随身小抄。他觉得准备美国运通卡（AMEX）很困难，并非因为他对微积分不自信——他的方法论才是他的基石——而是因为他害怕独自工作，害怕完全独立。他担心自己的口音，担心不得不在交易大厅里和一群热情奔放、汗流浃背的人推推搡搡、大喊大叫。他担心那些像小团体一样的交易员会联合起来对付他，过早地、不公平地结束他的实验。最重要的是，他担心失败，担心不得不满盘皆输地回到莫卡塔。

Peterffy packaged all of his papers together into a three-ring binder that would serve as his portable cheat sheet in the trading pits. He found preparing for the AMEX difficult, not because he wasn’t confident in his calculus—his methodology was his rock—but because he was scared of working alone, being utterly independent. He was worried about his accent and having to jostle, bounce, and shout with throngs of demonstrative and sweaty men in the pits. He fretted about clubby groups of traders ganging up on him, ending his experiment prematurely and unfairly. Most of all, he worried about failing, about having to return, defeated, to Mocatta.

彼得菲决心不让这种事情发生，于是手里拿着活页夹来到美国运通交易大厅。他很快发现，把活页夹摊到面前，他的体型就和拥挤的场内两个交易员差不多了。其他交易员可不乐意让他腾出空间，让他打开那本神奇的书。“这书里到底写了什么？”其他交易员问道。他们宣扬，交易靠的是智慧、勇气和胆量，而不是一堆傻乎乎的文件。

Determined to not let that happen, Peterffy showed up on the AMEX floor, binder in hand. He quickly discovered that the binder, when held out in front of him, effectively made him the size of two traders in the packed pits. Other traders did not appreciate surrendering space so that he could crack open his magic book. And just what the hell was in the book, anyway? the other traders asked. Trading, they preached, was about your wits, your guts, and your balls, not some goofy clutch of papers.

“人们认为我用这个活页夹工作简直太荒唐了，”彼得菲说。

“People thought I was absolutely ridiculous working out of this binder,” Peterffy says.

为了融入其中，也为了让自己在交易大厅里的日子过得更轻松，彼得菲把最重要的笔记浓缩成几张双面纸，方便折叠后塞进后兜。当他觉得价格合适时，就会把手伸进口袋，翻阅那张纸。他站在那里，阅读着算法生成的小字，交易大厅的人潮把他推来推去。但他依然坚持，丝毫没有注意到周围的推搡，直到他抬起头，举起手，引起另一个交易员或做市商的注意，用浓重的口音大声喊出他的订单。事实上，口音是个问题；他从口袋里掏出脏兮兮的折叠纸条，这个怪习惯也同样是个问题。彼得菲说，其他交易员“觉得我疯了”。

So to fit in, and to make life generally easier for himself in the pits, Peterffy boiled his most important notes down to a series of double-sided sheets that he could easily fold and stuff into his back pocket. When he thought the price was right, he would dip into his pocket and consult his sheet. As he stood there reading the tiny print that came from his algorithms, the tide of the pits shoved him to and fro. But he carried on, oblivious to the jostling, until he could shoot his head up, raise his hand, and catch the eye of another trader or market maker, barking out his order in a heavily accented burst of words. The accent, in fact, was a problem; so too was his peculiar habit of consulting grungy folded sheets of paper from his pocket. The other traders, Peterffy says, “thought I was quite mad.”

彼得菲有时会在交易大厅里一连几个小时，一句话也不说，甚至连一笔交易也不做。他虔诚地查看着交易单。如果某个期权不符合他非常保守的盈利准则，他就不会买入。“我非常小心，”他说。

Peterffy would sometimes spend hours in the pits without uttering a word or making a single trade. He religiously consulted his sheets. If an option didn’t fit his very conservative profit guidelines, he didn’t buy it. “I was very careful,” he says.

尽管彼得菲谨慎谨慎，却还是无法避免市场对新手的强制性打击。在他交易生涯的早期，他曾花了一个上午的时间交易杜邦公司的期权。在交易进行到一半时，他注意到一个价外看涨期权的售价为31美元。根据他的交易单，该期权的实际价值为22美元。他计划做空。“对于一个匈牙利小伙子来说，这可是一笔巨款，”他说。

Despite his caution, Peterffy couldn’t avoid the market’s mandatory beatings for neophytes. Early in his trading career, he spent a morning swapping options on DuPont. In the middle of the session, he noticed an out-of-the-money call option selling for $31. According to his sheets, the option was actually worth $22. He planned to go short. “That was a big profit for a little Hungarian guy,” he says.

彼得菲实际上持有300份以18美元买入的期权合约，所以他以31美元的价格卖出，然后又卖出了200份。他卖出了200份看涨期权，但没有补仓——他既没有买入相应数量的股票，也没有用看跌期权来对冲他的押注。任何不利于他押注的走势都可能让他崩溃。但他怎么能错过这样的机会呢？

Peterffy actually had three hundred of the options contracts that he had picked up for $18, so he sold those at $31 and then sold two hundred more. He had sold two hundred call options without covering his call—he hadn’t bought a corresponding number of shares or hedged his bet with put options in the other direction. A move against his bet could crush him. But how could he pass up such a deal?

彼得菲卖出看涨期权后不久，杜邦公司就停止了交易。消息陆续传来。公司宣布盈利远超预期，并宣布将股票一拆二拆股，股价应声飙升。彼得菲持有的两百份期权合约，每份代表一百股股票，让他每股亏损5美元，也就是每份合约亏损500美元。他刚刚损失了10万美元，超过了他交易本金的一半。他将此事归咎于那些利用内幕信息进行交易的人。无论原因是什么，这10万美元的损失都是一场灾难。“我不知道是该哭还是该吐，”他说。那天晚上，他回家时崩溃了，对自己的方法感到怀疑。“我原以为自己很聪明。”

Just after Peterffy sold the calls, DuPont stopped trading. News trickled in. The company announced earnings much larger than expected and a two-for-one split of the stock, whose price soared. Peterffy’s two hundred options contracts, each representative of one hundred shares of stock, left him on the hook for a $5 loss per share, or $500 per contract. He had just blown $100,000, more than half of his trading capital. He blames the incident on people trading with insider knowledge. Whatever the reason, the $100,000 loss was a calamity. “I didn’t know if I should throw up or cry,” he says. He went home that night devastated, unsure of his methods. “I had thought I was so clever.”

彼得菲抽着烟，盯着上东区租住的小厨房餐桌，心想他需要把更多的生活、金钱和精力投入到交易中，尽管以大多数人的标准来看，他已经非常专注了。他决定，摆脱困境的唯一方法就是成为一台专注于一件事的机器：交易、储蓄和盈利。其他一切都不重要。彼得菲从桌边站起来，把烟盒扔进了厨房垃圾桶。他再也不抽烟了。他想，花在香烟上的钱最好用在交易大厅里。“我立刻计算了一下，如果20年后我不再吸烟，能省下多少钱，”他解释道。“我需要一切。”

Smoking a cigarette, staring at his small kitchen table in his Upper East Side rental, Peterffy thought he needed to dedicate even more of his life, his money, and his attention to trading, although by most standards he was already maniacally focused. The only way to dig out of this hole, he decided, was to become a machine bent on one thing: trading, saving, and winning. Nothing else mattered. Peterffy got up from the table and threw his pack of cigarettes into the kitchen garbage. He would never smoke again. The cash he spent on cigarettes would be better utilized on the trading floor, he reasoned. “I instantly calculated how much money I could save in twenty years by no longer smoking,” he explains. “I needed everything.”

彼得菲带着全新的专注力回到了维修站。他一如既往地坚守岗位，但由于杜邦公司的纠缠，他没有进行所谓的“牛仔式押注”。

Peterffy returned to the pits with a renewed focus. He stuck to his sheets, as always, but with DuPont haunting him, he didn’t make what he called “cowboy bets.”

他一天天慢慢地重建资本。他坚持自己的算法系统，很少经历巨额亏损。尽管布莱克-斯科尔斯公式七年前就已发布，但它对市场的冲击力还不足以让彼得菲或其他利用其天才获利的人感到不安。

He slowly rebuilt his capital, one grinding day at a time. Sticking to his algorithmic system, he rarely experienced days with substantial losses.
