Even though the Black-Scholes formula had been published seven years before, it wasn’t moving the markets enough to bother Peterffy or others who were cashing in on its genius.

尽管彼得菲的算法和交易表非常有效，但他毕竟只是个小人物。他需要更多人手参与交易。于是，他慢慢地雇佣了更多交易员。为了防止亏损，并控制交易员的操作，他训练他们只根据交易表上的价格进行买卖，并每晚用算法生成的新数据更新交易表。随着他在美国证券交易所 (AMEX) 的业务不断扩展，彼得菲将他的交易公司重新命名为“木材山”(Timber Hill)，以纪念他度假时在纽约乡村的一条道路。他购买了更多交易席位，并开始尝试其他策略，例如配对交易和套利，这两种策略都是他在为 Mocatta 开发交易策略时熟悉的。

As effective as his algorithms and sheets were, Peterffy was only one man. He needed more people in the pits. So he slowly hired more traders. To prevent losses and keep control of how his traders operated, he trained them to bid and offer only off of values on his sheets, which he would update with fresh numbers from his algorithm every night. As he expanded his operation on the AMEX, Peterffy renamed his trading operation Timber Hill, after a road in rural New York where he vacationed. He bought more trading seats and began dabbling in other strategies such as pairs trading and arbitrage, both of which he was familiar with from his time developing tactics for Mocatta.

即使交易大厅里挤满了交易员，彼得菲还是花了数小时琢磨如何将他所有的场内交易理论都输入到一台计算机中，让计算机能够比交易大厅里的人更好地执行他的算法。但目前还没有办法做到这一点。交易大厅的性质让他困惑不已。交易大厅的天花板超过40英尺高，交易大厅两旁排列着栏杆，工作人员站在高处，向下面的交易员发出买卖信号。“每个人都知道每个人的信号，”彼得菲说，所以很多交易大厅的人在交易员举手之前就知道他们发出的信号，导致他们的交易被伏击或窃取。“这太荒谬了。”

Even with additional traders jostling in the pits for him, Peterffy spent hours ruminating on ways he could drop all of his floor-trading theories into a computer that could execute his algorithms far better than people on a trading floor. But there was no avenue to do such a thing, not yet. The nature of the pits bedeviled him. The ceilings of the trading floor were more than forty feet high and the pits themselves were lined by railings where clerks would stand, far above, and signal to their traders below what to buy or sell. “Everybody knew everybody’s signals,” Peterffy says, so that much of the pits knew what was coming from some traders before they ever lifted their arms, resulting in their trades being ambushed or stolen. “It was ridiculous.”

彼得菲提出了一个想法，所有交易员都可以用连接到中央计算机的手持设备输入买卖信息，中央计算机会自动跟踪价格和时间的优先级，并公平地分配交易。这个想法没能持续多久，因为那些掌控全局的人——那些专家——否决了它。

Peterffy circulated an idea that bids and offers could be entered by all traders on handheld devices tethered to a central computer that would automatically track price-time priorities and spread the deals out fairly. The idea didn’t last long, as those in control—the specialists—quashed it.

彼得菲没有利用技术改善市场运作方式，而是决定以更大的规模参与其中，成为美国证券交易所 (AMEX) 部分期权的做市商。他认为，只要他能够根据自己的算法，在他认为公平的区间内交易，更高的交易量就能降低风险，提高利润。但首先，他必须找到一种方法，让控制交易的专家能够即时且持续地识别他的买入和卖出指令。由于他不像大多数交易员那样参与日常的闲聊和体育话题，他在某种程度上算是个局外人。专家们并不总是在人群中喊出他的交易，因为他们根本不喜欢和他打交道。因此，这位匈牙利人决定聘请那些他知道专家们会喜欢的人。

Rather than changing how the market worked for the better with technology, Peterffy decided to join in a larger capacity and become a market maker in some options on the AMEX, thinking the higher volumes would lower his risk and raise his profits so long as he was able to keep trading in bands he knew to be fair according to his algorithms. But first he had to find a way to have his bids and offers instantly and consistently recognized by the specialists who controlled trading. Because he didn’t traffic in the normal scuttlebutt and sports chatter that most traders did, he was something of an outsider. The specialists didn’t always call out his trades from the crowd because they simply didn’t enjoy dealing with him. So the Hungarian decided to hire people whom he knew the specialists would like.

金融行业，如同大多数高薪领域一样，往往由男性主导，而男性也更倾向于雇佣男性。因此，当彼得菲雇佣他能找到的最高、最漂亮、最丰满的女性时，他的计划就显得颇为新颖了。这一策略对他的订单流产生了奇迹般的效果。突然之间，那些专员就总是接他的订单了。他们热情地拥抱他的交易员，攀谈起来，并且能以最快的速度识别出金发女郎的订单。“专员们当时心想，‘这些愚蠢的金发女郎，她们懂什么，对吧？’”彼得菲说。

The financial industry, as is the case with most high-paying fields, tends to be dominated by men who are wont to hire more men. So when Peterffy hired the tallest, prettiest, most buxom women he could find, the plan was more than a bit novel. The tactic worked miracles for his order flow. Suddenly, the specialists always took his trades. They put their arms around his traders, chitchatted, and recognized the blondes’ orders as fast as they were issued. “The specialists were thinking, ‘These dumb blondes, what do they know, right?’” Peterffy says.

彼得菲雇佣的那些女人确实不太懂交易，更别提算法了。但当时他的交易员们都没什么本事，单打独斗也没什么成就。而且现在她们也都不再用交易表来指导交易了。彼得菲设计了一套新系统，让任何人都能做出明智的交易。

It’s true that the women Peterffy hired didn’t know much about trading, let alone algorithms. But none of his traders at that time were any good out on their own. And none of them were using the sheets for guidance anymore. Peterffy had devised a new system that empowered anybody to make smart trades.

与许多创新一样，该系统的诞生源于偶然。1982年中，彼得菲膝盖韧带撕裂。康复期间，膝盖感染，他无法长时间站立，更别提与交易大厅里的那些笨蛋搏斗了。他被调到美国运通（AMEX）楼上的办公室，只能在楼下打电话报告交易，独自一人忙着修修补补。最终，他的注意力集中在他的Quotron机器上，这台机器每次只向用户提供一只股票或期权的价格。Quotron的数据通过一条专用电话线传输。彼得菲曾问过当时数据行业占据主导地位的Quotron，他们是否愿意将发送到Quotron机器上的数据卖给他。答案每次都是断然拒绝。

Like many innovations, the system was conceived by accident. In the middle of 1982, Peterffy tore several ligaments in his knee. During his rehab, the knee became infected and he was unable to stand on the floor for long periods, let alone wrestle with the meatheads in the pits. Relegated to his office upstairs at the AMEX, he called trades downstairs and was left by himself to tinker. His attention eventually settled on his Quotron machine, which gave users one stock or option price at a time. The data for the Quotron came in on a dedicated phone line. Peterffy had asked Quotron, which dominated the data industry at the time, if they would sell him the feed they sent to their machines. The answer, every time, was a curt no.

彼得菲躲在办公室里，用一把电线钳子偷看了Quotron的新闻，这启发了他后来入侵纳斯达克。“所以，当然了，”他说，“我们窃取了数据。”

Cooped up in his office, Peterffy took to the Quotron feed with a pair of wire snippers, a move that would later inspire his Nasdaq hack. “So, of course,” he says, “we stole the data.”

彼得菲在楼上剪断了Quotron机器的电线，然后开始使用电气工程师的老式工具。他用示波器测量电线中的电脉冲，并将脉冲与数据匹配，解码电线信号的含义。弄清这些含义后，他为自己的电脑编写了一个程序，可以实时读取Quotron数据并将其存储在内存中。然后，该程序会扫描海量的股票和期权数据，并将其传输到彼得菲的算法中。首先，也是最重要的，这些算法会搜索那些定价严重错误的期权。

Upstairs, having severed the wire to his Quotron machine, Peterffy wielded the old-school tools of an electrical engineer. He used an oscilloscope to measure the electric pulses in the wire and, matching the pulses to data, decoded what the wire’s signals meant. Once he knew that, he wrote a program for his PC that would inhale the Quotron data as it was issued and store it within its memory. The program would then scan the warrens of stock and option data and route it through Peterffy’s algorithms. First and foremost, the algorithms searched for options that were egregiously mispriced.

彼得菲特别感兴趣的，也是他编写算法寻找的，是所谓的Delta中性交易。在这些交易中，彼得菲会卖出一份定价过高的看涨期权，同时买入一份定价过低的看跌期权，从而创建一个不会受到市场波动影响的头寸。

What Peterffy was especially interested in—and what he wrote his algorithms to search for—were what’s known as delta neutral trades. In these trades, an overpriced call option, which Peterffy would sell, could be coupled with buying an underpriced put option to create a position that wouldn’t be adversely affected by a spike or a dip in the market.

例如，假设IBM的股票交易价格为75美元。彼得菲的Delta中性交易可能如下所示：他将以每股1美元的价格（高估期权）卖出10,000份看涨期权（在未来60天内以75美元的执行价格买入IBM股票的权利），获利10,000美元。几乎与此同时，另一位彼得菲交易员将以每股85美分的价格（低估期权）买入10,000份看跌期权（在未来60天内以75美元的执行价格卖出IBM股票的权利），获利8,500美元。这笔交易的结果：几乎无风险地获利1,500美元。

For example, say shares of IBM were trading hands at $75. A delta neutral trade for Peterffy could look something like this: He would sell 10,000 call options (the right to buy IBM at a strike price of $75 during the next sixty days) for $1 each (the overpriced option), taking in the $10,000. Almost simultaneously, another Peterffy trader would buy 10,000 put options (the right to sell IBM at a strike price of $75 during the next sixty days) for 85 cents each (the underpriced option), for $8,500. The result of the trade: a near-riskless $1,500 profit.

由于IBM等大公司股票的期权有几十种不同的执行价格和多种不同的到期日，20世纪80年代的期权市场充斥着那些能够找到Delta中性交易的人。一些场内交易员掌握了这种策略——他们扫描报价带和行情机，寻找那些定价错误的期权，以便轻松对冲，获得无风险利润。但少数几个在场内寻找交易的人的力量，终究敌不过彼得菲那台不知疲倦的机器。

Because options on stocks of big companies such as IBM traded at dozens of different strike prices as well as multitudes of diverse expirations, the 1980s options market was rife with delta neutral trades for those who could find them. Some floor traders had caught on to the tactic—they scanned the tapes and tickers for mispriced options that could easily be hedged for riskless profits. But the power of a few men searching out trades in the pits was no match for Peterffy’s indefatigable machine.

计算机会汇总那些符合 delta 中性策略的交易，并立即打印出来。彼得菲膝盖受伤，只能坐在椅子上，然后打电话给他的场内职员，后者会把交易信息转交给他的女兵团队。就这样一直进行下去。在破解 Quotron 链接并启动计算机系统四个月后，彼得菲赚的钱比以往任何时候都多。这一切的关键在于可靠的纯数据流，而很少有人拥有这样的数据。正如当今许多热门公司所证明的那样，数据可以决定一个行业的成败。彼得菲的行动开创了华尔街海量数据存储的自动汇编和使用，而此类数据的挖掘正是从华尔街开始的。

The computer would put together trades that made for delta neutral plays and print them out immediately. Peterffy, confined to a chair with a bum knee, would then place a call to his floor clerk, who would get the trades to his corps of women. And on it went. Four months after hacking the Quotron link and getting his computer system operational, Peterffy was making more money than ever. The key to it all was a dependable flow of pure data that few others had. And data, as so many hot companies of today have demonstrated, can be the difference between domination of an industry and failure. Peterffy’s operation pioneered the automated compilation and employment of vast data stores on Wall Street, where the mining of such things got its start.

算法走进好莱坞

THE ALGORITHM GOES HOLLYWOOD

在安装了一套利用被黑客入侵的Quotron机器的交易系统，并雇佣了一批刚入行的漂亮女交易员后，彼得菲觉得自己打造出了完美的盈利引擎。他告诉朋友们：“任何人，都可以跟我交易赚钱。任何人。”

After installing a trading system that leveraged a hacked Quotron machine along with attractive female traders fresh to the pits, Peterffy felt he had built the perfect profit engine. “Anybody,” he told friends, “can make money trading with me. Anybody.”

华尔街人毕竟是华尔街人，许多人都对彼得菲的言论指手画脚。他的吹嘘听起来多么荒谬——竟然声称在他的体系里，任何人都可以涉足一个满是真正专家的圈子，那些人毕生都在磨练自己的直觉和交易技巧，并从他们那里赚钱。彼得菲坚持自己的立场，为了证明这一点，他请来了梅尔文·范·皮布尔斯 (Melvin Van Peebles)，他和彼得菲以前的老板贾雷基 (Jarecki) 是朋友，而且是最不可能进入交易圈的人。1971年，范·皮布尔斯在短短的十九天内，自编自导自演、制作并主演了电影《甜心背的坏蛋之歌》(Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song)。他需要比尔·考斯比 (Bill Cosby) 5万美元的贷款才能完成这部电影，但这部电影最终大获成功，票房收入达到1000万美元，也从此开启了范·皮布尔斯作为制片人、导演和演员的职业生涯。

Wall Street men being Wall Street men, many called Peterffy on his assertions. How ridiculous his bragging must have sounded—to claim that anybody in his system could wade into a pit full of veritable experts, people who had spent entire careers honing their instincts and trading prowess, and take money from them. Peterffy stood his ground, and to prove it, he brought on Melvin Van Peebles, who was friends with Peterffy’s old boss, Jarecki, and as unlikely a person as any to end up in the trading pits. In 1971, Van Peebles wrote, directed, produced, and starred in Sweet Sweetback’s Baadassssss Song in a furious nineteen days. He needed a $50,000 loan from Bill Cosby to get it done, but the film eventually became a hit, grossing $10 million and launching Van Peebles’s career as a producer, director, and actor.

尽管范·皮布尔斯名声显赫，生活也早已忙碌（当时，他正忙于制作百老汇音乐剧），这位作家还是对华尔街的本质产生了浓厚的兴趣，于1982年11月加入了彼得菲旗下的Timber Hill公司，与该公司的其他交易员（均为女性）一起工作。他在Timber Hill公司待了整整一年，几乎所有人都感到惊讶，除了彼得菲和他自己。“我只是在做我一直以来做的事情——做交易，”范·皮布尔斯告诉《纽约》杂志。3

Despite his celebrity status and an already busy life (at the time, Van Peebles was busy producing Broadway musicals), the writer, intrigued by the nature of Wall Street, went to work for Peterffy’s Timber Hill alongside the firm’s other traders, all women, in November 1982. He remained on the floor for Timber Hill an entire year, surprising almost everybody except Peterffy and himself. “I’m doing just what I’ve always done—making deals,” Van Peebles told New York magazine.3

范·皮布尔斯也赚了很多钱。他解释自己的成功：“你得会算计——成交！我能。”4他说，他学过数学，曾在荷兰和空军学习天文学，但他交易中用到的任何数学运算很可能都直接来自 Peterffy 的算法，而该算法正在啃食被劫持的 Quotron 线路的原始数据。

Van Peebles also made money, a lot of it. He explained his success: “You gotta be able to calculate doo-boop-be-deeliyaboop—deal! I can do that.”4 He had learned math, he said, studying astronomy in the Netherlands and in the air force, but it’s most likely any math being done for his trades came straight out of Peterffy’s algorithm, which was gnawing on raw data from the hijacked Quotron line.

和彼得菲的其他交易员一样，范·皮布尔斯经常跑到交易大厅的一大堆电话机前，与Timber Hill总部沟通。在电话里，他匆匆写下一堆乱七八糟的字母、数字和分数——他的指令。然后，他又飞奔回一个熙熙攘攘的交易大厅，举起双手，下达新的Delta中性交易指令。范·皮布尔斯的故事凸显了纽约交易大厅里那支最不可思议的交易团队的成功，或许直到今天，他们依然在：三位金发女郎和一位备受赞誉的黑人作家、导演兼演员，他们都是机器内部算法的伪装者。

Just as with Peterffy’s other traders, Van Peebles frequently ran sorties to a large bank of phones on the trading floor to communicate with Timber Hill’s headquarters. On the phone, he scribbled down a jumble of letters, numbers, and fractions—his instructions. From there, he careened back into one of the roiling pits and put up his hands, ordering fresh delta neutral trades. Van Peebles’s story accentuated the success of the most improbable trading squad roaming the pits of New York, perhaps to this day: three blonde women and one highly acclaimed black writer, director, and actor, all of them well-disguised proxies of an algorithm that dwelled inside a machine.

iPad 的前身

THE IPAD’S FORERUNNER

彼得菲迎合交易员臭名昭著的沙文主义的策略奏效了，期权专家们继续优先考虑他的女人们的订单。但在彼得菲轻松获利六个月后，专家们开始注意到彼得菲的交易员似乎拥有不可思议的市场嗅觉。

Peterffy’s strategy to play to the pits’ infamous chauvinism paid off as the options specialists continued to take his women’s orders above most others. But after six months of his generating easy profits, the specialists began to notice the uncanny market sense that Peterffy’s traders seemed to possess.

一位专家找到彼得菲，说道：“你看，我们知道这些交易没什么用。每次交易都会让我们损失惨重。你在干什么？”

One of the specialists came to Peterffy and said, “Look, we know these trades are no good. We’re getting killed on every single one. What are you doing?”

敏锐的观察者认为彼得菲发现了什么，但他们无法确定是什么。不过，他们确信的是，他们几乎不想参与彼得菲的女同事们带来的交易——尽管他们可能喜欢这种关注。在此之前的某个时候，彼得菲被专家们指定为做市商，这让他可以优先在交易大厅处理新订单。从技术上讲，做市商需要始终保持买入价和卖出价一致，无论市场如何波动。但彼得菲一直在违反规则，就像许多做市商一样，根据算法的指示挑选他想要的交易。他从来没有保持过恒定的买入价和卖出价。

Keen observers assumed Peterffy had figured something out, but they couldn’t be sure what it was. What they were certain of, though, was that they wanted little to do with the trades Peterffy’s women were bringing to them—as much as they might have liked the attention. Sometime before this, Peterffy had been designated a market maker by the specialists, which gave him first crack at new orders in the pits. Technically, a market maker is required to keep both bids and offers up at all times, no matter where the market goes. But Peterffy had been bending the rules, as a lot of market makers did, cherry-picking the trades he wanted according to the instructions of his algorithm. At no point was he maintaining constant bids and offers.

这些专家几乎在与彼得菲的每笔交易中都被他打败，他们已经受够了，于是告诉这位匈牙利人，他必须维持最低数量的期权公开买入和卖出，否则他们将取消他的做市商资格。彼得菲尽可能谨慎地对这些要求提出异议，同时绞尽脑汁寻找一个既能保持利润流转，又能安抚那些可能让他破产的人的解决方案。

The specialists, sick of getting beaten by Peterffy on nearly every trade they did with him, told the Hungarian that he would have to maintain open bids and offers on a minimum number of options or else they would pull his market-maker status. He quibbled with the demands as much as prudence would allow, while his brain searched for a solution that would keep profits flowing and pacify those who might scuttle him.

由于彼得菲需要持续监控某些证券的买卖报价，他无法要求交易员每次接到指令后都拨打电话。保持报价始终开放意味着交易员必须坚守场内，并时刻警惕市场动向。他的交易员大多直接根据个人电脑内部的算法获取指令，他又如何能指望他们真正地进行交易而不惹上麻烦呢？

Because he was required to keep constant bids and offers up on certain securities, Peterffy couldn’t ask his traders to duck into the phone bank for every directive. Keeping quotes open at all times meant sticking to the pits and paying attention to market movements with vigilance. How could he expect his traders, who largely took their directions straight from an algorithm housed in the guts of a personal computer, to truly make markets without courting disaster?

答案就藏在他过去给交易所的一个建议里：手持电脑。彼得菲此前曾推动在整个交易大厅配备这种设备，以取代那些专家们过时的计算方法，但他提出这个建议时并没有想到具体的设备（这种设备根本不存在），也没有认真考虑交易所的教条主义作风以及谁才是真正的掌权者：也就是他之前建议被取代的那些人。

The answer was buried in one of his past suggestions to the exchange: handheld computers. Peterffy had previously pushed to outfit the whole floor with the devices to do away with the anachronistic methods of the specialists, but he had made this proposal without a specific device in mind (they didn’t exist) and without properly considering the dogmatic ways of the exchanges and who truly held power: the exact people he had suggested be displaced.

彼得菲的新计划并非为整个交易所配备手持电脑，而只是为他的交易员配备。但这种事情真的会被允许吗？彼得菲希望如此；如果他的设备能在美国证券交易所（AMEX）取得成功，他计划将他的策略——以及他的算法、电脑和交易机——带到美国最大的期权交易大厅——芝加哥期权交易所（Chicago Board Options Exchange）。

Peterffy’s new plan wasn’t to equip the entire exchange with handheld computers—just his traders. But would such things even be allowed? Peterffy hoped so; if he could succeed with his devices on the AMEX, he planned to take his game—and his algorithms, computers, and pit machines—to the Chicago Board Options Exchange, the largest options trading floor in the United States.

美国运通的理事们对彼得菲的提议并不感冒；一些会员对此感到歇斯底里。机器在场内交易！大多数反对者声称，这些机器会妨碍交易员的忙碌，甚至可能发出鲁莽的指令，如果市场对他不利，彼得菲将无力承担。

The AMEX governors weren’t crazy for Peterffy’s pitch; some members were hysterical about the matter. Machines, on the floor, trading! Most objectors claimed the machines would get in the way of the jostling traders and perhaps even issue reckless orders that Peterffy wouldn’t be able to cover if the market soured on him.

尽管遭到抗议，美国运通还是同意彼得菲的交易员将小型平板电脑带入交易大厅。彼得菲现在面临一个新问题：他没有任何平板电脑。在iPad问世30年前，其他人也没有。这些设备必须从零开始制造。

In spite of the protests, the AMEX agreed to allow Peterffy’s traders to bring small tablet computers into the pits. Peterffy now had a new problem: he had no tablet computer of any kind. Nor did anybody else, thirty years before the advent of the iPad. The devices would have to be built from scratch.

彼得菲对自己的想法还只是个模糊的概念，于是他从纽约大学请来物理学博士生，帮他用黑色塑料薄膜（Mylar）制作了一些小矩形盒子。这些盒子大约长八英寸，宽十二英寸，深两英寸。盒子里塞满了晶体管和电路板，电路板顶部是一个带有一系列金线的面板。当用户用手指按压时，这些金线会感应到，形成一个触摸屏。彼得菲随后将不同的薄塑料模板放在盒子上，用作键盘。不同类型的选项需要不同的键盘和不同的程序。每个覆盖层都类似于一个应用程序。这样，彼得菲只需制作一种盒子，然后根据用户的交易需求，为每个盒子编写相应的算法。5

With a vague idea of what he wanted, Peterffy brought in physics PhD candidates from NYU who helped him construct small rectangular boxes out of Mylar, a black plastic. The boxes measured roughly eight inches by twelve and were two inches deep. Inside were packed transistors and circuit boards that gave way to a top panel that included a series of gold wires. The wires detected when users pressed them with a finger, creating a touchscreen. Peterffy could then drop different sets of thin plastic templates on the boxes to serve as keypads. Different kinds of options required different keypads and different programs. Each overlay was similar to an app. This way, Peterffy could make just one type of box and then program each with the algorithm for what its user would be trading.5

早上市场铃声响起之前，彼得菲会拆开每台设备，从里面拔出一根细小的线束，将其插入一直收集Quotron生产线数据的电脑。手持设备会从电脑上下载最新的市场价格和数据，以便指导其交易大厅用户在哪里报价股票和期权。用户输入当前市场价格，平板电脑显示屏上的指示灯就会显示这笔交易是否值得进行。现在，当专家们联系彼得菲的经纪人询问买卖报价时，她们可以快速给出价格，因为她们知道自己的价格与彼得菲的算法一致。

In the morning before the market bell rang, Peterffy would crack open each device and pluck a small wire harness from inside, plugging it into the PC that had been collecting data from the Quotron line. From the computer, the handheld device would download the latest market prices and data, enabling it to instruct its pit-bound user on where to quote stock and options prices. Users punched in current market prices, and lights on the tablet’s display indicated whether the trade was worth making. Now when specialists called on Peterffy’s women for a bid and offer, the women could quickly give prices, knowing they were aligned with Petertffy’s algorithm.

此时，彼得菲的年收入已超过100万美元。现在他面临的问题是，这笔交易能发展到多大？在用算法征服了美国证券交易所（AMEX）之后，他开始寻找新的挑战。他自信能够主宰任何能够运用代码的市场。他将目光投向了交易量最大的芝加哥期权交易所（Chicago Board Options Exchange）。那里的理事会与他作对，拒绝允许他的手持设备进入交易大厅，声称这些设备太大，无法放入拥挤的交易大厅。彼得菲接受了这个现实，回到工作台，设计出新的、更小的、尺寸为7英寸见方的盒子，比最初的设计小了很多。面对这种可以轻松贴在交易员胸前的新盒子，芝加哥期权交易所（CBOE）直击问题的核心：交易所成员绝对不允许任何类型的计算机进入交易大厅，显然担心这些设备会给用户带来什么优势。至于投资者和市场在效率和或许更窄的价差方面能获得的利益，则完全不在考虑范围之内。

At this point, Peterffy was making more than $1 million a year. The question that faced him now was, how big could this become? Having tamed the AMEX with algorithms, he looked for new challenges. He felt confident he could dominate any market to which he could apply his code. He set his sights on the Chicago Board Options Exchange, where volumes were biggest. The governors’ board there fought him and refused to allow his handheld devices on the floor, claiming the boxes were too big and wouldn’t fit inside the crowded trading pits. Peterffy accepted this and went back to his workbench, fashioning new, smaller boxes that measured seven inches square, a big reduction on the original design. Presented with the new boxes that could be easily held tight to a trader’s chest, the CBOE cut straight to the heart of the matter: members of the exchange would tolerate absolutely no computers of any kind of the floor, clearly afraid of what kind of edge the devices might afford their users. Benefits to investors and the market in the form of efficiency and perhaps tighter spreads wasn’t a consideration.

“交易所当然会跟我作对，”彼得菲说。“他们总是跟我作对。”

“Of course the exchanges fought me,” Peterffy said. “They always fought everything.”

于是彼得菲向纽约证券交易所求助，该交易所希望通过设立期权交易大厅来巩固其在股票交易所的主导地位。纽约证券交易所通常是一个发号施令的主导者，因此急于争取彼得菲的交易量。为了进一步协助那些已经配备了场内电脑的交易员，彼得菲在场内操作员的岗位上方安装了一组灯条。这些灯条被分成一系列不同颜色的灯泡。然后，他编写了一个系统，可以使用这些彩色灯​​条向场内交易员发出新交易信号。

So Peterffy turned to the New York Stock Exchange, which wanted to bolster its position as the dominant equity exchange with an options floor. Normally a kingpin that dictated terms, the NYSE was eager to court Peterffy’s volume. To further assist his traders, who were already armed with pit computers, Peterffy constructed a set of light bars he mounted high above his clerk’s post on the floor. The bars were broken up into a series of different-colored bulbs. He then wrote a system in which he could signal new trades to the pit using the colored bars.

一切仍然依赖于他电脑的编程，这些程序最近经过彻底改造，改用C语言运行，这是一种比彼得菲之前在公司大部分代码中使用的Fortran语言更现代、更高效的编程语言。和往常一样，电脑会梳理输入的数据，寻找合适的交易机会。当电脑发现机会时，它会立即向纽约证券交易所大厅的彩色条发送一系列电脉冲，Timber Hill的交易员们会从开盘到收盘一直密切关注着这些条。不久之后，彼得菲就成为了纽约证券交易所的主要做市商之一。

Everything still relied on his computers’ programming, which had recently been overhauled and rewritten to operate in C, a more modern and efficient programming language than the Fortran that Peterffy had used for most of his shop’s code. As always, the computers combed incoming data for ripe trades. When the computer struck opportunity, it would immediately send a series of electric pulses to the colored bars on the NYSE floor, which a set of Timber Hill’s traders watched from opening bell to closing. Before long, Peterffy became one of the major market makers at the NYSE.

自1977年以3.6万美元的价格买下美国运通（AMEX）的首个席位以来，彼得菲一直将自己的主要办公室设在该交易所。随着业务进一步扩张，他需要的空间超过了美国运通所能提供的。因此，1986年，他将总部迁至世界贸易中心，那里有更大的空间来指挥多个交易所的交易员。

Since buying his original seat on the AMEX for $36,000 in 1977, Peterffy had kept his main offices at that exchange. With further expansion on his mind, he needed more room than the AMEX could give him. So in 1986 he moved his headquarters to the World Trade Center, where he had more room to command traders at multiple exchanges.

将业务转移到距离交易大厅几个街区的世贸中心，使得平板电脑更新数据变得更加困难，因为提供数据的电脑也搬走了。彼得菲对这个问题的简单解决方案无意中让人联想到华尔街的过去：当时，跑腿的人会抢在新闻传播到其他地方之前，把市场动态播报给上城区的人们。他雇佣了几个动作敏捷的员工，除了处理各种办公室事务外，他们的主要任务就是抱着更新后的手持设备从世贸中心飞奔到交易所。

Moving operations to the Trade Center, which was several blocks from the trading floors, made it harder to keep the tablets updated with fresh data, because the PCs that supplied the data had been moved as well. Peterffy’s simple solution to this problem gave an unwitting nod to Wall Street’s past, when runners used to broadcast word of what was happening on the markets to people uptown before the news could spread otherwise. He hired a couple of swift workers whose main purpose, outside of sundry office work, was to sprint from the World Trade Center to the exchanges with updated handheld devices under their arms.

“如果你曾经去过市中心，看到一个疯子拿着黑匣子在街上飞奔，”彼得菲说，“那么你就看到了我们的人。”

“If you were ever downtown and you saw some crazy guy running as fast as he could down the street with a black box,” said Peterffy, “then you saw our guys.”

最终，跑腿的人的工作被专用电话线取代。到 20 世纪 80 年代中期，这种线路开始在一些技术娴熟的贸易公司中找到用武之地。彼得菲是这条线路的负责人，他租用电话线在其贸易中心办公室和交易所分支机构之间来回传送数据，交易所的计算机会从总部获取数据并将其转储到手持设备上。即使有了这次更新，交易员仍然需要每天多次将设备从交易大厅运行到交易所的计算机上。为了省去这个步骤，彼得菲和他的工程团队在手持设备和交易所的 Timber Hill 计算机中安装了微型无线电发射器。完成这项任务后，数据现在可以毫不费力地流向交易大厅的手持设备。

The running men eventually lost their jobs to dedicated phone lines carrying data, which were beginning to find homes in some of the tech-savvy trading houses by the mid-1980s. Peterffy was at the head of the line, leasing phone lines that fired data back and forth between his Trade Center offices and his exchange outposts, where computers would consume data from headquarters and dump it into the handhelds. Even with this update, traders still had to run the devices from the pit up to the computers at the exchanges several times a day. To eliminate this step, Peterffy and his engineering team built mini radio transmitters into the handhelds as well as Timber Hill’s computers at the exchange. With that task completed, data now flowed effortlessly to the handhelds on the trading floor.

到了1986年，交易大厅已成为彼得菲交易团队的提款机。算法生成的订单源源不断地流出，资金也源源不断地流入。无线电设备让彼得菲可以自由地增加交易量，而不必担心发布的报价与算法不符。1986年，Timber Hill以100万美元的资本起步。年底，银行账户里有500万美元，回报率高达400%。这些不断积累的成功，让彼得菲开始考虑扩张。

By 1986, the pits had become cash machines for Peterffy’s trader corps. The algorithms’ orders flowed out, money flowed in. The radio-enabled devices gave Peterffy the freedom to move more volume without the fear of posting a quote that was out of line with his algorithms. Timber Hill started 1986 with $1 million in capital. It ended the year with $5 million in the bank, a 400 percent return. The successes, now piling up, allowed Peterffy to think expansion.

随着科技的进步，彼得菲最精明的对手也纷纷效仿，效仿他的方法。乔·里奇的芝加哥研究与交易集团已成为芝加哥的巨头，而布莱尔·赫尔的赫尔交易公司在1985年成立后也迅速蹿升。同样位于芝加哥的奥康纳联合公司（O'Connor & Associates）也采用了与彼得菲非常相似的策略，为交易员配备期权估值的速查表，并用计算机不断在楼上处理数据，同时将新数据传送到交易大厅。奥康纳对其交易方法讳莫如深，以至于在20世纪80年代中期购买了200台Symbolics计算机时，高管们甚至将包装撕碎，以便那些翻箱倒柜的竞争对手无法确定该公司使用了何种技术。6

As technology advanced, so did Peterffy’s most adroit opponents, who copied his methods. Joe Ritchie’s Chicago Research and Trading Group had become a power in Chicago, and Blair Hull’s Hull Trading charged up the ladder quickly after being founded in 1985. O’Connor & Associates, also in Chicago, was employing very similar tactics to Peterffy’s, outfitting its traders with cheat sheets for valuing options and supplementing that information with computers that constantly crunched data upstairs while piping new numbers down to the pits. O’Connor was so secretive about its methods that when it bought two hundred Symbolics computers in the mid-1980s, executives shredded the packaging so Dumpster-diving competitors couldn’t determine what technology the firm used.6

算法传播到全国各地

THE ALGORITHMS SPREAD COAST TO COAST

到 1987 年，追踪标准普尔 500 等股票组合的指数基金不仅在公众中越来越受欢迎，而且在专业交易员中也越来越受欢迎。但某些指数，包括标准普尔 500 指数，只能在一个市场获得交易许可。就标准普尔 500 指数而言，许可证属于芝加哥商品交易所。因此，其他交易所采用的指数并不完全相同，但很接近。芝加哥期权交易所交易的 OEX 与标准普尔 100 指数相同；纽约证券交易所交易的纽约证券交易所综合指数跟踪整个纽约证券交易所；美国证券交易所交易的主要市场指数跟踪 30 只最大的股票；太平洋交易所则拥有所谓的 PSE，该指数以科技公司为基础，市场份额不断增长。

By 1987, index funds, which tracked groups of stocks such as the S&P 500, had grown popular not only with the public but also with professional traders. But certain indexes, the S&P 500 included, could only be licensed for trade in one market. In the case of the S&P 500, the license belonged to the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. So other exchanges employed indexes that were not exactly the same, but close. The Chicago Board Options Exchange traded the OEX, which was the same as the S&P 100; the New York Stock Exchange traded the NYSE composite, which tracked the entire NYSE; the AMEX traded the Major Market Index, which tracked the thirty biggest stocks; and the Pacific Exchange had what it called the PSE, which was based on technology companies, a growing share of the market.

所有这些指数都包含不同的内容，但其核心持股却相似。标准普尔500指数虽然只包含500家公司，但却占据了纽约证券交易所指数90%的权重，而纽约证券交易所指数则包含了所有在纽约证券交易所上市的公司。由于纽约证券交易所最大的500只股票的市值远超其他股票，因此纽约证券交易所指数基本上跟踪标准普尔500指数，反之亦然。标准普尔100指数、主要市场指数以及其他指数也是如此。

All of these indexes contained different things, but their core holdings were similar. The S&P 500 index, although only five hundred companies, comprised 90 percent of the weight of the NYSE index, which contained every company traded on the Big Board. Because the five hundred largest stocks on the Big Board were so disproportionately larger than the rest of the market, the NYSE index basically tracked the S&P 500 index and vice versa. The same could be said for the S&P 100, the Major Market Index, and the rest.

彼得菲推断，如果这些指数的走势大体相同，那么它们的波动率也就相同，其期权和期货的价格也应该相同。然而，实际上，这些工具的价格在不同交易所之间可能存在很大差异。一份纽约证券交易所 (NYSE) 指数的 11 月看涨期权在纽约的交易价格可能为 2 美元，而一份类似的看涨期权在芝加哥的 OEX 指数上的交易价格可能为 3 美元，而另一份看涨期权在旧金山的太平洋交易所的交易价格则为 2.25 美元。“因此，至少对我们来说，人们应该做什么是相当明显的，”彼得菲说。这就像小孩子的游戏：卖出昂贵的指数衍生品，买入便宜的。“这是一件很棒的事情，”他满怀深情地回忆道。

If the indexes more or less followed the same path, Peterffy reasoned, then their volatilities were the same and so should be the price of their options and futures. In reality, however, the prices of these instruments could vary greatly from exchange to exchange. A November call option on the NYSE index might be trading for $2 in New York, while a similar call might be trading for $3 on the OEX index in Chicago, and a third one for $2.25 on the Pacific Exchange in San Francisco. “So it was fairly obvious, at least to us, what people should be doing,” Peterffy said. This was child’s play: sell the expensive index derivatives and buy the cheap ones. “It was a wonderful thing,” he recalls fondly.

为了充分利用这些便捷的交易，彼得菲需要在旧金山、芝加哥两家交易所以及纽约两家交易所的场内人员。他和他的团队为即将在美国其他交易大厅建立Timber Hill滩头阵地的交易员们制造了新的手持设备。彼得菲购买了数十台新电脑，并租用了可随时传输数据的跨国电话线，使他的计算机网络能够保持实时联系，并随时调整团队在全国范围内的报价。新交易所还安装了无线电发射器，使彼得菲的芝加哥场内交易员能够获得与旧金山和纽约相同的信息。现在，纽约的卖出可以立即用芝加哥的买入进行对冲。

To take advantage of all these easy trades, Peterffy needed people on the floor in San Francisco, the two Chicago exchanges, and the two New York exchanges. He and his team of tinkerers manufactured new sets of handheld devices for the waves of trading recruits who would establish Timber Hill beachheads on the country’s other trading floors. Peterffy bought dozens of new computers and leased cross-country phone lines that would stay open for data at all times, allowing his computer network to maintain real-time contact and adjust his team’s prices on the fly across the entire country. Radio transmitters were fitted and installed at the new exchanges, giving Peterffy’s Chicago pit traders the same information available to those in San Francisco and New York. Now a sale in New York could be instantly hedged with buys in Chicago.

当衍生品的价格收敛到预期范围时，彼得菲的电脑就会指示交易员平仓多头和空头仓位，锁定利润。由于指数衍生品在所有市场交易量都很大，每天都有数百甚至数千个套利机会。很少有交易员像彼得菲那样利用技术。一些交易公司在纽约和芝加哥之间保持着畅通的电话线路，以便工作人员可以来回叫价，并抓住巨大的价格差异。彼得菲的自动化系统不仅能让交易员获得巨大的错误定价，还能获得较小的错误定价——而且他们几乎总是能先于其他人发现。彼得菲创建了第一个横跨美国东西海岸的算法交易系统。

When the values of the derivatives converged back to their expected ranges, Peterffy’s computers would tell his traders to dump both the long and the short positions, locking in profits. Because the index derivatives were heavily traded in all markets, there were hundreds—if not thousands—of arbitrage opportunities every day. Few, if any, traders were taking advantage of technology the way Peterffy did. Some trading houses kept open phone lines between New York and Chicago so that clerks could bark prices back and forth and pounce on large pricing discrepancies. Peterffy’s automated system allowed his traders to harvest not only large mispricings but also smaller ones—and they almost always got to them before others. Peterffy had created the first algorithmic trading operation working from coast to coast.

所有手持设备的交易活动都通过无线电传送到彼得菲在每个交易所安装的等候终端。那里的计算机随后会通过租用的电话线将数据直接传送到世界贸易中心的 Timber Hill 办公室，在那里，数据会被一个叫做“相关器”的大型主算法接收，该算法运行大量代码来剖析市场并找出其弱点，同时派遣每个城市的 Timber Hill 交易员对其进行打击。相关器分析十几个股票和衍生品市场的实时价格，并发出几乎保证轻松获利的交易。当已完成的交易通过数据线传来时，相关器会吞下 Timber Hill 的头寸并吐出交易来对冲它们。有些相关器的交易是 100% 自动化的——它们被直接传送到彼得菲被黑的纳斯达克终端，该终端会自动敲击键盘。

All trading activity from the handhelds was radioed to waiting terminals Peterffy had installed at each exchange. The computers there would then wire the data across the leased phone lines straight to Timber Hill’s offices in the World Trade Center, where it would be received by a large master algorithm called simply the Correlator, which ran phalanxes of code to dissect markets and pinpoint their weaknesses, while dispatching Timber Hill traders in each city to hammer them. The Correlator analyzed real-time prices across a dozen equity and derivative markets and issued salvos of trades almost guaranteed to generate easy profit. As completed trades came in through the data lines, the Correlator swallowed Timber Hill’s positions and spit out trades to hedge them. Some of the Correlator’s trades were 100 percent automated—they were shipped directly over to Peterffy’s hacked Nasdaq terminal, which rapped the keyboard automatically.

一笔交易始于 Correlator，最终通过 Peterffy 收买的纳斯达克终端自动执行，这构成了算法接管的第二阶段。在这一阶段，算法梳理数据，解读市场，并发出不再由人类执行、而是由另一台机器执行的订单。Peterffy 最终帮助打造了这样一个华尔街：其最重要的信息传递不再由人类，而是在机器之间进行。这种二级接管蔓延到整个美国市场体系还需要十多年的时间，但这一切都始于 Peterffy 和纳斯达克。在 Peterffy 耍了个花招之后，只剩下第三阶段——算法独立于其人类主人进行调整，在某些情况下甚至编写自己的算法——来完成彻底的机器人接管。

A trade that began with the Correlator and ended with an automated execution through Peterffy’s co-opted Nasdaq terminal constitutes phase two of algorithmic takeover. Here algorithms comb the data, read the market, and issue an order that is no longer carried out by humans but by another machine. What Peterffy ultimately helped create was a Wall Street whose most important communications travel back and forth between machines, not humans. It would be more than a decade before this second-degree takeover spread across the entire U.S. market system, but it all started with Peterffy and the Nasdaq. After Peterffy’s trick here, there remained only phase three—wherein algorithms adjust independently of their human masters, and in some cases write algorithms of their own—to complete a total bot takeover.

彼得菲经常坐在世贸中心的办公室里，看着交易员的工作成果涌入相关器。屏幕上列出了已完成的交易以及这些交易应如何对冲，并将信息发送给相关市场的 Timber Hill 人员。对冲交易一旦完成，也会发布在相关器的屏幕上。彼得菲从来都不是赌徒。他的策略是进行轻松的押注，确保盈利，尽管有时利润不高，同时尽可能将亏损控制在接近于零的水平。当相关器的屏幕上出现大额交易时，彼得菲会全神贯注地盯着那些单色像素，等待交易员对冲赌注。但即使是强大的相关器也有其弱点——所有无人监督的算法都有其弱点。

Peterffy often sat in his World Trade Center office watching his traders’ work pour into the Correlator. The screen listed completed trades and how those trades should be hedged, sending word to Timber Hill’s people in the relevant markets. Once the hedging trades had been made, they too would be posted on the Correlator’s screen. Peterffy had never been a gambler. His game was to make easy bets where profit, albeit sometimes small, was assured, while keeping the downside as close to zero as possible. When large trades popped up on the Correlator’s screen, Peterffy would focus intently on the monochrome pixels, watching for his traders to hedge the bet. But even the mighty Correlator had its weaknesses—as do all algorithms left on their own with no human supervision.

1987年初的一个早晨，彼得菲看着交易纷至沓来，突然注意到了一条“鲸鱼”。他的一位交易员卖出了10万份纽约证券交易所指数看跌期权，这意味着交易员有权在未来以约定的价格卖出10万股该指数的股票。如果该指数崩盘——就像当年晚些时候最终发生的那样——那么这样的仓位对Timber Hill来说将是毁灭性的打击。看到这笔交易，彼得菲皱起了眉头，心想究竟是谁会做出如此大规模的看跌投机。和往常一样，他的思绪又回到了那笔灾难性的杜邦交易。他没能通过押注相反方向来对冲杜邦的损失，这才是导致这笔交易如此惨重的原因。但现在，Timber Hill已经对冲了所有风险。

One morning in early 1987, as Peterffy watched trades stream in, he noticed a whale. One of his traders sold 100,000 NYSE index puts, giving somebody in the crowd the right to sell 100,000 shares of the index at a guaranteed price in the future. If the index were to crash, as it would eventually do later in the year, such a position could be ruinous for Timber Hill. Seeing the trade, Peterffy’s brow arched as he wondered who would be making such a large and bearish speculation. His mind, as it often did, wandered back to his disastrous DuPont trade. He had failed to hedge his DuPont play with a bet on the opposite side, which was why it had proved so calamitous. But now Timber Hill hedged everything.

彼得菲坐在椅子上，等待着他知道即将发生的事情：对冲交易。正如预期的那样，计算机调查了市场，确定了最便宜的规避交易风险的方式，并发出了相应的指令。由于卖出看跌期权是看涨交易，相关器命令交易员在其他交易所买入类似、更便宜的看跌期权，同时卖出与纽交所空头头寸类似的指数。他的系统完全按照他设定的程序运行。对冲交易确认后，彼得菲轻松地坐回椅子上。

Peterffy sat up in his chair and waited for what he knew was coming: the hedging trades. Just like it was supposed to do, the computer surveyed the markets and determined the cheapest way to shed the trade’s risk and dispatched orders to do so. Because selling the puts was a bullish trade, the Correlator ordered traders to buy similar, cheaper puts on other exchanges as well as selling indexes similar to the NYSE short. His system worked exactly as he had programmed it. Peterffy eased back into his chair as the hedged trades were confirmed.

但两分钟后，那笔大额交易又出现了：一位交易员卖出了10万份纽交所指数看跌期权。杜邦的幽灵现在正萦绕在彼得菲的脑海里。他转身拿起电话，拨通了纽交所交易员的办公桌。

But then two minutes later the large trade popped up again: a trader sold 100,000 NYSE index puts. Ghosts of DuPont were poking Peterffy now. He whirled and picked up the phone, dialing his traders’ desk at the NYSE.

“你要把这些看跌期权卖给谁？”彼得菲问。

“Who are you selling these puts to?” Peterffy said.

“什么看跌期权？”对方回答道。Timber Hill 在纽约证券交易所有六名交易员，所以接电话的交易员不知道这笔交易完全可以理解。彼得菲解释了这笔交易。“去查查是谁做的，”他说着挂断了电话。

“What puts?” came the response. Timber Hill had six traders on the NYSE floor, so it was perfectly understandable that the trader who answered the phone didn’t know about the sale. Peterffy explained the trade. “Go find out who is doing this,” he said, hanging up.

彼得菲这才心烦意乱地坐了下来。他看着相关器不断发出对冲指令，他的交易员也按时执行。然后，他感到一阵恶心。相关器屏幕上第三次显示：“已售：10万份纽约证券交易所指数看跌期权。”

Now ruffled, Peterffy sat back down. He watched the Correlator mete out more hedging moves, which his traders duly carried out. Then his stomach turned. For the third time, the Correlator screen read, SOLD: 100,000 NYSE INDEX PUTS.

“这是什么鬼？！”彼得菲大喊。他赶紧跑回电话机，拨通了纽交所的交易大厅。一位交易员接了电话。

“What is this shit?!” Peterffy yelled. He scrambled back to the phone and dialed the NYSE floor. A trader picked up.

“到底发生了什么事——是谁在卖出这些看跌期权？”彼得菲说。

“What the hell is going on—who is selling these puts?” Peterffy said.

“我什么都不知道！”交易员回答道。

“I don’t know anything!” the trader responded.

彼得菲大喊道：“把所有的绳子都拔出来，全部拔出来！”

Peterffy yelled, “Pull out all of the cords, just pull them out!”

交易员立即转身，拔掉了交易所电脑的所有电源和数据线，关闭了Timber Hill在纽约证券交易所的运营。Timber Hill在纽约证券交易所剩下的交易员们的手持设备没有收到任何信息，一头雾水地走回了办公室。

The trader immediately turned around and pulled out all of the power and data cords going into the exchange computers, shutting down Timber Hill’s operations on the NYSE. Their handhelds not receiving any information, Timber Hill’s remaining NYSE traders, confused, wandered back to the office.

彼得菲冲出世贸中心，冲进纽约证券交易所。他爬上位于华尔街11号、新古典主义风格的纽约证券交易所总部的楼梯，猛地推开Timber Hill小办公室的门。他询问了所有交易员。“怎么没人知道这些交易是从哪里来的？”他问道。

Peterffy rushed out of the World Trade Center and into the New York Stock Exchange. Scaling the stairs at the neoclassical NYSE headquarters at 11 Wall Street, he swung open the door to Timber Hill’s small office. He interrogated all of his traders. “How is it that nobody has any idea where these trades came from?” he asked.

彼得菲思绪万千，决定清点一下大楼里他所有的手持设备。每位交易员迅速拿出自己的平板电脑。它们都安然无恙，名存实亡。但彼得菲突然想起办公室里还有一台备用设备，以防万一坏掉——这种情况经常发生。彼得菲很快就发现了一个放在门口桌子上的小长方形设备。就在他去拿的时候，一位之前去洗手间的交易员回到了办公室。他打开办公室门，听到一阵明显的气流。彼得菲看着那台设备，空气吹过它的塑料外壳，发出阵阵沙沙声。

His mind jumping, Peterffy decided to count all of his handheld devices in the building. Each trader quickly produced their tablet. They were all safe and accounted for. But then Peterffy remembered there was a spare device kept in the office in case another broke, something that happened fairly often. Peterffy quickly spotted the small rectangle, which sat on a desk near the door. Just as he went to retrieve it, one of his traders, who had been in the bathroom, came back into the office. A noticeable whoosh of air accompanied him as he opened the door to the office. Peterffy looked at the device, whose plastic overlay riffled as the air passed over it.

办公室的门关上了，空气变得静止。然而就在这时，办公室门被办公室外的气流推开，再次猛烈地冲击着平板电脑，触摸屏盖板发出刺耳的嘎吱声。

The door to the office closed and the air grew still. But then the door, forced by the air outside the office, cracked open again, sending another burst of air across the tablet, making its touchscreen overlay crinkle out loud.

“打开电脑，”彼得菲现在很感兴趣，对他的一位交易员说。

“Turn on the computer,” Peterffy, now intrigued, said to one of his traders.

门再次被推开，电脑此时已启动并开始记录平板电脑的输入，显示一笔10万份纽约证券交易所指数看跌期权的成交。从门缝吹出的一股小风对设备表面施加了足够的力量，使其记录的成交量如同有人用指尖输入一样。由于办公室的门不断被从交易大厅涌入走廊的气流撞开，订单不断涌入。交易员不仅要输入订单，还要进行后续确认，才能将交易记录合法化。当平板电脑闪烁提示确认时，气流轻触平板电脑上的“是”按钮，相关器便会收到交易通知。

The door cracked again, and the computer, now on and registering the tablet’s entries, showed a sale for 100,000 NYSE index puts. The small blast of air from the door applied enough force to the device’s face that it registered sales as if somebody were entering them with their fingertips. The order kept coming through because the office door was being continuously bumped open by air rushing in from the trading floor to the hallway. For a trade to be registered as legitimate, a trader had to not only enter it but also follow up with a confirmation. When the tablet blinked for the confirmation, the air feathered the yes button on the tablet and the Correlator was notified of the trade.

这些大额交易从未发生过。但相关器按照其设计运作，并不知道这一点。它下达的所有对冲交易都根本不是对冲。它们都是纯粹的直接交易。当天市场收盘时，Timber Hill 持有价值超过 300 万美元的裸方向性押注。彼得菲刚刚变成了他一直努力避免的那种人——一个高风险的赌博牛仔。他必须等到第二天早上才能平仓；他只能祈祷市场在开盘前不要对他不利。

None of these big trades had ever happened. But the Correlator, working as it was designed, didn’t know that. All of the hedging trades it ordered up weren’t hedging at all. They were straight trades, pure and simple. When the market closed that day, Timber Hill was sitting on more than $3 million worth of naked directional bets. Peterffy had just become what he worked so hard to avoid—a high-stakes betting cowboy. He would have to wait until the next morning to unwind his positions; he simply had to hope the market didn’t move against him before the opening.

那天晚上，彼得菲睡不着觉，他整晚都盯着天花板，直到最后该回办公室了。

That night, Peterffy couldn’t sleep. He stared at the ceiling all night long until it was finally time to go back to the office.

幸运的是，市场波动不大，Timber Hill 得以平仓，几乎没有造成任何损失。如果这发生在1987年晚些时候——10月19日的“黑色星期一”——这些错误的大赌注可能会终结彼得菲的职业生涯。

Luckily, the market hadn’t moved much and Timber Hill was able to dump its positions with little bloodshed. Had this been a later day in 1987—October 19’s Black Monday—these erroneous big bets could have ended Peterffy’s career.

一名黑客在华尔街升至皇室成员

A HACKER RISES TO ROYALTY ON WALL STREET

1988年，彼得菲赚了5000万美元，这对他来说是一笔惊人的财富，也标志着他迈入了人生巅峰。凭借着他领先的优势——当时很少有人知道他在做什么——他一路领先，并凭借不断超越人类对手的机器人继续主宰股票和期权市场。然而，到了某个时候，华尔街的其他公司开始迎头赶上——量化热潮席卷了曼哈顿下城，并开始吸引科学家和工程师投身金融行业。

In 1988, Peterffy made $50 million, an astonishing amount of money to him and a sum that marked his arrival to the big time. From his lead vantage point—few people knew what he was up to—he sprinted out ahead of the pack and continued to dominate stock and options markets with bots that consistently outdueled their human adversaries. At some point, however, the rest of Wall Street began to catch up—and that’s when quant mania took hold of lower Manhattan and began to beckon scientists and engineers to careers in finance.

1999年，高盛出价9亿美元收购彼得菲的业务，而他当时的期望是30亿美元。高盛最终以5亿美元的价格收购了布莱尔·赫尔在芝加哥的自动交易业务。赫尔的自动交易业务规模远小于彼得菲，但赫尔在彼得菲引领这一潮流六年多后，于20世纪90年代初开始在辛辛那提证券交易所使用机器人进行交易，这引起了轰动。

In 1999, Goldman Sachs offered Peterffy $900 million for his business. He wanted $3 billion. Goldman instead bought Blair Hull’s automated trading operation in Chicago for $500 million. Hull’s shop was far smaller than Peterffy’s, but Hull had made waves when, more than six years after Peterffy started the trend, he began using bots to trade on the Cincinnati Stock Exchange in the early 1990s.

投资银行和华尔街的蓝筹股玩家开始追赶彼得菲和其他多年来一直胜过人类交易员的程序员只是时间问题。这些金融巨头们雇佣了自己的黑客和工程师，并尽快进入这个领域。赫尔将公司出售给高盛，从而退出了这场游戏，后来在伊利诺伊州的美国参议院初选中输给了巴拉克·奥巴马。其他算法先驱甚至更早地离开了。1992年，电脑机箱粉碎机制造商奥康纳联合公司（O'Connor & Associates）被出售给瑞士银行，乔·里奇的芝加哥研究与交易集团（Chicago Research and Trading Group）被出售给国家银行（NationsBank），后者在一年后成为美国银行。最初的算法交易员彼得菲留下来与这些自封的宇宙主宰者对抗。这位匈牙利人最终将自己的公司更名为盈透证券（Interactive Brokers），并将公司总部迁至康涅狄格州格林威治。这家公司在20世纪90年代继续引领华尔街，至今仍是如此。

It was only a matter of time before the investment banks and Wall Street’s blue-chip players started to catch up with Peterffy and the other programmers who had been getting the better of human traders for years. The monsters of finance hired their own hackers and engineers and moved into the space as quickly as they could. Hull ducked out of the game when he sold to Goldman, later losing a U.S. Senate primary race to Barack Obama in Illinois. Other algorithmic pioneers left even earlier. O’Connor & Associates, the shredder of computer boxes, sold to Swiss Bank in 1992, and Joe Ritchie’s Chicago Research and Trading Group sold out to NationsBank, which would later become Bank of America, a year later. Peterffy, the original algorithmic trader, remained to face off against the self-appointed masters of the universe. The Hungarian’s operation, which he eventually renamed Interactive Brokers while moving the company’s headquarters to Greenwich, Connecticut, continued to pace Wall Street in the 1990s, as it does to this day.

部分原因在于，彼得菲坚称，他的公司过去和现在都由工程师和程序员组成。高盛等华尔街巨头都在寻找工程人才来充实量化部门，但在盈透证券，工程师就是公司本身——这使得彼得菲的公司类似于华尔街版的谷歌，工程师负责产品开发和重大决策。事实上，盈透证券致力于确保其75%的员工都是程序员和工程师。“大多数华尔街公司专注于自己最擅长的领域，”彼得菲说，“这意味着他们销售产品。但我们编写代码。这就是我们的工作。”

Part of the reason for this was that Peterffy’s organization was, and will remain, he asserts, one of engineers and programmers. Goldman and the others on Wall Street seek out engineering talent to stock their quant departments, but at Interactive Brokers, the engineers are the company—making Peterffy’s firm something akin to Wall Street’s version of Google, a place where engineers make the product and the big decisions. Interactive Brokers, in fact, works to ensure that 75 percent of its employees are programmers and engineers. “Most Wall Street firms concentrate on what they do best,” Peterffy says. “And that means they sell. But we write code. That’s what we do.”

彼得菲指出，盈透证券公司（Interactive Brokers）没有一个员工拥有商学学位，这使得该公司在同行中显得格格不入。彼得菲坚称，他的公司永远不会有MBA学位。

Nobody at Interactive Brokers has a business degree, Peterffy points out, making the firm flagrantly out of place among its peers. Peterffy insists he won’t have an MBA at his company—ever.

从20世纪90年代到21世纪初，盈透证券不断发展壮大，将其算法引入欧洲市场，同时在美国市场也不断扩大市场份额。2007年5月4日，星期五，彼得菲为所有公司（无论科技还是金融）梦寐以求的一天做准备。这一天是盈透证券的IPO日。他穿着一套带有精致格纹的米色西装，搭配熨烫过的白衬衫，系着一条蓝得几乎泛紫的领带。他早早来到办公室，啜饮着绿茶，透过办公室角落的窗户，凝视着格林威治熙熙攘攘的车流。

During the 1990s and into the 2000s, Interactive Brokers expanded, bringing its algorithms to European markets as he continued gaining more share in the United States. On Friday, May 4, 2007, Peterffy prepared for a day that all companies, tech and finance alike, dream of having. It was IPO day for Interactive Brokers. He wore a beige suit with a subtle check pattern paired with a pressed white shirt and a tie so blue it nearly looked purple. He arrived at work early, sipped green tea, and peered out the corner windows of his office at the bubbling traffic of Greenwich.

早上7点30分，盈透证券公司（Interactive Brokers）已是人头攒动。彼得菲走出办公室，迎接来访者。9点29分，几十个人齐聚一堂，彼得菲站在他们中间。时钟敲响9点30分时，他举起双手，鼓掌、呐喊，然后迅速将手放在一个巨大的橙色按钮上，掌声在他周围响起。20年前，纳斯达克曾试图拆除他那套依靠拼接电线、窃取数据线和自定义代码维持的自动交易系统，如今彼得菲敲响了纳斯达克的开市钟。当时，他的公司市值达到了120亿美元。

By 7:30 a.m., Interactive Brokers was humming. Peterffy headed out of his office and greeted visitors. At 9:29 a.m., several dozen people all grouped into one place, Peterffy at their center. As the clock hit 9:30, he raised his hands, clapped, yelled, and brought his hand quickly down on a large orange button as applause erupted all around him. Twenty years after the Nasdaq had tried to dismantle his automated trading operation that subsisted on spliced wires, hacked data lines, and custom-written code, Peterffy rang the Nasdaq’s opening bell. The market valued his company at $12 billion.

彼得菲保留了盈透证券85%的所有权，并在此次IPO中仅出售了10%的股份。即便如此，这笔交易还是直接为他带来了11.8亿美元的收益，成为当年美国第二大IPO。对于一位没有完整工程学位、在20世纪60年代决定通过阅读计算机手册学习编程的匈牙利移民来说，这算是一个不错的结果。

Peterffy retained an 85 percent ownership share of Interactive Brokers and only put 10 percent of its stock up for sale in the offering. Even so, the deal put $1.18 billion directly into his pocket and was the second-largest IPO in the United States that year. Not a bad outcome for a Hungarian immigrant who, lacking a full engineering degree, decided to pick up programming by reading computer manuals in the 1960s.

未知的金融前沿

THE UNKNOWN FINANCIAL FRONTIER

随着新代码和更新更快的硬件涌入华尔街，交易速度和交易量持续攀升。随着20世纪90年代末至21世纪初华尔街的“军备竞赛”不断展开，一些方法和人才开始渗透到其他领域。华尔街或许抄袭了一些科技成果，但没有哪个行业在开发极其复杂的算法和自动化机器人方面如此精益求精。

The speed and volume of trading continue to tick up on Wall Street as fresh code and newer and faster hardware flood the game. As the arms race played out on Wall Street in the late 1990s and into the 2000s, some of its methods and talents began to leak into other fields. Wall Street may have cribbed some of the science, but no other industry has so perfected the development of endlessly complex algorithms and automated bots.

在如今的股市中，人类在很大程度上沦为感兴趣的观察者。如今，算法掌控着市场。道琼斯和彭博社提供的新闻服务是专门为交易机器人撰写的。这些报道对人类来说可能难以理解，但对机器人来说却完全可以理解。新闻影响着市场，就像华尔街交易员曾经在从格林威治坐火车过来的路上浏览《巴伦周刊》一样，现在算法也会阅读报纸。它们只是阅读速度快得多。

In today’s stock market, humans have largely been reduced to interested observers. The algorithms own the market now. Dow Jones and Bloomberg offer news services that are written specifically for the trading bots. These stories would be incomprehensible to a human, but make perfect sense to a bot. The news affects the markets, and just as Wall Street traders once skimmed Barron’s on their train ride in from Greenwich, now algorithms read the paper too. They just read it a lot faster.

当机器掌控市场时，我们永远无法确切知道市场究竟会如何变化。2010 年 5 月 6 日 1 万亿美元财富的消失就是一个例子。余震还在继续。六个月后，北卡罗来纳州的一家公用事业公司 Progress Energy 的股价在几分钟内无缘无故地下跌了 90%。5 月 6 日价格剧烈波动的苹果股价在几个月后莫名其妙地下跌了 4%，市值蒸发了 160 亿美元，随后才有所反弹。宾夕法尼亚大学教授迈克尔·卡恩斯 (Michael Kearns) 曾为交易员编写算法，并研究过这个新的机器统治市场。他说，我们无法理解让算法完全掌控市场会带来什么后果。7

When machines are at the controls, we can never be sure exactly what the market will do. The disappearance of $1 trillion in wealth on May 6, 2010, is a case in point. And the aftershocks continue. Six months later, Progress Energy, a utility in North Carolina, saw its shares shed 90 percent of their value in minutes for no apparent reason. Apple shares, which rode wild price swings on May 6, inexplicably dropped 4 percent several months later, wiping out $16 billion of market cap before rebounding. Michael Kearns, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania who has written algorithms for traders and studied this new, machine-ruled market, says there’s no way to understand the implications of giving algorithms the full control that they now have.7

华尔街算法之间的竞争已经变得如此诡异，以至于从纳斯达克到纽约证券交易所，美国所有交易所40%的交易都由两家中西部公司完成，而大多数人，甚至金融界人士，都从未听说过这两家公司。其中一家是Getco，位于芝加哥；另一家是Tradebot，位于堪萨斯城。两家公司都聘请了世界一流的黑客和工程师，专注于获取通常不到每股1美分的利润。Getco和Tradebot部署了数千种算法，在市场上搜寻最微小的机会。此外，还有成千上万家其他公司，有大有小，存在的目的只有一个——利用机器人在市场上赚钱。总而言之，这意味着算法就是股票市场，因为它们现在执行着美国60%的交易；欧洲和亚洲市场紧随其后。曾经由成群结队的人类撕咬、蜂拥和咆哮所决定的比赛结果，如今则由战斗算法来决定，这些算法不断相互测试、争夺优势、伪装意图并在交易中学习。

The competition between Wall Street algorithms has become so bizarre that there are days when 40 percent of the trades on all U.S. exchanges, from the Nasdaq to the NYSE, are made by just two midwestern companies that most people, even those who work in finance, have never heard of. One of them, Getco, is located in Chicago; the other, Tradebot, is in Kansas City. Both firms employ world-class hackers and engineers who are focused on clearing profits of often less than one cent per share. Getco and Tradebot deploy thousands of algorithms to scour the markets for the tiniest of opportunities. And there are thousands of other companies, some big, some small, that exist only to do the same thing—to make money on the market with bots. All in all, this means that algorithms are the stock market, as they now carry out 60 percent of all trades in the United States; European and Asian markets aren’t far behind. What once was determined by biting, swarming, and barking hordes of men is now decided by battling algorithms that are constantly testing each other, grappling for an edge, feigning their intentions, and learning as they trade.

算法在我们的市场中发挥了诸多作用，其中最主要的是普通人能够在自家厨房的笔记本电脑屏幕上以 7 美元的价格交易股票。随着市场从每笔订单都必须经过人工操作的时代转变为由算法和托管在计算机服务器上的交易所推动的时代，交易成本大幅下降。然而，我们却被更廉价的交易员的效用所淹没，陷入了一场类似星球大战的奇特战斗，这场战斗的人力投入更少，算法的自主性更强。事情出错的速度之快令人担忧。

There’s plenty of good that has arisen from algorithms’ role in our markets—the normal man’s ability to trade stock for $7 from the laptop screen in his kitchen being chief among them. As the market shifted from one where each order had to pass through pits of humans to one that’s facilitated by algorithms and exchanges hosted on computer servers, the costs of trading have plummeted. But we’ve blown by the utility of cheaper traders to a strange Star Wars–like battle that features fewer human inputs and more algorithmic autonomy. The speed at which something can go wrong is frightening.

我们的股票市场已经变成了如此专业的战场，以至于一些算法会默默地潜伏数月，等待伏击那些存在设计缺陷、代码过时或交易模式明显的敌方算法。许多在股票市场中运作的算法都是为了模拟随机性而构建的。随机性是无法被操纵、策划或劫持的。例如，华尔街一些最重要的算法交易的股票属于普通人——这些人可能在401(k)计划或个人退休账户中持有共同基金份额。当一家共同基金公司（无论是富达、先锋还是普信）进行增持或减持交易时，这笔订单不可避免地非常大。交易一百万股股票，即使是像苹果或埃克森美孚这样交易量很大的股票，也可能对市场产生不利影响。如果其他交易者知道有一笔买入一百万股的订单正在通过管道发出，他们会竭尽所能抢先买入。这样，他们就可以将新获得的股票以更高的价格重新出售，因为他们知道自己会被卷入共同基金订单。

Our stock markets have become such specialized battlegrounds that some algorithms sit silently for months, waiting to ambush enemy algorithms that display design flaws, dated code, or a discernible pattern to their trading. Many of the algorithms plying our stock markets are built to mimic randomness. What’s random can’t be gamed, planned upon, or hijacked. For example, some of the most important algorithms on Wall Street trade stocks that belong to normal people—people who may own mutual fund shares in their 401(k) plans or IRAs. When a mutual fund company, be it Fidelity, Vanguard, or T. Rowe Price, makes a trade to add to a position or subtract from one, it’s inevitably a very large order. Trading a million shares of a stock, even a heavily traded one such as Apple or ExxonMobil, can move the market against the large seller or buyer. If other traders know that an order to buy a million shares is coming through the pipe, they will do whatever they can to get in front of it and buy up available shares. That way, they can repost their newly acquired shares for sale at a higher price knowing that they’ll get sucked into the mutual fund order.

当共同基金需要支付更高的价格购买其份额时，该基金的所有者——那些为退休储蓄的普通人——就会损失金钱。为了打击那些四处寻找大额订单进行欺诈的交易员，共同基金和其他机构交易员雇佣黑客开发算法，将大额交易拆分成多个小额交易，从而进行随机伪装。这个想法有点像隐形技术。隐形飞机的设计和外壳并非像空中一块巨大的金属块，而是在雷达上显示出数百个较小的物体，这些物体可能是云层、鸟类或其他碎屑。派遣飞机拦截跨越整个大陆的每一个鸟群是徒劳的，这就是隐形技术奏效的原因。但俄罗斯人最终开发出了一些方法，有时可以从80吨美国钢铁中辨别出真正的鸟群。同样的事情也发生在华尔街。那些最初被伪装机构大额订单的算法所击败的交易员，很快就开发出了自己复杂的、精心设计的算法，可以嗅探市场上被伪装的大额交易。

When a mutual fund has to pay more for its shares, it costs the owners of that fund—normal people saving for retirement—money. To combat traders prowling for big orders to abuse, mutual funds and other institutional traders hired hackers to develop algorithms that randomly disguise their large trades by breaking them up into smaller ones. The idea is a bit like stealth technology. Instead of appearing as a giant chunk of metal in the sky, the design and coverings on a stealth plane show radar hundreds of smaller objects, which could be cloud cover, birds, or other detritus. Dispatching sorties to intercept every bird pack across a continent is futile, which is why stealth worked. But the Russians eventually developed ways that could sometimes discern true packs of birds from eighty tons of American steel. The same thing happened on Wall Street. Traders who were at first defeated by algorithms disguising big institutional orders soon developed complex scheming algorithms of their own that could sniff the market for large trades that had been disguised.

共同基金和交易巨额股票的机构对此作出了反应，构建了更先进的伪装算法——这些机器人会发出诱饵交易，一旦怀疑被发现，就会轻易调整策略。猎手们再次以牙还牙，导致股市如今的现状：算法充当角斗士，而普通人则像罗马斗兽场时代一样，袖手旁观。这场比赛精彩纷呈，尽管它与股市的基本使命几乎没有关联：为成长型公司提供便捷的融资途径，同时让公众有机会投资于能够以有意义的方式积累财富的事物。

Mutual funds and institutions dealing in giant blocks of stock reacted by building better algorithms of disguise—bots that issued decoy trades and would easily shift strategies if they suspected detection. The hunters, again, responded in kind, leading us to the current state of the stock market wherein algorithms are the gladiators and normal people, just like in the days of the Colosseum, stand by and watch. It’s a fantastic game, although it has little to do with the base mission of the stock market: allowing growing companies an easy path to raising capital while giving the public a chance to invest in something that can build wealth in a meaningful way.

彼得菲认为事情发展得太过火了。他已经退出了公司在做市业务的参与。这位曾经掌控华尔街、如今正向其他领域进军的算法背后的最强大力量之一，如今却改变了主意。“当时我只看到了好的一面，”他说。

Peterffy thinks things have gone too far. He has already stepped back his company’s participation in making markets. The man who was one of the most powerful forces behind the algorithms that have taken over Wall Street—and are now headed everywhere else—has second thoughts. “I only saw the good sides at the time,” he says.

当然，当时彼得菲正在积累美国最大的财富之一，所以事后看来，他这么说似乎很容易。彼得菲认为，在这个光速交易的时代，股票买卖应该暂停一段最短的时间，虽然仍然远少于一秒钟，但足以消除当代市场中那些导致我们跌宕起伏、火箭般飙升的假动作、躲闪和欺骗行为。

At the time, of course, Peterffy was building up one of the largest fortunes in America, so this might seem like an easy thing for him to say in hindsight. Peterffy thinks that in this age of light-speed trading, bids and offers on stocks should be held up for a minimum amount of time, still far less than a second, but enough to eliminate the head fakes, parries, and trickery that comprise the contemporary market and that lead us to clifflike falls and rocketlike spikes.

他最担心的是，一系列失控的算法会引发一连串巨额损失，让其所有者无力弥补。由于一些高速交易算法能够进行杠杆保证金交易，因此可以想象，几秒钟内发生的一系列不良交易可能会导致流动性危机，使交易员的经纪人及其交易的客户破产。此类事件几乎发生过。2009年末，芝加哥的Infinium资本管理公司（美国最神秘、最强大的交易公司之一）两次失去对一个算法的控制，该算法开始以最快的速度抛售标准普尔500指数期货，导致市场暴跌。2010年2月，Infinium再次遭遇同样的命运，一种旨在从原油交易中攫取微薄利润的新算法在疯狂交易中摧毁了大宗商品市场，在三秒钟内损失超过100万美元。该公司因“未能认真监管其系统”而被芝加哥商品交易所罚款85万美元。芝加哥商品交易所表示，Infinium 通过发布这种有缺陷的算法“在实时交易环境中运行，实施了有损交易所福祉的行为”。8据报道，Infinium 并未按照标准对算法进行六至八周的测试，而是仅进行了两个小时的检查后就将其释放。9

His ultimate fear is that a rogue series of algorithms sparks a string of colossal losses that their owners can’t cover. Because some high-speed trading algorithms are able to trade on margin with leverage, it’s conceivable that a series of bad trades, all conducted in seconds, could lead to a liquidity crisis, bankrupting a trader’s broker and the clients he trades for. Such incidents have nearly happened before. In late 2009, Chicago’s Infinium Capital Management, one of the more secretive and powerful trading houses in the United States, twice lost control of an algorithm that began selling S&P 500 futures as fast as it could, dropping the market. It happened again to Infinium in February 2010, when a new algorithm meant to capture small profits on crude oil trades tore up the commodities market as it traded wildly, losing more than $1 million in three seconds. The firm was fined $850,000 by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange for “failing to diligently supervise its systems.” The CME said that by unleashing such a flawed algorithm “to operate in a live trading environment, Infinium committed an act detrimental to the welfare of the exchange.”8 It was reported that Infinium, rather than testing the algorithm for six to eight weeks, as was its standard, set it loose after only two hours of checks.9

这个充斥着互相争斗的算法的虚拟世界，正是华尔街和我们金钱的化身。它远不止于此。华尔街的机器人传奇为我们未来世界的走向提供了线索。

This virtual world of warring algorithms is what has become of Wall Street and our money. It doesn’t stop there. The bot saga on Wall Street offers clues to what’s in store for much of our future world.

2

2

人类与算法简史

A BRIEF HISTORY OF MAN AND ALGORITHMS

最杰出算法背后的高深数学 正在复兴。理解它的人从未如此之多，也从未如此之多的人致力于通过讨论和研究来传播他们的理解。想要亲眼见证这一切，只需前往 Y Combinator 的 Hacker News 留言板即可。1现已发展成为世界上最具影响力的网站之一。

THE HIGH MATH BEHIND THE most brilliant algorithms is currently enjoying a renaissance. There have never been more people who understand it, and there have never been more people working to spread their understanding through discussion and investigation. To see this in action, all one needs to do is head to Y Combinator’s Hacker News message board,1 which has grown into one of the more influential Web sites in the world.

这里汇聚了黑客、数学家、创业者、华尔街程序员以及那些紧跟网络潮流的人士，他们几乎无所不谈。大部分讨论都围绕着编程、初创企业和硅谷展开。但首页上总会有一两篇文章讨论高斯函数、布尔逻辑或其他数学分支，正是这些分支让这个日益以算法为中心的世界成为可能。

Here, hackers, math folk, entrepreneurs, Wall Street programmers, and people who are generally in tune with the waves of the Web come to discuss almost everything. Much of the discussion is about programming, startups, and Silicon Valley. But there’s invariably a post or two on the front page discussing Gaussian functions, Boolean logic, or some other branch of mathematics that makes this increasingly algorithm-centric world possible.

自从算法背后的数学原理被揭示以来，无论是在会计办公室还是在客服台，算法接管我们世界的可能性就一直存在。我们赞扬那些用算法和机器人征服市场、改造社会的人——但他们之所以能够做到这一点，完全是因为250年前构建的理论。

The takeover of our world by algorithms, whether in an accounting office or at a customer service desk, has been looming ever since the math enabling such things was uncovered. We praise those who conquer our markets and rework society with algorithms and bots—but they were able to do so only because of theories constructed 250 years ago.

算法从何而来？

WHERE DID ALGORITHMS COME FROM?

早在“算法”一词出现之前，人类就已设计、修改和共享算法数千年。算法并不需要研究生数学，甚至根本不需要数学知识。巴比伦人将算法应用于法律事务；古代拉丁语教师使用算法检查语法；医生长期以来依靠算法进行预后；世界各地无数的人也曾尝试使用算法来预测未来。2

Humans have been devising, altering, and sharing algorithms for thousands of years, long before the term itself ever surfaced. Algorithms needn’t involve graduate school math or even math at all. The Babylonians employed algorithms in matters of law; ancient teachers of Latin checked grammar using algorithms; doctors have long relied on algorithms to assign prognoses; and countless numbers of men from all corners of the earth have used them in an attempt to predict the future.2

算法的核心是一组指令，需要按部就班地执行才能达到理想的结果。信息输入到给定的算法中，答案就会出来。在大学一年级的编程课上，许多大学工程师设计了一种简单的算法，可以完美地玩井字游戏。3在他们的程序中，对手（或人类）玩家的走法构成输入。利用这些信息，算法会以自己的走法产生输出。一个期望在这类问题上获得 A 的学生会写出一个永远不会输的算法（但经常打成平局）。

At its core, an algorithm is a set of instructions to be carried out perfunctorily to achieve an ideal result. Information goes into a given algorithm, answers come out. In their freshman-year programming classes, many college engineers design a simple algorithm to flawlessly play the game of tic-tac-toe.3 In their program, the opposing, or human, player’s move forms the input. With that information, the algorithm produces an output in the way of its own moves. A student expecting an A on such a problem will produce an algorithm that never loses a game (but often plays to a draw).

高频交易员或语音识别程序使用的算法工作原理相同。它们被输入数据——可能是不同股票指数的走势、汇率波动和油价——并据此产生输出：比如，买入通用电气股票。算法交易无非就是依靠算法来决定何时买入、卖出什么。构建一个包含多个变量的算法比构建一个玩井字游戏的算法更难，但其理念是相同的。

The algorithms used by a high-frequency trader or a speech recognition program work the same way. They’re fed inputs—perhaps the movements of different stock indices, currency rate fluctuations, and oil prices—with which they produce an output: say, buy GE stock. Algorithmic trading is nothing more than relying on an algorithm for the answers of when and what to buy and sell. Building an algorithm with many variables is more difficult than building one to play tic-tac-toe, but the idea is identical.

“算法”一词源自阿布·阿卜杜拉·穆罕默德·伊本·穆萨·花拉子密 (Abu Abdullah Muhammad ibn Musa Al-Khwarizmi)，他是一位公元九世纪的波斯数学家，著有已知第一本代数著作《Al-Kitab al-Mukhtasar fi Hisab al-Jabr wa l-Muqabala》（《完成与平衡计算简明书》）。“代数”一词直接源于书名中的“al-Jabr”。随着中世纪学者们用拉丁语传播花拉子密的著作，他的名字“algorism”（算法）的译名开始用来描述任何系统或自动计算的方法。4

The word algorithm comes from Abu Abdullah Muhammad ibn Musa Al-Khwarizmi, a Persian mathematician from the ninth century who produced the first known book of algebra, Al-Kitab al-Mukhtasar fi Hisab al-Jabr wa l-Muqabala (The Compendious Book on Calculation by Completion and Balancing). Algebra’s name comes straight from the al-Jabr in the book’s title. As scholars disseminated Al-Khwarizmi’s work in Latin during the Middle Ages, the translation of his name—“algorism”—came to describe any method of systematic or automatic calculation.4

现代文明最早记录并随后发现的算法来自舒鲁帕克（Shuruppak），位于现代巴格达附近。苏美尔人统治了幼发拉底河谷地区长达一千五百年，他们留下了大约公元前2500年的泥板，上面描述了一种可重复的方法，用于将谷物平均分配给不同数量的人。这种方法使用了小型测量工具；由于当时的小贩没有足够大的秤来一次称量数千磅的食物，这种方法非常实用。这些以符号形式记录着这种算法的泥板，现藏于伊斯坦布尔博物馆。5

The first algorithm recorded and later found by modern civilization comes from Shuruppak, near modern Baghdad. The Sumerians, who ruled their piece of the Euphrates Valley for fifteen hundred years, left behind clay tablets dating from roughly 2500 BC that illustrate a repeatable method for equally dividing a grain harvest between a varying number of men. The method described utilized small measuring tools; it was useful because vendors of that time didn’t have scales large enough to weigh thousands of pounds of food at once. The tablets carrying this algorithm, depicted in symbols, now sit in the Istanbul Museum.5

一些几千年前开发的算法在当今的计算机世界中仍然发挥着非常重要的作用——尽管它们的创造者当时无法想象。许多网站、无线路由器以及其他必须加密密码和用户名的地方，都采用了一种由古希腊数学家欧几里得在两千多年前构思的算法。

Some algorithms developed thousands of years ago still play very real roles—albeit ones their creators couldn’t have imagined—in the computerized world of today. Many Web sites, wireless routers, and other places where passwords and user names must be encrypted employ an algorithm that was conceived more than two thousand years ago by Euclid of Alexandria, a Greek mathematician.

欧几里得算法，正如数学学者经常提到的那样，在数十个现代行业中应用，可用于推导出大多数（如果不是全部）现代音乐的节奏模式。6大约公元前300年，欧几里得写下了《几何原本》，这部著作成为了此后两千三百年几何教材的支柱。在《几何原本》中，欧几里得提出了一个算法，可以求两个不同数的最大除数。任何具有五年级数学水平的人都能用它快速确定17是1785和374的最大公约数。7

The Euclidean algorithm, as it’s often referred to by math scholars, dots programming within dozens of modern industries and can be used to derive most, if not all, of modern music’s rhythm patterns.6 Around 300 BC, Euclid wrote his Elements, a work that would form the backbone of geometry texts for the next twenty-three hundred years. In Elements, Euclid included an algorithm that finds the largest divisor of two different numbers. Anybody with fifth-grade math skills can use it to quickly determine that 17 is the largest common divisor of 1,785 and 374.7

中庸之道

THE GOLDEN MEAN

从事生物学、植物学、天文学甚至建筑学的人们都应该熟悉欧洲在十二世纪首次采用现代数字和十进制时发展起来的一个概念。8数学家们开始研究 1.618 这个奇特的比例——被称为黄金分割率——这个数字经常出现在自然界中，例如蕨类植物的分形几何、DNA 的原子结构和星系的轨道模式。9对比例和尺度感敏锐的建筑师也会被这个比例所吸引。看起来“恰到好处”的伟大建筑，其间距和图案通常都基于1.618的比例。20世纪颇具影响力的瑞士裔法国建筑师勒·柯布西耶，在他的许多建筑中都明确地运用了这一比例，例如自1929年起在巴黎附近加尔什设计的斯坦别墅。近年来，平面设计师也在苹果的许多产品中，包括其标志中，都体现了这一比例。10

People who work in biology, botany, astronomy, and even architecture should all be familiar with a concept developed when Europe was first adopting modern numerals and the decimal system in the twelfth century.8 Mathematicians in particular began toying with the curious ratio of 1.618—known as the golden mean—a number often exhibited in nature, such as in the fractal geometry of ferns, the atomic structure of DNA, and the orbital patterns of galaxies.9 Architects with keen senses of proportion and scale gravitate toward the ratio as well. Great buildings that look “right” often have spacings and patterns based on a ratio of 1.618. Le Corbusier, the influential twentieth-century Swiss-French architect, explicitly used the ratio in many of his buildings, such as Villa Stein in Garches near Paris, beginning in 1929. More recently, graphic designers have spotted the ratio in many of Apple’s products, including its logo.10

黄金分割理论的提出者列奥纳多·斐波那契，对欧洲采用现代数字做出了重要贡献，并被许多历史学家视为中世纪最重要的数学家。在意大利中部兴起类似于现代银行业的金融体系之前，比萨的列奥纳多曾在地中海盆地乃至东方广泛游历；他的父亲是一位比萨海关官员，驻扎在如今的阿尔及利亚贝贾亚。11斐波那契，大多数人都这么称呼他，他看到了阿拉伯-印度数字系统与笨重的罗马数字相比的实用性，尤其是在数学计算方面。

Leonardo Fibonacci, the man behind the golden mean, was most responsible for Europe’s adoption of modern numbers and is considered by many historians to be the most important mathematician of the Middle Ages. Before the rise in central Italy of what would come to resemble modern banking, Leonardo of Pisa traveled widely within the Mediterranean basin and even to the Orient; his father was a Pisan customs official based in what is now Bejaïa, Algeria.11 Fibonacci, as he’s known to most, saw the utility of Arabic-Indian numbering systems compared with clunky Roman numerals, especially when it came to mathematical computations.

斐波那契于1202年出版了《算盘之书》（ Liber Abaci）。在书中，这位年轻的数学奇才解释了小数与分数的关系，以及如何运用它们简化记账并解决实际问题。斐波那契解答了当时常见的难题；在他的例子中，他列举了辣椒、兽皮和奶酪等主食的分割方法。斐波那契引用了花剌子米的著作，为西方文明提供了一系列算法，这些算法在几个世纪中被广泛使用，例如用于计算未来资金流现值的算法，以及类似于我们现代抵押贷款的利息支付系统。12

Fibonacci published Liber Abaci (The Book of Calculation) in 1202. Within the book, the young math whiz explained how decimals relate to fractions and how they can be wielded to make bookkeeping simple and solve real-life problems. Fibonacci dispatched conundrums common for the time; in his examples, he includes methods for dividing staples such as peppers, animal skins, and cheese. While citing Al-Khwarizmi, Fibonacci provided Western civilization with a series of algorithms that would be heavily used for centuries, such as those for calculating the present value of future money streams and for interest payment systems that resemble our modern mortgages.12

尽管大多数古代数学家的贡献都被尘封在尘封的历史巨著中，斐波那契的名字却在华尔街和流行文化中蜚声遐迩。小说家丹·布朗在《达芬奇密码》中对斐波那契进行了深入研究，这本书已售出近一亿册。布朗关注的是《算盘之书》中所谓的斐波那契数列的奇妙之处，该数列中的每个数字都是其前两位数字之和：1、1、2、3、5、8、13、21、34 等等。随着数列的递增，其前两位数字与其前两位数字之比逐渐收敛至黄金分割点 1.618。

Whereas most ancient math scholars’ significance gets left to dusty history tomes, Fibonacci’s name remains well known on Wall Street as well as in popular culture. Novelist Dan Brown put a spotlight on Fibonacci in The Da Vinci Code, a book that has sold nearly one hundred million copies. Brown keyed on the curiosity of the so-called Fibonacci sequence, included in Liber Abaci, in which each number is the sum of the two digits preceding it: 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21, 34, etc. As the sequence progresses, the ratio of its numbers and their immediate predecessor converges toward the golden mean of 1.618.

在华尔街，这个数字也激发了人们对其威力的广泛信仰，一些古怪的交易员甚至投入数十亿美元，用于研究基于黄金分割或所谓斐波那契数列的算法。已有一百多本书籍出版，宣扬黄金分割的威力及其在商品、股票和外汇等各种市场中的应用。而这仅仅是过去二十年发生的事情。几乎没有证据表明这些说法属实，但华尔街本身就是一个悖论，荒谬的理论和僵化的逻辑在这里和谐共存。

On Wall Street the number has also kindled plenty of belief in its powers, as some quirky traders have ventured billions of dollars on algorithms based on the golden mean or the so-called Fibonacci numbers. More than a hundred books have been published touting the power of the golden mean and its presence within marketplaces as diverse as commodities, stocks, and foreign exchange. And that’s just in the last twenty years. There’s little evidence that any of this is true, but Wall Street is nothing if not a paradox where cockamamie theories and rigid logic happily coexist in equal abundance.

现代算法的教父

THE GODFATHER OF THE MODERN ALGORITHM

戈特弗里德·莱布尼茨与他同时代的艾萨克·牛顿一样，博学多识。他的知识和好奇心遍布欧洲大陆及其大多数有趣的学科。莱布尼茨说，哲学上有两个简单的绝对：上帝和虚无。13一切万物皆源于这两者。莱布尼茨构想出一种由且仅由两个数字定义的计算语言，这是多么恰当啊：0 和 1。

Gottfried Leibniz, like Isaac Newton, his contemporary, was a polymath. His knowledge and curiosity spanned the European continent and most of its interesting subjects. On philosophy, Leibniz said, there are two simple absolutes: God and nothingness.13 From these two, all other things come. How fitting, then, that Leibniz conceived of a calculating language defined by two and only two figures: 0 and 1.

莱布尼茨开发了这个系统，用1和0的二进制语言来表达数字和所有算术运算——加、减、乘、除。这位数学家在1703年的论文《二进制算术的解释》中定义了这种语言。

Leibniz developed this system to express numbers and all operations of arithmetic—addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division—in the binary language of 1’s and 0’s. The mathematician defined the language in his 1703 paper “Explanation of Binary Arithmetic.”

莱布尼茨于1646年出生在莱比锡，出生地如今以他的名字命名。他从小就成绩优异，15岁进入大学，20岁就获得了博士学位。他以善于交际而闻名，在70岁弥留之际，他仍与他的医生聊起了炼金术。14莱布尼茨在这个故事中的巨大影响力源于他对二进制应用范围之广的坚信。他的思考远远超越了博学的数学定理世界和牛顿式的微积分理论之争。

Leibniz was born in Leipzig in 1646 on a street that now bears his name. An overachiever from the start, he began university at fifteen and had his doctorate by the time he was twenty. Known for being gregarious, he chatted up his physician on the subject of alchemy as he lay dying in bed at the age of seventy.14 The large shadow of Leibniz in this story traces to his convictions about the breadth with which his binary system could be applied. He thought far beyond the erudite world of math theorems and the Newtonian wars of calculus theory.

莱布尼茨说，一切物理变化皆有因果。即使是人，在某种程度上，其轨迹也由作用于其上的外力所决定，而莱布尼茨时代之后很久才发展起来的博弈论正是利用了这一事实。因此，莱布尼茨认为，大多数事物的未来都可以通过考察其因果关系来预测。15这一点，许多现代华尔街巨头比任何人都更清楚。如果这个人出生得晚一些，甚至晚得多，他无疑可以在华尔街建立起一个庞大而成功的企业。

All physical changes have causes, Leibniz said. Even people, to some degree, have their paths set by the outside forces acting upon them, a fact that game theory, developed long after Leibniz’s time, exploits. Leibniz therefore believed that the future of most things could be predicted by examining their causal connections.15 This is what much of the modern Wall Street titans have realized better than anybody else. Had the man been born later, much later, he could undoubtedly have raised a large and successful Wall Street tent.

莱布尼茨比其他任何人都更早地构想出了人工智能。这位数学家认为，认知思维和逻辑可以简化为一系列二进制表达式。思维越复杂，就越需要所谓的简单概念来描述它。反过来，复杂的算法也是一系列简单算法的集合。莱布尼茨说，逻辑可以无情地归结为其骨架，就像一串简单的双向铁路道岔构成了令人眼花缭乱、错综复杂的全国铁路网。如果逻辑可以分解为一串二进制决策，即使这些序列绵延数英里，那么为什么它不能由人类以外的其他东西来执行呢？莱布尼茨将所有逻辑思维简化为机械操作的梦想始于他自己设计的一台机器。16

Before anyone else, Leibniz conceived of something reaching toward artificial intelligence. The mathematician stipulated that cognitive thought and logic could be reduced to a series of binary expressions. The more complicated the thought, the more so-called simple concepts are necessary to describe it. Complicated algorithms are, in turn, a large series of simple algorithms. Logic, Leibniz said, could be relentlessly boiled down to its skeleton, like a string of simple two-way railroad switches comprising a dizzying and complicated national rail network. If logic could be factored to a string of binary decisions, even if such sequences stretched for miles, then why couldn’t it be executed by something other than a human? Leibniz’s dream of reducing all logical thought to mechanical operations began with a machine he designed himself.16

莱布尼茨听说了布莱斯·帕斯卡（Blaise Pascal）制造的加法机后，便决心超越他。他的机器不仅能更流畅地进行加减运算，还能解决乘除运算，而帕斯卡的机器根本做不到这一点。莱布尼茨将设计图写在纸上，并于1674年聘请了一位巴黎钟表匠将机器制成。17

After hearing of an adding machine built by Blaise Pascal, Leibniz set out to best him. His machine would perform addition and subtraction more smoothly and could also solve multiplication and division problems, something Pascal’s machine couldn’t do at all. Putting the design down on paper, Leibniz hired a Paris clockmaker to make the machine reality in 1674.17

莱布尼茨跨越英吉利海峡，向当时学术权威的权威机构——伦敦皇家学会——演示了这台机器的有效性。然而，机器在演示过程中失灵了，莱布尼茨只能手动计算除法余数。18展览结束后，他似乎对这台机器失去了兴趣，但他的设计在之后的两百年里一直占据主导地位，后续的几代计算器都基于其记录在案的设计建造。这台机器本身则在历史长河中湮没了两个多世纪。莱布尼茨似乎将这个黄铜圆筒存放在哥廷根大学一栋建筑的阁楼里，一直放在一个低矮的角落里，直到1879年，一支维修队被派上楼去修补屋顶漏水时才发现了它。

Leibniz crossed the English Channel to demonstrate the machine’s efficacy to the Royal Society in London, the arbiters of the day’s intellectual prestige. But the machine failed during his demonstration and Leibniz was reduced to carrying division remainders by hand.18 He seemed to lose interest in the machine after the exhibition, but his design remained the dominant one for two hundred years, with subsequent generations of calculators built on its plan, which had been recorded. The machine itself was lost to history for more than two centuries. Leibniz apparently stored the brass cylinder in the attic of a building at the University of Göttingen, where it remained in a low-slung corner until a maintenance crew, sent upstairs to fix a roof leak, found it in 1879.

除了计算机器之外，莱布尼茨相信，通过将逻辑和思维分解为算术计算，他能找到一种推理演算器（calculus reciprocator），一种能够解决争论的算法。他设想，分歧不再需要通过一方大声呵斥另一方来解决。相反，两个对手会手拿纸笔，走到一张桌子旁，准备根据逻辑推算谁是对的。19如果美国政治能给我们任何启示的话，莱布尼茨从未找到他神圣的推理演算器。

Beyond calculating machines, Leibniz believed that by breaking logic and thought down to arithmetical calculations, he would find a calculus ratiocinator, a kind of algorithm that would resolve arguments. He imagined that disagreements wouldn’t need to be settled by one opponent shouting down the other. Instead, two adversaries would proceed to a table with pencil and paper in hand, ready to calculate who, according to logic, was right.19 If U.S. politics gives us any indication, Leibniz never found his sacred calculus ratiocinator.

莱布尼茨的晚年饱受争议。尽管如今普遍认为他和牛顿同时发现了微积分，但当时经常与牛顿通信的莱布尼茨却被指控窃取了这位英国人的发现。虽然与有史以来最多产的数学家和物理学家牛顿同台竞技可能有些艰难，但莱布尼茨的成就足以让他声名鹊起。至于微积分，是他，而不是牛顿，创立了至今仍在学习的积分和导数的优雅符号。

Controversy marred the end of Leibniz’s life. Although it’s now universally accepted that he and Newton discovered calculus in parallel, at the time, Leibniz, who often corresponded with Newton by letter, was accused of pilfering the Englishman’s discovery for himself. And while it may have been hard to share the stage with Newton, the most prolific mathematician and physicist who ever lived, Leibniz did plenty to distinguish himself. As for calculus, it was he, not Newton, who developed elegant notations for integrals and derivatives that all calculus students still learn today.

莱布尼茨发展了微积分背后的符号和理论，使得对变化进行精确研究和建模成为可能，这为数学家提供了一种武器，使他们能够创建足够强大的算法来制造半导体，通过无线电将我们连接起来，20并以激光般的精度将卫星送入轨道。微积分和算法有着交织的历史、意义和力量。数学家大卫·柏林斯基在其著作《无限上升》中很好地总结了这种关系：

Leibniz’s development of the symbols and theory behind calculus, which allows for the precise study and modeling of change, gave mathematicians a weapon with which to create algorithms powerful enough to build semiconductors, connect us through radio,20 and launch satellites into orbit with a laser’s precision. Calculus and algorithms have intertwined histories, meanings, and power. The relationship is well summed up by mathematician David Berlinski in his book Infinite Ascent:

 

 

如今，思想史上正响起一声回荡的音爆！在微积分发现之前，数学曾是一门备受关注的学科；之后，它更是一门强大的学科。只有二十世纪计算机算法的出现，才代表了一种具有同等影响力的数学思想。微积分和算法是西方科学的两大主导思想。21

There now occurs a reverberating sonic boom! in the history of thought. Before the discovery of calculus, mathematics had been a discipline of great interest; afterward, it became a discipline of great power. Only the advent of the [computer] algorithm in the twentieth century has represented a mathematical idea of comparable influence. The calculus and the algorithm are the two leading ideas of Western science.21

20世纪60年代之前，很少有人被普遍称为“黑客”或“量化分析师”。但或许，这样的称号应该延伸到这位生活在欧洲文艺复兴后期的德国人身上。莱布尼茨以三种不同的方式推动了算法科学的发展。他是微积分的奠基人之一，而且，对本次讨论同样重要的是，他提出了一种构建算法的方法，用一系列简单的二进制块来表达复杂的解。

No one who lived before the 1960s has ever been commonly referred to as a hacker, or a quant. But perhaps such a moniker should be extended to this German who lived during the latter days of Europe’s Renaissance. Leibniz moved algorithmic science forward in three distinct ways. He was one of the founding instigators of calculus, and, just as important to this discussion, he introduced the method of building algorithms to express complicated solutions out of a series of simple binary blocks.

莱布尼茨对算法力量的第三个重要贡献在于，他探寻了语言中最简单的片段与其所揭示的人类情感之间的联系。莱布尼茨认为，语言及其使用方式应该以严谨的学术方式进行研究。他认为，如果像人类存在这样复杂的东西可以分解为两个绝对值，无论是上帝与虚无，还是1与0，那么为什么语言不能被解构，从而筛选出段落、句子、从句和词语以获得更多意义呢？这位哲学家兼数学家推测，人类说出的词语和短语与其个人情感和感知相符。22
