Leibniz’s third important contribution to the power of algorithms lay in the link he sought between the simplest fragments of language and the human emotions they reveal. Leibniz thought language and how humans use it should be studied in a rigorous academic way. He figured that if something as complicated as man’s existence could be broken down into two absolutes, be they God and nothingness or 1 and 0, why couldn’t language be deconstructed in a manner in which paragraphs, sentences, clauses, and words could be sifted for more meaning? The philosopher-mathematician speculated that humans uttered words and phrases that fit their individual emotions and perceptions.22

通过了解一个人说的话，我们就能知道他们是谁。通过了解一个人，我们就能更容易地预测他们未来的行为。华尔街及其他地区所有这些由算法驱动的革命的核心，都存在一个永恒的目标：预测——更确切地说，预测其他人的行为。这就是赚钱的方式。莱布尼茨的直觉——人类被设定为以某些可预测的方式行事——比许多人所知道的更为准确，而这一事实如今驱动着华尔街的许多算法。在本书的后面，我们将看到莱布尼茨最初推测的这种人类预测科学是如何在美国宇航局（NASA）发展起来的，以及它如今是如何渗透到我们生活的其他领域的。

By knowing what a person says, we can know who they are. By knowing who somebody is, it becomes easier to predict what exactly they’ll do in the future. At the heart of all of these algorithm-enabled revolutions on Wall Street and elsewhere, there exists one persistent goal: prediction—to be more exact, prediction of what other humans will do. That’s how money gets made. Leibniz’s hunch—that individual humans are programmed to behave in certain predictable manners—was more accurate than many knew, and it’s a fact that powers many Wall Street algorithms today. Later in the book, we’ll see how this human predictive science that Leibniz first speculated on was developed at NASA and how it’s now spreading into the rest of our lives.

莱布尼茨从未看到他的二进制创造达到他所设想的高度。但从20世纪30年代开始，能够执行算术问题的电子电路开始在美国、德国和法国出现。它利用了莱布尼茨的二进制计数系统，而后者已经等待了250年，希望材料科学能够赶上它简单的辉煌。

Leibniz never saw his binary creation reach the heights he envisioned for it. But beginning in the 1930s, electronic circuitry capable of executing arithmetic problems began to manifest in the United States, Germany, and France. It utilized Leibniz’s binary numbering system, which had been waiting 250 years for material science to catch up to its simple brilliance.

二进制系统支撑着当今所有的计算机编程语言，这些语言不过是编写算法的载体。它也驱动着运行这些算法的计算机芯片和电路。

The binary system enables all of today’s computer programming languages, which are nothing more than vehicles for easily writing algorithms. It also powers the chips and circuits of our computers that run those algorithms.

高斯：使算法背后的逻辑成为可能

GAUSS: MAKING THE LOGIC BEHIND ALGORITHMS POSSIBLE

只有当我们确切地知道需要检查或操纵哪些因素时，算法才能发挥作用。如果不知道股票期权的公平价值完全取决于该股票的历史价格、利率和期权的执行价格的波动性，就不可能构建一个确定该股票期权公平价值的算法。如果彼得菲或布莱克和斯科尔斯不知道这些是影响期权价格的最重要因素，那么创建一种能够有效交易并击败人类的算法将是不可能的。同样，一个通过检查你所说的话来了解你真实想法的算法也是如此。这个算法必须融入我们说话方式和句子结构的实际含义的逻辑。

Algorithms only work when we know the exact factors that need to be examined or manipulated. An algorithm that determines the fair worth of a stock option would be impossible to construct without knowing that this price is wholly dependent on the volatility of that stock’s historical prices, interest rates, and the strike price of the option. If Peterffy or Black and Scholes didn’t know that these were the most important factors affecting options’ prices, then creating an algorithm to effectively trade and defeat humans would be unfeasible. The same goes for an algorithm that knows what you’re really thinking by examining the words you speak. This algorithm has to be imbued with the logic of what our speech patterns and sentence structure actually mean.

有时，找出这些关系中最重要的变量，与构建能够自动应用这些发现的算法一样困难。在股票市场或我们一天说出的单词数量等模型中，成千上万的事物可以被分类并搜索其潜在含义。但大多数数据只是噪音，毫无意义。为了正常工作，预测算法需要指令，使其能够忽略噪音，专注于重要的因素。梳理这些重要因素，无论是真正影响期权价格的因素，还是让一首歌引人入胜的原因，都需要通过分析大量数据来实现。筛选数据并找出最有趣、最不直观的关系的最常用方法称为回归分析，这种技术使物理学家、统计学家或工程师能够根据过去的数据做出准确的预测。使模型拟合现有数据的方法的发展，至少部分归功于英国王室。

Sometimes figuring out which variables matter most in these relationships is as hard as constructing the algorithm that will automatically put these findings to use. In a model such as the stock market or, say, the number of words we utter in a day, thousands of things can be categorized and searched for underlying meanings. But most of the data is just noise; it’s meaningless. To work properly, predictive algorithms need instructions that allow them to ignore the noise and zero in on the factors that matter. Teasing out these important factors, be they what truly affects options prices or what makes a song catchy to our ears, is done by analyzing heaps of data. The most common method of sifting data and dusting off the most interesting and unintuitive relationships is called regression analysis, a technique that allows a physicist, a statistician, or an engineer to make accurate predictions based on data from the past. The development of methods to make models fit existing data owes at least part of its existence to the English royal family.

皇室成员并非聪明到能自己解决这一问题。但乔治四世国王却足够聪明，他于1817年委托卡尔·弗里德里希·高斯勘测汉诺威王国。23高斯当时已是一位颇有成就的数学家，他发现当时的测量工具不够精确，于是发明了一种名为“太阳反射镜”的新仪器，它利用镜子将阳光反射到很远的地方。即使有了这种新仪器，高斯也知道，测量如此广阔的土地很容易出错。二十年前，也就是他十八岁的时候，他粗略地开发了一种处理这类问题的方法。这种方法被称为最小二乘法。

The royals weren’t so clever that they figured this out for themselves. But King George IV was smart enough to commission Carl Friedrich Gauss in 1817 to survey the Kingdom of Hanover.23 Gauss, already an accomplished mathematician, found the surveying tools of the day to be inaccurate, so he invented a new one, called a heliotrope, which used a mirror to reflect sunlight across large distances. Even with this new instrument, Gauss knew that an attempt to measure a land so large would be prone to error. He had roughly developed a method for dealing with this sort of problem twenty years previously when he was eighteen. It’s known as the least squares method.

最小二乘法允许基于观察结果构建预测模型。为了根据现有数据找到最佳模型，高斯开发了一些方程，用于最小化测量值（可以是过去的股票价格）与预测模型提供的值之间差异的平方。该模型（可以是从二次方程到多层算法的任何形式）不断调整，直到找到最小二乘点。最小二乘法构成了现代统计学和算法模型构建的支柱。例如，在构建一个算法来预测未来股票价格时，测试它意味着要循环运行代表已发生日期和价格的数据。函数或曲线是从过去的数据中得出的，操作者希望它能够预测未来的数据。当量化分析师、工程师或物理学家谈论数据拟合或回归分析时，他们很可能正在运用高斯的创新。24

The least squares method allows for predictive model building based on observed results. To find the best model according to the data in hand, Gauss developed equations that minimize the squares of the differences between measured values, which could be stock prices of the past, and values provided by a predictive model. The model—which can be anything from a quadratic equation to a multitiered algorithm—is adjusted up and down until the point of least squares is found. The least squares method forms the backbone of modern statistics and algorithmic model building. When building an algorithm to, say, predict future stock prices, testing it means running the algorithm through loops of data representing days and prices that have already taken place. A function, or curve, is derived from the past data that the operator hopes will be predictive of future data. When quants, engineers, or physicists talk about data fitting or regression analysis, they’re likely wielding Gauss’s innovation.24

高斯在研究测量误差分布时，也得出了偏差（即误差）服从正态分布（现称为高斯分布）的结论。这种分布绘制成曲线时，形似钟形。高斯和同时期的其他人观察到，大多数可测量的事物，即使是自然界中的事物，例如人的身高或头部大小，也遵循相同的分布。25在钟形的中间，平均值附近存在大量的数据点，而随着钟形的扩大，远离平均值的数据点越来越少。学生的考试成绩、人的身高体型以及自然界中的许多事物都存在类似的分布。

In his research on the distribution of measurement errors, Gauss would also conclude that deviations (the errors) had what’s called a normal (now also known as Gaussian) distribution. Such a distribution, when plotted as a curve, resembles a bell. Gauss and others of the era observed that most measurable things, even those in nature such as the heights or head sizes of people, maintain the same distribution.25 There exist a large bunch of data points near the mean value, in the middle of the bell, and fewer and fewer data points as the bell spreads out, away from the mean. Similar distributions are seen on student test scores, the size and height of people, and a multitude of things in nature.

钟形曲线的远侧边缘被称为尾部。在高斯分布中，这些尾部逐渐变细，趋近于零。在现实生活中，例如金融市场，受人类非理性影响的情形下，尾部并没有那么细。当涉及到人类的心理和行为时，出现异常事件的可能性更高，从而产生所谓的厚尾分布，即非高斯分布。华尔街的巨额财富源于押注高斯分布——同样，也有同样多的巨额财富源于那些包含高斯分布结果但不考虑厚尾的算法。

The far edges of the bell curve are referred to as the tails. In a Gaussian distribution, those tails taper off toward zero. In real-life situations that can be affected by the irrationality of humans, such as financial markets, the tails aren’t so thin. When human psyches and behavior are involved, there is a higher chance of outlier events, producing a distribution with so-called fat tails, something that is not Gaussian. Wall Street fortunes have been made betting on Gaussian distributions—and just as many have been lost on algorithms that embrace Gaussian outcomes but don’t account for fat tails.

编写符合正态分布的算法更容易。尽管历史反复证明人类行为绝非正常，但一些黑客仍然选择只考虑正态分布。利用这一假设，你100天都能赚到钱。但真正让那些依赖纯粹基于高斯分布设计的算法的人破产的是第101天，例如1987年的黑色星期一、1998年的俄罗斯债务违约、2010年的闪电崩盘。即使是高斯，在两百多年前就警告说，正态分布中可能存在任何程度的误差。二十六

It’s easier to write algorithms to fit normal distributions. And despite history showing us repeatedly that human behavior is anything but normal, some hackers choose to account for only normal distribution. Using this assumption can make money 100 out of 100 days. But it’s day 101, the Black Monday of 1987, the Russian debt default of 1998, the Flash Crash of 2010, that can ruin those banking on algorithms designed purely around Gaussian distributions. Even Gauss, more than two hundred years ago, warned that errors of any magnitude are possible within a normal distribution.26

正态分布的引入改变了人类，开创了现代统计学领域，使我们能够轻松购买人寿保险、建造更好的桥梁，甚至（尽管不那么重要）投注篮球比赛。

The introduction of normal distributions changed humankind and ushered in the modern field of statistics, which allows for the easy purchase of things like life insurance, the building of better bridges, and even, though not as important, betting on basketball games.

尽管高斯早年取得了诸多成就，但他始终保持谦逊，避免争议，只发表他认为绝对无可辩驳的著作。他认为欧拉和牛顿是最伟大的数学家。27但大多数专家都会把高斯本人也算在内。许多学者认为，阿基米德、牛顿和高斯构成了数学界不朽的三巨头。关于高斯早期数学天赋的传说有很多，其中一些甚至讲述了他三岁时就展现出的惊人算术能力。28有一个故事讲的是，高斯七岁上学时，老师布置的作业是把 1 到 100 的所有数字加起来。几秒钟后，高斯说出了答案，显然他已经在脑海中推导出毕达哥拉斯学派用作其秘密社团密码的算法：二十九

Despite much success early in his life, Gauss stayed relatively humble, avoiding controversy and only publishing work he considered utterly irrefutable. He considered Euler and Newton to be the greatest mathematicians.27 But most experts would include Gauss himself within their company. Many scholars say Archimedes, Newton, and Gauss comprise math’s immortal triumvirate. There exist dozens of tales of Gauss’s early talent for mathematics, some of which recount his amazing arithmetic skills at age three.28 One story tells of him in school at seven years old when his teacher assigned his class the task of adding up all of the numbers from 1 to 100. A few seconds later, Gauss piped up with the answer, apparently having deduced in his head an algorithm used by the Pythagoreans as a password for their secret society: 29

1 / 2 n ( n + 1) = S

1/2n(n + 1) = S

变量n表示数列中的最后一个数字，在本例中为 100，S等于和。年轻的高斯很可能注意到，1 + 100 等于 101，99 + 2 和 97 + 3 也等于 101，这意味着 101 共有 50 组，即 5 × 101 = 5050。

The variable n denotes the last number in the sequence, in this case 100, and S equals the sum. The young Gauss likely noticed that 1 + 100 totaled 101, as did 99 + 2 and 97 + 3, which meant there were 50 sets of 101, or 5 × 101 = 5,050.

高斯出生于1777年，家境贫寒，与通常的贵族知识分子阶层相去甚远。十四岁时，他的数学天赋引起了布伦瑞克公爵的注意，公爵授予他一笔津贴，后来又让他进入哥廷根大学学习。30他的想法产生得如此之快，有时他很难把它们全部写下来。31

Born in 1777, Gauss came from a poorer family, a long way from the normally gilded class of leading intellectuals. When he was fourteen, his mathematical talents drew the attention of the Duke of Brunswick, who assigned him a stipend and, later, a spot at the University of Göttingen.30 His mind produced ideas so rapidly that he sometimes had trouble writing all of them down.31

高斯在二十一岁时获得博士学位，他的论文首次完整证明了代数的基本理论，这是牛顿和欧拉都曾尝试但未能完成的事情。32高斯的头脑使他在数学的许多领域都有所发现，包括数论、二次方程以及整数中素数的一般分布模式。

Gauss earned his PhD at age twenty-one with a dissertation that offered the first complete proof of the fundamental theory of algebra, something Newton and Euler had each attempted but failed to finish.32 Gauss’s mind would lead him to discoveries in many corners of mathematics, including number theory, quadratic equations, and the general distribution pattern of prime numbers among the integers.

有些人可能会把高斯的名字与高斯连接函数（Copula）联系起来。后者是一个经常被妖魔化的公式，由戴维·李（David X. Li）于2000年引入华尔街。在统计学中，连接函数用于确定两个或多个变量之间的行为关系。李当时正在寻找一种方法，来衡量当一笔看似无关的抵押贷款违约时，另一笔抵押贷款违约的风险。这被称为关联风险。由于李没有大量的次级抵押贷款历史违约数据（这些数据根本就不存在），他基于现有数据构建了连接函数：信用违约掉期（CDS）的历史价格。如果标的证券（在本例中为抵押贷款）违约，CDS 的持有者将获得一笔赔偿。然而，正如我们现在所知，CDS 市场的定价被那些交易掉期并设定价格的人严重错误地低估了。尽管如此，华尔街仍然将李的公式奉为铁一般的事实。 Copula 本应是分析师和评级机构审查并批准抵押贷款支持证券的利器之一，但却成了唯一的利器。

Some may associate Gauss’s name with that of the Gaussian copula, an often demonized formula introduced to Wall Street in 2000 by David X. Li. In statistics, a copula is used to determine the behavioral relationship between two or more variables. Li was searching for a way to measure the risk of one mortgage defaulting if another, seemingly unrelated mortgage defaulted. This is called correlative risk. Because Li didn’t have piles of historical default data on subprime mortgages (it simply didn’t exist), he built his copula on data that did exist: historical prices of credit default swaps, which result in a payment to the owner of the swap if the underlying securities (mortgages in this case) go into default. But the CDS market was, as we now well know, egregiously mispriced by the humans who traded the swaps and set the prices. Nevertheless, Wall Street embraced Li’s formula as stone-solid fact. The copula should have been one arrow in the quiver of analysts and rating agencies who examined and stamped their approval on mortgage-backed securities. Instead, it became the only arrow.

由此引发的抵押债务凭证（CDO）繁荣和房地产市场泡沫，直接源于银行家们对本应无害算法的滥用。高斯连接函数是实用工具，在诸多领域都有应用，但它们唯一无法做到的就是模拟极端事件之间的依赖关系，而这正是人类擅长促成的。33

The resultant boom in collateralized debt obligations and the housing market bubble came straight from bankers’ misuse of what should have been a harmless algorithm. Gaussian copulas are useful tools and are utilized in a number of fields, but the one thing they do not do is model dependence between extreme events, something humans excel at precipitating.33

帕斯卡、伯努利和改变世界的骰子游戏

PASCAL, BERNOULLI, AND THE DICE GAME THAT CHANGED THE WORLD

从年金到保险再到算法交易，现代金融的大部分都源于概率论——从赌场到摩天大楼建设再到飞机制造，无数其他行业也都源于概率论。现代医学中最有前景的变革，其大部分测试和诊断方法都基于概率论。政党对候选人及其精神方向的决定并非基于实用主义或事实，而是基于概率论。足球教练会查阅口袋卡片，根据剩余时间内其他比赛事件发生的概率来指导他们做出决策。

Much of modern finance, from annuities to insurance to algorithmic trading, has roots in probability theory—as do myriad other businesses from casinos to skyscraper construction to airplane manufacturing. The most promising movement in modern medicine bases much of its testing and diagnostic methodologies on probability. Political parties make decisions on candidates and the direction of their ethos not based on pragmatism or facts, but on probability theory. Football coaches consult pocket cards instructing them on what decision to make based on the probabilities of other game events happening in the time left on the clock.

所有这些现代概率论的表现形式都可以追溯到1654年两位法国人之间的一封信。当时，布莱兹·帕斯卡（Blaise Pascal）写信给皮埃尔·费马（Pierre Fermat），思考如何分配一场尚未结束的赌博游戏的彩池。例如，一位玩家赢了五轮，另一位玩家赢了两轮——那么每个人能从公共彩池中分到多少钱？帕斯卡这篇三千字的文章建立了一种精确计算事件发生可能性的方法。这个博弈问题的答案是计算剩余每位玩家赢得彩池的可能性，并根据这些百分比进行分配。三十四

All of these modern manifestations of probability theory can be traced to a letter sent between two Frenchmen in 1654 when Blaise Pascal wrote a note to Pierre Fermat contemplating how one might break up the pot of a game of chance that has yet to be finished. One player, for instance, has won five rounds and the other has won two—how much does each take home from the communal pot? Pascal’s three-thousand-word essay established a method for the exact calculation of events’ likelihoods. The answer to the gaming question is to calculate the likelihood of each of the remaining players winning the pot and split it according to those percentages.34

信封在法国各地从一位著名数学家手中传到另一位著名数学家手中，五年之内，世界也随之发生了变化。能够更好地预测未来可能发生的情况，催生了蓬勃发展的工业，也让人们能够更加确定地管理生活和生意。帕斯卡写给费马的信，让农民能够将市场风险与谷物作物区分开来；正因如此，仅仅一百年后，欧洲金融部门就能精确地发布死亡率表。帕斯卡的信，也是伦敦在至少一个世纪内崛起成为全球最重要城市的主要原因之一，因为伦敦的商人为世界上最大的远洋船队投保，鼓励企业开拓新土地，而不必担心此类投资带来的巨大风险。

Within five years of that envelope crossing France from one famous mathematician to another, the world began to change accordingly. Being able to better calculate what might happen in the future gave rise to burgeoning industries and allowed people to manage their lives and businesses with far more certainty. Pascal’s letter to Fermat is what allows farmers to disconnect market risk from their grain crop; it’s why, just one hundred years later, mortality tables were being issued with precision by Europe’s financial sector. Pascal’s letter is one of the chief reasons why London ascended to become the world’s most consequential city for at least a century as its merchants insured much of the world’s largest seagoing fleet, encouraging businesses to strike out for new lands without fixating on the enormous risks such ventures entailed.

在帕斯卡工作的基础上，雅各布·伯努利与几年前的克里斯蒂安·惠更斯一样，开始着迷于在涉及骰子和纸牌等机会游戏中加入严格的概率。35正是通过对这些游戏的研究，伯努利提出了现在所谓的大数定律。三十六

Building on Pascal’s work, Jacob Bernoulli, like Christiaan Huygens a few years before him, became transfixed with putting rigid probabilities on games of chance involving things such as dice and cards.35 It was through his study of these games that Bernoulli developed what is now known as the law of large numbers.36

对于概率可计算的过程，例如抛硬币（正面和反面的概率分别为 50%），伯努利定律指出，随着抛硬币次数的增加（或抛硬币次数的增加），平均结果将趋近于预先计算的概率。例如，抛 10 次硬币，有 70% 的概率出现正面并非完全不可能。然而，抛 1000 次硬币，有 70% 的概率出现正面，几乎是不可能的。

For processes with probabilities that can be calculated, such as the flipping of a coin (50 percent chance of heads, 50 percent chance of tails), Bernoulli’s law said that as more iterations of the game are played (or coins are flipped), the average result will converge upon the precalculated probability. Turning heads in 70 percent of ten coin flips, for instance, isn’t all that unlikely. Getting heads on 70 percent of a thousand coin flips, however, is virtually impossible.

这一原则指导着二十一点赌徒和扑克玩家。它也指导着华尔街的许多（如果不是大多数的话）高频交易员，他们保持高交易量，以确保他们的净利润接近一个可能的平均值。概率论也指导着现代棒球总经理，他们寻找那些常规数据（例如自责分和打击率）因长期厄运而偏低的天才球员。这种不幸或许可以通过更复杂的统计测量来揭示，这些测量可以显示，对于投手来说，为什么大量的地滚球变成了安打，或者对于击球手来说，为什么平飞球没有变成安打。还有一类新的医生，他们在诊断病人时，首先会忽略自身的偏见，转而依靠基于概率的算法。

This principle guides blackjack gamblers and poker players. It also guides many, if not most, of Wall Street’s high-frequency traders, who keep their trade volumes high to ensure that their net hones close to a probable mean. Probability theory also guides modern baseball general managers, who look for players with talent whose regular stats, such as earned run and batting averages, have been skewed lower by a prolonged string of bad luck. Such misfortune might be revealed by more complex stat measurements that show how, in the case of a pitcher, perhaps, an outsized number of ground balls have turned into hits, or how, in the case of a batter, line drives haven’t resulted in hits. There is also a new class of doctors who, in diagnosing patients, before all else ignore their biases and look to algorithms based on probabilities.

以股票交易员为例，一种旨在捕捉股票买卖价差的算法，在市场波动时可能会受阻，导致交易员及其算法只能做单边交易——错误的交易方向。如果一个算法以 50.00 美元的买入价买入微软股票，却未能在几秒钟内以 50.02 美元的卖出价卖出，随后市场下跌，那么当交易员以 49.99 美元的新卖出价卖出时，他就会蒙受损失。

In the case of a stock trader, an algorithm that seeks to capture the spread between a stock’s bid and offer prices can be thwarted when the market moves, which can leave the trader and his algorithm with only one side—the wrong side—of a trade. If an algorithm bought Microsoft at the bid of $50.00 and then failed to sell it within the same several seconds at the ask of $50.02 before the market went down, the trader will be taking a loss when he sells at the new ask of $49.99.

这些算法旨在预测市场走向。要想成功，算法的正确率只需达到51%。但即使51%的正确率，如果高频交易员每天只交易10次，他仍然可能面临巨额亏损。很多时候，他10次交易中可能7次都会亏损。但高频交易员之所以被称为“高频”，是有原因的。他们每天进行数万笔交易，交易数百万股。正如伯努利指出的那样，随着重复次数的增加，他们盈利交易的数量将趋近于51%的平均值。这就是为什么许多规模最大、实力最强的算法交易员能够一年甚至更长时间不亏损的原因。

These algorithms are built to predict market direction. To be successful, the algorithm has to be right only 51 percent of the time. But a 51 percent probability could still leave a high-frequency trader open to big losses if he trades only ten times a day. There could be plenty of days where he loses on seven of ten trades. But high-frequency traders are called “high frequency” for a reason. They make tens of thousands of trades a day representing millions of shares. As their repetitions escalate, as Bernoulli pointed out, their number of profitable trades will converge toward the mean of 51 percent. This is why many of the biggest, most powerful algorithmic traders can go a year or longer without having a losing day.

除了华尔街，我们当中的数学爱好者也要感谢伯努利，他定义了复利计算公式。复利是大多数人接触金融时最先学习和掌握的概念之一。伯努利在他的连续复利算法中发现了一个数学常数，叫做e。在与莱布尼茨的通信中，伯努利将这个数字称为b，或许是取自他自己的姓氏，但后来，一位名叫莱昂哈德·欧拉的人用e来称呼它，它才为世人所知。

Beyond Wall Street, the math mortals among us can thank Bernoulli for his work on defining formulas for calculating compound interest, one of the first ideas most people learn and retain when it comes to finance. Within his algorithm for continually compounding interest, Bernoulli uncovered the mathematical constant known as e. In correspondence with Leibniz, Bernoulli referred to the number as b, perhaps for his own last name, but it became known to the world as e after a man named Leonhard Euler referred to it as such.

为算法赋予视觉形状

GIVING VISUAL SHAPE TO ALGORITHMS

1791年，著名的奥地利作曲家约瑟夫·海顿在伦敦威斯敏斯特教堂观看了乔治·弗里德里希·亨德尔的《弥赛亚》的盛大舞台演出。在这场由一千名合唱团和管弦乐队成员共同演绎的演出结束时，海顿落泪了。他泪流满面地评价他的同代人亨德尔：“他是我们所有人的大师。”三十七

In 1791, the famous Austrian composer Joseph Haydn attended a grandly staged version of George Frideric Handel’s Messiah at Westminster Abbey in London. At the close of the performance, put on by a thousand choral and orchestra members, Haydn wept. Through his tears, he declared of Handel, his contemporary, “He is the master of us all.”37

大约在同一时期，法国数学家、统计学领域的思想巨擘之一皮埃尔-西蒙·拉普拉斯也发出了同样的感叹，但他并非针对弥赛亚的 作曲家。拉普拉斯所称的“我们所有人的导师”其实是莱昂哈德·欧拉。三十八

At about the same time, Pierre-Simon Laplace, the French mathematician and one of the thought giants who developed the field of statistics, was exclaiming the same thing, but not of the Messiah’s composer. The man Laplace proclaimed the “master of us all” was Leonhard Euler.38

欧拉是巴塞尔大学的另一位杰出人才，巴塞尔大学汇聚了众多改变世界的人才。教皇庇护二世于1460年创办了这所瑞士最古老的大学，几个世纪以来，它吸引了众多高智商人士，例如鹿特丹的伊拉斯谟、伯努利家族、欧拉家族、雅各布·布克哈特、弗里德里希·尼采和卡尔·荣格。欧拉出生于1707年，曾师从雅各布的兄弟约翰·伯努利，后者可能是当时世界上最伟大的在职数学家。三十九

Euler was another product of the University of Basel, a world-altering cluster of intelligence. Pope Pius II founded the university, the oldest in Switzerland, in 1460, and for centuries it drew in high intellects such as Erasmus of Rotterdam, the Bernoullis, the Eulers, Jacob Burckhardt, Friedrich Nietzsche, and Carl Jung. Born in 1707, Euler was schooled for a time by Johann Bernoulli, Jacob’s brother, who was at the time likely the world’s greatest working mathematician.39

大学期间，欧拉经常利用周六下午的时间与伯努利弟弟讨论数学和哲学。“他总是很友善地向我解释所有我不明白的地方，”欧拉回忆道。40当他的研究结束时，已经没有什么需要解释的了。欧拉由此开始了或许是有史以来个人数学著作最丰硕的时期。

While at university, Euler spent his Saturday afternoons talking with the younger Bernoulli brother about mathematics and philosophy. “He kindly explained to me everything I could not understand,” Euler remembered.40 By the time his studies were finished, there wasn’t much left needing explanation. Euler then began perhaps the most prolific stretch of mathematical publication ever undertaken by one man.

欧拉在俄罗斯圣彼得堡科学院担任新教授期间，着手解决一个名为“柯尼斯堡七桥”的问题。这个问题曾困扰着这片大陆上的许多人。柯尼斯堡，现在被称为加里宁格勒，位于俄罗斯的一块小飞地，夹在波兰和立陶宛之间，在欧拉时代属于普鲁士。这座城市被普雷格尔河的支流分割成几块陆地，其中包括两个岛屿，这些陆地由七座桥梁连接起来。在柯尼斯堡漫步的人们经常会遇到一个难题：找到一条穿过城镇的路线，每座桥只能通过一次。41

As a new professor at the Saint Petersburg Academy of Sciences in Russia, Euler tackled a problem known as the Seven Bridges of Königsberg, which had bedeviled many people in this part of the continent. Königsberg, now called Kaliningrad and situated in a small exclave of Russia wedged between Poland and Lithuania, was in Euler’s time a part of Prussia. The city was divided into several landmasses, including two islands, by branches of the Pregel River, and these were connected by a series of seven bridges. A popular puzzle for those strolling the city would be to try to find a route through the town that crossed each bridge but only once.41

为了说明这个问题，欧拉绘制了一系列点，称为节点，这些点由线（称为边）连接起来，分别代表陆地和桥梁。他指出，这些线的距离和形状可以任意改变，节点也可以移动，只要所有线（桥梁）保持完整即可。欧拉所创造的图，在数学上被称为“图”。它证明了，通过每座桥梁一次且仅一次穿越柯尼斯堡实际上是不可能的。为了解决这个问题，欧拉发展了图论。

To illustrate the problem, Euler drew a series of points, called nodes, connected by lines, called edges, representing the landmasses and the bridges. He noted that the distances and the shape of the lines could be altered in any fashion and that the nodes could be moved around, so long as all of the lines (bridges) remained intact. What Euler created is now known in mathematics as a graph, and it proved that crossing Königsberg using every bridge once and only once was in fact impossible. In solving this problem, Euler developed graph theory.

欧拉所发展的图论与我们习以为常的图表（例如股票市场或销售报告）截然不同。欧拉的图是树状图，可以象征自然界的网络、微芯片上的电路或城市中不同人之间的关系。专门为图论编写算法代表了现代计算机科学令人兴奋的新篇章之一，它使生物学家能够将DNA链与身体特征联系起来，使教授能够解码披头士乐队的音乐，使中央情报局能够联系世界各地的恐怖分子，使华尔街的观察家能够发现看似毫不相关的事物之间的关系。图论对于那些研究Facebook网络的人来说尤其有用，通过分析图中哪些节点（人）绘制了最多的边（连接），以及哪些边在吸引眼球和评论方面最活跃，可以确定其中最具影响力的成员。Facebook的工程师面试时经常会被问到图论问题。

The graph theory that Euler developed is separate from the graphs we are used to viewing of, say, the stock market or a sales report. Euler’s graphs are treelike diagrams that can symbolize networks in nature, circuitry on a microchip, or relationships between different humans within a city. Writing algorithms specifically for graph theory represents one of the exciting new leafs of modern computer science, allowing biologists to make connections between DNA strands and physical traits, professors to decode the music of the Beatles, the CIA to connect terrorists across the world, and Wall Street observers to find relationships between seemingly disparate things. Graph theory is especially useful to those examining Facebook networks, where the most influential members can be determined by analyzing which nodes in the graph (people) draw the most edges (connections) and which edges are most active in terms of drawing eyeballs and comments. Engineers who interview for jobs at Facebook are often quizzed on graph theory.

欧拉享年七十六岁，但他的著作在他去世后近一个世纪里仍在不断出版。他撰写了886本书籍、文章、教科书和技术手册，占其生前欧洲数学出版物总量的三分之一。他开辟了如此多的数学新路，以至于为了避免以一个人的名字命名太多定理和方程式，许多定理和方程式都以第一个发现或应用它们的人的名字命名，以欧拉的名字命名。四十二

Euler lived for seventy-six years, but his work continued to be published for nearly a century after his death. He authored 886 books, articles, textbooks, and technical manuals, representing a full third of all European mathematical publishing during his lifetime. He blazed so many new paths in mathematics that, in an effort to avoid naming so much after one man, many theorems and equations carry the name of the first person who discovered or applied them after Euler.42

有些人可能还记得学校里学过的欧拉公式：V - E + F = 2。无数算法都基于这个公式，它描述了三维形状，其中V表示顶点（线相交的角）的数量，E表示形状的边数，F表示物体的面数。例如，一个立方体有六个面（面）、十二条边和八个顶点：8 - 12 + 6 = 2。

Some people might remember from school what’s known as Euler’s formula: V - E + F = 2. The equation, upon which countless algorithms are written, describes three-dimensional shapes with V equaling the number of vertices (corners where lines intersect), E being the number of edges for the shape, and F equaling the number of faces of the object. A cube, for instance, has six sides or faces, twelve edges, and eight vertices: 8 - 12 + 6 = 2.

这个方程使欧拉的研究范围远远超出了立方体、金字塔、圆锥体和球体等基本刚性形状。欧拉公式后来有助于解释碳分子的几何形状、看似随机的天气系统、光学、磁学和流体力学。通过与其同名的公式背后的理论，欧拉开始思考非刚性形状，这方面的研究被称为拓扑学。拓扑学是混沌理论的一部分，在过去的二十年里，混沌理论为来到华尔街并围绕它构建算法的数学家们带来了巨大的财富。

This equation took Euler far beyond elementary and rigid shapes like cubes, pyramids, cones, and spheres. Euler’s formula would later help explain the geometry of carbon molecules, seemingly random weather systems, optics, magnetism, and hydrodynamics. Through the theory behind his namesake formula, Euler began pondering nonrigid shapes, the study of which is known as topology. Topology is part of chaos theory, which in the last two decades has yielded fortunes to mathematicians who came to Wall Street and built algorithms around it.

布尔逻辑机

BOOLEAN LOGIC MACHINES

这里提到的所有数学天才都对人类思维进行了思考，包括它的起源、局限性和方法。莱布尼茨率先提出了人类思维可以分解为最基本的齿轮的理论，这些齿轮由一系列二元决策表示。莱布尼茨说，这些二元选择可以根据需要堆叠，形成越来越复杂的思维——或者说算法。

All of the math geniuses mentioned here contemplated human thought, its origins, its limits, and its methods. Leibniz was first to theorize that human thought could be broken down to its basest of cogs, represented by a series of binary decisions. These binary choices, Leibniz said, could then be stacked on top of one another, as high as needed, to form thoughts—or algorithms—growing more complex.

如果莱布尼茨迈出了构建如今统治我们生活的机器的第一步，那么乔治·布尔则继承了莱布尼茨的势头，而这股势头在他那个时代已有近两百年的历史。正是布尔的计算系统和创新的代数形式，使得网络得以运行，从人们在Facebook上发布的图片到他们在博客上发布的文本。如果那些统治我们生活的复杂算法不能像人类一样在逻辑上跳跃，它们就毫无意义。例如，只有当Gmail用户正确输入密码，并 在提示下正确解读出那个难以辨认的波浪线字母时，谷歌才会显示他的收件箱。谷歌不会显示一封被标记为垃圾邮件的电子邮件，因为同一封邮件发送到了一千万个Gmail邮箱，而且它并非来自像Groupon这样值得信赖的群发机构，也不是这些人都曾与之进行过邮件交流的某个人。正是这些修饰符，if、and、or、not，使得计算机科学和算法得以运作。

If Leibniz took the first step toward building the machines that now rule our lives, it was George Boole who seized Leibniz’s momentum, which was by his time nearly two hundred years old. It’s Boole’s calculating system and innovative form of algebra that allows the Web to work, from the images people post on Facebook to the text they post on their blogs. The complex algorithms that have come to rule our lives would be nothing if they couldn’t make humanlike jumps in their logic. For example, Google will show a Gmail user his in-box only if he correctly types his password and if he, if prompted, correctly deciphers that squiggly word that’s hard to read. Google will not show you an e-mail that is marked as spam because the same e-mail went to ten million Gmail boxes and it’s not from a trusted mass sender such as Groupon or somebody with whom each one of these people has already held an e-mail conversation. It’s these modifiers, the ifs, ands, ors, nots, that make computer science and algorithms tick.

这一启示的根源，在十七岁的布尔漫步草地时，突然闪过。他突然萌生了一个想法：某种代数符号可以用来定义一种逻辑语言，一种思维语言——一种打破人类理性化内在运作方式的方法。这个想法对世界产生了革命性的影响，对布尔的人生也至关重要，以至于他开始思考一颗不受干扰的心灵的力量。科学已经充分证明，人类的潜意识或许是人类最强大的工具，但在布尔之前，没有人对此进行过理论研究。他称之为“无意识”。43

The roots of this revelation struck a seventeen-year-old Boole while he strolled across a meadow. From out of nowhere, he formed the idea that algebraic symbols of some sort could be used to define a language of logic, a language of thought—a way to break down the inner workings of human rationalization. The idea proved so revolutionary to the world and so important to Boole’s life that he began to ponder the power of an unengaged mind. Science has well proven that the human subconscious is perhaps man’s strongest tool, but nobody theorized on the fact before Boole. He referred to it as “the unconscious.”43

乔治·布尔于1815年出生于英国林肯。他的父亲约翰是一位鞋匠，但他却拥有丰富的博学爱好，包括数学、天文学和光学仪器的制造。约翰·布尔无力供儿子上大学，于是乔治自学成才。他的自学方法非常有效，以至于他在十几岁之前就掌握了四种语言的读写能力，并在那时开始在当地学校任教。四十四

Boole was born in 1815 in Lincoln, England. His father, John, was a shoemaker, but he possessed a bevy of erudite hobbies, including mathematics, astronomy, and the construction of optical instruments. John Boole couldn’t afford to send his son to college, so George taught himself. His autodidactic methods worked so well, in fact, that he could read and write in four languages before he reached his teen years, by which time he was teaching in local schools.44

二十几岁时，布尔开始攻克高等数学难题；1841年，他的研究成果开始在期刊上发表。四年后，他被任命为爱尔兰科克皇后学院（现更名为科克大学）的创始数学教授。1854年，布尔收获了十七岁时在那片草地上萌芽的种子，出版了《思维规律研究——逻辑和概率的数学理论的基础》。他通过这一努力，追寻莱布尼茨很久以前就想到的某个东西。但最终将这个想法转化为可用工具的人是布尔，而不是莱布尼茨。

In his twenties, Boole began to attack problems of advanced math; journals began publishing his work in 1841. Four years later, he was named the founding professor of mathematics at Queen’s College in Cork, Ireland (now called University College Cork). In 1854, Boole harvested the seeds that had started to bloom in that meadow when he was seventeen, publishing An Investigation of the Laws of Thought, on Which Are Founded the Mathematical Theories of Logic and Probabilities. With this effort, he chased something Leibniz had thought of long before. But it was Boole, not Leibniz, who managed to corral the idea into a medium that could be used.

布尔在他的书的开头是这样的：

Boole opened his book with this:

 

 

以下论文的目的是研究进行推理的思维活动的基本规律。

The design of the following treatise is to investigate the fundamental laws of those operations of the mind by which reasoning is performed.

这位英国人试图定义一种思维语言，将人类的推理分解成一系列易于书写的数学表达式，创造出代表人类思维之门的符号：如果、与、或、非，这些符号可以用于乘法和除法等常规算术运算。任何编写过简单计算机代码的人都熟悉这些修饰符。布尔代数赋予计算机电路核心。没有它，那些无比复杂的算法——那些如今每天都在改变世界的算法——将无法执行。

The Englishman sought to define a language of thought that could break human deduction into a series of mathematical expressions easily written onto paper, creating symbols that represented the gates within human thought: if, and, or, not, which could be used with normal arithmetic operations such as multiplication and division. Anybody who has written just an elementary chunk of computer code is familiar with these modifiers. Boolean algebra gives computer circuitry its guts. Without it, the execution of endlessly complex algorithms—the kinds that now change the world every day—would be impossible.

布尔的思想发表后并没有引起世界轰动。包括英国数学家在内的少数英国人都熟悉逻辑理论。而且，如果没有能够读取算法的机器或计算机，当时也没有明显的方法来应用现在所谓的布尔代数。

Boole’s ideas did not set the world on fire after he published. Few Britons, including the country’s mathematicians, were familiar with logic theory. And there was no obvious way to apply what’s now called Boolean algebra without machines or computers capable of reading algorithms.

这并不是说没人尝试过。或许最重要的一位是艾达·洛夫莱斯，她不仅是在女性很少被允许学习的时代成为一名女性数学学者，还常被公认为第一位黑客。1842年，在记录查尔斯·巴贝奇的分析机（一台巴贝奇从未完成的机械计算机器）时，洛夫莱斯设计了几种不同的输入，理论上可以使机器执行某些计算和任务。就这样，洛夫莱斯编写出了第一个用于机器的算法。洛夫莱斯的工作没有使用布尔符号，因此她一直在寻找一种表达人类思维过程的方法。她写道，她希望这台设备能够“摸索”以发现正确的决策或路径。45 1979 年，在洛夫莱斯去世一个多世纪后，美国国防部以这位最初的黑客的名字将其新的计算机语言命名为 Ada。46

That’s not to say nobody tried. Perhaps the most important was Ada Lovelace, who, aside from being a female math scholar in a time when few women were allowed to study, is often recognized as the first hacker. In 1842, while documenting Charles Babbage’s Analytical Engine, a mechanical computing machine that Babbage never completed, Lovelace devised several different inputs that, theoretically, would make the machine perform certain calculations and tasks. In doing so, Lovelace had composed the first algorithm meant for a machine. Lovelace’s work did not use Boolean symbols, so it was left searching for a way to express the processes of human thought. She wrote that she wanted the device to “feel about” to discover the correct decision or path.45 In 1979, well over a century after Lovelace’s death, the U.S. Department of Defense named its new computer language Ada, after the original hacker.46

尽管巴贝奇、洛夫莱斯等人都曾尝试研制机械计算机，但布尔的顿悟虽然在 20 世纪初被尊为数学定理，却并没有被那些开始构建电子时代的工程师和物理学家所接受。47但随着技术的进步和科学家们试图构建越来越先进的电路，工程师们发现他们需要一些东西——一种数学工具——来帮助他们驯服和充分利用他们正在构建的复杂电子设备。

Despite the attempts at mechanical computers by Babbage, Lovelace, and others, Boole’s epiphany, while respected as a mathematical theorem in the early 1900s, hadn’t caught on with the engineers and physicists who started building the electronic age.47 But as technology progressed and scientists attempted to build more and more advanced circuitry, engineers found themselves needing something—a mathematical tool—that would help them tame and fully utilize the sophisticated electronics they were building.

20世纪30年代末，麻省理工学院的研究生克劳德·香农将莱布尼茨的二进制计算和数字系统与布尔运算符（例如“与”、“或”、“非”、“非或”和“如果”等）相结合。香农发现，所有这些表达式都可以内置到电子电路中，而且它们还能解决几乎所有数学问题、存储数据，以及编辑从图像到文本的各种信息。香农在其漫长的一生中取得了丰硕的成就，被誉为信息时代之父。四十八

In the late 1930s, an MIT graduate student named Claude Shannon combined the binary calculating and number system of Leibniz with Boolean operators such as and, or, not, not-or, and if, among others. Shannon found that all of these expressions could be built into electronic circuits—and they could also solve nearly any math problem, store data, and edit all kinds of information from images to text. Shannon, who achieved much in his long life, is known as the father of the information age.48

这就是计算机电路和语言的真正诞生，随之而来的是现代算法和能够模仿人类的机器的开端。

And here was the true birth of computer circuitry and language, and with it the modern algorithm and the beginnings of machines that can mimic man.

3

3

机器人前 40 名

THE BOT TOP 40

2004年，一家大型电影 制片厂使用算法扫描了九部未发行电影的剧本。分析结果由一家名为Epagogix的新公司进行，随后被保存起来。这些电影最终都上映了，当最后一部电影下映后，该电影制片厂回过头去查看算法的预测结果。该算法原本应该预测每部电影的票房收入，但结果却出奇地准确。在九部电影中，有三部预测结果与预期相差甚远。然而，其余六部电影的预测却出奇地准确。其中一部制片厂预计票房收入在1亿美元或以上，但最终总票房仅为4000万美元，这令人大失所望。1算法预测票房为4900万美元。另一个预测的票房在120万美元以内。Epagogix突然成为电影公司在电影开拍前分析剧本（尤其是那些可能涉及大预算的剧本）的必备工具。Epagogix是由两位电影爱好者构思和创建的，一位是律师，另一位来自华尔街最钟爱的领域：风险管理。其目的是最大限度地降低制作烂片的风险，就像迪士尼在2012年拍摄《异星战场》 （John Carter）时那样，当时迪士尼损失了近2亿美元。

IN 2004, A MAJOR MOVIE studio allowed an algorithm to scan nine scripts of unreleased movies. The results of the analysis, run by a new company named Epagogix, were then tucked away. The movies all eventually hit the screen, and when the last one was out of theaters, the movie studio went back to take a look at what the algorithm, which was supposed to tell them how much money each film would gross at the box office, had predicted. In three of the nine cases, the algorithm missed by a wide margin. The other six forecasts, however, were bizarrely accurate. On one movie that the studio expected $100 million or more on, the total gross was $40 million, a huge disappointment.1 The algorithm predicted $49 million. Another prediction was within $1.2 million. Epagogix was suddenly on its way to becoming an indispensable tool for studios to use in analyzing scripts—especially ones that may be attached to big budgets—before the movie gets made. Epagogix was conceived and built by two movie lovers, one of them a lawyer and the other from Wall Street’s favorite of disciplines: risk management. The point is to minimize the risk of producing a stinker like Disney did in 2012 when John Carter lost the studio nearly $200 million.

算法真正扫描的是一份报告，这份报告是由阅读剧本的人撰写的，他们根据数百个不同的因素对其进行评分，从背景设定到引领影片的英雄类型，再到情节中的道德困境、配角、结局、爱情故事等等。无需焦点小组讨论、董事会辩论，也无需高管们就是否购买新剧本发生冲突；只需评分后交给算法即可。但这个算法，尽管非常巧妙，仍然需要人们评估文字、故事、情节、人物等等。如果有一种算法不需要人类的输入，那会怎样？如果有一种算法可以自己创作剧本，那会怎样？

What the algorithm actually scans is a report produced by people who read the script and grade it on hundreds of different factors, from its setting to the kind of heroes who lead the film to the moral dilemmas within the plot to the supporting characters, the ending, the love stories, and so on. No need for focus groups, boardroom arguments, or executive clashes over whether to buy a new script; just grade it out and give it to the algorithm. But this algorithm, as genius as it is, still needs people to evaluate the words, the story, the plot, the characters, all of it. What if there were an algorithm that didn’t need people for input? What if there were algorithms that could create the script itself?

那些构思艺术、创新、文字、公司新策略以及改变世界的产品的人——他们的工作一直被认为超出了算法的范畴。这些职业及其地位备受尊重，薪资优厚，并且对于那些从事这些职业的人来说，他们拥有在职场中自由流动的感觉。有人称这些人为创意阶层，有人称他们为大学毕业生，还有人干脆称他们为聪明人。

Those who imagine art, innovations, words, novel strategies for companies, products that change the world—their jobs have always been considered outside the reach of algorithms. These professions and their perches hold esteem, good salaries, and a sense, for those who occupy them, of freedom and mobility within the workforce. Some call these people the creative class, some call them post–college educated, and some just call them smart people.

聪明人以为，这场悄然兴起的机器人工人革命对他们来说毫无影响。他们的想法是，算法无法创新，机器人无法创造。然而，我们现在意识到，这些都是危险的假设。

Smart people assume that this creeping revolution of bot workers can’t touch them. The notion is that algorithms can’t innovate, that a bot can’t create. We’re now learning, however, that these are dangerous assumptions.

算法可以被训练来评估他人创作的质量和原创性。它们也可以创作自己的作品。音乐是算法最不可能入侵的领域之一。对许多人来说，音乐反映了人类灵魂跳动的创造力。我们很难描述音乐究竟如何影响我们、改变我们的情绪和意识。音乐创作者几乎无法解释灵感是如何迸发的。这个过程被归结为人类潜意识中难以言喻的火花——右脑能力和长时间专注思考的混合体，有些是有意识的，有些是无意识的。创造力被认为是一种无形的东西，几乎无法被教授，更不用说交给机器去完成了。

Algorithms can be taught to evaluate the quality and originality of others’ creations. They can generate their own creations too. One of the more unlikely areas for an algorithm invasion is music. To many, music reflects the beating creativity of the human soul. We can have difficulty describing how exactly music affects us, changes our mood, and alters our consciousness. Those who make music can barely explain how inspiration strikes. It’s a process that’s been chalked up as one of those indefinable sparks within the human subconscious—a mixture of right brainpower and long stretches of dedicated thinking on the matter, some conscious, some not. Creativity is thought of as something so incorporeal that it can hardly be taught, let alone left for a machine to carry out.

但现在已有算法，其中一种算法的名字叫安妮，它可以创作出像勃拉姆斯、巴赫和莫扎特等大师的作品一样大胆和原创的音乐，也可以创作出像大型商店里播放的曲调一样流行和朗朗上口的音乐。

But there now exist algorithms, including one with a human name—Annie—that can produce music as daring and original as the works of masters like Brahms, Bach, and Mozart, and as popular and catchy as the tunes played inside a big-box store.

你有 41% 的几率成为 Lady Gaga

YOU HAVE A 41 PERCENT CHANCE OF BEING LADY GAGA

2004年，身为音乐家兼作家的本·诺瓦克开着他能负担得起的车：一辆1993年的日产蓝鸟。这辆车载着他在家乡新西兰奥克兰四处转悠，一路顺畅。诺瓦克对这辆车最大的不满在于它的收音机，它只能收听到市内几十个调频电台中的两个。作为一个把所有闲暇时间都用来喝酒或听音乐的人，诺瓦克觉得这可不是什么小麻烦。但他没钱买新车，所以就一直把收音机调到BBC，这是他唯一能接受的电台。

As a musician and writer, Ben Novak drove the car he could afford in 2004: a 1993 Nissan Bluebird. The vehicle propelled him around his hometown of Auckland, New Zealand, just fine. Novak’s main complaint about the car concerned its radio, which could capture only two FM stations out of the dozens broadcasting in the city. As somebody who spent every spare minute imbibing or playing music, Novak found this no minor aggravation. But he didn’t have money for a new car, so he left the dial fixed on the BBC, his only acceptable option.

被困在BBC也有好处。诺瓦克对鸡尾酒会上谈论时事了如指掌，闲聊乏味之时，他总能找到新的话题。更重要的是，他没有错过BBC关于西班牙研发技术的一篇简短报道，该报道的作者声称，这项技术可以预测哪些歌曲会成为流行金曲。

Being stuck on the BBC had its benefits. Novak was well armed for cocktail conversation on current events, and he could always crack off a new piece of intellectual fodder when chitchat grew stale. More important, he didn’t miss a short BBC report on technology developed in Spain that, the person being profiled claimed, could predict which songs would turn into pop hits.

“我一边开车一边听着这事儿，心想‘真有意思’，”诺瓦克回忆道。“说实话，我本来可以继续开车，忘了这事儿，但我要在下一个出口下车了。”

“I’m driving down the road listening to this and I think, ‘That’s interesting,’” Novak remembers. “I could have just kept driving and forgot about it, frankly, but I was getting off at the next exit.”

诺瓦克下车后，开车回家，坐在电脑前。他打开了当时名为 Polyphonic HMI 的网站。只需 50 美元，该网站的算法就能分析诺瓦克上传的所有音乐文件。潜在的热门歌曲会获得高分，而质量较差的歌曲则会获得低分。

Novak hit his exit, drove to his house, and sat down in front of his computer. He brought up the Web site belonging to what was then called Polyphonic HMI. For fifty dollars, its algorithm would analyze any music file Novak uploaded. Potential hits earned high scores, duds got low ones.

“我的意思是，为了五十美元——想想长远来看意味着什么，这笔钱真是少得可怜，”诺瓦克说。“所以我就这么做了。”

“I mean, for fifty dollars—it was such a small amount of money when you think about what it could mean in the long run,” Novak says. “So I did it.”

诺瓦克几年前写了一首歌，名叫《Turn Your Car Around》，他认为这首歌很有潜力。他上传了这首歌，然后坐在屏幕前等待结果。

Novak had written a song a few years before called “Turn Your Car Around” that he believed held significant potential. He uploaded the song and sat at his screen, waiting for a result.

诺瓦克十二岁开始写歌，十几岁时开始弹吉他。二十五六岁时，他已经全身心投入到歌曲创作中，放弃了大部分社交生活，以便晚上和周末待在家里创作音乐。他花了3000美元买了电脑和一些中档录音设备，把一间空余的卧室布置成了他的音乐巢穴。他在壁橱里铺了些旧棉被，把他最好的麦克风放在中央。这就是他录制《Turn Your Car Around》的录音棚。

Novak began writing songs when he was twelve and started playing the guitar in his late teens. He’d become so dedicated to songwriting by the time he was in his midtwenties that he’d forgone much of a social life so he could stay home on nights and weekends working on his music. He spent $3,000 on computers and midgrade recording equipment to outfit a spare bedroom as his music lair. He lined the closet with old comforters and positioned his best microphone in the center. This was the sound booth where he recorded “Turn Your Car Around.”

最终，网站启动了，诺瓦克得到了答案。网站背后的算法使用数字量表对歌曲进行评分。任何超过6.5分的歌曲都具有不错的热门潜力。任何超过7分的歌曲都可能成为流行音乐排行榜的热门歌曲。诺瓦克的歌曲获得了7.57分——与许多史上最伟大的摇滚金曲一样高的算法评分，例如草原狼乐队的《天生狂野》和老鹰乐队的《宁静轻松》。

Finally, the Web site whirred to life with an answer for Novak. The algorithm behind the site used a number scale to rate songs. Anything more than 6.5 had decent hit potential. Anything past 7 had a hook made for the pop charts. Novak’s song scored a 7.57—as high as the algorithm had scored many of the biggest rock hits of all time, such as “Born to be Wild” by Steppenwolf and “Peaceful Easy Feeling” by the Eagles.

“当然，我当时真的很高兴，”诺瓦克说，“但接下来会发生什么，我并不清楚。”

“I was really happy, obviously,” says Novak. “But it wasn’t really clear what came next.”

在Polyphonic HMI的西班牙总部，负责维护算法的计算机工程师注意到了这首歌的高分。他们从服务器上下载了这首歌，并在办公室里播放。

In Spain, where Polyphonic HMI was based, the computer engineers who maintained the algorithm took note of the song for its high score. They pulled it down off the server and played it in the office.

“这首歌显然很有意思，”公司负责人迈克·麦克雷迪说道。“我们的人一遍又一遍地播放这首歌。”麦克雷迪自己也是一名音乐家，他联系了欧洲的一些唱片公司，让这首歌广为流传。

“There was clearly something there,” says Mike McCready, who ran the company. “Our guys played it over and over again.” A musician himself, McCready called some recording label contacts in Europe and got the song circulating.

在将歌曲提交到麦克雷迪的网站大约两周后，诺瓦克的电话响了。是阿什·豪斯的代表打来的。豪斯是英国一位音乐制作人，手头有几十首热门歌曲。他有一位年轻的英国流行歌手李·瑞安，需要更多歌曲来充实他的专辑。豪斯觉得诺瓦克的歌很适合。事实上，他认为这首歌可以作为一首单曲。

About two weeks after he submitted his song on McCready’s Web site, Novak’s phone rang. It was a representative for Ash Howes, a music producer in the United Kingdom with a few dozen hits in his pocket. He had a young British pop star, Lee Ryan, who needed more tracks to fill out his album. Howe thought Novak’s song would fit in well. In fact, he thought it could be a single.

诺瓦克很快同意了一项优惠协议：当这首歌在电台、电视或广告中播放时，他将获得50%的版税。诺瓦克的歌曲不仅收录在瑞恩的专辑中，还被指定为专辑的首支单曲。这首歌首发即空降英国流行音乐排行榜第12位，并连续两个月成为英国播放次数最多的歌曲。它在欧洲大陆也同样表现不俗，电台广泛播放，并被拍成广告。在意大利，这首歌更是攀升至第二位。

Novak quickly agreed to a favorable deal: he would get 50 percent of all royalties when the song was played on the radio, on TV, or in an advertisement. Novak’s song not only went on Ryan’s album but was also designated the CD’s first single. The song debuted at No. 12 on the English pop charts, and for two months in a row it was the most played song in the UK. It fared just as well on the European continent, where radio played it extensively and it cracked into a few advertisements. In Italy, the song ascended to No. 2.

成功改变了诺瓦克的人生。他拿出部分版税收入，偿还了一系列投资的租赁房产。他购置了更好的录音设备，更新了乐器收藏。然而，直到写这篇文章的时候，他还有一件事没做：换掉那辆老款日产。“它开起来还不错——而且我以后再也不会关掉BBC了，”他说。

The success changed Novak’s life. He took some of his royalty proceeds and paid off a series of rental properties he had invested in. He bought better recording equipment and updated his instrument collection. There’s one thing he didn’t do, however, even by the time of this writing: replace that old Nissan. “It still drives just fine—and I’ll never turn the BBC off at this point,” he says.

诺瓦克毫不避讳地称赞算法。音乐界就是这样一个世界，一点点运气就能成就一位艺术家，也能让他们被人发现。而那些能够嗅出天赋的算法可以改变这一切。“对于任何涉足音乐界的人来说，这整个行业都是一场巨大的赌博，”他说，“这个程序，这个网站——它帮我安排好了一切。”

Novak isn’t shy about crediting an algorithm. The music world is one in which a hair’s width of luck can make an artist or keep them from being discovered. Algorithms that sniff out talent can change that. “This whole music thing is just a huge gamble for anybody who goes into it,” he says. “This program, this Web site—it aligned the planets for me.”

改变诺瓦克人生的算法是由一群西班牙工程师设计的，负责人是麦克雷迪，他是一位美国人，走上了一条奇特的道路，成为改变音乐未来的技术权威。

The algorithm that changed Novak’s life was devised by a group of engineers in Spain headed by McCready, an American who took an odd path to becoming an authority on the technology that’s changing the future of music.

麦克雷迪在内布拉斯加州的乡村长大，他说，要么永远离开，要么永远留在那里。1986年，高中毕业的麦克雷迪第一次有机会离开，尽管这次只是暂时离开。他参加了一个交换项目，离开内布拉斯加州九个月，寄宿在巴塞罗那郊外一个小村庄的一户人家。回国后，他进入奥马哈的克莱顿大学学习，主修心理学。大学毕业后，麦克雷迪觉得自己有两个选择。“我可以回到内布拉斯加州的乡村，也可以回到巴塞罗那，”他说。

McCready grew up in rural Nebraska, a place that, he says, you either leave forever or stay forever. In 1986, as a high school senior, McCready was presented with his first chance to leave, albeit just temporarily in this case. He participated in an exchange program in which he left Nebraska for nine months to board with a family in a small village outside of Barcelona. When he returned, he headed to college at Creighton University in Omaha, where he majored in psychology. As he wrapped up his university years, McCready felt he had two choices. “I could go back to rural Nebraska or go back to Barcelona,” he says.

麦克雷迪回到了西班牙。然而，在那里找工作却和在内布拉斯加州的农业小镇一样困难。西班牙政府没有给麦克雷迪发放工作许可，所以他既不能合法工作，也不能获得报酬。为了赚钱，他不得不自己做生意。起初，他辗转于各种零工之间，直到一个想法突然闪现。

McCready returned to Spain. Getting a job there, however, proved as difficult as it might have been in a Nebraska farm town. The Spanish government didn’t grant McCready a work permit, so he couldn’t legally hold a job or get paid. To make money, he had to go into business for himself. Early on, he bounced from odd job to odd job until an idea struck him.

麦克雷迪学生时代曾在西班牙的加泰罗尼亚语区生活过。此外，在法国、意大利以及安道尔等国的部分地区，加泰罗尼亚语（一种罗曼语）也是主要语言。世界上约有一千一百万加泰罗尼亚语使用者，他们表达时间的方式各不相同。1 :15绝不会说成1:15，而是说成2点15分。加泰罗尼亚语使用者不会把1:20说成1:20，而是说成2点15分5分。 “而且，随着时间的流逝，表达方式变得越来越奇怪，”麦克雷迪说道。

As a student, McCready had spent his time in a Catalan-speaking region of Spain. There are also tracts of France, Italy, and an entire country, Andorra, where Catalan, a Romance language, is the main tongue. The eleven million or so Catalan speakers in the world have unique ways of expressing the time. It’s never one-fifteen for 1:15. It’s one-quarter of two o’clock. Catalan speakers don’t say one-twenty for 1:20. They say it’s one-quarter and five minutes of two o’clock. “And it just gets stranger as you go around the dial,” McCready says.

麦克雷迪和一位朋友设计了一种表盘，能够像加泰罗尼亚语一样显示时间。他凑了几千美元，在法国找到了一家生产这种手表的工厂。五个月后，这家小手表公司开始盈利。不久之后，这些手表在西班牙掀起了一股时尚热潮，名流纷纷佩戴。麦克雷迪推出了新的限量版设计，几天之内就销售一空。

With a friend, McCready developed a design for a watch dial that expressed time in the same way it was spoken in Catalan. He scraped together a few thousand dollars and found a factory in France that would make the watches. After five months, the little watch company was profitable. Not long after that, the watches became a fashion sensation in Spain. Celebrities wore them. McCready issued new limited-edition designs that would sell out in days.

麦克雷迪一生致力于音乐创作，在创办自己的钟表事业的同时，他也保持着自己的爱好。他曾与一支布鲁斯乐队合作，这支乐队在巴塞罗那逐渐积累了一批乐迷，并最终与西班牙一家大型唱片公司签约。然而，就在乐队开始筹备录音棚录制时，乐队突然解散，成员们的个人问题也同时爆发。乐队用英语演唱歌曲，而麦克雷迪则一直在用加泰罗尼亚语独自录制歌曲。乐队的命运明朗后，他找到了唱片公司，提出了自己的个人创作。唱片公司很喜欢他的个人作品，并签下了他。

McCready, who had been a musician his entire life, kept his hobby alive while putting his watch venture together. He played with a blues band that began to build a flock of fans in Barcelona, and eventually landed a contract with one of Spain’s major labels. But as the band started putting their studio sessions together, it suddenly broke up, the members’ personal issues all exploding at the same time. The band sang its songs in English, but McCready had been recording tunes on his own in Catalan. Once the band’s fate became clear, he went to the record label and offered up his solo work. They liked it and signed him on.

麦克雷迪的两首歌曲荣登加泰罗尼亚音乐排行榜榜首。加泰罗尼亚市场或许不大，但这一成功让麦克雷迪成为了一股不容小觑的音乐力量，而他手表的故事在西班牙也成为了一个营销传奇。这些因素促使他被一家接管了1992年巴塞罗那夏季奥运会场馆的公司聘用。这家公司需要一位能够找到新方法来填补观众席的营销总监。这些场馆已经成了耗资巨大的“白象”，资金匮乏，举办的活动数量也少得可怜，难以维持运营。

Two of McCready’s songs went to the top of the Catalan charts. It may have been a small market, but the success branded McCready as a legitimate music force, while the story of his watches had become something of a marketing legend in Spain. That combination led to his recruitment by the company that had taken over the venues built and used for the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona. They wanted a marketing director who could find new ways to fill the seats. The stadiums had become white elephants that burned through cash and held too few events to justify their operations.

麦克雷迪成功地邀请大型巡演和音乐会在场馆演出。但即使大型演出来袭，通常也只持续一天；一次性收入固然不错，但场馆需要更稳定的收入来源。于是，麦克雷迪开始说服乐队在巴塞罗那开启巡演，这意味着他的场馆通常会进行一到两周的排练，外加几场开幕演出。这个计划奏效了，巴塞罗那成为了欧洲最时尚的乐队巡演举办地。然而，就在麦克雷迪让场馆公司盈利之际，硅谷的科技热潮席卷了西班牙。

McCready successfully courted big touring acts and concerts to play at the venues. But even when a big show came to town, it was usually just for one day; the onetime income was nice, but the venues needed something steadier. So McCready started convincing bands to open their tours in Barcelona, which meant his venues would usually host a week or two of rehearsals plus a couple of opening shows. The plan worked, as Barcelona became the hippest place in Europe for bands to launch their tours. But just as McCready got the venue company profitable, Silicon Valley’s tech boom wave reached Spain.

“我的朋友都靠互联网公司发财了——或者自以为发财了，”麦克雷迪说，“这似乎是我应该做的。”

“I had all these friends who were getting rich with Internet companies—or thought they were getting rich,” McCready says. “It seemed like the thing to do.”

这在2000年确实是个热门话题，麦克雷迪随后加入了一家名为Deo的在线音乐初创公司，担任市场营销主管。这家瑞典公司将自己定位为首个开放的音乐市场。音乐家和乐队可以将他们的音乐上传到Deo，然后直接出售给消费者。

It indeed was the thing to do in 2000, and McCready went to work as the head of marketing for an online music startup called Deo. The Swedish company fashioned itself as the first open marketplace for music. Musicians and bands could upload their music to Deo, where they could sell it directly to consumers.

和那个时代诞生的许多公司一样，Deo 充满了无限的乐观和雄厚的资金。但就像其他数百家初创公司一样，Deo 错误地判断了它的吸引力和市场。当时很少有人知道数字文件是什么，而那些知道的人很可能是通过 Napster 之类的网站非法获取的。

Like many companies born in that era, Deo had been infused with boundless optimism and a large pile of money. And just like hundreds of other startups, Deo had misjudged its appeal and market. Few people knew what a digital file was, and those who did were likely getting them illegally through sites like Napster.

一年后，Deo 资金耗尽，倒闭了。这段经历对 McCready 来说非常宝贵，因为他得以在音乐和科技的交汇点上度过了一年。

A year later, Deo ran out of cash and folded. The experience proved valuable for McCready as he got to spend a year at the crossroads of music and technology.

在那一年里，他遇到了巴塞罗那一家小型科技公司，这家公司开发了一种算法，用于分析流行音乐的底层结构、模式和架构。麦克雷迪与该公司的工程师们相处了一段时间，最终得出结论，这项技术确实有效。他提议成立一家围绕这项技术的新公司，专门面向音乐家和唱片公司。他们把这家公司命名为“复音”（Polyphonic）。

During that twelve months, he met a small tech firm in Barcelona that had developed an algorithm for analyzing the underlying structure, patterns, and architecture of popular music. McCready spent time with the company’s engineers and came to the conclusion that the technology actually worked. He proposed forming a new company built around the technology that would pitch to musicians and record companies. They called it Polyphonic.

Polyphonic 背后的算法会对输入的音乐进行奇妙的剖析。该公司算法背后的特殊科学被称为高级谱反卷积。不同的傅里叶变换序列和数学函数将歌曲分解，分离出曲调的旋律、节拍、速度、韵律、音高、和弦进行、声音饱满度、声音亮度和节奏的模式。Polyphonic 的软件利用这些数据构建三维模型。通过观察（而不是聆听）歌曲的三维结构，算法会尽可能客观地将歌曲与过去的热门歌曲进行比较。将一首刚刚分析过的歌曲与过去排名第一的歌曲一起放在屏幕上，会显示出一种云状结构，其中填充了代表歌曲的点。热门歌曲往往聚集成簇，从而揭示出它们相似的底层结构。接近其中一个热门歌曲簇的中间位置，虽然不能保证你一定能成功，但你的状态已经非常好了。

The algorithms behind Polyphonic work a wondrous dissection on the music they’re fed. The particular science behind the company’s algorithms is called advanced spectral deconvolution. Different sequences of Fourier transforms and mathematical functions break songs up, isolating tunes’ patterns of melody, beat, tempo, rhythm, pitch, chord progression, fullness of sound, sonic brilliance, and cadence. Polyphonic’s software takes this data and builds three-dimensional models with it. By looking at, instead of listening to, the song’s 3-D structure, the algorithm compares the song to hits of the past in as objective a way as is possible. Putting a just-analyzed song on the screen with No. 1 tracks of the past shows a kind of cloud structure filled in with dots representing songs. The hits tend to be grouped in clusters that reveal their similar underlying structures. Get close to the middle of one of those hit clusters and, while you’re not guaranteed success, you’re in very good shape.

当麦克雷迪在巴塞罗那完善算法时，他用他的机器人测试了尽可能多的待发行专辑。正是这些测试用例揭示了算法是否真的有效。算法将大多数未发行的CD评为平庸之作。但算法显示，其中一张CD在总共十四首歌曲中，包含了九首可能的热门歌曲。这可是披头士乐队的热门歌曲。麦克雷迪简直不敢相信。之前没人听说过这位艺术家，这让麦克雷迪担心机器人的预测完全错误。但后来，这张名为《Come Away with Me》的专辑发行了，销量超过两千万张，并为歌手诺拉·琼斯赢得了八项格莱美奖。2琼斯发现了这些星团。

When he was in Barcelona perfecting the algorithm, McCready ran as many to-be-released albums through his bot as possible. It was these test cases that would reveal if the algorithm had any real power. The algorithm rated most of the unreleased CDs as ho-hum. But one, the algorithm said, contained nine likely hits out of fourteen total songs. Those are Beatles numbers. McCready could hardly believe it. Nobody had heard of this artist, which made McCready worry that the bot was wildly wrong. But then the album, Come Away with Me, was released, selling more than twenty million copies and netting its artist, Norah Jones, eight Grammy Awards.2 Jones had found the clusters.

“有些人把一首热门歌曲比作一种脑部刺激，”麦克雷迪说，“而你通过一遍又一遍地听这首歌来满足这种刺激。”

“Some people describe a hit song as a brain itch,” McCready says. “And you scratch that itch by listening to the song over and over again.”

这些聚集点是最让人抓狂的地方，麦克雷迪认为他的公司找到了识别金曲的秘诀。音乐界已经尝试过自己挑选热门歌曲，但准确率只有20%。如果麦克雷迪的工具有效，它将成为音乐界的圣杯。

The clusters were the itchiest spots, and McCready thought his company had struck upon the formula for identifying musical gold. The music industry already tried to pick its own hits, but it was only right 20 percent of the time. McCready’s tool, if it worked, would be the industry’s holy grail.

A&R 机器人说我什么都没听到

THE A&R BOT SAID I DON’T HEAR A SINGLE

Polyphonic 的探索之路并非一帆风顺。一家名为 Savage Beast 的初创公司也志在必得，尽管它采用了截然不同的方法。Savage Beast 并没有使用算法筛选新音乐，而是雇佣了数百名音乐人聆听歌曲，并根据四百种不同的属性进行分类。该公司最初尝试将产品出售给 Sam Goody、Tower Records 和百思买等实体音乐商店。但随着 MP3 共享软件的盛行，这一计划最终失败。互联网泡沫破灭后，Savage Beast 多年来一直举步维艰，甚至没有给员工发工资。3 2005年，它改变了策略，更多地使用算法，减少人工干预来决定人们应该听什么。随后，它筹集了一笔资金，并更名为潘多拉 (Pandora)。到2011年7月，该公司在纽约证券交易所上市，估值达30亿美元。

Polyphonic had company in its quest. A startup that called itself Savage Beast was out to do the same thing, although it employed starkly different methods. Instead of sorting through new music with an algorithm, Savage Beast employed hundreds of musicians to listen to songs and categorize them based on four hundred different attributes. The company first tried to sell its product to brick-and-mortar music stores such as Sam Goody, Tower Records, and Best Buy. But that plan tanked with the advent of rampant MP3 sharing. After the dot-com crash, Savage Beast ran on fumes for years, not even paying its employees.3 Then in 2005 it changed strategy, using more algorithms and fewer humans to decide what people should hear, raised a little money, and got a new name: Pandora. By July 2011, the company was trading on the New York Stock Exchange, valued at $3 billion.

Pandora 的起步模式截然不同，McCready 也是如此。他的第一个“黑客”项目允许像 Ben Novak 这样的艺术家以 50 美元的价格上传歌曲，并通过 Polyphonic 的算法即时获得歌曲潜力的反馈。唱片公司和星探随后可以登录他的网站，浏览得分最高的自由歌手。McCready 试图修复，或者至少是改进音乐产业中困扰艺术家和唱片公司数十年的一个环节。

Pandora started with a different paradigm, and so too did McCready. His first hack allowed artists such as Ben Novak to upload his song for fifty dollars and get instant feedback on its potential via Polyphonic’s algorithm. Record companies and talent scouts could then log in and browse the highest-scoring free agents on his site. McCready was trying to fix, or at least improve, a part of the music industry that had bedeviled both artists and record labels for decades.

汤姆·佩蒂1991年的歌曲《Into the Great Wide Open》中有一句著名的歌词，指的是唱片业相当于棒球星探的A&R（艺人与曲目）人员。唱片公司的A&R（艺人与曲目）人员是唱片业的守门人。他们可以成就音乐人的事业，将一位默默无闻的音乐人推向巨星。在流行音乐界，A&R人员的工作依赖于发掘单曲。正如汤姆·佩蒂讽刺地引用这句老生常谈的台词所暗示的那样，一个没有单曲的艺人，价值不高。

Tom Petty’s 1991 song “Into the Great Wide Open” features a well-known verse that refers to the record industry’s equivalent of a baseball talent scout: the A&R man. A&R (artists and repertoire) staff at record labels are the gatekeepers to the recording industry. They can make careers and launch a musician from obscurity to stardom. In the pop music world, A&R people’s jobs depend on finding singles. An artist without a single, as Tom Petty’s sardonic invoking of that cliché suggests, isn’t worth much.

一个问题是，A&R 本质上是一种主观交易。这可不是棒球；一个球探眼中的 100 英里/小时的快速球，对另一个球探来说也是 100 英里/小时的快速球。不可否认，这种天赋很容易被量化衡量。然而，音乐界的天赋无处不在。但并非所有音乐天赋都有潜力吸引大众。世界上一些最杰出的艺术家可能永远不会在小圈子之外出名。然而，也有一些艺术家，他们的音乐天赋可能不比一个普通的八岁钢琴演奏者深厚，却能凭借一首朗朗上口的流行歌曲征服世界。

One problem is that A&R is an inherently subjective trade. It’s not baseball; a 100 mph fastball to one scout is a 100 mph fastball to another. There’s no denying that kind of raw talent that can be quantitatively measured so easily. With music, however, talent exists everywhere. But not all musical talent has the potential to appeal to mass audiences. Some of the most brilliant artists in the world may never become known outside a small circle of fans. Yet other artists whose musical talent may not be deeper than that of an average eight-year-old piano player can take over the world with one catchy pop lick.

因此，音乐依然是一门与图书出版类似的生意。唱片公司依靠每五十张专辑中的一张来维持盈利，并证明他们为新签约艺人发放的签约奖金是合理的。只有广撒网，唱片公司才能确保获得所需的热门歌曲。那些挖掘出比平均水平更多“钻石”的A&R人员获得了丰厚的报酬。那些不断从默默无闻中挖掘出明星的人会成为传奇人物；这些“雨露均沾”的人往往会晋升为唱片公司的高管。

For that reason, music remains a business much like book publishing. The record labels depend on one album out of fifty to keep them profitable and justify the signing bonuses they dole out to new acquisitions. It’s only by casting a wide net that labels assure themselves of scoring the hits they need. A&R people who unearth more diamonds than average are well compensated. Those who consistently pluck stars from obscurity become legends; these rainmakers often ascend to become leading executives at the label.

尽管A&R团队一直在寻找有前途的艺人，但他们的签约大多来自个人关系或直接推荐。即使衡量一个人是否优秀，其成功率也远非唯才是举。但如果A&R能成为一门科学呢？只要30%的准确率，就能大大提升该行业的历史水平。而那些擅长取悦听众的艺人，也无需等待那些可能永远不会出现的随机联系或推荐。麦克雷迪认为，Polyphonic的算法或许能解答这个问题。

Even though A&R people are always hunting for promising artists, most of their signings come through personal relationships or direct referrals. The music business remains far from a meritocracy, even if merit is measured by the ability to hook teenage girls’ ears. But what if A&R could be made into a science? Being right just 30 percent of the time would be a giant improvement on the industry’s historical rate. And artists with a knack for pleasing listeners wouldn’t have to wait for that random connection or recommendation that may never come. Polyphonic’s algorithm, McCready thought, could prove the answer.

诺瓦克的成功让复调音乐公司（Polyphonic）似乎达到了一个很高的上限。麦克雷迪的工具还在公众对魔力红乐队（Maroon 5）一无所知之前，就认定该乐队很有可能取得成功。当然，这款软件并非事事准确。它给很多从未获得广泛关注的歌曲打了高分。但不可否认的是，麦克雷迪创造了一个行之有效的东西，一个可以塑造音乐产业未来的东西。

Novak’s success primed Polyphonic for what seemed like a high ceiling. McCready’s tool also identified Maroon 5 as an act carrying a high probability of success before the public had any idea who the band was. The software certainly wasn’t right about everything. It’s given high marks to heaps of songs that never gained traction with wide audiences. But there was no denying that McCready had created something that worked, something that could shape the future of the music industry.

尽管这项技术前景光明，A&R 的人员却不太愿意相信这种工具，因为如果它真的兑现承诺，可能会威胁到他们的工作。许多 A&R 人员和唱片公司高管都对机器在他们的世界里有任何立足之地嗤之以鼻。当维珍唱片的全球营销经理洛林·巴里 (Lorraine Barry) 谈及 Polyphonic 背后的工作和理念时，她嗤之以鼻。“现代的 A&R 人——一台机器，一个电脑程序？想想都有点吓人，”巴里说。“我认为这是一种营销策略。他们假装自己可以成为一门科学。”4

But despite the promise of the technology, A&R personnel weren’t too keen on giving credence to a tool that, if it lived up to its claims, would threaten their jobs. Many A&R people and recording executives laughed at the notion that a machine had any place in their world. When told about the work and ideas behind Polyphonic, Lorraine Barry, the global marketing manager at Virgin Records, scoffed. “The modern-day A&R man—a machine, a computer program? A bit of a frightening thought,” Barry said. “I think it’s a marketing ploy. It’s pretending that it can be a science.”4

这款软件是否将A&R游戏变成了一门科学，仍有待商榷。但不可否认的是，麦克雷迪的团队在业内并不受欢迎。音乐行业向来不以乐于接受改变而闻名。“我认为在这方面，他们最终略胜阿米什人一筹，”麦克雷迪说。

Whether the software has made the A&R game into a science will remain debatable. But there’s no denying that McCready’s crew wasn’t welcome within the industry. The music business isn’t renowned for being open to change. “I think it finishes just ahead of the Amish in that respect,” McCready says.

Polyphonic 背后的商业模式依赖于音乐行业将其作为一种新的 A&R 工具。事实证明，这个赌注是大胆的。尽管 Polyphonic 拥有如此神奇的魔力，却未能赚到任何钱。A&R 人员不愿采用这种可能加速自身消亡的方法。没有了他们的合作，Polyphonic 陷入了困境。麦克雷迪解雇了员工，并思考着自己从内布拉斯加州的农场男孩到手表大亨、流行歌星，再到如今的科技创始人，下一步该做什么。

The business model behind Polyphonic depended on the music industry utilizing it as a new A&R instrument. That bet proved cheeky. Polyphonic, for all its wizardry, wasn’t able to make any money. A&R people were loath to use a method that could hasten their own demise. Without their cooperation, Polyphonic floundered. McCready laid off staff and thought about what he’d do next after going from Nebraska farm boy to watch mogul to pop star and now tech founder.

麦克雷迪几乎无计可施，于是改变了模式。2008年，他搬到了纽约，与音乐界的关系变得更加融洽。他引入了新的投资者，并将自己的公司命名为“音乐X射线”（Music X-Ray）。和以前一样，他邀请艺人上传作品到他的网站和数据库，但现在，他还允许A&R人员和制作人在寻找新曲子或艺人时，发布真正的招聘启事。

With little to lose, McCready changed his model. In 2008 he moved to New York and became friendlier with the music industry. He recapitalized with new investors and dubbed his company Music X-Ray. Just as before, he invited artists to upload their work to his site and databases, but now he also allowed A&R men and producers to post veritable help-wanted signs when they might be looking for a new tune or artist.

唱片公司、广告公司、市场营销人员和音乐制作人通常都在寻找特定类型的声音。例如，一家唱片公司可能正在努力寻找下一个电台司令乐队（Radiohead），或者一家市场营销公司可能认为滚石乐队的《Brown Sugar》是他们电视广告的完美之选，但他们却无力支付滚石乐队那样的广告费。不出所料，当一家大型唱片公司的资深星探发布寻找新艺人的广告时，通常会收到铺天盖地的回复。电影制片人发布原创配乐或特定类型歌曲的广告配乐征集时，情况也是如此。音乐界人士会告诉你，他们非常忙碌。从随机音乐人提交的数千份作品中筛选——其中很多水平平庸甚至更差——通常不会影响他们的日常工作。这就是为什么成名艺术家往往能获得大部分新作品的原因。寻找新音乐人需要花费太多时间。

Music labels, advertising firms, marketers, and music producers are often looking for a certain kind of sound. For instance, a music label may be on a mission to find the next Radiohead, or a marketing firm may think the Rolling Stones’ “Brown Sugar” is the perfect song for their television spot, but they can’t afford to pay the kind of money the Stones command. Unsurprisingly, when a legitimate talent scout at a major label issues a query looking for new artists, there’s usually an avalanche of responses. The same goes for when a movie producer posts a request for an original score or a particular kind of song for a sound track. As people in the music business will tell you, they’re very busy. Wading through thousands of submissions from random musicians—many of them mediocre or worse—isn’t something that will often crack their daily agenda. This is why established artists tend to get the lion’s share of new work. Finding new musicians takes too much time.

这正是 McCready 算法的用武之地。它可以快速筛选出正确的声音，帮助音乐业内人士找到与其原始查询最接近的匹配。以《Brown Sugar》为例，该算法会梳理其已提交音乐的数据库，找出最能模仿滚石乐队在这首歌中所运用的即兴重复乐段、节奏、韵律、风格以及整体音效的曲目。

This is where McCready’s algorithm comes in. It can quickly sort the right sounds from the wrong ones, allowing a music industry insider to find the closest match to their original query. In the instance of “Brown Sugar,” the algorithm would comb its databases of submitted music for the tracks that best imitate the riffs, beat, rhythm, style, and overall sound the Rolling Stones struck in that song.

或者，A&R 人员也可以简单地从上传到 Music X-Ray 的艺术家中寻找不同类型的最高得分歌曲。McCready 的数据库每周都在增长。它正迅速成为世界音乐人才的百科全书，这对像 Ben Novak 这样的音乐家来说是一个令人振奋的发展，他们尽管努力尝试，才华横溢，但仍担心自己的作品和声音可能永远无法走出车库。我们未来的许多音乐明星很有可能是由 Music X-Ray 的算法打造的。事实上，这已经发生了。自 2010 年以来，McCready 已经为 5,000 多名艺术家提供了与唱片公司和其他商业渠道合作的机会。

Or A&R people can simply look for the highest-scoring songs within different genres from the artists who have uploaded to Music X-Ray. McCready’s warehouse of data grows larger each week. It’s quickly becoming an encyclopedia of world musical talent, a heartening development for musicians out there, such as Ben Novak, who, as hard as they try and as talented as they may be, fear their work and sound may never make it out of their garage. It’s more than possible that many of our future music stars will be produced by Music X-Ray’s algorithm. It’s already happening, in fact. Since 2010, McCready has landed more than five thousand artists opportunities with music labels and other commercial outlets.

汤米·博茨（Tommy Botz）就是这样一位音乐家，他63岁，正在戒酒，偶然发现了网络上的Music X-Ray。博茨曾在戒酒中心住了七年，期间创作了两百首歌曲中的一部分，其中一些他决定上传到Music X-Ray。麦克雷迪的算法发现博茨的音乐是对约翰尼·卡什（Johnny Cash）式曲调的原创演绎，并将他与一家密歇根州的唱片公司联系起来，这家唱片公司的艺人曾剪辑过他的几首歌曲。

One such musician, Tommy Botz, was a sixty-three-year-old recovering alcoholic who stumbled into Music X-Ray on the Web. Botz had been living in a rehab center for seven years, during which he wrote some of his two hundred songs, some of which he decided to upload to Music X-Ray. McCready’s algorithm spotted Botz’s music as an original take on Johnny Cash–like tunes and connected him with a Michigan label whose artists cut several of his songs.

博茨并非个例。六个孩子的祖母琳恩·弗格森 (Lynne Ferguson) 凭借在 Music X-Ray 上发布的歌曲《Tears to Gold》引起了 Atrium Music Group 的注意。这家厂牌共收录了弗格森的十一首歌曲，并发行了一张专辑，封面上就印着弗格森的笑脸。独立音乐人也通过 McCreary 的机器人获得了成功。World Live Music & Distribution 在 Music X-Ray 上发现了多米尼克·戈麦斯 (Dominic Gomez)，并立即与他签约，并提供了数十万美元的录音预算。电影制片厂也在积极寻找这块市场。2011 年，由斯派克·李 (Spike Lee) 监制的电影《You're Nobody 'Til Somebody Kills You》就从 Music X-Ray 上找到的艺术家中挑选了三首歌曲作为配乐。

Botz isn’t an outlier. Lynne Ferguson, a grandmother of six, got the attention of the Atrium Music Group with her song “Tears to Gold” on Music X-Ray. The label picked up a total of eleven of Ferguson’s songs and put out an album, Ferguson’s smiling face right on the cover. Indie acts have found success through McCreary’s bot as well. World Live Music & Distribution discovered Dominic Gomez on Music X-Ray and immediately signed him to a deal and a recording budget for hundreds of thousands of dollars. Movie studios are fishing the waters too. The Spike Lee–produced 2011 film You’re Nobody ’Til Somebody Kills You plucked three songs for its score from artists found on Music X-Ray.

作为撮合双方的回报，Music X-Ray 可以从交易中获得一小部分分成。收入正在逐渐增加。McCready 摆脱了亏损，并打造出了一个深受音乐行业欢迎的平台。截至 2011 年底，已有 1500 家唱片公司和其他专业音乐收购机构使用他的算法，其中包括几乎所有主流唱片公司，例如哥伦比亚、时代华纳、格芬唱片和百代唱片。

In exchange for putting the two parties together, Music X-Ray gets a small piece of the transaction. The revenue is starting to add up. McCready has rid his business of red ink and built something that the music business has embraced. At the end of 2011, there were fifteen hundred record labels and other professional acquirers of music using his algorithm, including those from almost every major house, including Columbia, Time Warner, Geffen, and EMI.

“我终于收到唱片公司的热情来信了，”麦克雷迪说。他认为，某种程度上总会有人类的决策者，但他的机器人及其对流行度集群的感知最终会改变公众最终听到的歌曲。

“I’m finally getting love letters from record labels,” McCready says. There will always be human decision makers at some level, he thinks, but his bot and its feel for the clusters of popularity will eventually change who the public ultimately hears.

McCreary 的模式为音乐行业带来了效率的提升和艺术家的拓展，因此，主流唱片公司（实际上是所有唱片公司）最终都会依赖算法来挑选签约音乐人和推广歌曲，这只是时间问题。这就像文字处理器刚面世时一样。起初，大多数人只能敲打打字机，因为只有早期使用者才能忍受文字处理器的小屏幕、糟糕的打印输出，以及将所有作品都保存在五英寸软盘上而不是放在可以看得见、拿在手里的纸上所带来的恐惧。但最终，屏幕越来越大，软件越来越好，使用其他任何工具都变得毫无意义。音乐界的这一天即将到来。

The efficiencies and the new breadth of artists that McCreary’s model opens up to the music industry are such that it’s only a matter of time until the major labels—all labels, really—come to rely on an algorithm to pick the musicians they sign and the songs they market. It’s akin to when word processors first hit the market. At first, most people kept banging on their typewriters, as only the early adopters could see past the processors’ small screens, funky printouts, and the scary idea of keeping all of one’s work on a five-inch floppy disk rather than on paper that could be seen and held. But eventually, screens got bigger, the software got better, and the idea of using anything else became nonsensical. That day is coming to the music world.

这对音乐来说是好事吗？对普通的A&R（艺人与作品）来说肯定不是什么好事。但对于那些默默无闻或人脉不广的艺人呢？算法能给我们带来更好的Top 40榜单吗？答案很可能是否定的。算法或许能带来新的艺人，但由于它们的判断建立在过去的流行音乐之上，我们最终可能会得到一些和我们已有的一样容易被遗忘的流行音乐。多年来那些平庸的音乐都被纳入分析范围，这显然是技术的缺陷。

Will that be a good thing for music? It certainly won’t be a good thing for the average A&R man. But what about artists who are off the radar or not well connected? Will algorithms bring us a better Top 40? The answer is probably no. Algorithms may bring us new artists, but because they build their judgment on what was popular in the past, we will likely end up with some of the same kind of forgettable pop we already have. It’s a clear foible of the technology that all these years of so-so music are included in its analysis.

然而，麦克里里却不这么认为。他像任何一位企业家一样，希望他的算法在未来几十年成为音乐界的中心，但他表示，算法的存在将引领我们走向更加多样化的热门榜单，而不是更少。他表示，那些拥有另类音乐风格的艺术家，他们的歌曲实际上因为其潜移默化的节拍、旋律和韵律而接近热门榜单，现在将被人们发现，而不是被忽略。麦克里里还可以帮助制作人和艺术家通过调整节奏、节拍和节奏，使他们的作品更接近热门榜单。或许有一天，我们会看到车库乐队即兴创作一首曲目，然后跑到笔记本电脑屏幕前，看看这个版本在热门榜单的3D世界中表现如何。在创意领域，如此迅速的确认实属罕见。但这也引出了一个问题：算法不会导致音乐多样性的爆发，反而会导致音乐世界被迫同质化吗？

McCreary, though, thinks otherwise. He hopes, as any entrepreneur would, that his algorithm will be at the center of the music world in the coming decades, but he says that its presence will lead us toward hit charts of more variety, not less. Artists with alternative sounds whose songs actually land near hit clusters because of their just-below-the-surface beats, melodies, and cadences will now be found rather than dismissed, he says. McCready can also help producers and artists move their work closer to hit clusters by tweaking rhythms, beats, and tempos. It’s likely that one day we’ll see garage bands jamming out a track and then scrambling over to a laptop screen to see how that version fared in the 3-D world of hit clusters. Such quick affirmation in a creative field is rare. But it also begs the question: rather than an explosion of variety, will algorithms lead to a music world of forced homogenization?

事实是，榜单前40名的热门歌曲中，很大一部分出自同一群人之手。例如，马丁·桑德伯格，这位瑞典词曲作者，艺名马克斯·马丁，在20世纪90年代开始了自己的音乐生涯，当时他为邦·乔维、后街男孩​​和布兰妮·斯皮尔斯创作了一系列冠军单曲。自2008年以来，他创作了十多首冠军单曲和二十多首十大单曲，其中包括亚瑟小子的《DJ Got Us Fallin' in Love》和凯蒂·佩里的《I Kissed a Girl》。5鉴于某些人擅长为大众创作旋律——而且 Mike McCready 的算法早已掌握热门歌曲的普遍特征——我们很容易推测，流行音乐可能很快就会被机器人统治。唱片公司肯定会推出符合当下流行口味的作品——而没有什么比一个专门创作甜腻热门歌曲的算法更适合这项任务了。

It’s already true that a large chunk of the hits that populate the Top 40 were written by the same group of people. Martin Sandberg, for one, a Swedish songwriter who goes professionally by the name of Max Martin, got his start in the 1990s when he wrote a series of No. 1 hits for Bon Jovi, the Backstreet Boys, and Britney Spears. Since 2008, he’s written more than ten No. 1 hits and more than twenty Top 10 singles, including “DJ Got Us Fallin’ in Love” by Usher and “I Kissed a Girl” by Katy Perry.5 Knowing that particular humans are gifted at writing hooks for the masses—and knowing what Mike McCready’s algorithm already knows about the general characteristics of hit songs—it’s easy to speculate that popular music could soon be ruled by bots. It’s a certainty that record labels will serve up whatever the tastes of the day happen to be—and little could be better suited for such a task than an algorithm tuned to spin out saccharine hits.

巴赫机器人

THE BACH BOT

热门音乐集群不仅仅适用于流行音乐，它们也适用于昔日的大师——贝多芬、莫扎特、巴赫和亨德尔。麦克雷迪的软件展示了一些最受欢迎的交响曲是如何被划分成不同的集群的。虽然莫扎特和贝多芬对麦克雷迪用来计算这些音乐的电子设备或算法一无所知，但他们肯定明白，某些模式和节奏更能吸引公众。这就是为什么一些古典乐曲听起来相似的原因。一位音乐家的成功会引发其他音乐家的模仿，他们都在追求同一种声音——以及赞誉。因此，如果算法能够决定音乐的流行因素，无论是流行音乐还是古典音乐，那么它们是否有可能更进一步，创作出旨在取悦大众的新音乐？有些人有充分的理由相信，算法最终会创作出与人类一样优秀的音乐。其中最主要的信徒是加州大学圣克鲁斯分校名誉音乐教授大卫·科普。

Hit clusters don’t just apply to pop music. They’re relevant for the masters of yore as well—Beethoven, Mozart, Bach, and Handel. McCready’s software shows how some of the most popular symphonies fall into clusters of their own. While Mozart and Beethoven had no concept of the gadgetry or the algorithms McCready uses to figure this out, they most certainly understood that some patterns and rhythms had more power to appeal to the public. It’s why some classical pieces sound similar. One success by one musician begets imitation by others, all of them chasing that same kind of sound—and acclaim. So if algorithms can determine what makes music popular, be it pop or classical, is it possible that they can take the next leap and simply create new music designed to please? There are those who have good reason to believe that algorithms will come to compose music as fine as any human. Chief among those believers is University of California at Santa Cruz music professor emeritus David Cope.

科普运用算法创作交响乐、歌剧和清唱剧。他的音乐——或者更确切地说，是算法创作的音乐——如此优秀，甚至让一些音乐家感到恐惧，也让另一些人不禁思考：人类创作和机器创作的界限究竟在哪里？算法究竟在什么时候才能成为艺术家？

Cope uses algorithms to create symphonies, operas, and oratorios. His music—or rather, his algorithm’s music—has become so good that it scares some musicians and has others wondering, where is the line between human and machine creation? At what point does an algorithm become an artist?

这个问题是科普自20世纪80年代以来一直试图解答的。他认为，他现在越来越接近一个结论，而这个结论不会让那些希望在算法和人类创作之间划清界限的人感到满意。科普给他的音乐创作算法起了个人类的绰号，这更加剧了这种混乱的局面。他给自己的第一个机器人取名为艾美（Emmy）。

That’s a question that Cope has been trying to answer since the 1980s. He’s now getting ever closer, he thinks, to a conclusion that won’t please those who would prefer a clear divide between what algorithms and humans create. This muddled situation isn’t helped by the fact that Cope assigns his music-creating algorithms human monikers. He named his first bot Emmy.

当埃米创作的管弦乐作品如此震撼人心，以至于一些音乐学者都无法辨别其出自机器之手时，科普立刻树敌无数，这些人对他的作品不屑一顾，有时甚至会反对埃米作品的演奏。在德国的一次学术会议上，他的一位同行走到他面前，一拳打在他的鼻子上。每当科普的作品在古典音乐家的高层圈子里被讨论时，争吵就此爆发。加州大学圣克鲁兹分校的一些同事称科普为“铁皮人”，取自《绿野仙踪》中冷酷无情的魔法师角色。6

When Emmy produced orchestral pieces so impressive that some music scholars failed to identify them as the work of a machine, Cope instantly created legions of enemies who would give his work little due and, in some cases, would fight against Emmy’s pieces’ being performed. At an academic conference in Germany, one of his peers walked up to him and whacked him on the nose. Shouting matches often erupt when Cope’s work is discussed in the highest circles of classical musicians. Some of his colleagues at UC Santa Cruz call Cope “the Tin Man,” after the heartless Wizard of Oz character.6

科普的机器人可以将音符串在一起，交织出贝多芬般的力量或莫扎特般的细腻。机器能够创作出如此美妙的作品，对音乐界的许多人来说是一种威胁。“如果你一生中大部分时间都沉迷于这些已故作高贵的作曲家，而突然冒出一个蠢货，声称拥有一款软件，能以同样的方式打动你，你会突然问自己，‘这到底是怎么回事？’”科普说，“我正在破坏一些非常强大的关系。”

Cope’s bot can string together notes that weave in and out with the power of Beethoven or the finesse of Mozart. That a machine can produce things of such beauty is threatening to many in the music community. “If you’ve spent a good portion of your life being in love with these dead composers and along comes some twerp who claims to have this piece of software that can move you in the same way, suddenly you’re asking yourself, ‘What’s happened here?’” Cope says. “I’m messing with some very powerful relationships.”

艾美奖是科普多年艰苦学习、建设和重建的结晶。他的藏身之处位于圣克鲁斯，一个悠闲的海滨小镇，似乎远离科技界席卷而来的算法革命。然而，实际上，圣克鲁斯与世界上最密集的算法智能聚集地之间，唯一的屏障就是一条沿海山脉，而17号公路从硅谷蜿蜒而至海岸，三十英里便穿过了这条山脉。

Emmy was the culmination of years of arduous learning, building, and rebuilding for Cope, whose hideout in Santa Cruz, a laid-back beach town, seems far away from the algorithmic revolutions spreading from the tech world.
