In reality, however, the only thing separating Santa Cruz from the densest collection of algorithmic smarts in the world is a strip of coastal mountain range, which Route 17, as it courses from Silicon Valley to the coast, disposes of in thirty miles.

尽管音乐界许多人对他嗤之以鼻，科普却在计算机科学界获得了认可和认同。音乐家们竟然把科普斥为冷酷无情的科学家，这不禁让人觉得讽刺。这位加州教授首先是一位音乐家。科普最初的记忆是躺在地板上，凝视着一架大钢琴的底部，听着母亲的琴键。7

While many in the music community scorned him, Cope found acceptance and accord in the computer science world. That musicians would brush away Cope as a heartless scientist isn’t without irony. The California professor is a musician before all else. Cope’s first memory is of lying on the floor, gazing up at the bottom of a grand piano as his mother worked the keys.7

科普还在上小学时就迷上了柴可夫斯基、拉赫玛尼诺夫和斯特拉文斯基等作曲家的作品。十二岁时，他对自己创作音乐的前景充满了憧憬。最终，他前往洛杉矶，在南加州大学攻读音乐作曲研究生学位。

When he was still in grade school, Cope became hooked on composers like Tchaikovsky, Rachmaninoff, and Stravinsky. At the age of twelve, he was enthralled with the prospect of writing music himself. He eventually headed to Los Angeles for graduate school in music composition at the University of Southern California.

从南加州大学毕业后，科普于1973年在俄亥俄州牛津市的迈阿密大学找到了一份教职。这份工作让他有时间去做他一直认为自己命中注定要做的事情：作曲。他开始找到自己的风格，并得到了全世界的认可。从卡内基音乐厅到肯尼迪表演艺术中心，科普的原创作品在古典音乐界的一些顶级场所上演。他的乐谱甚至在国际上广为流传，被从秘鲁到波兰的众多管弦乐队演奏。

After USC, Cope landed a teaching gig at Miami University in Oxford, Ohio, in 1973. The job allowed him time to do what he always felt destined for: composing. He began to find his style and the world liked it. Cope’s original works were performed on some of the highest perches of classical music, from Carnegie Hall to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. His scores even spread internationally, being played by orchestras from Peru to Poland.

科普对音乐机器人的热爱始于他正在撰写的一本关于当代音乐的书的研究。他原本计划在其中加入一章来探讨计算机生成音乐这一新兴领域，但他觉得自己对计算机作曲了解甚少。于是，他选择了一条最艰难的道路：决定自己用电脑创作音乐，而不是简单地采访其他人。

Cope’s love affair with musical bots began with research on a book he was writing about contemporary music. He had planned to include a chapter on the new field of computer-generated music, but he felt he knew too little about computer composition. So he chose the thorniest path he could, deciding to make music on the computer himself rather than simply interviewing others on the process.

科普当然不是第一个将算法应用于音乐创作的人。公元1025年，阿雷佐的圭多（Guido of Arezzo）发明了一种自动将文本转换为和声的方法。他设计了一套规则，可以将看似毫无意义的杂乱信息（例如书面文字）转换成耳朵可以接受的内容。8十七世纪，曾为亨德尔的才华而潸然泪下的约瑟夫·海顿，发明了一种名为“音乐之锤”的游戏，通过掷骰子来决定乐曲的节拍。包括莫扎特在内的众多大师都曾尝试过这种方法。9 20 世纪 50 年代，伊利诺伊大学的两位研究人员 Lejaren Hiller 和 Leonard Isaacson 使用当时世界上速度最快的超级计算机 ILLIAC 计算机创建了所谓的Illiac Suite。

Cope certainly wasn’t the first to put algorithms to work making music. Guido of Arezzo in 1025 invented a method to automatically convert text into harmonies. He devised a set of rules that could take a seemingly meaningless jumble, like written words, and convert them to something bearable on the ears.8 In the seventeenth century, Joseph Haydn, the man who wept at the brilliance of Handel, conjured a game called Musikalisches Würfelspiel, wherein rolled dice determined measures in a piece. A bevy of masters, including Mozart, dallied with this method.9 In the 1950s, two researchers at the University of Illinois, Lejaren Hiller and Leonard Isaacson, used the ILLIAC computer, at the time the fastest supercomputer in the world, to create what they called the Illiac Suite.

但为了用现代机器按照自己的想法创作音乐，科普找不到用户手册。于是，他忙于学习当时的编程语言 Fortran、Pascal 和 Algo。为了编写代码并检查工作，他争分夺秒地在一台房间大小的 IBM 大型机上工作。计算机会按顺序输出打孔卡片，卡片上布满了孔，代表着科普的工作。然后，他会将打孔的数字转换成音高和音符，最后把乐谱拿到钢琴上，看看他到底创作了什么。

But to use modern machines to create music in the way he intended, Cope found no user manuals. So he busied himself with learning Fortran, Pascal, and Algo, the programming languages of the day. To compile his code and check his work, he fought for time on a room-sized IBM mainframe. The computer would spit out, in order, punch cards peppered with holes denoting the work Cope had done. He would then translate the numerical punches into pitches and notes before finally taking the score sheets to a piano to find out just what he’d created.

“我最终创作出了一首非常糟糕的合唱音乐，我宁愿不谈论它，”他说。

“I ended up producing an absolutely dreadful piece of choral music that I’d rather not talk about,” he says.

不管这首曲子是否糟糕，它都是在计算机处理器的帮助下创作的，因此科普成为了算法作曲这一尚处于萌芽阶段的领域中名副其实的权威。他撰写了章节，完成了整本书。在音乐学术领域，创作出新颖、创新且引人入胜的作品实属不易，而这本书引起了世界各地同行的关注。他接到了数十个电话，希望他能在其他大学担任教授。其中最持久的电话来自加州大学圣克鲁兹分校的音乐系，他们安排科普前往加州参加面试，并说服他在1977年搬来。

Dreadful or not, the piece had been composed with the help of a computer processor, so Cope became a legitimate authority on the still young subject of algorithmic composition. He wrote his chapter and finished the book. Creating something new, innovative, and intriguing within the academic field of music is hard to do, and the book drew the attention of his peers across the world. He fielded dozens of calls about taking professorial seats elsewhere. The most persistent rings came from the music department at UC Santa Cruz, which got Cope out to California for an interview and convinced him to move in 1977.

这位作曲家兼程序员在新大学安顿下来，很快就全力以赴地工作，教学和创作音乐，不断获得赞誉。然而，1981年，科普的创作之路却遭遇了阻碍。他曾签约创作一部歌剧，但却发现自己的音乐创作灵感枯竭了。他连续几个月盯着钢琴键和空白的纸张。他本想把歌剧的钱还回去，但“我已经把钱全花光了，”他说。他有四个年幼的儿子，工资微薄。

The composer-programmer settled in at his new college and was soon working at full capacity, teaching and writing music that continued to harvest acclaim. In 1981, however, Cope’s prolific ways were stymied. He had been contracted to write an opera, but found his brain’s well of music creativity dry. He stared at piano keys and blank pages of paper for months. He would have just given the money for the opera back, but “I had already spent all of it,” he says. He had four young boys and a modest paycheck.

科普茫然无措，心想或许可以通过引入计算机来打破僵局。于是，他开始旁听斯坦福大学和加州大学圣克鲁兹分校的计算机科学课程，并在图书馆里度过漫长的时光，钻研那些他直到第二遍才开始理解的编程书籍。在学习的某个阶段，他确信自己应该使用一种名为 Lisp 的语言进行编程，这是计算机科学领域最先进的语言之一。

At a loss, Cope thought he could perhaps end the stalemate by including a computer in his efforts. So he began sitting in on computer science courses at Stanford and UC Santa Cruz and spending long stretches in the library, poring over programming books that he would only begin to understand on the second pass. At some point in his studies, he became convinced he should be programming in a language called Lisp, one of the most advanced languages in computer science.

“没人告诉我这很艰难，所以我不知道这很艰难，”科普说。

“Nobody told me it was tough, so I didn’t know it was tough,” Cope says.

他开始这个项目的目标是复制自己的作曲风格，以便能以客户期望的方式完成歌剧。但他发现这个目标很模糊。他的风格是什么？这在编程上很难实现。于是，他决定构建一个程序，模仿终极大师约翰·塞巴斯蒂安·巴赫更为严谨的风格。他的黑客项目进行了一年，他的程序能够创作出合唱曲，虽然比他20世纪70年代的作品更胜一筹，但“效果并不好”，他回忆道。

He had begun the project with the goal of replicating his own composing style, so that he could complete the opera in a fashion his client would expect. But he found that mission amorphous. What was his style? It was a difficult thing to program. So he decided to build his program to mimic the more regimented style of the ultimate master: Johann Sebastian Bach. A year into his hacking project, his program was able to create chorales that, while they bested his effort from the 1970s, “weren’t very good,” he recalls.

这位音乐教授坚持不懈。科普建立了一个系统，对数百首巴赫众赞歌进行采样，并“学习”巴赫在创作他最动人乐曲时所使用的模式。这项工作非常繁琐。他的算法采样的每一小段音乐都需要格式化为计算机可以理解的更小的数据块。今天的音乐采样技术在 20 世纪 80 年代初甚至还未普及。为了将音乐转换成计算机代码，科普需要手动将乐谱上的每个音符和和弦翻译成原始数字。每个音符需要五个数字的代码，分别代表时间、音高、时值、声道（乐器）和响度或振幅。翻译一首乐曲可能需要数周时间。科普通常会花费六个月的时间来转录数据，以期获得一组结果。

The music professor kept at it. Cope built systems that sampled hundreds of Bach chorales and “learned” the patterns Bach used when composing his most moving pieces. The work was tedious. Each nibble of music his algorithm sampled needed to be formatted into smaller data pieces that made sense to the computer. The music-sampling technologies of today weren’t even whispers in the early 1980s. To get the music into computer code, Cope would translate each note and chord by hand from sheet music into raw numbers. Each note required five numbers of code, representing time, pitch, duration, channel (instrument), and loudness or amplitude. Translating one piece could take weeks. Cope would often spend six months transcribing data with the goal of netting one set of results.

将巴赫的才华分解成寥寥数字和一页页计算机乱码，科普深受触动。他不禁思考，这位天才真的能被简化到如此程度吗？真的存在巴赫算法吗？随着他的程序创作出越来越多的音乐，答案可能令人沮丧，也可能令人欣喜，这取决于个人视角。科普算法的作品开始呈现出巴赫的特质——模式、旋律和一致的节奏。

Breaking down Bach’s brilliance into mere digits and pages of computer garble affected Cope. Could the genius be simplified to such a level, he wondered? Could there really be a Bach algorithm? As his program created more and more music, the answer could be interpreted as deflating or wonderfully affirmative, depending on one’s perspective. The work of Cope’s algorithm began to take on characteristics of Bach—the patterns, the melodies, the congruent measures.

但有些不对劲。音乐听起来合情合理，和弦的变化恰如其分地发生在耳朵预期的时间。但音乐却缺乏一些活力。尽管音乐本身做得很好，却缺乏巴赫作品中那种活力。科普将更多音乐导入算法数据库，希望这种多样性能帮助算法取得突破。他反复研究代码，并反复修改。但似乎毫无进展。音乐依然毫无生气。

But something wasn’t right. The music made sense. The chord changes occurred when the ear expected. But the music lacked some essence of vitality. For all that it did right, the music didn’t carry the vigor that normally imbued Bach. Cope transferred even more music into the database of the algorithm, hoping that the variety would help it break through. He studied his code and rewrote it time and again. But nothing seemed to help. The music remained listless.

开发一个能够达到人类水平的程序似乎遥不可及。科普曾多次濒临精神崩溃。他坚信僵局难以解决，于是会连续几周放弃他的算法，发誓自己已经完成了。但他总是发现自己被电脑屏幕和他辛苦编写的数千行代码所吸引。

Building a program capable of human-level composition seemed as distant as ever. Cope had been driven to the edge of a nervous breakdown on several occasions. Convinced an impasse was intractable, he would walk away from his algorithm for weeks at a time, swearing he was done. But he always found himself drawn back to the computer screen and into the thousands of lines of code he’d so laboriously assembled.

有一天，科普出门办事，突然灵光一闪。或许问题不在于样本量，也不在于他编写的规则——或许问题在于他的算法过于遵循规则。伟大的作曲家的确会以过去的模式为基础进行创作，但他们之所以能够脱颖而出，是因为他们打破了音乐通常遵循的规则。巴赫的算法从未打破规则，因此它创作的音乐从未能够出乎意料地吸引听众的注意。科普又回到了 Lisp 语言，编写循环和随机函数，这些函数原本可以保持音乐的模式和结构，直到意外地打破节奏，迸发出高级人类作曲家的火花。

Out of the house on an errand one day, Cope was hit with a notion. Perhaps the problem wasn’t his sample size or the set of rules he’d written—maybe the problem was that his algorithm followed the rules too well. Great composers certainly create by building on the patterns of the past, but they become exceptional by breaking the rules their music usually obeys. The Bach algorithm never broke rules, hence it never made music that had the capacity to surprise or hook the listener’s ear. Cope dove back into Lisp, writing loops and random functions that would maintain patterns and structure in his music until unexpectedly breaking rhythm to lend the spark of an advanced human composer.

完成这项任务代表着科普算法作曲家的最后一条DNA。最终的程序知道如何创作节奏、小节、前奏和尾声。它能将缓慢柔和的音符与巴洛克式终曲的激昂隆隆声融合在一起。科普设计了一堆代码，一台机器，真正捕捉到了像约翰·塞巴斯蒂安·巴赫这样才华横溢的人物的精髓。

Completing this task represented the last strand of DNA for Cope’s algorithmic composer. The resulting program knew how to create rhythms, measures, intros, and endings. It could mix slow, gentle notes with the brash rumblings of a baroque finale. Cope had devised a pile of code, a machine, that truly captured the spirit of someone as brilliant as Johann Sebastian Bach.

科普意识到自己在七年后即将走到尽头，于是将自己的作品命名为“艾美”（Emmy），取自“音乐智能实验”（Experiments in Musical Intelligence）的缩写。1987年的一天，科普做了他经常做的事情——在午餐前，他启动了算法。当他回到电脑前时，艾美已经创作了五千首与巴赫风格极为接近的众赞歌。10

Sensing he was nearing some kind of ending seven years after he started, Cope named his creation Emmy, a play on the acronym for “Experiments in Musical Intelligence.” On a day in 1987, Cope did what he often did—he put the algorithm to work just before he left the office for lunch. When he returned to his computer, Emmy had created five thousand chorales that closely traced the style of Bach.10

巴赫作品首演于伊利诺伊大学厄巴纳分校主校区。当众赞歌的表演接近尾声时，观众们都惊呆了，鸦雀无声。这不可能是机器的杰作！观众们惊叹不已。在家乡圣克鲁斯举行的音乐节上，科普受到了数十位仰慕者的追捧，他们被这首乐曲深深震撼。与伊利诺伊的观众不同，他们并不知道这首乐曲是埃米创作的。当他们得知真相后，欢呼声四起，抱怨声不断，最后又是一片寂静。

The Bach pieces were first performed at the University of Illinois’s main campus in Urbana. As the chorales’ performance drew to a close, the audience sat in a stunned hush. Surely this couldn’t be the work of a machine! The crowd marveled. At a music festival in his hometown of Santa Cruz, Cope was approached by dozens of admirers who were blown away by the music. Unlike the Illinois crowd, they hadn’t known Emmy wrote it. When they found out, there were yells, complaints, and, again, stunned silence.

科普最终未能完成最初让他走上这条道路的歌剧。他把自己从20世纪70年代开始的大部分作品都提供给了艾米，然后算法开始塑造一部科普风格的歌剧。在算法的配合下，科普在一周内就创作完成了这部歌剧——此前他曾被困了六年。他最终完成了歌剧的创作。两年后，这部歌剧在弗吉尼亚州里士满进行了策划、排练和演出。当时，没有人知道艾米在这部歌剧中扮演的角色。这部歌剧获得了科普职业生涯中最引人入胜的评论。《里士满时报快报》评价道： “一个极致的戏剧性时刻，伴随着令人着迷的鼓点。”11

Cope had still never finished the opera that originally sent him down this road. He fed Emmy most of his work from the 1970s and the algorithm began to shape an opera in the style of Cope. Teaming up with the algorithm, he wrote the opera in a week—after six years of being stuck. He turned it in and two years later it was planned, rehearsed, and performed in Richmond, Virginia. Nobody at that time knew of Emmy’s role in the music. The opera garnered the most compelling reviews of Cope’s career. “A supreme dramatic moment, punctuated by the captivating beat of drums,” said the Richmond Times-Dispatch.11

事态的转变引出了一系列全新的问题：究竟是谁创作了这首乐曲——科普还是艾美？这位教授一直在苦苦思索这个问题，但最终，他推断，挖坑的功劳不在于铲子，而在于挖坑的人。然而，他承认自己看到了争论的双方。“作者是谁这个问题很难回答——而且从一开始就困扰着我，”他说。

This turn of events opened up a whole new set of questions: who truly created the music—Cope or Emmy? The professor has struggled with this question, but ultimately, he reasons, you don’t credit the shovel with digging the hole, you credit the digger. Yet he admits that he sees both sides of the argument. “The question of authorship is a difficult one to answer—and it’s one that’s plagued me from the beginning,” he says.

受人工智能领域轰动一时的名声鼓舞，科普开始为艾美奖寻找唱片合约。原本应该唾手可得的机会却变得异常艰难。古典唱片公司告诉科普，他们不做现代音乐。当代唱片公司也说他们不录制古典音乐。最终，科普终于拿到了唱片合约，却找不到高水平的艺术家来演奏，于是他被迫通过一台Disklavier（一种根据电子指令演奏的自动钢琴）来演奏。12

Encouraged by what was now earth-circling fame within the artificial intelligence world, Cope sought a recording contract for Emmy. What should have been a slam dunk proved immensely difficult. Classical music labels told Cope they didn’t do modern music. Contemporary recording labels said they didn’t record classical. When the record deal finally came, Cope could find no high-level artists who would play it, so he was forced to route it through a Disklavier, an automated piano that plays by electronic instruction.12

这张名为《电脑作曲的古典音乐》的专辑销量很好，同样重要的是，它给科普带来了很多工作。专辑里既有模仿巴赫的作品，也有模仿贝多芬、肖邦、拉赫玛尼诺夫、莫扎特、斯特拉文斯基的作品，甚至还有斯科特·乔普林的钢琴曲。

The album, Classical Music Composed by Computer, sold well and, just as important, landed Cope a lot of work. The recording included faux Bach as well as imitation Beethoven, Chopin, Rachmaninoff, Mozart, Stravinsky, and even a Scott Joplin piano tune.

这张专辑也成功地为科普赢得了一些音乐家在寻找艺术家录制唱片时不愿给予的尊重。很快，著名的古典演奏家们就联系上他，希望演奏科普认为艾美最杰出的作品。但这样的请求带来了一个问题：科普不知道该演奏哪首协奏曲。艾美已经创作了数千首类似的作品。这让音乐家们感到担忧。他们为什么要演奏一首仅仅是众多作品中的一首呢？艺术家们想要某种保证，确保他们演奏的是艾美最好的作品。但艾美可能在毫无征兆的情况下，明天就创作出更好的作品。音乐家们不想演奏如此容易被商品化的作品。

The album also succeeded in getting Cope some of the respect musicians wouldn’t grant him when he was seeking artists to record. Soon, famous classical performers were reaching out to him, hoping to play whatever Cope considered Emmy’s preeminent piece. But such requests posed a problem: Cope had no idea which concerto to offer up. Emmy had now created several thousand pieces of similar quality. This alarmed musicians. Why would they want to perform a piece that was merely one of many? Artists wanted something of a guarantee that they would be playing Emmy’s best. But Emmy could, with no warning, create something even better tomorrow. Musicians didn’t want to play something so easily commoditized.

这个话题差点让科普被音乐圈排斥。他认为，从巴赫到莫扎特再到贝多芬，所有多产的作曲家都在经营商品。科普说，他们根据一生中听过的音乐发展出各种模式。巴赫从未创造过全新的东西，科普说，他只是在前人的基础上循序渐进地进行创作。而且，他每次创作都会用类似的模式和构建方法重复这些步骤。科普坚持认为，这就是创造力——而这也恰恰描述了艾米所做的。这种认为古典大师不过是模式喷涌的算法的论断，在音乐界引发了意料之中的反应：拒绝科普、艾米以及他的作品。

This is a subject that has threatened to ostracize Cope from the musical herd. He argues that all prolific composers, from Bach to Mozart to Beethoven, dealt in commodities. They developed patterns, Cope says, that they based on music they had heard throughout their lifetimes. Bach was never creating something wholly new, says Cope, but simply building incrementally on those who came before him. And he would repeat those steps with similar methods of patterning and building when he created anything. That’s creativity, insists Cope—and it also exactly describes what Emmy did. This assertion that the classical masters were no better than pattern-spouting algorithms elicited the kind of response from the music world one would expect: rejection of Cope, Emmy, and his work.

但科普最终夺回了优势。1997年，在古典音乐界的广泛关注下，埃米在俄勒冈大学与两位强大的对手展开了激烈较量。学校的音乐理论教授史蒂夫·拉尔森参与了这次活动，他也是参赛选手之一。数百名观众聆听了三首钢琴曲的演奏，这三首曲子都模仿巴赫的作品：一首由埃米创作，一首由拉尔森创作，还有一首由巴赫本人创作。随后，观众投票选出每首曲子的真实来源。当拉尔森的作品被认定为计算机作品时，他的自尊心受到了打击。当观众认定埃米的作品才是这位已故音乐家的真正作品时，拉尔森不禁皱起了眉头。十三

But Cope would recapture the advantage. In 1997, with much of the classical music world paying attention, Emmy went head-to-head against two formidable opponents at the University of Oregon. Steve Larson, a professor of music theory at the school, helped put the event together. He also was one of the combatants. An audience of a few hundred people listened while three piano pieces, all meant to sound like Bach, were played, one composed by Emmy, one by Larson, and one by Bach himself. The audience then voted on the identity of each composition. Larson’s pride took a ding when his piece was fingered as that belonging to the computer. When the crowd decided that Emmy’s piece was the true product of the late musician, Larson winced.13

印第安纳大学认知科学教授道格拉斯·霍夫施塔特（Douglas Hofstadter）负责监督拉尔森、埃米和巴赫之间的竞赛。霍夫施塔特于1979年出版的著作《哥德尔、埃舍尔、巴赫：永恒的金缕》探讨了人工智能与音乐创作之间的关系，并因此荣获普利策奖。

Douglas Hofstadter, a professor of cognitive science at Indiana University, oversaw the competition among Larson, Emmy, and Bach. Hofstadter’s 1979 book Gödel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid contemplated artificial intelligence and music composition and was awarded the Pulitzer Prize.

霍夫施塔特当时说道：“艾美奖迫使我们去欣赏伟大的艺术作品，并思考它们来自哪里，以及它们的内涵到底有多深。”14

“Emmy forces us to look at great works of art and wonder where they came from and how deep they really are,” Hofstadter said at the time.14

在受控的学术环境中获胜后，艾美的知名度飙升，科普也一样。但随着请求和赞扬纷至沓来，嘲讽也随之而来。批评者们不断咆哮，机器无法像人类那样赋予音乐灵魂。斯坦福大学音乐与声学计算机研究中心的作曲家兼研究员乔纳森·伯杰是其中一位批评者，他说艾美知道音符的位置，但它无法赋予音乐人类作曲家的真正精髓。“科普所说的‘签名’和我所说的‘风格’之间有着巨大的差距，”他说。15

With a victory in a controlled, academic setting, Emmy’s profile soared, as did Cope’s. But as the requests and praised poured in, so did the scorn. A machine couldn’t bring the kind of soul to music that a person could, the critics kept on blaring. One detractor, Jonathan Berger, a composer and researcher at the Center for Computer Research in Music and Acoustics at Stanford, said Emmy knew where to put the notes, but it couldn’t give music the true essence of a human composer. “There is a big jump between what Cope calls signatures and I call style,” he said.15

塔夫茨大学哲学家兼认知科学家丹尼尔·丹尼特欣赏艾美奖的非凡成就，但仍认为机器无法与之匹敌。“科普的作品虽然精彩，但还是有些单薄，”他说。16丹尼特认为，用软件创作的作曲家对现实世界没有任何感觉，因此不知道如何通过音乐表达真实的感受。

Daniel Dennett, a philosopher and cognitive scientist at Tufts University, appreciated the marvel of Emmy, but still didn’t think a machine could compete. “As wonderful as Cope’s work is, there is something thin about it,” he said.16 A composer built from software has no sense of the real world and therefore no idea how to express true feelings through music, Dennett reasoned.

许多人对艾美奖的轻蔑态度开始让科普感到不安。他认为人们听到的只是他们想听的。科普发现，如果人们知道自己正在听的音乐是由一套计算机算法创作的，他们就不会让音乐影响自己。听众会说音乐创作得很好，但缺少了一些无形的灵魂。但当科普为人们播放同样的音乐，却不告诉他们它是从电脑处理器芯片中萌芽而出时，听众往往会陶醉于其中，并感叹音乐对他们的触动有多么深。

The dismissive attitude many held toward Emmy began to grind on Cope. He thought people heard what they wanted to hear. If people knew they were listening to music composed by a set of computer algorithms, Cope found they wouldn’t allow the music to affect them. The listeners would say the music was well composed, but missing some intangible wisp of soul. But when Cope would play the same music for people and not inform them it had sprouted from the processor chip of a PC, the listeners would often revel in the sound and remark on how deeply the music touched them.

偏见潜意识的力量已得到充分证实；对抗这种自然潮流让科普感到愤怒。更糟糕的是，在他看来，人们开始把艾美奖视为某种展览，就像车展上的概念车，每个参观者都知道它只是个摆设。但科普的概念并非遥不可及的梦想。它改变了他看待音乐和创造力的方式。他说，像艾美奖这样的算法代表着音乐的未来。他解释说，人类作曲家将一如既往地存在，但他们将不断进化，运用他们掌握的一切工具——包括算法。

The power of a biased subconscious has been well documented; fighting against such natural tides exasperated Cope. Even worse, as far as he was concerned, people began to view Emmy as some kind of exhibition, like a concept car at an auto show that every attendee knows is just for show. But Cope’s concept wasn’t a far-fetched dream. It changed the way he viewed music and creativity. Algorithms like Emmy are the future of music, he says. Human composers will exist as they always have, he explains, but they will evolve to use every tool at their disposal—including algorithms.

尽管科普在人工智能领域已是巨星，在世界各地的计算机科学大会上发表主题演讲，但他仍对艾美奖在音乐界缺乏认可感到惋惜。尽管科普通过二十年的努力，成为了一位杰出的计算机科学家，但他首先是一位音乐家。

Even as Cope attained superstar status within the artificial intelligence community—he gave keynotes at computer science conventions around the world—he lamented Emmy’s lack of acceptance within musical ranks. As much as he’d made himself into a preeminent computer scientist through two decades of work, Cope remained a musician first.

这位教授并非有意创造新奇事物。他厌倦了人们问“艾米”能否完成舒伯特未完成的《第八交响曲》或马勒的《第十交响曲》，或者它能否演绎出肖邦歌剧的音效（肖邦本人从未创作过歌剧）。“我开始觉得我被简单地视为一个程序员，一个下载文件并整合数据库的人，而不是一个真正参与创作的人，”科普说。

The professor hadn’t set out to create a novelty. He grew tired of people asking if Emmy could complete Schubert’s unfinished Eighth Symphony or Mahler’s Tenth—or if it could conjure what a Chopin opera would sound like (the composer himself never wrote one). “I began to feel I was viewed as simply a programmer, somebody who downloaded files and put together databases rather than someone who was involved in creativity,” Cope says.

他还担心艾美的永生会影响人们的认知。“人类作曲家会死去，”他说。他们的作品之所以有趣且重要，是因为它们变得稀有。艾美的作品似乎永远不会变得稀有，因为她可以永远作曲，创作出如此多的作品，“以至于我们沉浸其中。”

He also worried that Emmy’s effective immortality affected people’s perceptions. “Human composers die,” he says. Their works become interesting and important because they become rare. Emmy’s work seemed like it was never going to become rare because she could compose forever and create so many pieces that “we just drown in them.”

2004年，科普凭直觉毁掉了艾米。他抹去了所有算法数据库，其中许多数据库是他费尽心思手工拼凑起来的。艾米再也无法创作出一系列模仿巴赫键盘作品或贝多芬交响曲的作品。科普保留了原始代码用于教学，因为事实证明，这在算法创造力方面是一次真正的飞跃。但是，通过摧毁那些为艾米提供数据、使她能够如此出色地模仿人类作曲的数据，他终止了实验，也让批评者们少了些抱怨。算法音乐的世界，这个曾经越来越接近人类音乐的世界，被彻底压制了。

In 2004 Cope followed his gut and destroyed Emmy. He erased all of the algorithm’s databases, many of which he had arduously put together by hand. Emmy would never again create a series of imitation Bach keyboard inventions or Beethoven symphonies. Cope preserved the original code for teaching, because it had proven to be a true leap forward in algorithmic creativity. But by destroying the data crops that fed Emmy and enabled her to so well emulate human composition, he had ended the experiment and given his critics little to complain about. The world of algorithmic music, which had been creeping ever closer to that of humans, had been silenced.

这只是暂时的平静。

It would prove a temporary quiet.

科普真正想要的是远离聚光灯和批评。当他毁掉艾米时，他已经秘密开始了第二个算法项目。他将自己的新作品命名为艾米丽·豪厄尔。这个算法是艾米的直接产物，尽管更加先进。豪厄尔运行着同样的逻辑、技巧和方程式。但她更胜一筹。豪厄尔就像是 MacBook Pro，而艾米是 Apple IIe。在圣克鲁斯的一次艾米丽音乐表演中，观众全神贯注地聆听，完全没有意识到这首曲子是由电脑创作的。一位科普很熟悉的教授说，这首曲子是他一生中听过的最动人的音乐之一。几个月后，这位同事听了科普关于艾米丽·豪厄尔的讲座后，立刻对她的音乐不屑一顾，认为它没有灵魂。

What Cope really wanted was a retreat from the spotlight and his critics. When he destroyed Emmy, he had already begun, in secret, on a second algorithm project. He dubbed his new creation Emily Howell. The algorithm is the direct, though more advanced, spawn of Emmy. Howell runs on the same kinds of logic, tricks, and equations. But she’s better. Howell is the MacBook Pro to Emmy’s Apple IIe. During one performance of her music in Santa Cruz, the audience listened rapt, unaware that the composition came from a computer. A professor whom Cope knows well said the score ranked among the most moving he’d heard in his life. Several months later, the same colleague attended one of Cope’s lectures on Emily Howell and immediately discounted her music, saying it had no soul.

无论是否是灵魂乐，艾米莉·豪厄尔都创作了八部歌剧和几首钢琴协奏曲。豪厄尔的首张专辑《来自黑暗，光明》广受好评，有人称赞其才华横溢，也有人批评其音乐缺乏调性且肤浅。为了避免重蹈《艾米》的覆辙——作品太多，却缺乏尊重，科普在她2011年发行第二张专辑后就终止了她短暂的作曲生涯。

Soul or not, Emily Howell has composed eight operas as well as a handful of piano concertos. Howell’s first record, From Darkness, Light, elicited reviews hailing it as brilliant, as well as those that fingered the music as atonal and shallow. Not wanting to tempt the same results that he did with Emmy—too many pieces, too little respect—Cope put an end to Emily Howell’s short composing career following the work she did on her second album in 2011.

科普在突破算法极限三十年后依然意犹未尽，他正在酝酿另一位更具活力的机器人作曲家。他正在研发这台最新、最先进的音乐制作机器，并将其记录在一本名为《超越机器》（The Transcendent Machine）的书中。

Not one to rest after three decades of pushing algorithmic limits, Cope has yet another, more dynamic cyborg composer in the works. As he develops his latest, most advanced music-making machine, he’s chronicling it in a book entitled The Transcendent Machine.

科普的新灵感来自安妮。他没有像对待艾米和豪厄尔那样给安妮制定一套必须遵守的规则，而是利用所谓的机器学习让安妮自己编写规则。机器学习算法种类繁多，但科普走在科技前沿。简单的机器学习程序可以被告知期望的结果，然后学习实现目标的最佳方法。科学家们利用它们在海量数据中梳理出非直觉的关系。随着数据量的增加，算法变得越来越智能。例如，新西兰智能研究团队创建了一种机器学习算法 Winestein，它可以为你准备的晚餐推荐葡萄酒搭配。Winestein 通过扫描来自世界顶级餐厅和侍酒师的数千份餐酒搭配菜单获得了它的智能。它收集的数据越多，Winestein 的推荐就越细致入微，也越智能。

Cope’s new muse is named Annie. Instead of giving Annie a set of rules by which she must compose, as he did with Emmy and Howell, Cope has developed Annie to write her own rules utilizing what’s called machine learning. There are different kinds of machine-learning algorithms, but Cope’s dance on the edge of technology. Simpler machine-learning programs can be told desired outcomes and they then learn the best ways to get there. Scientists use them to tease out nonintuitive relationships inside vast stores of data. As they ingest more data, the algorithms get smarter. For example, Winestein is a machine-learning algorithm created by New Zealand’s Smart Research team that recommends wine pairings for the dinner you’re putting together. Winestein got its smarts by scanning thousands of menus with food-wine pairings from the best restaurants and sommeliers in the world. The more data it was able to gather, the more nuanced and smart Winestein’s recommendations became.

然而，安妮所做的比怀恩斯坦更进了一步。安妮学会了如何学习。她决定了偏好是什么，标准是什么，以及最终她创作和声的路径。这或许能带来一些疯狂的音乐。

What Annie does, however, is a step past Winestein. Annie learns how to learn. She decides what the biases will be, what the criteria are, and, ultimately, the path she takes to making harmonies. It can lead to some crazy music.

“真正有趣的是，有时候我完全不知道她会做什么，”他解释道。“她总是让我感到惊讶，就像其他人一样。”

“The really interesting thing is that I have no idea what she’s going to do sometimes,” he explains. “She surprises me as much as anybody.”

科普构建了安妮的算法，使其超越音乐。任何能够提供大量可组织和采样的过去作品的东西都是可以考虑的。2011 年，科普出版了一本包含两千首俳句的书，名为《炽热之夜来临时》。安妮创作了书中的一些俳句；其余部分则收录了日本大师的经典作品。俳句传统上包括三行诗，分别有五个、七个和五个音节。短长短的节奏在英语中悦耳，但在日语中更具力量，因为在日语中，俳句必须以最高的效率书写，因为十七个音节在英语中通常比在日语中能传达更多的东西。

Cope has built Annie’s algorithm to go beyond music. Anything that offers large volumes of past work that can be organized and sampled is fair game. In 2011, Cope published a book of two thousand haiku entitled Comes the Fiery Night. Annie wrote some of the book’s haiku; the balance is composed of classics by Japanese masters. Haiku traditionally include three lines of verse with five, seven, and five syllables, respectively. The short-long-short rhythm pleases the ear in English, but it’s even more powerful in Japanese, in which haiku must be written with the utmost efficiency because seventeen syllables can typically convey far more in English than in Japanese.

这本书没有区分诗歌的作者。科普也不愿透露书中有多少内容来自他的算法。“我意识到，告诉人们哪些是哪些，并没有什么好处，”他说。

The book does not distinguish which poems belong to whom. Nor will Cope say what percentage of the book came from his algorithm. “I’ve learned there’s little advantage in telling people which are which,” he says.

这里有三首俳句，其中至少有一首是人类的诗，还有一首是安妮的诗（科普不会告诉我是谁写的）：

Here are three of the haiku, with at least one poem from a human and one from Annie (Cope wouldn’t tell me who wrote what):

无法热情

Cannot the fervor

在河的尽头

Over the river’s ending

推迟到现在？

Be postponed to now?

水蛇翻腾，

Water snakes writhe,

他们的身后溅起水花，

Water splashes in their wake,

青蛙回家

A frog heads for home

火焰噼啪作响

The fire crackles loud

在清晨的空气中

In the morning air as I

漫步在路上17

Wander on the path17

哪些俳句是人类的文字，哪些又来自一组比特？安妮从数百年的俳句中汲取灵感，设计规则，发现规律，并不断探索注入原创性的方法，她对日本短篇散文的处理方式，与科普所有算法处理古典音乐的方式如出一辙。“说到底，它们只是一层又一层的二进制数学，”他说。

Which haiku are human writing and which are from a group of bits? Sampling centuries of haiku, devising rules, spotting patterns, and inventing ways to inject originality, Annie took to the short Japanese sets of prose the same way all of Cope’s algorithms tackled classical music. “In the end, it’s just layers and layers of binary math,” he says.

科普说，安妮对高雅原创的热爱，或许会让她超越大多数人类作曲家，因为后者只是在过去作品的基础上进行创作，而这些作品又建立在更古老的作品之上。科普毫无感情地说道，但他仍然对音乐精英们对艾美奖的反应耿耿于怀。他不愿承认，但似乎已经做好了反击的准备。

Cope says Annie’s penchant for tasteful originality could push her past most human composers, who simply build on the work of the past, which, in turn, was built on older works. Cope offers this without emotion, but he still harbors bruises from the music elite’s reaction to Emmy. He won’t admit it, but he seems ready for a fight.

双方的辩论都将坦诚相待。将有史以来最伟大的音乐分解成模式识别、规则制定和受控的规则打破，这种想法对某些音乐人来说实在难以接受。艺术家往往以作品定义自我。他们认为创造力是他们区别于格子间里的普通人、四处奔波的销售员、沉迷于电子表格的MBA——那些平庸的大众——的关键。科普认为，这种工匠式的优越感可以简化为一个冗长高效的方程式，而非某种神秘的天赋和精心培养的才能。这位以其创造力改变了我们对人工智能看法的人，无意中颠覆了成千上万（甚至数百万）其他人在创造力游戏中的赌注。如果作曲家在社会中的角色可以由算法来填补，那么人类还剩下什么？

The arguments will be honest on both sides. The specter that the greatest music ever created could be broken down into pattern recognition, rule making, and controlled rule breaking is just too much for some musical types to take. Artists tend to be people who define themselves by their work. They perceive their creativity as what separates them from the person in the cubicle, the salesman on the road, the MBA doting on a spreadsheet—the banal masses. Cope suggests that this artisan shield of superiority can be reduced to a long, efficient equation rather than some mystically endowed and carefully cultured gift. The man whose own creativity altered how we think of artificial intelligence inadvertently subverted thousands—if not millions—of others’ stakes in the creativity game. If a composer’s role to society can be filled by an algorithm, then what are humans left with?

但随着机器人进军音乐创作领域，这扇大门将为颠覆者敞开。尽管颠覆通常源于科技，但流行音乐排行榜——其根基无疑在于算法创作的歌曲——很可能在那些创作出真正与众不同作品的独立艺术家面前显得脆弱不堪。算法能否仅凭过去的经验，就创造出涅槃乐队的第二张专辑《Nevermind 》，从而催生出一种全新的音乐类型和乐队？或者想想流浪者合唱团（Outkast）的歌曲《Hey Ya》，由安德烈·3000创作。这首2003年的歌曲与大多数人从未听过的音乐截然不同；很难想象一个算法能够根据过去的流行歌曲创作出这样的歌曲。这几乎是不可能的。如今，人们已经把《Hey Ya》视为理所当然，因为他们已经听过它上千遍了。但这首歌却真正地与众不同，尽管它与其他任何音乐都截然不同——这种特质通常会阻碍音乐的广泛流行——但它仍然能够成为美国电台长达半年的圣歌。几乎所有人，无论是独立音乐爱好者还是热爱音乐的青少年，都对这首歌赞不绝口。正是这种旋律需要真正的人类创造力。科普或许正在朝着这个目标前进，但距离目标仍然很远。正因如此，即使算法统治着广播电台，人类艺术家也始终需要努力，尽管这种差距正在缩小。

But as bots move into the business of music creation, the door will be left open for disruptors. And whereas disruption usually comes from technology, it’s likely that the pop charts, with what will certainly be a backbone of algorithmically conceived songs, will be left vulnerable to indie artists who create something truly different. Is it possible that an algorithm could have given us, based solely upon the past, Nirvana’s second album, Nevermind, which spawned a new genre of music and bands? Or consider Outkast’s “Hey Ya,” written by Andre 3000. The 2003 song was like nothing most people had ever heard before; it’s hard to imagine an algorithm drawing on popular songs of the past being able to conjure that. It’s almost impossible. People take “Hey Ya” for granted now because they’ve heard it a thousand times, but that song was a true outlier in that despite being utterly different from anything else out there—a trait that usually disqualifies music from achieving widespread popularity—it was still able to become the anthem of American radio for half a year. Almost everybody, indie snobs and bubble-popping teens alike, adored the song. It’s that kind of tune that requires true human invention. Cope may be on the road to such a thing, but he’s still far away. And that’s why there will always be a gap, albeit narrowing, for human artists to shoot for, even when algorithms rule the airwaves.

“机器依靠二进制数学运行，而人类则不然，”科普说。“试图用二进制数学复制人脑与用细胞和DNA创造人脑截然不同。这些都是很棒的算法，但我们可能永远无法做到这一点。”

“Machines run on binary mathematics. Human’s don’t,” Cope says. “Trying to replicate the human brain using binary mathematics is a lot different than creating it with cells and DNA. These are wonderful algorithms, but we may never do that.”

然而，创作广告歌曲、流行歌曲、背景音乐和平淡无趣的电影配乐的艺术家应该小心。

Artists who compose jingles, pop hits, background music, and uninspiring movie scores should beware, however.

解开披头士乐队之谜

SOLVING BEATLES MYSTERIES

正如算法决定着我们未来会听到什么一样，它们也在告诉我们过去听到过什么。有些算法会探究巴赫与其同时代艺术家的相似之处，寻找谁启发了谁。有些算法会寻找线索，看看巴洛克时期的匿名作品是否出自我们已知的伟大艺术家。此外，还有一组属于一位加拿大教授的算法，在全球最大、最狂热的音乐爱好者群体之一——披头士狂热者——中引起了不小的骚动。

Just as algorithms are deciding what we hear in the future, they’re also informing us of what we heard in the past. Some algorithms plumb the similarities of Bach and his contemporaries, looking for who inspired whom. Some algorithms look for clues that anonymous baroque-era pieces might belong to a great artist we already know. And then there’s a set of algorithms belonging to a Canadian professor that has stirred up a bit of fuss within one of the largest and most ardent groups of music fans in the world: Beatlemaniacs.

几乎每个人都对披头士乐队抱有某种程度的欣赏。对于那些不为《我想握住你的手》这首简单的旋律所倾倒的人来说，还有一大堆更有感染力的歌曲。从触动灵魂的《当我的吉他轻轻哭泣》到充满诗意的《顺其自然》，披头士乐队的创新精神使他们声名鹊起。他们的广度使他们才华横溢，而他们仅用七年时间就完成了的丰富专辑，展现了惊人的生产力。

Nearly everybody has an appreciation for the Beatles on some level. For those who don’t swoon at the simple melody of “I Want to Hold Your Hand,” there’s a crate full of more potent songs. From the soul-scratching “While My Guitar Gently Weeps” to the poetic “Let It Be,” the Beatles’ innovation made them famous. Their breadth made them brilliant and their prolific catalog, completed in just seven years, shows an uncanny productivity.

从披头士乐队每句歌词的含义，到他们演奏的乐器，再到他们约会的女性，披头士乐队及其音乐的方方面面都已被研究。他们的音乐发展如此迅速，以至于除了承认他们是天才之外，任何评价都显得不合常理。披头士乐队的忠实粉丝们对他们的赞美之情溢于言表。但杰森·布朗并非普通的披头士乐迷。他是一位数学博士，却能用吉他弹奏出乔治·哈里森的优美乐句。更重要的是，布朗因其将音乐的各个方面与其背后的精细数学联系起来的专业知识而受到世界各地的赞誉。他还认为披头士乐队成员——尤其是约翰和保罗——是数学天才。

Every aspect of the Beatles and their music has been studied, from the meaning of each verse they sang to the instruments they played to the women they dated. Their music evolved so quickly that acknowledging them as anything but genius seems irrational. Ebullient praise is common among the Beatle faithful. But Jason Brown is no normal Beatles fan. He’s a math PhD who snaps off passable George Harrison licks on his guitar. More important, Brown has been cited around the world for his expertise in linking various sides of music to the granular math behind it. He also believes the Beatles—especially John and Paul—were math savants.

“如果他们热爱数学，他们就会成为半个世纪才出现一次的天才，”布朗说。“他们是那种能解决各种别人无法解决的证明的人。他们身处世界的同一角落，却最终以这样的方式相遇，这种概率简直令人难以置信。”

“If they had been inclined toward mathematics, they would have been among those geniuses that come along only every half century,” says Brown. “They were the kind of people who solve all sorts of proofs that nobody else had. The odds that they would even be in the same part of the world and end up finding each other in the way they did—it’s just amazing.”

布朗利用自己的数学和编程背景，开始研究几十年来一直困扰着披头士乐队的一些更为突出的问题，首先是一个特定的声音：“A Hard Day's Night”的开场和弦。

Drawing on his math and programming background, Brown began looking at some of the more prominent questions that have nipped at the Beatles’ legacy for decades, beginning with one particular sound: the opening chord to “A Hard Day’s Night.”

《A Hard Day's Night》的第一个和弦或许是有史以来最具辨识度的摇滚弹奏。尽管它只持续了一秒多一点，但即使是普通的广播听众也能清楚地知道接下来会发生什么。这是披头士乐队创作的最令人难忘的声音之一。披头士乐队的长期制作人乔治·马丁承认了这段和弦的效果和重要性。“我们知道它会为电影和原声带LP拉开序幕，所以我们想要一个特别强劲有力的开场，”他说。“这段刺耳的吉他和弦是完美的开场。”18

The first chord of “A Hard Day’s Night” may be the most recognizable rock strum ever recorded. Although it resonates for barely more than a second, even casual radio listeners know exactly what comes next. It’s one of the more indelible sounds created by the Beatles. George Martin, the Beatles’ longtime producer, acknowledged the effect and importance of the chord. “We knew it would open both the film and the sound track LP, so we wanted a particularly strong and effective beginning,” he said. “The strident guitar chord was the perfect launch.”18

但任何一位优秀的吉他手都会告诉你，复制那个和弦是不可能的。乐谱上也会出现错误。因为没有人确切知道乔治主音吉他和弦是如何产生的，不同的歌本列出了这首歌开头的不同和弦和音符。没有一个是准确的。一位数学家用计算机和算法花了四十年的时间才解开了这个声音的谜团。

But any good guitar player can tell you that reproducing that chord is impossible. Sheet music gets it wrong as well. Because nobody knew exactly how the sound of George’s lead guitar chord was produced, different songbooks list different chords and notes for the song’s opening shot. None of them are right. It took forty years for a mathematician with a computer and an algorithm to come along and solve the mystery of how the sound was made.

诚然，关于这首特定和弦的创作机制，存在诸多理论。其中许多理论与哈里森的十二弦 Rickenbacker 吉他有关，这把吉他是他在 1964 年披头士乐队首次美国巡演时获得的。19但单凭十二弦琴声还不够。许多乐迷说，他们在声音中听出了钢琴的韵味。另一些人说，他们听到了约翰的六弦琴声，甚至保罗的贝斯声。

To be sure, there have been plenty of theories as to what created that particular chord. Many involved Harrison’s twelve-string Rickenbacker guitar, which he’d been given on the Beatles’ first U.S. tour in 1964.19 But the twelve-string by itself wasn’t enough. Many aficionados said they detected a piano in the sound. Others said they heard John’s six-string and even Paul’s bass.

哈里森本人在 2001 年去世前不久的雅虎聊天中部分回答了和弦问题：

Harrison himself half answered the chord question in a 2001 Yahoo! chat not long before he died:

 

 

a_t_m98 问：哈里森先生，您在《A Hard Days Night》中使用的开场和弦是什么？

a_t_m98 asks: Mr. Harrison..what is the opening chord you used for “A Hard Days Night”?

 

 

george_harrison_live：这是 F，上面有一个 G（在 12 弦上）

george_harrison_live: It is F with a G on top (on the 12-string)

 

 

george_harrison_live：但你必须向保罗询问低音才能得到正确的故事。20

george_harrison_live: but you’ll have to ask Paul about the bass note to get the proper story.20

大多数粉丝都无力接触保罗·麦卡特尼，因此谜团依然存在。

Getting access to Paul McCartney isn’t within most fans’ wherewithal, so the mystery remained intact.

布朗自己的披头士狂热阶段始于他十一岁那年，当时他在多伦多附近长大，他得到了披头士乐队的“红”和“蓝”专辑，这是乐队解散后不久发行的热门单曲合辑。音乐感染了布朗，他立刻缠着父母要了一把吉他。他不停地练习和演奏吉他，1972 年夏天经常每天演奏八到十个小时。他一直参加酒吧乐队演奏到大学毕业，在大学期间他考虑过主修音乐，但最终选择了数学，因为它有更好的职业前景。多年后，作为新斯科舍省哈利法克斯市达尔豪西大学的数学教授，布朗使用所谓的傅里叶级数构建了一个算法来解决披头士乐队的和弦之谜。

Brown’s own Beatlemaniac phase began when he was eleven, growing up near Toronto, when he got his hands on the Beatles’ “Red” and “Blue” albums, a large compilation of the band’s hit singles released just after the group disbanded. The music affected Brown and he immediately bugged his parents for a guitar. He practiced and played the instrument incessantly, often putting in eight- or ten-hour days during the summer of 1972. He played in bar bands all the way through college, where he considered majoring in music but ultimately picked math for its better career prospects. Years later, as a professor of mathematics at Dalhousie University in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Brown built an algorithm using what are called Fourier series to solve the Beatles chord riddle.

1807年，约瑟夫·傅立叶发表了他的热方程，描述了金属板内某一点受热后，热量随时间的变化。傅立叶的周期函数建立在欧拉和丹尼尔·伯努利的工作之上，从而发展了一系列三角积分（现称为傅立叶级数），这些积分在数十个应用中被证明极其有用。

In 1807, Joseph Fourier published his heat equation, which described the distribution of heat over time within a metal plate that had been warmed from one point. Fourier’s periodic function built on the work of Euler and Daniel Bernoulli to develop a series of trigonometric integrals—now called a Fourier series—that have proven incredibly handy in dozens of applications.

从傅立叶的研究成果中获益的人包括菲舍尔·布莱克和迈伦·斯科尔斯，他们利用傅立叶热方程的变体创建了自己的算法，该算法后来重塑了华尔街，并为斯科尔斯赢得了诺贝尔奖。21 1985 年，赫伯特·A·豪普特曼 (Herbert A. Hauptman) 和杰罗姆·卡尔 (Jerome Karle) 因利用傅里叶级数通过 X 射线模拟晶体结构而获得诺贝尔奖。22

Among those who profited from Fourier’s work were Fischer Black and Myron Scholes, who used a variation of Fourier’s heat equation to create their algorithm that would go on to reorder Wall Street and earn Scholes a Nobel Prize.21 An earlier Nobel was awarded to Herbert A. Hauptman and Jerome Karle in 1985 for their work utilizing Fourier series to model crystalline structures using X-rays.22

傅立叶的理论在解码音乐方面也发挥了重要作用，布朗在20世纪90年代中期从一本数学期刊上了解到了这一点。他对此十分好奇，并将这一发现深藏在自己的潜意识中。

Fourier’s work has also proved useful in decoding music, a fact Brown picked up in a math journal in the mid-1990s. Intrigued, he tucked the tip away in his subconscious.

2004年，披头士乐队在世界各地庆祝成立四十周年。布朗被这盛大的庆典吸引，不禁想起了《A Hard Day's Night》的开场谜语。一直以来，布朗的脑海里都萦绕着十年前那篇关于傅立叶系列的期刊文章中的那句小诗。

In 2004, the Beatles were celebrated around the world for their fortieth anniversary. Brown found himself drawn in by the fanfare, which got him thinking about the opening riddle to “A Hard Day’s Night.” All the while, Brown’s brain had been clinging to that little nugget from the journal article on Fourier series a decade before.

布朗没有花几个小时弹吉他，不切实际地重现和弦，而是想，“我为什么不运用科学来解决这个问题呢？”

Instead of spending hours with his guitar on a quixotic mission to reproduce the chord, Brown thought, “Why don’t I apply science to this problem?”

要理解布朗的意图，首先要掌握音乐和声音背后的科学原理。所有声音，比如我们听到的乐队演奏的声音，都是由音调组成的。音调具有频率和振幅。音调的频率与其音高相关，振幅与其响度相关。将音调组合起来就形成了和弦。要得到和弦的数学函数，需要将其固有音调的函数相加。23音调的频率和振幅可以用正弦和余弦函数进行数学建模，与傅里叶级数中使用的函数完全相同。24

To understand what Brown was seeking to do, it’s important to have a light grasp on the scientific principles behind music and sound. All sounds, like those we hear a band create, are made up of tones. Musical tones possess a frequency and an amplitude. The tone’s frequency relates to its pitch and the amplitude relates to its loudness. Combining tones creates chords. To get the mathematical function of a chord, you add up the functions of its inherent tones.23 The frequencies and amplitudes of tones can be modeled mathematically with sine and cosine functions, exactly like those used in Fourier series.24

当乐器演奏时，它们的录音既包含乐器的纯音，也包含所有乐器发出的较小合成音，更不用说当时可能反射到录音麦克风中的任何其他噪音。通过利用傅里叶变换的算法对和弦进行运算，布朗认为他可以对构成和弦的每种乐器的预期音进行排序。这样做将为这个四十年来的谜题提供无可辩驳的答案。

When instruments are played, their recordings include both the pure tone of the instrument plus the smaller resultant sounds that all instruments emit, not to mention any other noises that may have been reflected into the recording microphone at that moment. By running the chord through an algorithm utilizing Fourier transforms, Brown thought he could sort the intended tones of each instrument contributing to the chord. Doing this would render an irrefutable answer to the forty-year-old riddle.

布朗首先将他能找到的歌曲样本尽可能纯净地传输到电脑里。然后，他从开头和弦的中间截取了一段大约一秒长的音。这段简短的和声包含了他需要知道的一切。他用为此专门编写的傅里叶变换对音乐进行处理，将和弦分解成各个独立的声频。唯一的问题是，录音中出现了29,375个不同的频率。这些频率包括乐器演奏的实际音符，以及背景噪音和英国音乐家无意中发出的边频。

Brown started by transferring as pure a sample of the song as he could find to his computer. From there, he cut out a chunk of sound from the middle of the opening chord about one second in length. This little burst of harmonic sound would hold everything he needed to know. He ran the music through Fourier transforms he had composed for this purpose that disassembled the chord into its separate sound frequencies. The only problem was, the recording turned up 29,375 different frequencies. Those frequencies encompass the actual notes being played by the instruments plus background noise and side frequencies unwittingly emitted by the English musicians.

为了找到正确的音调，布朗对数千个频率进行了排序，只选择了振幅大于 0.02 的频率。这样做将他的列表精简到 48 个频率；这些频率就是披头士乐队演奏的音符。布朗随后创建了第二个算法，将这些频率转换为乐队演奏的音符。25他的数学换算假设披头士乐队的乐器音准完美。但结果显示，披头士乐队并没有对他们的乐器进行任何严格的调音——但这对他们的音乐或歌曲并没有什么不利影响（就我们这些凡人听众而言）。

To focus on the correct tones, Brown sorted the thousands of frequencies by selecting only those with amplitudes greater than .02. Doing this thinned his list down to forty-eight frequencies; these would be the ones the Beatles were belting off their instruments. Brown then created a second algorithm to convert the frequencies to the notes played by the band.25 His mathematical conversion assumed that the Beatles’ instruments were in perfect tune. But the results showed that the Beatles had not tuned their instruments with any kind of rigor—not that it had any detrimental effect on their music or the song (as far as we mortal listeners would care).

拿到这四十八个音符后，布朗开始分析它们。他首先推断出，这个和弦最广为人知的三个版本都是错误的。每个版本都包含一个低G2（2是八度），而布朗的数据中没有这个音。披头士乐队根本没弹过这个音。所以，在他还没解决整个问题之前，布朗就已经推翻了三个最流行的答案。

With the forty-eight notes in hand, Brown began analyzing them. The first thing he deduced was that the three best-known transcriptions of the chord were incorrect. Each of these versions featured a low G2 (2 is the octave), which was absent from Brown’s data. The Beatles played no such note. So before he had even solved the whole problem, Brown had debunked its three most popular answers.

一个音符，D3，格外突出，其振幅几乎是其他音符的​​两倍。布朗确信哈里森弹的是他的十二弦吉他，这把吉他的声音在歌曲的后半部分可以清晰地听到。但这把吉他的琴弦大小一致，产生的音符振幅也大致相同，这意味着它不可能发出超响的D3。出于同样的原因，这个音符也不可能是列侬的吉他发出的。它一定是麦卡特尼的霍夫纳贝斯发出的。

One note, a D3, stuck out with an amplitude of nearly twice any other note. Brown was certain that Harrison had played his twelve-string guitar, whose sound can be heard definitively later in the song. But that instrument has consistently sized strings that produce notes of roughly the same amplitude, meaning it couldn’t have produced the extra-loud D3. Nor would the note be from Lennon’s guitar, for the same reasons. It had to belong to McCartney’s Hofner bass.

但布朗的数据里有四个D3，所以其中三个（振幅较小的）没有被记录下来。即使一个来自哈里森的十二弦吉他，另一个来自列侬的六弦吉他，仍然会有一个。除此之外，还有一组令人讨厌的三个F3音符四处飘荡。如果哈里森在他的十二弦吉他上弹奏其中一个，他的吉他也会发出F4音——但那个音符却完全没有踪迹。

But there were four D3s in Brown’s data, so three of them (those with lesser amplitudes) remained unaccounted for. Even if one came from Harrison’s twelve-string and another from Lennon’s six-string, there still remained one more. On top of that was a pesky group of three F3 notes floating around. If Harrison had played one of them on his twelve-string, his guitar would also have produced an F4—but there was no trace of that note whatsoever.

布朗查看数据后，突然想到了一个答案：这三组音符是从钢琴而不是吉他中发出的。任何仔细研究过三角钢琴内部构造的人都知道，钢琴的琴键通过小锤敲击琴弦来发出我们听到的声音。但一个琴键的锤子并非只敲击一根琴弦。事实上，钢琴的高音是由三根琴弦产生的（两根琴弦负责中音，一根琴弦负责低音）。这是一个高音，所以钢琴的琴弦可以解释为什么音符是三重的，以及为什么没有F4。布朗现在知道这个和弦里有乔治·马丁的参与，就像他在那个时代的披头士乐队其他歌曲中经常做的那样，他同时演奏了钢琴，而乐队则坚持使用核心乐器。

Looking at his data, Brown was struck with an answer: the triple sets of notes erupted from a piano, not guitars. Anybody who has peered into a grand piano to case its innards knows that the instrument’s keys bounce little hammers off strings to make the sounds we hear. But one key’s hammer doesn’t strike just one string. Three strings, in fact, create a piano’s higher notes (with two strings for middle notes and one for the lower notes). This was a higher note, so a piano’s strings would explain the notes in triplicate and the lack of an F4. Brown now knew that the chord included George Martin, who, as he often did in other Beatles’ songs of that era, doubled on the piano while the band stuck to its core instruments.

布朗的算法分析找到了哈里森在他的里肯巴克钢琴上弹奏的真实音符：A2、A3、D3、D4、G3、G4、C4、C4。这份合集与世界上流传的任何乐谱都截然不同，我们现在知道，这些乐谱错误地指导人们如何弹奏这个最经典的和弦。列侬在他的六弦琴上弹奏出了一个响亮的C5，而马丁在钢琴上弹奏的是D3、F3、D5、G5、E6。

Brown’s algorithmic analysis turned up the real notes that Harrison had played on his Rickenbacker: A2, A3, D3, D4, G3, G4, C4, C4. This collection in no way resembles any of the sheet music floating about the world, which we now know was erroneously instructing people how to play this most classic of chords. Lennon hit a loud C5 on his six-string and Martin played D3, F3, D5, G5, E6 on the piano.

了解了这些之后，哈里森在 2001 年网络聊天中所说的话就变得更加清晰了：“这是 F 调，上面有一个 G（在 12 弦上）……但你得问保罗低音调，才能知道正确的故事。”

With that knowledge, Harrison’s 2001 Web chat remark becomes all the more clearer: “It is F with a G on top (on the 12-string) . . . but you’ll have to ask Paul about the bass note to get the proper story.”

那确实是个F，上面加个G。哈里森打字的时候，十二弦琴就弹奏出了G。大多数人只是简单地假设——哈里森可能也希望他们这么想——吉他也弹奏出了F。但实际上，F来自马丁的斯坦威钢琴，而保罗弹奏的是一个完全不同的音符。布朗说，马丁在混录最终曲目时，把钢琴的振幅调得几乎与十二弦琴的振幅相同，将其隐藏在吉他更尖锐的声音之后。

It was indeed an F with a G on top. And just as Harrison typed, the twelve-string played the G. Most people simply assumed, as Harrison probably wanted them to, that the guitar played the F as well. But the F actually came from Martin’s Steinway piano, while Paul played a different note entirely. When Martin mixed the final track, Brown says, he made the amplitudes on the piano almost identical to those emitted by the twelve-string, hiding it behind the sharper sound of the guitar.

1979年，马丁回顾自己与披头士乐队合作的岁月，提到了电影制作人将真实素材与特效相结合以营造理想幻觉的过程。“我们不应该期望人们必然会像在唱片里那样去做，”他写道。二十六

In 1979, looking back on his years with the Beatles, Martin alluded to the process that filmmakers undertake when they mix real footage with effects to create the illusion they want. “It shouldn’t be expected that people are necessarily doing what they appear to be doing on records,” he wrote.26

布朗教授对这首歌开头和弦的分析远不止于此。乔治·哈里森在歌曲中那段精彩绝伦的吉他独奏，一连串完美拨弦的断奏，在布朗看来总感觉有点太完美了。哈里森怎么弹得这么快？布朗一直认为这段独奏可能是以半速录制的，然后在最终混音时加速。除了直觉之外，几乎没有任何证据表明他的假设是正确的。

Professor Brown wasn’t done with just dissecting the song’s opening chord. George Harrison’s guitar solo in the song, a brilliant blast of perfectly plucked staccato notes, had always seemed a smidge too perfect to Brown. How did Harrison play it so quickly? Brown had always thought it was possible that the solo had been recorded at half speed and then sped up for the final mix. There was little that pointed to his hypothesis being correct other than his gut.

几位披头士乐队专家曾向布朗保证，马丁和乐队在录音纸上总会记录磁带速度的变化。然而，这首歌的录音纸上却没有这样的记录。其他人则坚持认为，如果这段独奏是以半速录制的，它就会被充分记录下来，广为人知。但布朗在开场和弦上的突破鼓舞下，继续追问。

Several Beatles experts had assured Brown that Martin and the band always noted on the recording sheets when changes in tape speed were used. There were no such notes on the song’s sheets, however. If the solo had been recorded at half speed, others insisted, it would be well documented and well known. But Brown, emboldened by his breakthrough on the opening chord, kept on with his inquiry.

众所周知，这段独奏实际上是哈里森用十二弦吉他和马丁用钢琴演奏的结合。如果两人最初以一半的速度录制这段，他们的演奏速度就会比听起来低一个八度，因为磁带速度加倍会导致音乐升高一个八度。

It was well known that the solo was actually a combination of Harrison on his twelve-string guitar mirrored by Martin on the piano. If the men had originally recorded the segment at half speed, they would have played it an octave lower than it sounds because doubling the speed of the tape results in the music kicking up an octave.

因为涉及到钢琴，布朗找到了一个可以发现的漏洞。于是，他采样了一小段独奏，并用他的算法进行计算。他选择了一段包含哈里森吉他和马丁钢琴演奏的G3音的独奏。布朗检查了录音中出现的频率，发现G3音确实出现在三个频率中。其中一个频率应该来自哈里森的十二弦琴。另外两个频率来自钢琴。这真是个意外的惊喜。如果独奏全速演奏，钢琴应该会出现三个G3音。

Because the piano was involved, Brown had a crack he could expose. So he sampled a tiny chunk of the solo and ran it through his algorithm. He chose a piece of the solo that included a G3 played by both Harrison’s guitar and Martin’s piano. When Brown examined the frequencies present in the recording, the G3 was indeed present in three frequencies. One of them would have been from Harrison’s twelve-string. The other two were from the piano. This was the jackpot. There should have been three G3s from the piano had the solo been played at full speed.

如前所述，钢琴的高音部分由三根弦组成，而中音部分的琴槌只敲击两根弦。如果以正确的八度全速弹奏这首曲子，马丁会敲击出三根弦的G音。然而，如果在钢琴上降低一个八度，就会敲击出两根弦的G音。所以答案就在这里——布朗拿出了确凿的证据，证明磁带确实是对折的。

As mentioned earlier, the higher notes inside a piano include three strings, while hammers for the middle notes strike only two strings. If playing the piece at full speed in the correct octave, Martin would have struck a G with three strings. Stepping down an octave on the piano, however, would produce a G note from two strings. So that was the answer—Brown had produced irrefutable proof that the tape had indeed been doubled up.

当他回头观看1964年BBC的一档名为《Top Gear》的节目时，发现披头士乐队在录音室录制完成三个月后现场演奏了《A Hard Day's Night》。布朗很久以前就注意到的一些不一致之处开始变得清晰起来。就在乔治独奏之前，影片因一个明显的拼接而出现了卡顿。布朗说，造成这种情况的原因是哈里森当时还没有掌握以正常速度演奏独奏的技巧，所以节目组把这部分配音了进去。

When he went back and looked at a BBC show from 1964 called Top Gear, which featured a live performance of the Beatles playing “A Hard Day’s Night” about three months after they finished recording it in the studio, some inconsistencies Brown had noticed long before began to make more sense. Right before George’s solo, the film hiccups from an obvious splice. The reason for this, says Brown, was because Harrison had not yet mastered playing the solo at normal speed, so the show dubbed that part in.

布朗很快指出，这段录音丝毫没有贬低哈里森的水平。事实上，哈里森在BBC录音后的几周内就掌握了全速独奏的技巧。布朗在一篇数学期刊上写道：“乔治·哈里森有勇气以半速演奏如此大胆而快速的独奏，这值得称赞（披头士的粉丝们也为此感到高兴），因为他知道，很快他就必须站出来，在全世界的注视下，以全速演奏。”二十七

Brown is quick to point out that this studio work in no way detracts from Harrison’s ability. Harrison did in fact go on to master the solo at full speed within weeks of the BBC recording. Brown wrote in a math journal, “It is to George Harrison’s credit (and Beatles’ fans’ delight) that he had the nerve to play such a daring and quick solo at half speed, knowing that very soon he would have to step up to the plate and play it up to speed, with all the world watching.”27

布朗现在着手破解披头士乐队的另一个谜团，而这个谜团将引向一个微妙的领域。这个和弦之谜一直是披头士乐队和马丁乐于维持的，并且在某种程度上明确承认的。另一方面，许多狂热的披头士乐迷都知道，麦卡特尼和列侬都声称自己创作了《我生命中》（In My Life）的大部分内容，这首歌被公认为乐队最优秀的作品之一。包括《Mojo》杂志在内的一些人认为它是有史以来最伟大的歌曲。它仍然是列侬和麦卡特尼公开持有不同意见的极少数几首歌曲之一，考虑到两人共同创作的音乐数量之多，这真是令人惊叹。

Brown has now set out to tackle another Beatles mystery, one that leads to delicate territory. The chord riddle has always been one that the Beatles and Martin enjoyed sustaining and, to some degree, explicitly acknowledging. Alternatively, many passionate Beatles fans know that both McCartney and Lennon claimed to have written the majority of “In My Life,” a song recognized as one of the band’s very best. Some, including Mojo magazine, say it’s the greatest song ever recorded. It remains one of the very few tunes that Lennon and McCartney publicly disagreed on, a remarkable thing considering how much music the two created together.

为了确定谁更有可能是这首歌的作者，布朗构建了一个算法引擎，分析已知的麦卡特尼或列侬创作的歌曲。通过这些歌曲输入，算法构建了两位作者风格的典型基础结构。

To determine who was more likely to have authored the song, Brown built an algorithmic engine analyzing songs known to have been written by either McCartney or Lennon. From these song inputs, the algorithm builds a typical base structure of both writers’ styles.

为了实现这一点，布朗运用了图论，正如欧拉桥问题所示，图论运用了边和节点。布朗指导他的算法将重复的副歌定义为节点，将副歌之间的诗句定义为边。

To do this, Brown utilized graph theory, which, as illustrated in Euler’s bridge problem, employs edges and nodes. Brown instructed his algorithm to define repeating choruses as nodes and the verses in between as edges.

截至撰写本文时，布朗表示他尚未将《In My Life》输入算法。如果输入了，他会将其结构与两位作者的平均水平进行比较。然后，他会做出最终决定。然而，从这个项目的进展来看，布朗可能不愿涉足披头士乐队两位成员争议的领域，其中一位成员至今仍然健在。

As of this writing, Brown says he’s yet to feed “In My Life” to the algorithm. When and if he does, he’ll compare its structure to that of the mean of both writers. From there, he’ll make a declaration. Judging from the time that’s elapsed on this project, however, Brown may be reticent to trespass on ground disputed by two of the Beatles, one of whom is still quite alive.

4

4

机器人的秘密高速公路

THE SECRET HIGHWAYS OF BOTS

算法的价值 在于其速度。如果它们无法在几分之一秒内完成复杂的任务，就无法成为如今的革命性力量。速度很大程度上取决于一个因素：硬件。

THE VALUE OF ALGORITHMS IS all in their speed. If they weren’t able to run through complex tasks in fractions of a second, they wouldn’t be the revolutionizing force they’ve become. Speed is largely determined by one thing: hardware.

如果没有过去几十年硬件的飞速发展，华尔街如今纷争不断的算法，以及未来日益被算法统治的世界的幽灵，都不可能出现。我们家中的算法很大程度上得益于构成网络的神奇代码和电信基础设施。像Netflix那样决定你想看什么电影的算法之所以重要，是因为它能够快速正确地权衡数千个输入因素，并将决策反馈给你。如果这个过程不是几乎即时的，它就不是一个有效的工具。

Neither Wall Street’s warring algorithms nor the specter of a coming world that is increasingly ruled by algorithms would be possible without the galloping progress of hardware during the last several decades. Algorithms in our homes have been largely enabled by the wondrous code and telecommunications infrastructure that make up the Web. An algorithm that decides what movie you may want to watch, like the one employed by Netflix, is relevant because of the speed at which it can weight thousands of input factors correctly and get a decision back to you. If the process weren’t almost instantaneous, it wouldn’t be an effective tool.

算法让我们能够将时间压缩到更多。在算法和计算机的世界里，用更少的时间完成更多的事情被称为消除延迟。在消除延迟的努力中，华尔街处于最前沿，在那里，算法之战已经变成了一场竞赛，看谁能更快地完成同样的事情。

Algorithms allow us to squeeze more and more into our days. Doing more in less time, in the algorithmic and computer world, is known as removing latency. At the cutting edge of this effort to eliminate latency is Wall Street, where the algorithm wars have become something of a contest to see who can do the same thing faster.

20世纪90年代，随着华尔街涌现出大量黑客人才，越来越多的公司采用了类似的策略和算法。由于他们的策略和代码与其他公司几乎没有区别，交易员们不断追求更优的硬件、更先进的计算机和更完善的电信线路。他们的想法是，如果交易员们无法战胜竞争对手，那么或许他们可以用火力压制对手。即使是最好的算法，速度也会让他们望尘莫及。正因如此，2010年，两名男子建造了一个横跨半个国家的秘密地鼠洞。

As Wall Street filled up with hacker talent throughout the 1990s, more and more firms employed similar strategies and similar algorithms. With so little separating their tactics and their code from others, traders continually pushed for better hardware, better computers, and better telecommunications lines. If traders couldn’t outsmart their competition, then perhaps, the thinking went, they could outgun them. Even the best algorithms can be thwarted by speed. This is why, in 2010, two men built a secret gopher hole that stretched halfway across the country.

贸易就是挖掘

TO TRADE IS TO DIG

这个不可思议的故事始于2008年，当时一家纽约对冲基金委托丹尼尔·斯皮维（Daniel Spivey）开发一种算法交易策略，用于寻找芝加哥指数期货与其纽约标的股票和证券之间微小的价格差异。如果芝加哥期货价格高于其在纽约的所有股票价格，该策略就会卖出芝加哥期货，买入纽约股票。当芝加哥和纽约的价格重新调整时——而且它们总是会重新调整——斯皮维的程序就会平仓获利。

The unlikely tale begins in 2008, when a New York hedge fund asked Daniel Spivey to develop an algorithmic trading strategy that searched out tiny price discrepancies between index futures in Chicago and their underlying stocks and securities in New York. If the future cost more in Chicago than did all of its stocks in New York, the strategy would sell futures in Chicago and buy stocks in New York. When prices in Chicago and New York realigned—and they always realigned—Spivey’s program would dump its positions and book its profit.

斯皮维的策略与托马斯·彼得菲在不同市场利用类似股指进行套利并无二致——只是斯皮维必须更快。随着算法交易的兴起，任何低风险套利交易都会吸引大量人群，因此这类策略对速度的要求更高。如果交易员或对冲基金能够率先入场，就能轻松获利。而对于那些仅仅落后一毫秒的人来说，就什么都不是。

Spivey’s strategy was no different than the arbitrage Thomas Peterffy did with similar stock indexes in disparate markets—except Spivey had to do it a lot faster. With the rise of algorithmic trading, any kind of low-risk arbitrage bet draws a crowd, which is why such strategies demand speed. If a trader or hedge fund can be first in to the trade, there’s easy money to be made. For those just a millisecond behind, there’s nothing.

为了正确执行他为对冲基金编写的算法，斯皮维需要在芝加哥和纽约之间最快的光纤网络上获得空间。他的交易信号必须排在数百万条在市场之间来回传递的交易信息的最前面。但斯皮维和对冲基金都无法获得任何带宽；这条线路已经完全占满，很少出现故障。

To properly execute the algorithms he had composed for the hedge fund, Spivey needed space on the fastest fiber-optic network between Chicago and New York. His trade signals had to be among the first in line of the millions of trade messages firing back and forth between the markets. But neither Spivey nor the hedge fund could secure any bandwidth on the line; it was 100 percent full and defections were rare.

斯皮维能够在所谓的“亮光纤”上找到一些空间——亮光纤是指光纤电缆上的共享空间，由其他人（例如电信公司）拥有和运营。它以光速传输信息，但信息在光纤束中获得的带宽较少，而且经常面临更多的中断和绕行，因为电信公司必须满足许多地方客户的多种需求。但斯皮维需要的是暗光纤，即一根由购买者或租赁者完全拥有带宽的光缆。暗光纤之所以被称为暗光纤，是因为它本质上是未经加工的；控制这条光缆的人必须提供激光器，而激光器的成本可能高达 500 万美元甚至更多，用于点亮线路并从头到尾传输数据。信息不会与光缆中的任何其他内容竞争；无论光缆到达哪里，它都可以自由地以光速快速传输。暗光纤是人类已知的最快通信载体。

Spivey was able to find some space on what’s known as lit fiber—shared space on a fiber cable that somebody else, such as a telecom company, owns and operates. It transmits information at the speed of light, but the information gets less bandwidth within the fiber strand and often faces more stopoffs and detours because a telecom company must satisfy customers in many places with many needs. But Spivey needed dark fiber, a strand of fiber-optic cable for which the buyer or leaser wholly owns the bandwidth. Dark fiber is called dark because it’s essentially raw; whoever assumes control of the strand must supply the lasers, which can cost $5 million or more, to light the line and transmit the data from the beginning to the end. The information competes with nothing else within the strand; it’s free to zip along at the speed of light wherever the strand may go. Dark fiber enables the fastest communication vehicle known to man.

由于没有可用的暗光纤，斯皮维和他的对冲基金客户无法与其他采用类似策略的投资公司和交易员竞争。他们的策略及其背后的代码，无论写得多么精彩，都毫无用处。在寻找可用的暗光纤线路的过程中，斯皮维不止一次地对自己和其他人说：“我们应该架设一条新线路——这应该没那么难。”

With no dark fiber available to him, Spivey and his hedge fund client couldn’t compete with the other investment houses and traders employing similar strategies. Their strategy and the code behind it, no matter how eloquently written, was useless. During the search for an available dark fiber line, Spivey had more than once remarked to himself and to others, “We ought to just string up a new line—it can’t be that hard.”

于是他想：“我为什么不应该这么做？”然而，还有更尖锐的问题：线路该通向哪里？如何获得土地所有者的许可？谁来租赁线路空间？这样一个项目要花多少钱？谁来买单？斯皮维对此束手无策。于是，他全身心投入到电信、土地权和高速线路的神秘世界中。

So he thought, “Why shouldn’t I do this?” There were more pointed questions, however: where would the line go, how would he gain permission from landowners, who would lease space on the line, how much would such a project cost, and who would pay for it? Spivey had few answers. So he immersed himself into the arcane world of telecom, land rights, and high-speed circuitry.

斯皮维是密西西比州人，他创办了芝加哥期权交易所最早的远程做市业务之一。他的程序交易标准普尔500指数的期权，而标准普尔500指数是世界上交易量最大的证券之一。作为算法交易专家，斯皮维花了几个月的时间学习利用光通过细管传输数据的细节。很快，他就在脑海中计算出了折射率及其对光速的影响。光在光纤中的传播路径并非完全笔直；它会在沿线传播的过程中从一面墙反射到另一面墙。折射率表示光在特定玻璃光纤中反射的速度。斯皮维天生数学天赋，他很快就投入到他的新项目中，不断地在记事本上涂鸦，并对刚刚计算出的数字进行批注。

Spivey, a native Mississippian, had started one of the first remote market-making operations on the Chicago Board Options Exchange. His programs traded options on the S&P 500 index, some of the most heavily traded securities in the world. Already an expert on algorithmic trading, Spivey spent months learning the finer points of transmitting data by light through a tiny tube. He soon was calculating in his head indexes of refraction and their effects on the speed of light. Light doesn’t travel in an exact straight path through a fiber; it bounces from wall to wall as it courses its way down the line. The index of refraction expresses how quickly light bounces through a particular glass fiber. A natural math savant, Spivey quickly took to his new project, constantly scrawling on a notepad and uncorking comments on figures he’d just calculated.

斯皮维走遍了他想象中的线路。他与铁路公司洽谈，他们同意将部分路权区域出租给他，供他铺设管道；他与管理公路的县委员会洽谈；他与农民洽谈；他与私人土地所有者、高尔夫球场以及环保人士洽谈。他了解得越多，就越相信在芝加哥和纽约之间建造一条新的私人暗光纤管道是可能的。

Spivey traveled the territory of his imagined line. He talked to railroad companies who could lease him space in their rights-of-way for part of his pipe’s journey; he talked to county boards that controlled highways; he talked to farmers; he talked to private landowners, golf courses, and environmentalists. The more he learned, the more he believed it was possible to build a new, private dark fiber pipe between Chicago and New York.

最重要的是，斯皮维设计了一种方法，使他的线路比两座城市之间现有的光纤路径更短。这些线路全程都遵循铁路通行权。电信公司喜欢这样的线路，因为它们只需要与一两家不同的实体（通常是铁路公司）打交道，就能在芝加哥和纽约之间通行。但主要的铁路走廊在宾夕法尼亚州和新泽西州会稍微向南绕行。斯皮维提出的线路将从芝加哥出发，绕过密歇根湖的尖端，然后直奔纽约，无需绕行。

Most important, Spivey had devised a way to make his line shorter than existing paths of fiber between the two cities. These lines followed railroad rights-of-way for their entire route. Telecom companies like such paths because they require dealing with just one or two different entities, usually rail companies, to get between Chicago and New York. But the major rail corridors take a slight detour south in Pennsylvania and New Jersey. Spivey’s proposed path would leave Chicago, nudge around the tip of Lake Michigan, and fire straight east toward New York with no detours.

这条线路将比现有最短光纤路径的往返距离缩短一百英里。然而，光纤中的光速在不到四毫秒（千分之四秒）的时间内就能完成这段距离。“这在自动化交易中几乎是永恒的，”伊利诺伊理工学院教授本·范·弗利特说道。“这就像从地上捡起金币一样——只有速度最快的人才能拿到金币。”

The route would trim a hundred miles off the round-trip of existing shortest fiber paths. The speed of light in fiber, however, covers that distance in less than four milliseconds—four thousandths of a second. “That’s close to an eternity in automated trading,” says Ben Van Vliet, a professor at the Illinois Institute of Technology. “This is all about picking gold coins up off the floor—only the fastest person is going to get the coins.”

斯皮维知道他的项目能引起人们的极大兴趣。如果这条线路能够建成，像 Peterffy、Getco、Tradebot 和 Infinium 这样的大型算法交易商会斥巨资确保自己能参与其中。高盛、瑞信和摩根士丹利等银行也同样如此。

Spivey knew his project could generate plenty of interest. If the line could be built, big algorithmic traders like Peterffy, Getco, Tradebot, and Infinium would pay large sums to ensure they were on it. The same went for banks like Goldman Sachs, Credit Suisse, and Morgan Stanley.

斯皮维利用地图软件，标出了芝加哥和纽约之间直线延伸的县级和州级公路。与现有的光纤线路一样，他可以在最西端的路段使用铁路通行权，因为这些线路与他的路线一致。这样可以节省一些成本。在这种地形平坦的地方铺设新光纤的成本约为每英里25万美元。但沿着宾夕法尼亚州的山区公路和新泽西州的丘陵地带铺设地下管道的成本将是这个数字的三到四倍。整个项目至少需要2亿美元。

Using mapping software, Spivey highlighted county and state highways that hugged a straight line between Chicago and New York. Like existing fiber lines, he could use rail rights-of-way for the westernmost leg of the trip, as they stayed true to his course. That would save him some money. Laying new fiber in easy terrain like this runs about $250,000 per mile. But threading a pipe underground along the mountain highways of Pennsylvania and through the hills of New Jersey would cost three or four times as much. The project would run at least $200 million.

斯皮维需要一个有影响力、有资金、并且能承受风险的人来与他合作开展这项事业。他立刻想到了一位密西西比同乡。詹姆斯·巴克斯代尔曾在20世纪80年代担任联邦快递的首席运营官，后来又担任AT&T无线的首席执行官，他的履历光彩夺目。在被硅谷最具传奇色彩的公司之一任命为首席执行官之前，他曾将AT&T无线推向电信行业的巅峰。

Spivey needed somebody with clout, money, and a tolerance for risk to partner with him on the venture. A fellow Mississippian came immediately to mind. James Barksdale had burnished his résumé as the COO of FedEx during the 1980s and as CEO of AT&T Wireless, which he propelled to the top of the telecom heap before he was tapped to be CEO by one of the most legendary companies Silicon Valley ever produced.

网景公司诞生于20世纪90年代的伊利诺伊大学香槟分校，当时马克·安德森带领学生们开发了第一款流行的网络浏览器，当时名为Mosaic，它开启了互联网时代。现代浏览器仍然保留着安德森及其团队在校期间编写的大部分代码。尽管安德森编写了代码并开启了这场革命，并在24岁时登上了《时代》杂志的封面，但正是巴克斯代尔帮助网景公司成为科技热潮中最炙手可热的公司之一，直到1998年美国在线以42亿美元收购了网景公司。

Netscape came out of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in the 1990s when students led by Marc Andreessen developed the first popular Web browser, then called Mosaic, which ushered in the age of the Internet. Modern browsers still carry much of the code Andreessen and his team produced while in school. And though Andreessen wrote the code and started the revolution, ending up on the cover of Time magazine at the age of twenty-four, it was Barksdale who helped Netscape become one of the hottest companies of the tech boom before AOL bought it in 1998 for $4.2 billion.

繁荣过后，巴克斯代尔搬回了家乡密西西比州杰克逊。他基本上已经退休了，但斯皮维觉得或许可以试试另一个古怪的想法。斯皮维利用自己的关系安排了一次会面。巴克斯代尔听了计划，却不知该作何感想。

After the boom, Barksdale moved back to his native Jackson, Mississippi. He was essentially retired, but Spivey thought he might want to roll the dice on another zany idea. Spivey tapped his connections and got a meeting. Barksdale listened to the plan. He didn’t know what to think.

“一开始我说，‘拜托，你在开玩笑吧，’”他回忆道，当时他很纳闷，这个项目要如何才能以合理的成本翻越群山。但他仔细思考后意识到：“如果不是难题，早就有人做了。”

“At first I said, ‘Come on, you’re pulling my leg,’” he recalls, wondering how the project would get through the mountains at a reasonable cost. But as he pondered it, he realized, “If it wasn’t a tough problem, somebody else would have already done it.”

巴克斯代尔同意担任该项目的主要融资方，由于保密需要，无法提前获得任何光纤合同，因此风险巨大。更令巴克斯代尔感到不安的是，由于该项目必须完全秘密进行，他无法与许多熟知的电信业内人士沟通。如果过早公开建设计划，某些人，甚至可能只是一家贸易公司，都可能试图建设自己的线路，从而削弱斯皮维和巴克斯代尔独有的速度优势。尽管风险重重，巴克斯代尔还是加入了进来。他的儿子，一位并购律师大卫，担任首席执行官，斯皮维则担任总裁。Spread Networks 由此诞生。

Barksdale agreed to be the primary financer of the project, a big risk when no fiber contracts could be secured ahead of time because of the need for secrecy. Also disconcerting to Barksdale, he was unable to bounce the idea off many telecom people he knew because the project had to proceed in total stealth. If the construction became public too early, somebody, perhaps even a single trading house, could try to build their own line, quashing Spivey and Barksdale’s exclusive speed advantage. Despite all the risks, Barksdale climbed aboard. His son, David, a mergers and acquisitions lawyer, became CEO and Spivey assumed the role of president. Spread Networks was born.

斯皮维和小巴克斯代尔立即踏上征程，争取获得许可，在他们铺设直线路线所需的每一块地块上进行挖掘。“这并不总是一件容易的事；有些人不希望在俄亥俄州的农村地区铺设光纤，”斯皮维说道。他必须向县议会成员（其中一些人仍在使用美国在线拨号上网）详细解释他为什么要在他们的地盘上挖掘。有些人对华尔街心存疑虑，有些人对联邦政府心存疑虑，而斯皮维与联邦政府毫无关系，大多数人之所以心存疑虑，是因为他们根本无法理解秘密通信线路的意义。

Spivey and the younger Barksdale immediately set out on a journey to secure permission to burrow through each and every land parcel their straight-line path required. “It’s not always an easy pitch; some people don’t want fiber optics in rural Ohio,” says Spivey, who had to explain in exacting detail to county board members, some of whom still used AOL to dial into the Internet, why he wanted to dig through their territory. Some were suspicious of Wall Street, some were suspicious of the federal government, which Spivey had nothing to do with, and most were suspicious because they simply couldn’t understand the point of a secret communications line.

到2009年初，这些人甚至说服了那些顽固的反对者。他们现在有了一条从芝加哥到纽约的畅通道路。到了3月，Spread公司的工作人员开始搬运泥土。初期的进展极其缓慢。承包商习惯于受控的环境，例如开阔的田野或铁路通行权。斯皮维和巴克斯代尔让他们钻探、挖掘和疏浚各种地形和材料：山地片岩、山谷页岩、泥土和宾夕法尼亚州的花岗岩。

By early 2009, the men had converted even the stubborn holdouts. They now had a clear path from Chicago to New York. By March, crews for Spread were moving dirt. The early going was excruciatingly slow. The contractors were used to controlled conditions, like those of open fields or rail rights-of-way. Spivey and Barksdale had them drilling, digging, and dredging through all manner of terrain and materials: mountain schist, valley shale, earthy mud, and Pennsylvania granite.

斯皮维和巴克斯代尔对这种节奏感到恼火，他们时刻警惕着可能抢占先机的竞争对手。他们担心大型自营交易公司会发现他们的计划，并抢先一步实施。尽管该项目规模庞大、成本高昂，对一家交易公司来说几乎是深不可测的，但像芝加哥的Getco这样的公司资金雄厚，愿意出钱来获得优势。

Exasperated with the pace, Spivey and Barksdale kept an ear to the ground for rivals who could usurp them. They feared that one of the large proprietary trading houses would find out about their dig and pull the trick off first. Even though the project’s scope was huge, expensive, and almost unfathomable for a trading firm, players like Chicago’s Getco had the cash and would gladly have paid to gain the advantage.

随着施工队在复杂地形中的操作越来越熟练，项目进度也越来越快，且没有竞争对手出现，Spread 的担忧也逐渐减轻。到了项目高峰期，Spread 拥有 125 个施工队同时工作。有些在印第安纳州挖沟渠，有些在俄亥俄州涉水过溪，或者在宾夕法尼亚州的州道旁驾驶反铲挖土机。阿勒格尼山脉的工人们攀附在悬崖边，小心翼翼地放置炸药，以便炸开足够的岩石，形成可以支撑钻机的岩架。钻孔机在史前岩石上钻孔，直到钻头发出灼热的白光。

Spread’s fears diminished as their crews became better in difficult terrain and the project’s velocity increased without a competitor emerging. By the height of the project, Spread had 125 construction crews working at once. Some dug ditches in Indiana; others waded streams in Ohio or ran backhoes next to state roads in Pennsylvania. Workers in the Allegheny Mountains hung off the sides of cliffs, carefully placing blast charges that would remove enough rock to create ledges to hold their drilling rigs. Boring machines drove holes through prehistoric rock until their bits glowed white with heat.

在与世隔绝的交易圈内，Spread 的项目几乎无人知晓。这就像乔治·华盛顿在圣诞夜横渡特拉华河一样。Spread 会彻底出其不意地打动整个行业。他们只需要率先行动。

Inside the insular world of trading, there hadn’t been so much as a whisper of Spread’s project. This was like George Washington crossing the Delaware in the middle of Christmas night. Spread would take the industry entirely by surprise. They only had to be first.

Spread 的小洞长达 825 英里，是 212 区号和 312 区号之间可能的最短路径。信息通过这条通道以光速传输，从纽约到芝加哥，再返回仅需千分之十三秒，比之前最快的路线节省了近四毫秒。

Spread’s little hole ran for 825 miles, the shortest path possible between the 212 and 312 area codes. Information passing through this conduit travels at the speed of light, getting from New York to Chicago and back in thirteen thousandths of a second, shaving nearly four milliseconds off the previous fastest route.

2010年7月，就在光纤最终接续前夕，Spread开始向贸易公司、银行、经纪公司——所有资金雄厚、追求速度的商家——推销其“武器”。人们的反应五花八门，有的难以置信——“你们是怎么做到的！？”，有的表示愿意—— “我们加入！”，还有的则对此事持观望态度——“我们不会受敲诈！”

Just before the final splice was made to the fiber in July 2010, Spread started pitching its weapon to trading houses, banks, brokerages—anybody with a lot of money and a thirst for speed. The reactions ranged from incredulous—how did you do this!?—to willing—we’re in!—to those who felt less positive on the matter—we will not be extorted!

任何直接与Spread沟通的客户都受到保密协议的约束，必须保持沉默。但非交易员的观察者却表达了他们的震惊。追踪算法交易的OptionMonster联合创始人乔恩·A·纳贾里安(Jon A. Najarian)表示：“任何同时追踪两个市场的人都必须保持这种联系，否则就完蛋了。”

Any customer who spoke directly with Spread was bound to silence by a nondisclosure agreement. But nontrader observers registered their shock. “Anybody pinging both markets has to be on this line, or they’re dead,” said Jon A. Najarian, a cofounder at OptionMonster, which tracks algorithmic trading.

Spread 的最终连接一完成，客户就排起了长队。任何在常见套利策略中具有优势的东西都将永远有价值，因为套利的低风险利润总是很受欢迎。速度才是决定谁能获得所有这些无风险利润的关键。

As soon as Spread made its final connections, customers queued up to get onto its lines. Anything that gives an advantage in common arbitrage strategies will always be valuable because arbitrage’s low-risk profits will always be popular. Playing the referee in deciding who gets all of this riskless profit is speed.

作为延迟最低的路径，Spread 的费率可能远超其他线路。Allied Fiber 在更长的铁路规划路径上铺设暗光纤，其服务费每年 30 万美元。多位与 Spread 谈判的消息人士表示，他们的要价是现行费率的八到十倍，高达每年 300 万美元。Spread 不愿透露其总容量，但其一英寸长的电缆可能足以承载至少 200 个暗光纤客户端。即使有些人对 Spread 的高费率不满，Spivey-Barksdale 的赌注也能轻松获得所需的现金流，从而证明其投资的合理性。

As the path of lowest latency, Spread could command rates dwarfing those of other lines. Allied Fiber, which runs dark fiber through the longer railroad-plotted paths, asks $300,000 a year for its service. Multiple sources who negotiated with Spread said they were asking for eight to ten times the going rates, as much as $3 million per year. Spread won’t divulge its total capacity, but its one-inch cable likely allows it to carry at least two hundred dark fiber clients. Even if some people aren’t happy about Spread’s high rates, the Spivey-Barksdale gamble is easily earning the cash flow it needs to justify its investment.

Spread Networks 只不过是 20 世纪 80 年代开始的硬件战争中最新、最先进的武器。随着算法成为执行复杂策略的首选媒介，其影响力也随着运行硬件的规模不断扩大。

Spread Networks is merely the latest and most advanced weapon in an escalating war of hardware that began in the 1980s. As algorithms became the medium of choice for executing complicated strategies, their reach has expanded in tandem with the hardware on which they run.

虽然廉价个人电脑的出现释放了发达国家算法的潜力，但互联网对我们生活的方方面面的窥探，才让算法变得更加重要。决定机器人下一个入侵的领域，取决于两个简单的因素：颠覆的潜力以及颠覆带来的回报。

While the advent of affordable PCs unleashed the potential of algorithms across the developed world, it was the Internet nosing into every facet of our lives that has made them all the more relevant. Determining the next field to be invaded by bots is the sum of two simple functions: the potential to disrupt plus the reward for disruption.

长期以来，这个公式计算出的总数在华尔街是最高的，这就是为什么我们这么多最聪明的人，从工程师到物理学家，再到博士，都开始涌向那里。然而，这些人才的聚集并没有阻止该行业在2008年播下经济灾难的种子，华尔街的这支智力队伍也没有解决人类面临的任何最棘手的问题。他们就是没有做到这一点，尽管高盛首席执行官劳埃德·布兰克费恩认为他们“在做上帝的工作”。

For a long time, that equation yielded the largest total on Wall Street, which is why so many of our smartest people, from engineers to physicists to PhDs, began flocking there. Still, that collection of brainpower didn’t stop the industry from seeding economic disaster in 2008, nor has this corps of intelligence on Wall Street managed to solve any of the most vexing issues facing humanity. They just don’t do that, even though by Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein’s reckoning they’re “doing God’s work.”

华尔街将世界推向无政府状态的边缘，然后又销声匿迹，这并不奇怪。这种情况可能永远不会改变。但几乎每天都在变化的是，可供交易员及其算法使用的硬件和技术。华尔街技术的发展历程至关重要，因为它的进步最终惠及了经济的其他领域。即使是像Spread Networks这样为华尔街建造的光纤隧道，其影响也早已超出了算法交易员的小圈子。斯皮维和巴克斯代尔的线路现在将宽带传输到以前没有宽带的小城镇。Spread正在为医院和诊所传输大型医学影像文件。该公司以可承受的价格为这些非华尔街实体提供亮光纤——这个机会之所以存在，是因为算法交易员愿意花费数百万美元购买Spread暗光纤的独家线路。

That Wall Street would bring the world to the edge of anarchy and then go whistling into the night is hardly surprising. That’s a condition that may never change. But what does change, almost daily, is the hardware and technology available to grappling traders and their algorithms. The story of how Wall Street’s technology has evolved is important because its progress eventually flowed to the rest of the economy. Even in the case of Spread Networks, a fiber-optic tunnel built for Wall Street, its effects have already leaked beyond the small world of algorithmic traders. Spivey and Barksdale’s line now carries broadband to small towns that didn’t have it. Spread is transferring large medical image files for hospitals and doctor’s offices. The company offers these non–Wall Street entities lit fiber at affordable prices—an opportunity that exists only because algorithmic traders were willing to shell out millions for exclusive strands of Spread’s dark fiber.

金钱、速度和技术总是相辅相成，无论好坏

MONEY, SPEED, AND TECHNOLOGY HAVE ALWAYS GONE TOGETHER, FOR BETTER OR WORSE

Spread Networks 将暗光纤独家提供给那些拥有巨额资金的人，这或许会让人觉得不公平、不民主，或许也应该如此。如果每年租赁所需的武器就需要花费 300 万美元，自由市场又怎么能算自由呢？但几个世纪以来，独家、昂贵且保密的技术一直是我们金融和商业网络结构的一部分。那些拥有最快资源的人拥有了赚钱的优势。而那些拥有这些资源的人早已致富。这其实是资本主义的一个弱点，并非新鲜事。

The exclusivity of Spread Networks’ dark fiber to those possessing barrels of cash may strike some as unfair and undemocratic, and perhaps it should. How can a free market be free when it takes $3 million a year just to lease the weapons required to play? But exclusive, expensive, and secretive technology has been part of the fabric of our financial and business networks for centuries. Those with the means to be fastest have an edge that enables them to make money. And those with the means are already rich. It’s a foible of capitalism that is hardly new.

但如果没有金融市场的压力，不可否认的是，我们的通信网络，无论是口口相传、信鸽、电报、电话、电视、互联网，还是专用的暗光纤，发展速度都会慢得多。没有光速通信，就不会有云计算。没有云计算——它允许远程服务器和计算机将其处理能力扩展到几乎任何地方——那么无所不知的算法就不可能存在。

But without the pressure applied by our financial markets, there’s no denying that our communications networks, be they word of mouth, pigeons, telegraphs, telephones, television, the Web, or dedicated strands of dark fiber, would have been developed at a slower pace. Without light-speed communication, there would be no cloud computing. Without cloud computing, which allows remote servers and computers to extend their processing power almost anywhere, all-knowing algorithms wouldn’t be possible.

1815年，内森·罗斯柴尔德是世界上最富有的人之一，他经常利用自己掌握的科技资源来增加财富。他与他的四个兄弟一起在伦敦、巴黎、维也纳、那不勒斯和法兰克福经营银行。兄弟俩经常使用信鸽携带加密信息的小卷在银行之间进行通信。这种系统使罗斯柴尔德家族的银行比那些等待马匹信使传递信息的竞争对手更具优势。1

In 1815, Nathan Rothschild was one of the richest people in the world, and he regularly used his access to technology to add to his fortune. Along with his four brothers, he ran banks in London, Paris, Vienna, Naples, and Frankfurt.
