The brothers often used carrier pigeons carrying tiny rolls of encoded messages to communicate from bank to bank. This system afforded the Rothschilds’ banks advantages over competitors who waited for communications via horse-bound courier.1

数千年来，鸽子一直在世界各地传递信息，从中国、希腊到波斯和印度。为了拦截敌人的信息，罗马人使用猎鸽鹰。这使得信息发送者使用诱饵鸽和密码——所有这些在19世纪都被罗斯柴尔德家族运用。1815年，欧洲卷入了一场偶发性混战，这场混战是由拿破仑在法国重新掌权引发的。6月18日，拿破仑的法国军队在滑铁卢战役中与英国、普鲁士、荷兰和其他盟国的联军遭遇。

Pigeons have ferried messages for thousands of years across much of the world, from China and Greece to Persia and India. To intercept the messages of enemies, the Romans employed pigeon-seeking hawks. This led message senders to employ decoy pigeons as well as codes—all of which the Rothschild family used in the 1800s. In 1815, Europe was embroiled in one of its episodic melees, this one brought on by the return of Napoleon to power in France. Napoleon’s French forces met the combined forces of Britain, Prussia, the Netherlands, and other allies in the battle of Waterloo on June 18.

在伦敦的债券交易大厅里，玩家们等待着战争的消息。英国的失败会导致债券价格暴跌，因为人们担心政府会因此陷入困境。对内森·罗斯柴尔德来说，这无疑是一个绝佳的操控时机。他的信鸽网络比伦敦的其他人，包括英国政府，提前24小时将拿破仑战败的消息传递给他。

On the bond trading floors of London, players waited for the arrival of news about the battle. A British defeat would send bond values diving for fear that the government would be on shaky ground. For Nathan Rothschild, this was the perfect situation to manipulate. His pigeon network delivered him news of Napoleon’s defeat twenty-four hours before anyone else in London, including the British government.

罗斯柴尔德知道胜利属于英国，于是走到交易大厅里他惯常的位置——一根柱子前。交易一开始，他立即神气活现地开始抛售债券。其他交易员以为他了解战事，觉得消息不妙。市场一落千丈，正如罗斯柴尔德预料的那样，他已经停止抛售自己的股票。随着抛售的持续，罗斯柴尔德的数十名爪牙开始悄悄买入债券。第二天，当英国胜利的真正消息传遍大众耳中时，罗斯柴尔德购买的债券价格暴涨。2

Knowing victory belonged to the British, Rothschild headed to his normal spot in front of a pillar on the trading floor. When the session began, he immediately, with a flourish, started dumping bonds. Other traders assumed he knew something about the battle and that the news was bad. The market went into a free fall, just as Rothschild, who had stopped selling himself, knew it would. As the selling continued, dozens of Rothschild’s minions began quietly buying up bonds. When the true news of British victory reached the masses the next day, the bonds Rothschild had purchased exploded in value.2

技术总是始于少数特权阶层。然而，那些创造巨额财富的人，正是那些让技术大众化的人。以色列·比尔·约萨法特就是这样的人。他19世纪初在哥廷根长大，在叔叔的银行担任职员，在那里他学习了金融知识。约萨法特移民到伦敦，改名为保罗·朱利叶斯·路透。他想出了一个主意，在当时正开始在欧洲兴起的电报线路末端部署鸽队。路透的鸽子会把巴黎证券交易所的收盘价从布鲁塞尔传到一百英里外的亚琛。他的鸽子比马车信使和铁路更胜一筹。3

Technology always begins in the hands of a privileged few. Some of those who make the greatest fortunes, however, are the people who democratize technology. Such is the case of Israel Beer Josaphat, who grew up in Göttingen in the early nineteenth century and worked as a clerk at his uncle’s bank, where he learned the fabric of finance. Josaphat emigrated to London, changing his name to Paul Julius Reuter. He came up with the idea of stationing pigeon fleets at the end of telegraph lines, which were starting to sprout across Europe. Reuter’s pigeons would carry news of closing prices on the Paris Stock Exchange from Brussels to Aachen, one hundred miles away. His birds beat horse couriers and railroads.3

随着电报覆盖越来越多的城市，路透社开始将价格信息传播到几个街区之外，而不是几英里之外。他的座右铭变成了“跟着电缆走”，这句箴言至今仍适用于路透社如今发展成为的全球信息网络。随着路透社等服务的扩张，富人和穷人之间的信息鸿沟正在缩小。即使是Spread Networks，也有数十家实体加入了该公司的暗光纤，从而削弱了个体经营者如果这条线路是由大型贸易公司或银行建造的，原本可以享有的优势。诚然，加入Spread Networks服务的高昂价格，为那些想要与最大的电子交易商竞争的人设置了一道排他性障碍。但Spread Networks的可用性仍然提供了一种比罗斯柴尔德家族时代更加民主化的局面，当时他们的信鸽网络是100%专有和排他性的。

As telegraphs moved to more and more cities, Reuter began disseminating prices across distances of blocks rather than miles. His motto became “follow the cable,” a mantra that still well applies to the global information network that Reuters has grown into. As services like Reuter’s expanded, the information gap between the richest and the rest narrowed. Even in the case of Spread Networks, dozens of entities have climbed aboard the company’s dark fiber, thus diluting the advantage that a sole proprietor could have claimed had the line been built by a large trading house or a bank. It’s true that the high price of joining Spread Networks’ service makes for an exclusive barrier to those who want to brawl with the biggest electronic traders. But Spread’s availability still provides for a more democratized situation than existed in the Rothschilds’ day, when their pigeon network was 100 percent proprietary and exclusive.

速度的孵化器

THE INCUBATOR OF SPEED

南北战争结束后，纽约的经纪公司通过跑腿人员随时了解场内价格，这些跑腿人员会从一家经纪公司跑到另一家经纪公司，就像彼得菲的跑腿人员全天向交易所运送新的电脑机箱一样。

Following the Civil War, brokerage houses in New York were kept apprised of prices on the floor by runners who would sprint from one brokerage house to another, not unlike Peterffy’s running men who delivered new computer boxes to the exchange throughout the day.

从1867年开始，纽约证券交易所开始将市场价格电报到股票行情自动收录机上。第一批股票行情自动收录机运行缓慢。“慢得连跑腿的都觉得它不值一提，”《纽约时报》评论道。4尽管如此，股票行情自动收录系统是世界上第一个电子广播系统，并引领了华尔街技术的发展潮流。

Beginning in 1867, the New York Stock Exchange began telegraphing market prices to ticker-tape machines. The first ticker machines were lethargic. “So slow even runners could view it with scorn,” said the New York Times.4 Nevertheless, the stock ticker system was the first electronic broadcast system on earth and would set the trend of technology debuting on Wall Street.

黄金和股票电报公司（后来被西联汇款收购）拥有首个股票行情机网络。这些设备经常出现故障。一次特别令人困惑的故障，让一位住在黄金交易所锅炉房的22岁机械师来到交易大厅。几个小时后，这位年轻的技师解决了困扰他资深同事的一个问题。一年后，这位机械师发明了一种更新、更快的股票行情机，并在整个美国网络中安装使用。这位机械师就是托马斯·爱迪生，他的股票行情机系统持续运行了近60年。5 1929 年夏天，就在大萧条之前的十月危机的几个月前，纽约证券交易所和西联汇款宣布了一项耗资 400 万美元的计划，将更换美国所有的股票行情自动收录机。

The Gold and Stock Telegraph Company, later absorbed by Western Union, owned the first network of stock ticker machines. The devices broke constantly. One particularly flummoxing break summoned to the trading floor a twenty-two-year-old mechanic who lived in the Gold Exchange’s boiler room. After a few hours, the young technician was able to fix a problem that had stymied his senior coworkers. A year later, the same mechanic invented a newer, faster ticker machine that was installed across the entire U.S. network. The mechanic was Thomas Edison, and his system of ticker machines remained in operation for almost sixty years.5 In the summer of 1929, just months before the October crash that preceded the Depression, the New York Stock Exchange and Western Union announced a $4 million program that would replace every ticker machine in the United States.

任何不彻底改造系统的做法都是不公平的，因为老款的自动收银机会让那些阅读的人处于不利地位。事实上，由于新机器是分阶段安装的，西联汇款不得不想办法降低它们的速度，使其运行速度与老机器相同，这样它们就不会给那些想要抢占市场先机的交易员带来不公平的优势。6新收银机安装后不久，西联汇款就宣布，十年来首次将月费从 25 美元上调。7从那时起，以技术允许的最快速度获取信息的价格就无情地上涨，最终导致我们的单根暗光纤每年的价格高达 300 万美元。

Anything less than a total overhaul of the system would be unfair, as the older ticker machines would leave those reading them at a disadvantage. In fact, as the new machines were installed in phases, Western Union had to devise a way to slow them down to run at the same speed as the older machines so they wouldn’t offer unfair advantages to traders looking to front-run the rest of the market.6 Not long after the new tickers were installed, Western Union announced that they would be raising the rates from $25 per month for the first time in a decade.7 From there, the price of getting information as quickly as technology allowed escalated inexorably, culminating in our single strands of dark fiber that fetch $3 million per year.

Spread Networks 完成其线路铺设几周后，有传言称，一条更短的管道即将从纽约通往芝加哥。这条传言在热门财经博客和黑客聊天室（例如 NuclearPhynance）上流传，声称有一家公司正在从芝加哥到纽约钻一个绝对直线的地洞。这个地洞将消除地球曲率的影响，确保尽可能短的线路。

Just weeks after Spread Networks completed its route, rumors popped up of a yet shorter pipe from New York to Chicago. The gossip, circulated on popular finance blogs and hacker chat rooms such as NuclearPhynance, posited that a company was drilling a hole in an absolute straight line through the earth from Chicago to New York. This hole would dispense with the earth’s curvature, ensuring the shortest route possible.

这个项目听起来很有趣，但其实完全是个骗局。“是啊，我听说过，”Spread Networks 总裁斯皮维笑着说。“但愿它短期内别搞出来。”

As fun as it sounded, the project was a complete hoax. “Yeah, I heard about that one,” says Spivey, the Spread Networks president, with a laugh. “Let’s hope it doesn’t get done anytime soon.”

然而，在量化分析师和黑客的追捕下，Spread 的“城堡”永远无法完全稳固。2011 年末，一家名为 Cielo Networks 的公司开始研究在芝加哥和纽约之间构建无线微波网络。微波以光速传播，但不会因光纤电缆内部的折射而减慢速度。理论上，这种方法可以将 Spread 13.3 毫秒的往返时间缩短 4 毫秒。

But with quants and hackers chasing them, Spread’s castle will never be totally secure. In late 2011, a company called Cielo Networks started investigating constructing a wireless microwave network between Chicago and New York. Microwaves travel at the speed of light but aren’t slowed by the refraction inside a fiber-optic cable. The method could theoretically shave four more milliseconds off Spread’s 13.3-millisecond round-trip.

对 Spread 来说幸运的是，该计划仍然存在巨大的障碍。大多数能够承载足够数据的频率必须获得政府许可，而且目前尚不清楚这些带宽何时才能开放，甚至根本无法确定。购买这些频率所需的资金将是巨大的。交易员并非资金短缺，但他们可能会发现自己正在与谷歌或微软之类的公司竞价，这些公司的财力雄厚，如果他们愿意，甚至可以抵御华尔街的攻击。即使频率得到保障，微波也需要从发射站到发射站的清晰视线。在某些情况下，Cielo Networks 需要摧毁山顶，并确保发射塔的位置接近纽约和芝加哥之间的直线，这项任务既不容易，成本也不低。

Luckily for Spread, there still exist large barriers to the scheme. Most frequencies that can carry enough data must be licensed from the government, and there’s no knowing when such bandwidths will become available, if at all. And the money needed to buy such frequencies would be enormous. Not that traders have a shortage of cash, but they could find themselves bidding against the likes of Google or Microsoft, companies with pockets deep enough to ward off even Wall Street if they so choose. Even if the frequencies are secured, microwaves require clear lines of sight from transmitting station to transmitting station. Cielo Networks would in some cases need to obliterate mountaintops and secure towers that hew close to the true straight line between New York and Chicago, a task neither easy nor cheap.

正如网络会受到地理位置的限制（至少是暂时的），算法也会受到其运行硬件的限制（至少是暂时的）。硬件在速度、尺寸和效率方面的飞跃，如同太阳的升起和落下一样可靠。随着这些飞跃，算法的效用也随之扩展。你口袋里的手机比 20 世纪 80 年代早期的大多数超级计算机都强大；这个小小的矩形是算法渗透到我们生活的最新媒介，它们的力量远远超出了我们的办公桌和电脑屏幕。入侵并没有止步于华尔街房间大小的交易机器，也不会止步于你的手机。

Just as networks can be limited by geography, at least temporarily, algorithms can be limited by the hardware on which they run, at least temporarily. Hardware leaps in speed, size, and efficiency are as dependable as the sun’s rise and fall. With these leaps, algorithms’ utility expands in tandem. The phone in your pocket is more powerful than most supercomputers of the early 1980s; this little rectangle is the latest medium through which algorithms have infiltrated our lives, extending their power far past our desks and computer screens. The invasion didn’t stop with room-sized trading machines on Wall Street, and it won’t stop with your phone either.

5

5

钻制度的空子

GAMING THE SYSTEM

1989年，IBM批准 几位科学家开始研发一台机器，其目标是击败世界上最优秀的国际象棋选手。众所周知，这台机器最终被命名为“深蓝”（Deep Blue）。1997年，深蓝击败了国际象棋大师加里·卡斯帕罗夫，达到了其巅峰状态。深蓝重达1.4吨，同时运行着256个处理器，每秒能够分析2亿种不同的棋局。卡斯帕罗夫每秒分析的棋局大约是三种。1 《新闻周刊》称这场象棋比赛是“大脑的最后一战”。

IN 1989, IBM CLEARED A few scientists to begin working on a machine whose stated goal was to beat the best chess players in the world. The machine, as many well know, was eventually dubbed Deep Blue. At the height of its powers in 1997, when it defeated the grand master Garry Kasparov, Deep Blue weighed 1.4 tons and ran 256 processors in tandem, which allowed it to examine 200 million different chess positions per second. Kasparov examined about three positions per second.1 Newsweek declared the chess match “The Brain’s Last Stand.”

深蓝的胜利并没有什么优雅之处。这只是用更多的武器压制对手而已。在一场国际象棋比赛中，计算机几乎会探索每一步棋可能出现的所有情况。它会对任何可用的走法都进行探索——无论这一步棋多么无用或愚蠢。然后，机器人会先为对手绘制各种可能性，然后再为自己绘制，然后再为对手绘制，如此反复，最终形成一个包含数百万种可能性的复杂走法矩阵。但深蓝的设计初衷就是为了处理这种繁重的任务。

There was little elegant about Deep Blue’s victory. This was a case of simply outgunning an opponent with more armaments. During a chess match, the computer explored nearly every possible scenario leading from a given move. It did this for any available move—no matter how useless or stupid the move might be. The bot then mapped possibilities for the opponent, and then again for itself, and then again for the opponent, and so on, resulting in a twisted matrix of moves with millions of possibilities. But Deep Blue was built to handle that load.

一个庞大的科学家团队耗费数年时间才打造出一个下棋机器人。深蓝的成功能否引领机器人深入研究那些需要细致入微的分析以及构成人类直觉的更多不可量化元素的领域？在国际象棋中，所有信息都一览无余，双方都可以看到。没有什么是未知的，这使得它成为算法攻击的绝佳游戏。但即便如此，攻击难度也很大。在扑克这样的游戏中，击败最优秀的人类选手似乎是不可能的，因为扑克包含虚张声势、跟注、弃牌——所有这些动作都包含不可量化且非常人性化的元素。但自深蓝获胜以来，有一点变得清晰：算法将继续入侵我们一直认为仍是人类固有技能的职业和领域。国际象棋仅仅是个开始。

It took a large team of scientists years to build, simply, a bot to play chess. Was it possible to expect, coming off of Deep Blue’s success, bots to delve into realms that required nuance and more of the unquantifiable elements that make up human intuition? In chess, all of the information is laid bare for both sides to see. There’s nothing that’s unknown, which made it a perfect game to be attacked with algorithms. And even that was hard. Beating the best humans at a game like poker, which incorporates bluffing, calling, folding—all moves that involve an unquantifiable and very human element—seemed impossible. But what’s become clear in the years since Deep Blue’s victory is that algorithms will continue to invade professions and skill areas that we have always assumed will remain inherently human. Chess was just the beginning.

2011年初，IBM 的最新成果沃森在智力游戏节目《危险边缘！》（Jeopardy!）中击败了所有人类选手，包括该节目历史上最多产的冠军肯·詹宁斯（Ken Jennings）。一个机器人能够如此敏捷地处理随机问题，快速查阅原始数据并给出答案，令人印象深刻。国际象棋是在有限的棋盘上进行，规则严格，而《危险边缘！》则混乱、随意，几乎没有任何关于其问题内容或性质的指导，充斥着幽默、双关和讽刺。为了做到这一点，IBM 将 2 亿页内容存储在 4 TB 的磁盘驱动器上，由 2800 个处理器核心（我写这本书时使用的较新的苹果电脑有两个核心）读取，并由 16 TB 的内存 (RAM) 辅助读取。 Watson 运行时温度极高，需要两台制冷设备来冷却其十个服务器机架，这些机架占据了位于纽约州约克敦高地 IBM 园区的整整一个房间。整个装置的设计初衷是运行一种算法，该算法运用超过六百万条逻辑规则来确定 Watson 的答案。

In early 2011, IBM’s newest creation, Watson, bested all human contestants on the game show Jeopardy!—including Ken Jennings, the most prolific champion in the show’s history. That a bot could be so intellectually nimble in the way it processed random questions, speedily consulted raw stores of data, and issued answers was impressive. Whereas chess is a game played on a limited board with rigid rules, Jeopardy! is chaotic, arbitrary, and offers almost no guidelines on the content or nature of its queries, which can be pocked with humor, puns, and irony. To do it, IBM stored 200 million pages of content on four terabytes of disk drives that were read by twenty-eight hundred processor cores (the newish Apple computer I used to write this book has two) assisted by sixteen terabytes of memory (RAM). Watson ran so hot that it required two refrigeration units to cool its ten server racks that filled an entire room at IBM’s campus in Yorktown Heights, New York. The whole contraption was built to run an algorithm that determined Watson’s answers using more than six million logic rules.

然而，尽管沃森能力超群，它却无法与大佬们玩扑克。华尔街一直对扑克着迷，扑克游戏在很多方面都是人类生活的缩影。扑克体现了华尔街最看重的两大特质：虚张声势和快速的分析能力。交易巨头之间的秘密游戏已成为传奇。华尔街扑克之夜锦标赛汇集了世界上一些最著名的黑客交易员，已经成为一项顶级赛事，摩根士丹利算法交易业务的创始人彼得·穆勒 (Peter Muller) 与来自芝加哥的亿万富翁对冲基金经理肯·格里芬 (Ken Griffin) 等人在此展开较量。穆勒赢得了 2006 年的比赛，在此之前他已经有了丰富的经验，包括参加世界扑克巡回赛，并赢得 10 万美元奖金。其他华尔街玩家包括绿光资本 (Greenlight Capital) 经理戴维·艾因霍恩 (David Einhorn)，他在 2009 年世界扑克系列赛中名列第 18 名，并带回了 659,730 美元的奖金，对于几乎所有人来说，这都是一笔惊人的财富（成功的对冲基金创始人除外）。2更妙的是，已倒闭的贝尔斯登公司前企业战略主管史蒂文·贝格莱特在同一场锦标赛中赢得了160万美元。扑克游戏的普遍受欢迎程度飙升，最终在2011年世界扑克锦标赛上，奖金突破了6400万美元，这进一步加深了华尔街对扑克的关注。

But for all its abilities, Watson can’t play poker with the big boys. Wall Street has always been fascinated with poker, a game that in many ways is a microcosm of human life. Poker encapsulates two of the most valued traits on Wall Street: a flare for bravado and quick analytical skills. Hush-hush games between trading titans have become legendary. A game featuring some of the most prominent hacker traders in the world, the Wall Street Poker Night Tournament, has become a premier event where people like Peter Muller, who built the algorithmic trading business of Morgan Stanley, lock horns with Ken Griffin, the billionaire hedge fund operator from Chicago. Muller won the 2006 game, and he’d had plenty of experience before then, including a stint on the World Poker Tour, where he won $100,000. Other Wall Street players include David Einhorn, the manager of Greenlight Capital, who placed eighteenth in the 2009 World Series of Poker and brought home $659,730, a staggering pile of money for almost anybody (except a successful hedge fund founder).2 Even better, Steven Begleiter, the former head of corporate strategy at the now-defunct Bear Stearns, won $1.6 million in the same tournament. Wall Street’s attention to poker was amplified by the game’s general popularity spike that culminated in a purse at the 2011 World Series of Poker topping $64 million.

就像市场一样，扑克游戏也涉及躲避、伪装、精明交易员、愚蠢交易员、内幕信息，以及成千上万的其他因素，其中最令人担忧的是人类非理性的威胁。因此，一位能够运用迄今为止最先进的算法驾驭复杂市场的计算机科学教授，选择挑战世界上最赚钱的纸牌游戏，也就不足为奇了。卡内基梅隆大学的计算机科学教授托马斯·桑德霍姆（Tuomas Sandholm）花了近十年的时间，致力于突破一种让世界上最优秀的扑克玩家都感到恐惧的算法。

Just like markets, poker involves parries, fakes, smart traders, dumb traders, inside information, and, among thousands of other factors, the ever-threatening prospect of human irrationality. So it only makes sense that a computer science professor who tamed complex markets with some of the most advanced algorithms ever conceived would take on the world’s most lucrative card game. Tuomas Sandholm, a computer science professor at Carnegie Mellon, has spent the better part of a decade working to break through on an algorithm that scares the best poker players in the world.

创建一种能够有效地与世界顶级牌手竞争的算法是一项复杂的任务。创建这样的算法不仅需要根据特定牌型的胜率进行数据处理，还需要算法具备人类的特质。仅仅依靠赔率是不可能在大型扑克游戏中获胜的。这种策略在二十一点游戏中也行得通——正如麻省理工学院学生团队在拉斯维加斯赢得数百万美元所证明的那样——但扑克需要更灵巧的技巧。要想在最高水平的扑克游戏中获胜，人类或算法必须善于用小额赌注隐藏大牌，并在其他时候用大额赌注炫耀自己的实力，吓退其他玩家。玩家，无论是人还是机器，都必须学会如何用弱牌“跛入”下注，以便有机会获得非常规的、因此也是狡猾的强牌——比如由六和二组成的葫芦。当然，这些策略不能同时使用。顶尖牌手会根据对手的实力，选择何时虚张声势、何时跟进或何时展现自己的实力。世界级的扑克玩家，最重要的是，必须学会如何利用人类心理为自己谋利。

Creating an algorithm to effectively compete against the world’s best card players is a complicated task. Making such an algorithm requires not only data crunching based upon the odds of winning a given hand with given cards, but also for the algorithm to acquire human qualities. It’s not possible to succeed at big-time poker by simply playing the odds. That strategy can work in blackjack—as evinced by the teams of MIT students who took Las Vegas for millions—but poker requires a defter touch. To play at the highest level of poker, humans or algorithms must be effective at hiding big hands with small bets, and at other times declaring one’s strength with large wagers to scare others out of the hand. The player, man or machine, must learn how to “limp in” to bets with weak hands for chances at unconventional, and thus sneaky, monster hands—like a full house of sixes and twos. None of these strategies can be used concurrently, of course. The best players pick when to bluff, limp in, or be demonstrative based upon the players they’re up against. A world-class poker player must, above all else, learn how to use human psychology to his advantage.

扑克游戏的最高境界是有史以来最微妙、最人性化的游戏之一。为了让扑克机器人能够与职业选手匹敌，桑多姆需要构建一种算法，使其从每秒进行数百万次强力计算（类似“深蓝”）的机器，跃升至能够模仿人类狡猾策略并有效预测人类对手理性（有时甚至是非理性）策略的优雅机器。如果机器人能够在这场游戏中与职业选手较量并击败他们，那么几乎没有什么事情是它们无法企及的。

At its highest levels, poker is one of the most nuanced and human games ever created. To make a poker bot worthy of the pros, Sandholm would need to construct an algorithm that made the leap from something doing millions of brute-force calculations per second (à la Deep Blue) to an elegant machine that could mimic human guile and effectively anticipate the rational—and sometimes irrational—strategies of its human opponents. If bots could tussle and beat the pros in this game, there exist few things beyond their reach.

用代码构建狡猾

TO BUILD CUNNING WITH CODE

桑德霍姆是博弈论专家，博弈论是一门数学领域，研究涉及未知变量和利益相关方等复杂问题。博弈论帮助桑德霍姆构建了扑克算法，这些算法仅基于问题的部分解进行决策。“当你开始尝试考虑扑克中的每一个变量时，你就会陷入困境，”他说。

Sandholm is an expert in game theory, the field of math concerning complex problems that include unknown variables and multiple parties with differing interests. Game theory has allowed Sandholm to build poker algorithms that make decisions with only partial solutions to their problem. “When you start trying to account for every single variable in poker, you get into trouble,” he says.

在国际象棋中，所有变量都是众所周知的；而在扑克中，玩家只知道自己的牌以及桌上朝上的牌（如果有的话）。除此之外，玩家必须依靠自己的直觉、对对手倾向的了解​​，以及解读其他玩家面部表情和手牌的能力，从中判断他们是在虚张声势还是握有一手好牌。扑克机器人无法解读面部表情，至少目前还不行，所以为了有效地对抗高手，它们必须学会如何虚张声势，如何识破他人的虚张声势，以及在对手可能拿到大牌的情况下何时弃牌。

In chess, every variable is known to all; in poker, the player only knows his own cards and the cards, if any, that are facing up on the table. Other than that, the player must rely on his own gut, his knowledge of his opponents’ tendencies, and his ability to read other players’ faces and hands for signs that they’re bluffing or holding a good hand. Poker bots can’t read faces, at least not yet, so to be effective against good players they must learn how to bluff, how to call others’ bluffs, and when to fold in the face of what’s likely a big hand for an opponent.

桑德霍姆说话略带口音，在芬兰出生长大，沙色头发、高颧骨和下巴裂开，看起来像个北欧征服者。1990年，他开发了自己的第一个商业算法，一个用于拼车的自动协商平台。乘客可以输入他们想要搭乘的路线，司机可以给出报价。每位乘客都会向每位司机输入不同的路线，这使得拼车市场变得复杂，只有完美的算法才能驾驭。桑德霍姆进军拼车市场最终失败了，因为市场表现不如他的机器人预期。事实证明，有些人很乐意为他人载客赚点钱；然而，其他人却要求更高的报酬——因此，在算法看来，这是不合理的——来补偿他们独自通勤的干扰。

Sandholm, who speaks with the slightest of accents, was born and raised in Finland and looks the part of Nordic conqueror with his sandy hair, high cheekbones, and cleft chin. In 1990 he built his first commercial algorithm, an automated negotiation platform for ride sharing. Riders could introduce routes for which they sought rides, and drivers could answer with price quotes. Each rider introduced a different route variation to each driver, making for a complex market that could only be tamed by the perfect algorithm. Sandholm’s foray into carpooling ultimately failed as the market didn’t behave how his bot had expected. It turned out that some humans were perfectly happy to make a few bucks to drive others; others, however, demanded far higher—and thus, to the algorithm, irrational—premiums for the disturbance of their solo commute.

随着在复杂交易中积累经验，桑德霍姆越来越擅长模拟人类及其各种决策方法。他编写了博弈论算法，用于在包含数千甚至数百万个变量的市场中进行谈判。例如，当像通用磨坊这样的公司试图对冲其谷物价格飙升的风险时，有成千上万种方法可以做到，从购买看涨期权到在纽约和芝加哥盲目看涨大宗商品。成千上万的因素会影响决策，从北美和亚洲的天气模式到股市走势、现行利率，以及影响农作物的虫害或干旱威胁。在正确的时间做出正确的选择——并且出于所有正确的理由——可以为通用磨坊节省数百万美元。但是，做出最佳决策所需的许多变量都是未知的。有些变量可以定量预测，但并非绝对准确，例如天气。其他变量，例如交易员对某些事件的反应以及其他大型谷物买家如何对冲自身头寸，则取决于这些参与者如何看待自身的最佳利益。这种自利正是博弈论所预测的。

As he gained experience in complex transactions, Sandholm became better at modeling humans and their varying methods of decision making. He wrote game theory algorithms that negotiated markets with thousands or even millions of variables. For instance, when a company such as General Mills seeks to hedge its exposure to spikes in the price of grain, there are thousands of ways to do it, from buying call options to placing blind and bullish bets on commodities in New York and Chicago. Thousands of factors affect the decision, from weather patterns in North America and Asia to the direction of the stock market, the prevailing interest rates, and the threat of an insect pest or drought affecting the crop. Making the right bet at the right time—and for all the right reasons—can save General Mills millions of dollars. But many of the variables required to make the best decision are unknown. Some can be predicted quantitatively, although not definitively, such as the weather. Other variables, like how traders will react to certain events and how other large grain buyers will hedge their own positions, depend on how those players view their best interest. That self-interest is exactly what game theory helps predict.

由于一个市场中投注者和参与者如此之多，最终的价格走向将取决于所有参与者的行动。每个参与者都会做出自己认为最符合自身利益的举动。博弈论利用包含数千甚至数百万个节点的矩阵来解释每个参与者的选择及其预期收益。在复杂的市场中，每个决策都会影响其他参与者的决策和可选路径。桑德霍尔姆最终创立了一家名为Combinet的公司，该公司开发了博弈论软件，帮助企业应对各种复杂的市场。2010年，桑德霍尔姆将当时拥有130名员工的Combinet公司出售给了一家私募股权公司。

With so many bettors and players in one market, the eventual direction of prices will be determined by the moves that all of the players make. Each player, in turn, does what she thinks is in her best interest. Game theory utilizes matrices with thousands and sometimes millions of nodes that account for each player’s choices and their perceived payoffs. In a complex market, every decision made affects the decisions and the paths available to other players. Sandholm eventually built a company, Combinet, that constructed game theory software to help companies navigate all manner of complex markets. In 2010, Sandholm sold Combinet, by then a 130-person operation, to a private equity firm.

2004 年，在用博弈论为全国各地的客户解决问题时，桑多姆从卡内基梅隆大学的其他教授那里了解到了扑克的奥秘。他认为，利用博弈论的算法可以有效应对像扑克这样包含未知变量的人类策略游戏。2005 年，桑多姆和卡内基梅隆大学的其他教授利用博弈论编写了一个算法，赢得了罗德岛扑克比赛。罗德岛扑克是一种三张牌而不是五张牌的扑克游戏。事实上，这个机器人非常厉害，甚至连职业选手都无法击败它。但是，罗德岛扑克是一个针对一个小州的小游戏，比最受欢迎的高额扑克游戏德州扑克简单得多。在罗德岛扑克中，桑多姆的算法必须考虑大约 31 亿种可能的情况。3桑德霍姆喜欢说，在德州扑克中，可能性的数量和宇宙中的原子数量一样多。

While solving problems with game theory for clients across the country, Sandholm was introduced to poker’s mystery by other professors at Carnegie Mellon in 2004. An algorithm utilizing game theory, he thought, could prove effective in human strategy games like poker that contain unknown variables. In 2005, Sandholm and other CMU professors used game theory to write an algorithm that won a contest of Rhode Island hold ’em, a poker game with three cards in play rather than five. The bot was so good, in fact, that even pros couldn’t beat it. But Rhode Island hold ’em, a small game for a small state, is a far simpler game than Texas hold ’em, the most popular game in high-stakes poker. In Rhode Island poker, there are approximately 3.1 billion possible situations that Sandholm’s algorithms must consider.3 In Texas hold ’em, there are as many possibilities as there are atoms in the universe, Sandholm likes to say.

在德州扑克变体中，玩家抽两张牌不告诉别人。然后桌上会发另外五张牌。玩家可以用自己的两张牌和桌上另外五张牌的任意组合组成五张牌。这种游戏性质使其特别适合那些善于读懂对手的玩家。比如说，一个拿着一对 K 的玩家可能会押大注，直到桌上发出一张面朝上的 A。同桌的一位谨慎的玩家，如果手中的牌几乎毫无价值，可能会假装自己拿着第二张 A，通过下大注来虚张声势。拿着 K 的玩家被大注愚弄，以为自己被一对 A 打败了，于是弃牌。最好的玩家会交替使用强牌大声或小声地玩，偶尔也会用弱牌虚张声势。要做到这一点，玩家需要擅长两件事：读懂别人的心思，并了解自己握有获胜牌的准确概率。这就是为什么构建世界级扑克机器人如此困难的原因；算法通常不太擅长预测、分析或博弈人类的非理性行为。对于一个完全线性的算法来说，拿着一张7和一张2（扑克牌中最差的牌）在满桌玩家面前下大注虚张声势显然是不合理的。但有时，这种做法对职业选手来说可能完全合理。这种不可预测的人为因素使得扑克成为只有最顶尖的算法创造者才能成功博弈的领域。

In the Texas variation of the game, players draw two cards that they keep to themselves. Then another five cards are dealt up on the table. Players can make hands of five cards from any combination of their two and the additional five on the table. The nature of the game makes it especially suited to those who can read opponents. A player holding, say, a pair of kings might be riding high, betting large, until an ace is dealt faceup on the table. A cagey player at the same table with a next-to-worthless hand may bluff as if he’s holding a second ace by placing a big bet. The holder of the kings, fooled by the big bet, thinks that he’s been beaten by a pair of aces and folds. The best players alternate between playing strong hands loudly or softly, and occasionally bluffing with weak hands. To do this, players need to be good at two things: reading people and knowing the precise odds that they hold the winning hand. This is why building a world-class poker bot is so hard; algorithms usually aren’t very good at predicting, analyzing, or gaming irrational human behavior. To a completely linear algorithm, bluffing a table full of players with a big bet while holding a seven and a two (the worst hand in poker) isn’t rational. But there are times when such a play could make total sense to a pro. This unpredictable human element makes poker a field where only the most elite algorithm creators can play with success.

桑霍姆开始痴迷于扑克难题，并从2004年开始投入多年时间，期间他遇到了其他志同道合的人。除了阿尔伯塔大学计算机扑克研究小组的机器之外，其他机器都无法与他的机器匹敌。阿尔伯塔大学计算机扑克研究小组已经研究扑克难题二十年了。桑霍姆的卡内基梅隆大学和阿尔伯塔大学的团队之间很快形成了友好的竞争关系。

As Sandholm became fixated on the poker problem and began to dedicate years of his life to it beginning in 2004, he met others who were on the same quest. None of them were much of a match for his machines except those at the University of Alberta’s Computer Poker Research Group, which had been hammering on the poker puzzle for twenty years. A friendly rivalry soon developed between Sanholm’s Carnegie Mellon and the crew at the University of Alberta.

2011年，桑德霍尔姆的算法击败了阿尔伯塔的算法，使其在过去三年中取得了两次胜利。2012年初，他的机器人在限注扑克（赌注有上限）的正面交锋中击败了所有人类玩家，甚至包括职业选手。在无限注扑克和多人参与（超过四人）的扑克游戏中，该机器人略逊于世界上最优秀的人类玩家。在这些大型游戏中，机器人更容易受到人类玩家的干扰，这些玩家一开始会用坏牌进行非理性的虚张声势，但最终可能会在牌局结束时落败，获得一张大牌，从而拯救自己。随着玩家人数的增加，在第四张或第五张牌发出时，有人拿到大牌的可能性也会更高。在涉及如此多人类玩家的扑克牌局中，由于他们是人类，所以随时可能做出非理性的举动，因此没有任何算法能够取代丰富的经验和良好的直觉。目前还没有。但考虑到桑德霍姆迄今为止的进步，职业选手们应该感到害怕。他们的“深蓝时刻”即将到来。

Sandholm’s algorithm defeated Alberta’s in 2011, giving it victory in two out of the last three years. Early in 2012, his bot outjousted every human it faced, even pros, when battling head-to-head in limit poker (where the bets have a ceiling). The bot slightly lags the best human players in the world when it comes to no-limit poker and poker with big numbers of people in a hand (more than four). In these larger games, bots are more prone to disruption by humans who bluff irrationally with bad hands to start but who may fall backward into a big card that saves them at the end of the hand. With more people in the game, there’s a higher likelihood of somebody hitting a big hand on the fourth or fifth card dealt. In the case of poker hands that involve so many humans who, because they’re human, can do something irrational at any moment, there’s no algorithmic replacement for a lot of experience and a good gut feeling. Not yet. But considering Sandholm’s progress thus far, the pros should be scared. Their Deep Blue moment is coming.

桑德霍姆的扑克项目深入挖掘了人们的理解，揭示了他们如何以及何时做出看似非理性的决定，以达到意想不到的结果——例如，虚张声势，迫使持有一对K的玩家弃牌。预测人类如何将看似非理性的行为视为符合自身最佳利益，是算法需要攻克的最后几道坎。如果算法能够感知牌桌上、市场中或日常生活中的非理性行为，就能挽救金钱和生命。秉持这一逻辑，桑德霍姆的扑克研究项目合伙人安德鲁·吉尔平将他们从人类扑克行为中学到的知识，运用到股票市场中，他于2010年创立了一支对冲基金。他的基金采用一种算法，就像扑克一样，旨在防止他人察觉其真实策略。

Sandholm’s poker project has peeled back layers of understanding when it comes to predicting how and when scheming humans may make what seems to be an irrational decision with the goal of achieving an unlikely result—like bluffing a player who holds a pair of kings into folding. Predicting how humans perceive seemingly irrational actions to be in their own best interest is one of the last walls to be scaled by algorithms. If algorithms could sense irrational movements at the poker table, in the markets, or in simple everyday situations, money and lives could be saved. With that logic in mind, Sandholm’s partner on the poker research project, Andrew Gilpin, has taken what they’ve learned from the behavior of humans in poker and applied it to the stock market with a hedge fund he started in 2010. His fund employs an algorithm that, just like in poker, is designed to keep others from smelling its true strategy.

体力游戏

GAMES OF THE PHYSICAL KIND

早在扑克成为对冲基金巨头和新兴量化分析师的首选游戏之前，体育博彩就已经存在了。交易大厅的存在是为了方便投注——而投注的范围总是远远超出了交易大厅应该交易的金融工具。有时，交易大厅里的附带赌注比合法交易还多。20世纪90年代末，我还在上大学的时候——那时在离岸网站上进行体育投注还不方便——我的一个室友经常会从我们这里收集一些大额投注，然后和一位在芝加哥商品交易所工作的朋友一起在交易大厅进行投注。这种精神被转移到了现在驻扎在拉斯维加斯一家名为M Resort Spa的赌场里的机器人身上，这家赌场专门经营一种新型的体育博彩，其模式模仿了交易大厅里不间断的运作。

Long before poker became the game of choice among hedge fund titans and rising quants, there was sports betting. Trading pits exist to facilitate betting—and the betting always goes far beyond the financial instruments the pit is supposed to be trading. Sometimes more side bets are taking place in a trading pit than legitimate trades. When I was in college in the late 1990s—before it was easy to place sports wagers with offshore Web sites—one of my roommates would often gather big-game wagers from us and have the bets placed on the trading floor with a friend who worked at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. That spirit has been transferred to a bot that now resides in a Las Vegas casino called the M Resort Spa, which specializes in a new brand of sports gambling modeled after the nonstop action of a trading floor.

这家赌场归华尔街金融服务公司 Cantor Fitzgerald 所有。Cantor 认为，其算法可以随时为几乎任何体育赛事提供精准的赔率，甚至可以精确到篮球比赛中的下一个三分球。M 赌场的体育博彩玩家可以随身携带触摸屏平板电脑，在赌场内随意走动，观看数百台电视直播的比赛。M 赌场几乎可以投注任何项目，例如击球手是否会在下一球挥棒，或者橄榄球比赛中的下一个回合是否会是一次不完整的传球。赔率每秒都在变化。篮球博彩玩家每分钟就能看到八次不同的赔率。

The casino is owned by Cantor Fitzgerald, a Wall Street financial services company. Cantor believes its algorithm can make accurate odds on almost any sports event at any moment, down to the next three-pointer in a basketball game. Bettors in the M’s sports book are given touchscreen tablet computers to carry with them as they roam the casino and watch hundreds of TVs tracking games. The M allows betting on virtually anything, like whether a batter will swing at the next pitch, or whether the next play in a football game will be an incomplete pass. The odds move every single second. Basketball bettors see different odds on their game eight times every minute.

为 Cantor Fitzgerald 运行所有这些疯狂操作的，是一个名为 Midas 的算法，它可以同时操纵数十场包含数百个支线剧情的游戏的赔率。Cantor 运用其在华尔街数十年的经验和专业知识，打造了 Midas，该公司是华尔街第一家将债券交易业务完全电子化的公司。Midas 的运行平台位于拉斯维加斯大道以北数英里的一个宽敞的服务器机房。4为了获得指导 Midas 构建所需的数据，Cantor 收购了拉斯维加斯体育顾问公司，这是一家自 1982 年以来一直在为比赛提供让分盘口的赔率制定公司。LVSC 近三十年的统计数据、结果和分数直接进入 Midas 的大脑，其过程与 Cantor 和其他在华尔街的人用来创建交易算法的过程类似。

Running all of this madness for Cantor Fitzgerald is an algorithm named Midas, which simultaneously juggles the odds on dozens of games featuring hundreds of subplots. Cantor built Midas with the lessons and expertise the firm gleaned from decades as a wily trading firm on Wall Street, where it was the first company to make its bond trading operations fully electronic. Midas runs from an expansive server room several miles north of the Vegas Strip.4 To get the data necessary to guide its construction of Midas, Cantor bought Las Vegas Sports Consultants, an odds maker that had been handicapping games since 1982. LVSC’s nearly thirty years of stats, results, and scores went straight into Midas’s brain in a process similar to what Cantor and others use on Wall Street to create their trading algorithms.

长期以来，体育博彩一直被直觉和赌场主导，赌场会根据顾客的投注情况设定赔率。如果巨人队的投注金额超过对手爱国者队的投注金额，拉斯维加斯的赌场就会调整赔率，让爱国者队的投注更具吸引力。双方均等的投注额可以最大限度地降低赌场的风险，并保证其10%的利润，也就是赌徒所说的“抽水”。大多数等额投注的体育博彩根本不是等额投注；每下注1美元，赢家就能获得90美分的利润——剩下的10美分，也就是“抽水”，则归赌场所有。但Cantor想要的远不止“抽水”。如果机器人认为谨慎行事，M并不惧怕在比赛中进行裸仓操作。Cantor拥有一支由15名黑客组成的团队及其Midas机器人，认为自己可以成为拉斯维加斯体育博彩的主导者。实现这一目标需要数年时间，但毫无疑问，M那种类似交易大厅的投注方式会让人上瘾。如果 M 获得巨大成功，那么哈拉斯、米高梅、凯撒以及拉斯维加斯大道上的其他赌场都会开始聘请他们能找到的最佳黑客。

Sports betting has long been a province dominated by gut hunches and casinos that set their lines according to how customers bet. If the money coming in on the Giants outweighs that of their opponent Patriots, Las Vegas casinos move their lines to make the Patriots bet more attractive. Equal bets on both sides minimize the house’s risk and guarantee their 10 percent profit, what bettors call “the juice.” Most even-money sports bets aren’t even money at all; for every dollar wagered, the winner makes a profit of ninety cents—the remaining ten cents, the juice, belongs to the house. But Cantor wants more than the juice. The M isn’t afraid to sometimes take naked positions on games—if the bot thinks it prudent. Cantor, with a team of fifteen hackers and its Midas bot, thinks it can become the dominant sports book in Vegas. Doing so will take years, but there’s little doubt that the trading-floor-style betting at the M can be addicting. If the M finds huge success, expect Harrah’s, MGM, Caesars, and the rest of the casinos on the Strip to start hiring the best hackers they can find.

算法作为中情局的间谍

ALGORITHMS AS CIA SPOOKS

或许，在下次玩棋盘游戏《妙探寻凶》时，能开发出一款使用博弈论算法制定策略的 iPhone 或 Android 应用会很酷——如果她认为是芥末上校在图书馆里拿着蜡烛台，那我就让这个可怜虫继续这么想——但桑多姆在扑克游戏方面的突破，为算法打开了大门，使其能够解决游戏之外无数其他更重要的问题——有些问题甚至可以决定生死。

While it might be wickedly cool to break out an iPhone or Android app that uses a game theory algorithm for strategy the next time you’re playing the board game Clue—if she thinks it was Colonel Mustard with the candlestick in the library, then I’ll let the wretch keep thinking that—Sandholm’s breakthroughs in poker have opened doors for algorithms to attack countless other, more important problems beyond games—some that literally can decide life and death.

在玩扑克时，不知道对方的策略或手中的牌会让决策变得困难。未知的因素也会给美国安全部队在追捕恐怖分子或确定如何将资源最佳地分配到不同的防御点时带来难题。这也是打击恐怖主义成本如此高昂的原因。但博弈论算法正在帮助改变这种状况。Sandholm 的扑克机器人启发了南加州大学计算机科学教授 Milind Tambe，他利用算法来应对恐怖主义威胁。Tambe 借鉴了 Sandholm 在扑克机器人中设计的几种策略，为洛杉矶国际机场开发了一种算法，可以创建高效且随机的安全巡逻模式，最适合挫败恐怖主义阴谋。该算法可以分析恐怖分子认为哪些计划是造成人员死亡、破坏和机场混乱的最佳策略，然后根据对恐怖分子想法的预测来做出阻止袭击的决策。

Not knowing the other guy’s strategy—or the cards in his hand—makes decisions difficult in poker. The specter of the unknown also gives U.S. security forces problems when trying to hunt terrorists or when determining how to best allocate resources to disparate points of defense. It’s also why fighting terrorism can be so expensive. But game theory algorithms are helping to change that. Sandholm’s poker bot inspired University of Southern California computer science professor Milind Tambe to scheme against terrorism threats with algorithms. Taking cues from several of Sandholm’s strategies inside the poker bot, Tambe developed an algorithm for Los Angeles International Airport that creates efficient and random security patrol patterns best suited to disrupt terrorism plots. The algorithm can examine what plans the terrorist might see as his best bet for inflicting damage through death, destruction, and chaos at the airport and then makes decisions to thwart attacks based on what it anticipates terrorists are thinking.

洛杉矶国际机场于2007年开始使用该算法。联邦政府对此印象深刻，于是委托坦贝博士开发一个机器人，用于指挥全美运输安全管理局（TSA）工作人员的巡逻。2011年，一个类似版本的机器人在匹兹堡国际机场投入测试。TSA也已开始使用该程序来决定飞机上空警的部署以及炸弹嗅探犬队的巡逻时间。这些研究成果激发了人们对机器人的研究，这些机器人有朝一日将在阿富汗等地做出关键的战场决策，在这些地方，车队路线、临时基地和战术都必须经过精心设计，以降低伏击的可能性。

LAX started using the algorithm in 2007. The federal government was so impressed that it asked Dr. Tambe to build a bot that dictated patrols for Transportation Security Administration staff all over the country. A similar version of the bot went into testing at Pittsburgh International Airport in 2011. TSA has also begun to use the program to decide placement of air marshals on planes and the patrol times of bomb-sniffing canine units. The results have kindled work on bots that will one day make crucial battlefield decisions in places like Afghanistan, where convoy routes, temporary bases, and tactics must be designed to decrease the chances of ambush.

但在博弈论算法被用于保卫机场和巡逻客机之前，中情局早已像依赖高技能的情报分析员一样依赖它们。冷战解冻后，即20世纪90年代初，共产主义垮台后，美俄情报团队曾有两年时间保持着二战以来的亲密关系。两国几乎没有交换过机密，但他们确实在短暂的时间内，悄悄地暂停了这场持续了五十年的博弈。在此期间，中情局和前克格勃就共享信息和情报系统进行了坦诚的讨论。俄罗斯人对美国人展示的一项成果非常感兴趣。这是一个复杂的博弈论算法，它预测苏联将像它之前那样崩溃，而这场政变的导火索是一场最终失败的反戈尔巴乔夫政变。

But before game theory algorithms took to defending airports and patrolling airliners, the CIA had come to depend on them like highly skilled intelligence analysts. When the Cold War thawed, there was a period of two years in the early 1990s, following communism’s collapse, when the American and Russian intelligence teams were as chummy as they’ve been since the Second World War. The two countries hardly swapped secrets, but they did, for just a short period, quietly hit the pause button on what had been a fifty-year chess match. During this stretch the CIA and what used to be the KGB held sincere discussions on sharing information and intelligence systems. The Russians were keenly intrigued by one item the Americans showed off. It was a complicated game theory algorithm that had predicted the Soviet Union would crumble exactly as it had, sparked by an anti-Gorbachev coup that would ultimately fail.

该算法的发明者是纽约大学政治学教授、斯坦福大学胡佛研究所高级研究员布鲁斯·布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔。当时，布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔只是密歇根大学一名普通的政治学研究生，后来他读到了威廉·H·赖克的《政治联盟理论》。这本书以博弈论为模板，预测政治走向。他被这个想法深深吸引，并加深了对微积分的理解。很快，他就改进了赖克的算法，到20世纪80年代中期，他已成为全球事件预测算法的领军人物。

The algorithm had been created by Bruce Bueno de Mesquita, a political science professor at New York University and a senior fellow at Stanford University’s Hoover Institution. Bueno de Mesquita had been just another political science graduate student at the University of Michigan when he picked up a book by William H. Riker, The Theory of Political Coalitions, that used game theory as a template to predict politics. He became enthralled with the idea and brushed up on his calculus. He was soon improving on Riker’s techniques, and by the mid-1980s he was the foremost creator of predictive event algorithms in the world.

在预测紧张的政治局势如何发展时，例如伊朗领导层内部就是否推进核武器生产的争论，必须考虑成千上万的因素。标准的福克斯新闻或CNN评论员会尽可能多地了解情况，凭直觉判断，回顾过去类似的事件，然后做出预测。中央情报局的分析员也采取类似的做法，只是他们掌握的信息比普通的评论员要多。事实上，情报分析员有时必须做出主观判断。

When trying to predict how an intense political situation will play out, like the debate within Iran’s leadership on whether to push through with the production of a nuclear weapon, there are thousands of factors that must be considered. The standard Fox News or CNN commentator would ingest all she could on the situation, consult her gut, examine similar events in the past, and then issue her prediction. Analysts at the CIA operate similarly, only with more information to work with than your average talking head. The fact remains that intelligence analysts at some point have to make a subjective call.

布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔创建的算法运作方式不同，而且效果远超预期。中情局聘请他进行过一千七百多次政治和军事预测，涉及全球各地不同的地缘政治局势。在一项涵盖布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔近二十年工作成果及其内部分析师研究的研究中，中情局发现，使用博弈论算法的教授预测正确率是中情局内部专家的两倍。这说明地缘政治分析师的职业前景如何？他们在电视领域拥有未来是件好事，因为他们在联邦调查局、中央情报局和国家安全局等重要机构中的作用可能正在减弱。

The algorithms that Bueno de Mesquita creates work differently—and they work quite a bit better. The CIA has hired him to perform more than seventeen hundred political and military predictions that span the globe and different geopolitical situations. In a study covering nearly twenty years of Bueno de Mesquita’s work versus that of their own analysts, the CIA found that the professor with the game theory algorithms was right twice as often as the CIA’s own experts. What does this say about geopolitical analysts? It’s good that they have a future in television, because their role in the places that matter—the FBI, the CIA, the NSA—may be diminishing.

“当我们依赖直觉时，我们会错过很多故事，”布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔说。“数学给了我们答案。”

“When we depend on intuition, we miss a lot of the story,” Bueno de Mesquita says. “Math gives us those answers.”

就像扑克机器人一样，布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔的算法会考虑伊朗等国家政治结果中每个参与者的个人利益。该算法唯一的假设是，大多数人会采取行动、争取并争取最符合自身利益的结果。话虽如此，问题对每个参与者的重要性也很重要。虽然最高领导人可能倾向于某个结果，但特定情况对他来说总体上可能并不重要，这使得结果可能更重要的下级参与者能够发挥更大的影响力。因此，要运行这些预测性地缘政治算法，用户仍然需要情报数据，但只需要特定类型的数据。他们需要确定哪些团体或个人正在影响政策决策，以及哪种决策对每个参与者来说都是最佳的。还需要了解每个参与者的影响力，以及同样重要的是，每个人对特定问题的关注程度。每一方都希望最大化收益并最小化损失——他们认为最能实现这一目标的行动就是他们将采取的行动。

Just like a poker bot, Bueno de Mesquita’s algorithms consider the personal interests of every player related to a political outcome in a country like Iran. The only thing the algorithm assumes is that most people will act, pull, and speak up for the outcome that best serves their own interest. That being said, it also matters how important the issue may be to each player. While a supreme leader may prefer one outcome in a matter, the given situation may be of low importance to him overall, which allows for lower-level players, to whom the outcome may be more important, to exert more influence. So to run these predictive geopolitical algorithms, the user still needs intelligence data, but only certain kinds of data. They need to determine what groups or individuals are affecting the policy decision and what decision is best for each of the players. It’s also necessary to know how much clout each player has and, just as important, how focused each individual is on this particular issue. Each party is looking to maximize their gains and minimize their losses—the move they believe will best allow them to do that is the move they will make.

这听起来可能像堆积如山的情报，但比大多数中情局分析师预想的要少得多。情报部门花费大量资金收集信息，仅仅是关于我们如何走到今天这一步。他们关心每个棋手的历史、个人经历、人际关系，以及他们如何占据目前的地位。但这位教授表示，这些信息并不重要——他的算法的成功证明了这一点。“如果你走进一个正在进行国际象棋比赛的房间，只要看一眼棋盘，你就能很快了解每个棋手可能采取的行动，”布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔说。“他们如何走到今天这一步并不重要——在现实世界中，情况基本相同。”

That may sound like a mountain of intel, but it’s less than what most CIA analysts consider. Intelligence services spend a lot of money gathering information on, simply, how we got here. They care about each player’s history, their personal tales, their relationships, and their road to occupying the perch they currently inhabit. But the professor says this intel is immaterial—and his algorithm’s success proves it. “If you walk into a room where a game of chess is going on and just look at the board, you can quickly understand what each player is likely to do,” Bueno de Mesquita says. “How they got there doesn’t matter—it’s basically the same thing in the real world.”

如果我们知道每个玩家的动机、影响力和兴趣程度，我们就可以放手让算法去做。这正是布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔的流程。他花了好几天的时间设置变量、玩家以及他们关心特定结果的原因，然后让算法完成剩下的工作。

If we know each player’s motivations, influence, and level of interest, we can set the algorithm loose. That’s exactly Bueno de Mesquita’s process. He spends days and days setting up the variables, the players, and the reasons why they care about this particular outcome, and then he lets the algorithm do the rest of the work.

至于伊朗及其研制核弹的可能性，布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔在2009年就此问题开发了一套算法。该机器人权衡了所有因素：参与者、国家、可能的制裁以及伊朗科学家的能力。机器人得出结论，到2014年，伊朗将研制出武器级铀——这一事实令许多人感到不安。但该算法也预测，伊朗不会利用这些铀来研制核弹。相反，伊朗将保持其民用核计划。该算法认为，伊朗的重要影响者将通过公开其研制核燃料的能力和必要资金而感到满足。伊朗领导人必须权衡拥有核武器的渴望与随之而来的诸多麻烦——制裁、以色列的军事打击以及无法出售石油。布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔表示，该算法可能认识到，拥有核武器带来的诸多好处——影响力、尊重和地区权威——几乎同样可以通过拥有核电计划获得，而伊朗根据国际核不扩散条约可以拥有核电计划。这一结论在撰写本文时看来准确无误，远胜于大多数中情局和传统分析人士的预测。

As for Iran and the likelihood it will build a nuclear bomb, Bueno de Mesquita put together an algorithm on the matter in 2009. The bot weighed each factor: player, country, possible sanctions, and the abilities of the scientists in Iran. The bot concluded that by 2014 Iran will develop weapons-grade uranium—a fact that leaves many uncomfortable. But the algorithm also predicted that Iran wouldn’t take that uranium and build a bomb. Instead, the country would keep its nuclear program a civilian one. The algorithm says that the important influencers in Iran will be sated by broadcasting their capability and wherewithal to create nuclear fuel. The leaders must weigh their desire to possess nuclear arms with the clear headaches—sanctions, Israeli military strikes, inability to sell oil—that come with them. Bueno de Mesquita says the algorithm probably recognized that many of the benefits of having nuclear arms—influence, respect, and regional authority—are also accorded almost as strongly by possessing a nuclear power program, something Iran is allowed to do under the international nonproliferation treaty. That conclusion, which at the time of this writing looks accurate, is far better than those put forward by most CIA and conventional analysts.

然而，我们的专家如此轻易地被算法击败，我们不应该感到惊讶。伯克利大学教授菲利普·泰特洛克对两千名政治专家进行了一项调查，要求他们为其关注领域内的某些事件分配概率。然后，他在一组控制数据中，为每个事件分配了随机概率。随着时间的推移，泰特洛克整理了这些结果，这些结果至少对那些所谓的专家来说令人沮丧。人类专家的预测并不比随机生成的预测更好。

We shouldn’t be surprised, though, that our experts are so easily bested by an algorithm. Berkeley professor Philip Tetlock conducted a survey of two thousand political experts and asked them to assign probabilities to certain events within their areas of focus. He then, in a control set of data, assigned random probabilities to each of the events. As the years went by, Tetlock collated the results, which, at least for the so-called experts, were disheartening. The predictions made by human experts were no better than those generated randomly.

大多数中情局人员都是大学毕业生，由于旧方法论要求分析员对所调查的地区和人员有深入的了解，大多数新员工都拥有人文学科学位，而非理工科学位。正因如此，我们的很多情报工作都侧重于个人历史以及权贵人士身边的种种戏剧性事件。谈论这些事情或许很有趣，但它们对于确定遥远国度的人们最终的行动并非至关重要。我们的情报工作将聚焦于文化差异、宗教冲突以及不同种族、国家或民族之间主流观点的差异。但真正重要的是，什么对当权者最有利。这也使得算法的编写更加便捷。如果能够明确界定关键人物及其利益（通常情况下，即使在像伊朗这样领导层僵硬的国家，也能如此），那么算法就能比人类分析员更好地预测人们未来的行动。

Most CIA’ers are hired out of college, and because the old methodology stipulates that analysts should possess deep wells of knowledge of the region and people they’re examining, most of the recruits have degrees in the humanities rather than science and engineering. For that reason, a lot of our intelligence focuses on personal histories and the drama that accompanies the entourages of people of power. These things might be interesting to talk about, but they’re not essential to determining what humans in a far-off country will ultimately do. Our intelligence will home in on cultural incongruities, religious conflicts, and differences in majority opinions between races, countries, or people. But what really matters is what’s best for those in control. Conveniently, this also makes for easier algorithm writing. If the seminal players and their interests can be well defined, and they usually can, even in the case of a country with leadership as stilted as Iran’s, then an algorithm can give us better guesses on what people will do in the future than human analysts can.

中央情报局正在开始改变其分析团队的组建方式，但这将是一个漫长的过程。中央情报局的职位很难获得，而评判候选人的标准——学历、GPA、经典智力测试——得出的结果可想而知：拥有人文学科教育背景的东海岸常春藤盟校学生过多。申请的工程和理科专业学生往往处于劣势，因为他们的GPA往往较低——这在我们所有的大学系统中都是普遍存在的。毫不奇怪，某些背景的人倾向于青睐那些拥有相似履历的人，并拒绝那些可能在这个地球上最强大的组织之一中取代他们同类的理论。如果博弈论教会了我们什么，那就是人类几乎总是会做他们认为最符合自身利益的事情。

The CIA is beginning to change how it builds its analysis teams, but it will be a long process. Jobs at the CIA are hard to get and the criteria by which candidates are judged—school, GPA, classic intelligence tests—produces a predictable result: an overabundance of East Coast Ivy Leaguers with humanities educations. The engineers and science majors who do apply are often at a disadvantage because their GPAs tend to be lower—a fact that’s true across all of our university systems. It should be no surprise that people of certain backgrounds tend to favor those with similar résumés and reject theories that may displace their kind in what is one of the more powerful organizations on the planet. If game theory teaches us anything, it’s that humans will almost always do what they perceive to be in their best interest.

但二十年来积累的可靠数据足以推翻哪怕是最顽固的教条。长期以来，中央情报局和国防部内部一直有人推动机器人在华盛顿的外交政策机器中发挥更关键的作用。其中最具影响力的机器人支持者是安德鲁·马歇尔，他在2012年时已年届89岁，至今仍担任国防部净评估办公室主任。马歇尔在尼克松总统任期内升任，此后每任总统都再次任命他为主任。他很可能是算法的盟友，因为他毕业于芝加哥大学，而芝加哥大学以其对量化方法的短视关注而闻名。

But hard data drawn across twenty years can unseat even the stickiest dogma. There have been people inside the CIA and Department of Defense who have long pushed for bots to play more critical roles within the foreign policy machine in Washington. The most influential of the bot backers is Andrew Marshall, who was eighty-nine in 2012 and still occupied the job of director of the DoD’s Office of Net Assessment. Marshall, who ascended to his position under President Nixon and has been reappointed by every president since, is a likely ally of algorithms, as he earned a graduate degree in economics from the University of Chicago, a place famous for its myopic focus on quantitative methods.

至于席卷全球政坛的阿拉伯之春，布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔也对此有所评论。2010年5月5日，他告诉一群人，他的算法预测埃及总统穆巴拉克将在一年内下台，而这一预测在2011年2月11日应验了。布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔从未公开这一预测，因为他只告诉了一小群听众。听众在他演讲后聘请了他，并让他签署了保密协议。但是谁会这么做呢？为什么呢？如果你还没猜到，那是一家你可能听说过的华尔街大型投资公司。他们为什么要这么做？为了完成本世纪最大的交易。5

As for the Arab Spring, a sweeping event in world politics, Bueno de Mesquita had a line on that too. On May 5, 2010, he told a group that his algorithms had predicted that Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak would fall within a year, a result that came to pass on February 11, 2011. Bueno de Mesquita never made the prediction public because he gave it to a small audience, who after his speech put him on retainer and had him sign a nondisclosure agreement. But who would do that—and why? If you haven’t already guessed, it was a large Wall Street investment house you’ve likely heard of. And why would they do it? To make the trade of the century.5

对于算法来说，爱情和棒球都是公平的

FOR ALGORITHMS, ALL IS FAIR IN LOVE AND BASEBALL

加里·卡斯帕罗夫在与“深蓝”的国际象棋比赛中落败后，已故作家兼演员乔治·普林普顿（George Plimpton）曾斥责算法接管世界的未来遥不可及。普林普顿本人也曾与卡斯帕罗夫下棋，但他对“深蓝”的进步无动于衷。“这是一种非常特殊的机器，”普林普顿说。“随着时间的推移，这台机器或许能够做其他事情。目前我还不确定是什么。它管理不了一支棒球队。它们无法告诉你如何处理一段糟糕的婚姻。所有这些事情它们都做不了。”6

When Garry Kasparov lost the chess match with Deep Blue, it prompted George Plimpton, the late writer and actor of zippy wit, to dismiss the future of algorithmic takeovers as far-fetched. Plimpton himself had played chess with Kasparov, but he remained unmoved by Deep Blue’s progress. “This is a very particularlized type of machine,” Plimpton said. “Over the years, it may be that the machine is likely to be able to do other things. I’m not sure what, at the moment. It can’t manage a baseball team. They can’t tell you what to do with a bad marriage. They can’t do any of these things.”6

普林普顿去世前亲眼目睹了数据迷们对棒球的接管。这些数据狂人使用算法在小联盟球员名单中寻找隐藏的人才，他们的一些方法已被详细记录。这一趋势始于比利·比恩的成功，迈克尔·刘易斯在其 2003 年出版的《点球成金》一书中对比利·比恩进行了简介。比恩通过基于晦涩复杂的数据分组（而不是棒球卡背面的传统数据）来寻找球员和阵容，使奥克兰运动家队成为美国联盟西区常年争夺冠军的球队。如果这些数字有效，那么比恩就做到了，即使这会导致场上的球员阵容相当杂乱（也就是说：胖乎乎、矮个子，而且经常留着胡须）。从 2000 年开始，运动家队七年中有五年进入棒球季后赛，而他们的工资总额是大联盟中最低的之一。相比之下，同样资金短缺的堪萨斯城和匹兹堡球队分别自 1985 年和 1992 年以来就没有进入过季后赛。

Before he died, Plimpton was able to witness the takeover of baseball by stat geeks firsthand. Some of the methods of these number hounds, who use algorithms to search minor-league rosters for hidden talent, have been well documented. The trend gained attention starting with the success of Billy Beane, whom Michael Lewis profiled in his 2003 book Moneyball. Beane made the Oakland Athletics into a perennial contender in the American League West Division by searching for players and lineups based on arcane groupings of complicated stats rather than the conventional ones that come on the backs of baseball cards. If the numbers worked, Beane did it, even if it led to some rather motley (read: chubby, short, and often bearded) collections of players on the field. The A’s reached baseball’s playoffs five out of seven years beginning in 2000 with one of the smallest payrolls in the big leagues. Compare that with the similarly cash-strapped teams in Kansas City and Pittsburgh, franchises that haven’t been to postseasons since 1985 and 1992 respectively.

奥克兰运动家队仍在派出人才评估员仔细考察新秀，同时也设置了算法来筛选最新的小联盟数据，寻找隐藏的瑰宝。比恩的成功或许可以归结为运气，但他在因资金短缺而交易掉队内一些顶级球星后，却屡屡带领球队重返季后赛。另一位大力推行这些新方法的教练是西奥·埃普斯坦，他带领波士顿红袜队在2004年夺得了近百年来的首个世界大赛冠军，并在2007年再次夺冠。2011年，芝加哥小熊队挖走了埃普斯坦，希望他能再次创造历史。尽管小熊队人气高涨、票价高昂、薪资丰厚，但他们自1908年以来就再也没有赢得过世界大赛冠军，这是历史上最长的冠军荒。

Oakland still sends talent evaluators to scrutinize prospects, but it also sets algorithms to sorting through the latest minor-league stats, searching for hidden gems. Beane’s success could have been brushed off as luck, except that he kept getting the A’s back to the playoffs after trading away some of the team’s biggest stars for lack of money to pay them. Another heavy wielder of these new methods, Theo Epstein, led the Boston Red Sox to their first World Series title in nearly a hundred years in 2004, and then another in 2007. In 2011 the Chicago Cubs hired Epstein away in hopes that he could repeat the feat. The Cubs, despite their popularity, high ticket prices, and large payrolls, haven’t won a World Series since 1908, the longest such drought in history.

从技术层面上来说，普林普顿的观点是正确的，机器人还没有在教练席上管理过一支大联盟球队，但一些人类教练已经是价格不菲的机器人代理了。越来越多的棒球教练开始依赖计算机和经过严格筛选的统计数据来指导他们的决策。对许多俱乐部来说，决定哪位投手上场的并非教练的直觉，而是一种算法，它会追踪投手在对阵与该局出场的击球手相似的击球手时的表现、近期的工作量、投手控制跑垒员上垒以防止其盗垒的能力、他们在主场和客场、夜间比赛和白天比赛、草地和人造草坪等场次的效率。

Plimpton would be technically right in that a bot has not yet managed a major-league team from the dugout, but some human managers are already very expensive bot proxies. A growing cadre of baseball skippers have come to rely on computers and heavily sifted statistics to guide their decisions. For many clubs, it’s not a manager’s gut that decides which pitcher heads to the mound. It’s an algorithm that tracks how well the pitcher has fared against hitters similar to those appearing that inning, recent workloads, the pitcher’s ability to hold runners on base so they don’t steal, their effectiveness at home versus on the road, night games versus day games, grass versus fake turf, and so on.

棒球或许是最容易被算法和神秘数据挖掘攻击的运动，但它并非唯一易受攻击的联盟。这类方法在NBA也很流行。年轻的球队总经理们——比如夏洛特山猫队总经理里奇·乔，他拥有工程学位，并在波音公司担任了五年工程师——与更倾向于凭直觉行事的老将们之间的分歧越来越大。用软件整理神秘数据最有助于评估中产阶级球员并发现划算的球员。凯文·杜兰特和布雷克·格里芬是顶尖球员，无需他人帮助就能看出。但即使是明星球员，人类观察者也可能忽略他们。

Baseball may be the sport most easily hacked by algorithms and the mining of arcane statistics, but it’s hardly the only league susceptible. Such methods have become popular in the NBA as well. There’s a growing divide between younger team general managers who make decisions with help from algorithms—like Rich Cho, the general manager of the Charlotte Bobcats, who has an engineering degree and five years of experience as an engineer at Boeing—and the old guard who prefer to roll with their gut. Sorting arcane stats with software is most helpful at evaluating midlevel players and identifying bargains. Nobody needs help to see that Kevin Durant and Blake Griffin are elite players. But even stars can be missed by human observers.

以林书豪 (Jeremy Lin) 为例，这位二年级控球后卫在 NBA 的前途一片渺茫，2012 年 2 月他还在哥哥家的沙发上睡觉，他的哥哥是纽约大学的一名牙科学生。7林书豪曾在哈佛大学打篮球，2010年落选，之后在联盟辗转，经常被裁员，直到2011-2012赛季初加盟尼克斯队。起初，他只是替补。但2012年2月，尼克斯队主力球员接连受伤，林书豪才得以进入首发阵容。在连续六场胜利中，他分别得到25、28、23、38、20和27分，第四场胜利是对阵科比·布莱恩特率领的洛杉矶湖人队。科比对此印象深刻。“回头看看，他的技术水平可能从一开始就存在；只是我们没有注意到，”他说。8

Take the case of Jeremy Lin, the second-year point guard whose NBA future was so tenuous in February 2012 that he was still sleeping on the couch of his brother, a dental student at New York University.7 Lin, who played college ball at Harvard, went undrafted in 2010 and bounced around the league, getting cut from rosters as often as he played, before landing a spot on the Knicks early in the 2011–2012 season. At first he rode the bench. But then a string of injuries to New York regulars in February 2012 pushed Lin into the starting lineup. In six consecutive wins he scored 25, 28, 23, 38, 20, and 27 points, the fourth effort coming against Kobe Bryant and the Los Angeles Lakers. Bryant was impressed. “Go back and take a look, and the skill level was probably there from the beginning; it’s just that we didn’t notice it,” he said.8

但篮球分析师艾德·韦兰德 (Ed Weiland) 的算法确实注意到了这一点——比这一切发生的早了两年。算法关注的是林书豪大学时期高达 0.598 的两分球命中率，以及韦兰德计算的一项名为 RSB40 的神秘数据，该数据反映了球员每 40 分钟比赛的篮板、抢断和盖帽数。韦兰德认为这项数据能够很好地表明一名新秀的整体运动能力以及在 NBA 水平的比赛中生存的能力。该算法显示，从纸面上看，林书豪的潜力与过去的大学控球后卫相似，例如阿伦·艾弗森、杰森·基德、拉简·隆多、安德烈·米勒和便士·哈达威——一群杰出的球员。2010 年，韦兰德根据自己的统计数据写道：“如果林书豪能把传球和控球都做好，他就有足够的实力成为 NBA 的首发球员，甚至可能成为明星。”9

But an algorithm belonging to basketball analyst Ed Weiland did notice it—two years before any of this happened. It keyed on Lin’s two-point field goal percentage in college, a lofty .598, and an arcane stat that Weiland calculates called RSB40, which reflects a player’s rebounds, steals, and blocks per 40 minutes of play. Weiland considers this stat a good indication of a prospect’s overall athleticism and ability to survive at the NBA level. The algorithm revealed that Lin’s potential, on paper, was similar to past college point guards such as Allen Iverson, Jason Kidd, Rajon Rondo, Andre Miller, and Penny Hardaway—an illustrious bunch. In 2010, backed by his statistics, Weiland wrote, “If he can get the passing thing down and handle the point, Jeremy Lin is a good enough player to start in the NBA and possibly star.”9

但韦兰德只是个联邦快递的司机，有个数据博客；他既不管理NBA球队，甚至连管理球队的人都听不进去。由于林书豪身材瘦削，又在常春藤联盟打球，而常春藤联盟并非NBA人才的摇篮，他落选了，也鲜有人关注。直到2012年2月，他才正式开始比赛。即使表现有所下滑，林书豪场均仍然能得到超过14分和6次助攻，对于一位缺乏职业经验的落选球员来说，这样的数据非常了不起。如果没有数据扫描算法，根本无法知道他是否正坐在那里，等待着被发掘。

But Weiland is a FedEx driver with a stat blog; he doesn’t manage an NBA team or even have the ear of people who do. Because of Lin’s slim frame and the fact that he played in the Ivy League, not known for being a hotbed of NBA talent, he went undrafted and unnoticed. He didn’t even play in earnest until February 2012. Even after a dip in production, Lin still averaged more than 14 points and 6 assists per game, remarkable numbers for an undrafted player with little pro seasoning. Without the use of stat-scanning algorithms, there was no way to know he was sitting out there, waiting to be discovered.

数据统计专家在过去十五年里才开始在棒球界的顶级赛事中占据主导地位。但用算法筛选潜在恋爱对象的技术可以追溯到1965年，当时年轻的会计师刘易斯·阿尔菲斯特（Lewis Altfest）和他的朋友、IBM的黑客罗伯特·罗斯（Robert Ross）创建了一个名为“技术自动兼容性测试”（TACT）的项目。10这是第一个基于纯数据的商业约会服务，不过一项专门针对哈佛学生的服务 Operation Match 比 TACT 早了一年。

Data-crunching stat guys only started taking over in baseball within the last fifteen years at the highest levels of the game. But sorting out potential love interests by algorithm can be traced back to 1965, when Lewis Altfest, a young accountant, together with his friend Robert Ross, a hacker at IBM, created what they called Project TACT (Technical Automated Compatibility Testing).10 It was the first commercial dating service that ran on pure data, though a service just for Harvard students, Operation Match, anticipated TACT by one year.

TACT 面向纽约单身人士推出，收费 5 美元，要求他们回答一百道选择题，涵盖从政治到发型等各种话题。Altfest 和 Ross 随后将问卷调查翻译成穿孔卡片，并输入 IBM 1400 系列计算机，该计算机会为每个人匹配五个匹配对象。一年之内，已有 5000 人注册，希望通过这项开创性的约会算法寻找爱情。这项服务只持续了几年，Ross 就被华尔街日新月异的世界及其日益增长的自动化所吸引，转而投身金融业。他说，他认为电脑约会只是一时的热潮。11

Available to New Yorkers, TACT charged single city dwellers five dollars and asked them to answer one hundred multiple-choice questions that covered topics from politics to hairstyles. Altfest and Ross then took the surveys, translated them onto punch cards, and fed them into an IBM 1400 Series computer, which would produce five matches for each person. Within a year, five thousand people had signed up to find love with this first of dating algorithms. The service only lasted a few years before Ross, beckoned by the changing world of Wall Street and its creeping automation, left for a career in finance. He said he thought computer dating was just a fad.11

这股热潮沉寂了三十年，但到了2011年，它已发展成为一个价值40亿美元的产业，并且日益壮大。六分之一的新婚姻源于互联网约会网站上的结识。12我的一位前同事在 eHarmony 上结识了他的妻子，这要归功于一个包含数百个变量的算法和一个价值数百万甚至数十亿美元的专有代码库。约会网站 eHarmony 根据 258 个问题匹配对象，这些问题基于 29 个核心特征进行评判。用户不能自行浏览约会对象；一切都由算法决定。

The fad did go dormant for thirty years, but in 2011 it was a $4 billion industry growing bigger by the day. One in six new marriages sprouts from connections made on Internet dating sites.12 One of my former coworkers met his wife on eHarmony thanks to an algorithm with hundreds of variables and a proprietary base of code that’s surely worth millions of dollars, if not billions. The dating Web site eHarmony matches people based on 258 questions that judge them on twenty-nine core traits. Users aren’t allowed to browse for dates on their own; the algorithm decides all.

eHarmony 的算法基于盖伦·巴克沃特（Galen Buckwalter）的研究，巴克沃特在加入这家网络公司之前曾是南加州大学的心理学教授。该网站称，目前其促成的婚姻占美国婚姻总数的 2% 以上，相当于每天促成 120 对婚姻。13其他算法也在不断涌现。Perfectmatch.com 利用华盛顿大学社会学家佩珀·施瓦茨 (Pepper Schwartz) 创建的算法将人们撮合在一起。据 Chemistry.com 称，罗格斯大学人类学家海伦·费舍尔 (Helen Fisher) 为 Chemistry.com 开发了一种算法，该算法基于恋爱中人们的神经化学反应。另一家约会服务网站 OkCupid 由四位哈佛大学数学专业的学生创立，他们创建了一个不断引导用户获取更多信息的网站，这些信息可以输入 OkCupid 的算法。现在，大多数测验都是由用户编写的，这些测验内容可以是长短不一的调查问卷，问题数量不限，其中一些会被输入 OkCupid 的算法。截至 2012 年，该网站的测验数量已超过四万个。

eHarmony’s algorithm is based on research by Galen Buckwalter, who was a psychology professor at the University of Southern California before heading to the Web company. The site says it now has a hand in more than 2 percent of all marriages in the United States, which translates to 120 marriages per day.13 Other algorithms are plying the waters too. Perfectmatch.com puts people together with an algorithm created by University of Washington sociologist Pepper Schwartz. Helen Fisher, an anthropologist at Rutgers, created an algorithm for Chemistry.com based on the neural chemistry of people in love, according to the company. OkCupid, yet another dating service, was founded by four math majors from Harvard who built a site that continually nudges users for more information that can be fed to OkCupid’s algorithms. Users now compose most of the quizzes, which can be short or long surveys asking any number of questions, some of which get dumped into OkCupid’s algorithm. As of 2012 the site had more than forty thousand quizzes.

但仍有科学家不相信算法能比随机转瓶更好地带来爱情。西北大学社会心理学教授伊莱·芬克尔和加州大学洛杉矶分校教授本杰明·卡尼的研究表明，大型约会网站背后的算法在筛选用户时，即使只剩下最匹配的几率，其匹配率也并不比随机筛选的结果高。这或许有一定的道理。OkCupid分析了其网站上3.5万对情侣的数据，发现在数十万个问题中，最能预示恋爱关系长久的可能性的是“你喜欢恐怖电影吗？”

But there are scientists who still don’t buy that algorithms can bring us love any better than random bottle spinning. Research done by Eli Finkel, a professor of social psychology at Northwestern University, and Benjamin Karney, the same at UCLA, says that when the algorithms behind big dating sites cull the field for users down to a top set of matches, they do not outperform the compatibility potential of picking people out of the field at random. There may be something to that. OkCupid has analyzed thirty-five thousand couples from its site and discovered that, of its hundreds of thousands of questions, the one that best signals the potential for relationship longevity is, “Do you like horror movies?”

芬克尔说：“八十年的关系科学研究已经可靠地表明，你无法根据不认识彼此的人的信息来预测一段关系是否会成功。”14

“Eighty years of relationship science has reliably shown you can’t predict whether a relationship succeeds based on information about people who are unaware of each other,” Finkel says.14

芬克尔和卡尼表示，算法失败的原因在于，大多数关系都是由一些问题所破坏的，这些问题只有在情侣见面并开始共度时光后才会出现。15教授们表示，人们在压力下如何沟通以及如何与他人解决问题，更能预示一段关系的长期发展。但毫无疑问，约会算法的创造者会想方设法识别学者们所说的这些特质。我们有理由相信，他们最终会成功。正如特里·麦奎尔将在第七章中向我们展示的那样，算法已经能够解读我们话语背后的真正含义。它们知道我们在想什么。

The reason for algorithms’ failures, Finkel and Karney say, is that most relationships are subverted by issues that emerge only after the couple meets and begins spending time together.15 How people communicate under stress and how they solve problems with others, the professors say, are far more indicative of how a relationship will fare in the long run. But there is little doubt that the creators of dating algorithms will search out ways to discern these exact traits the academics talk about. There are reasons to believe they’ll eventually be successful. As Terry McGuire will show us in chapter 7, algorithms can already read our words for the true meaning behind them. They know what we’re thinking.

6

6

呼叫机器人医生

PAGING DR. BOT

《医生桌上参考手册》（PDR）是 一本汇集了制药公司处方信息和每种药品说明书的书籍。你可能在自家的初级保健诊所里见过它。PDR每年更新一次；2012 年版长达 3250 页。理论上，医生应该随时了解书中的内容，因为每年都会更新数千条关于剂量、副作用、并发症以及可能有害的药物组合的信息。即使是最严谨的学者也很难理解并记住书中的信息。平心而论，这本书是医生在不完全了解或理解某种药物时需要查阅的参考书。但扮演医生角色的算法可以获取PDR中的信息，并在几秒钟内将其记忆下来，并根据药品制造商发布的最新数据不断进行细微调整。尽管从表面上看，医学似乎很难被破解，但事实是，它已经被算法所动摇——而真正的改变尚未到来。

THE PHYSICIANS’ DESK REFERENCE IS a book that combines pharmaceutical companies’ prescribing information and directions for every drug they make. You’ve likely seen it in the background at your own primary care office. The PDR is updated annually; the 2012 version has 3,250 pages. Theoretically, doctors are supposed to keep apprised of what’s inside the book, which includes thousands of updates every year on dosages, side effects, complications, and possible harmful drug combinations. Even the most pedantic studiers would have a hard time ingesting and retaining the information contained in its pages. To be fair, the book is a reference work to be checked when a doctor doesn’t fully know or understand everything about a drug. But an algorithm acting as a doctor could take the information found in the PDR and commit it to memory in seconds, constantly updating itself with nuanced adjustments based on new data pushed out by drug manufacturers. While medicine seems to be rather unhackable on its face, the truth is that it’s already been shaken by algorithms—and the real changes are yet to come.

生命的仲裁者

THE ARBITER OF LIFE

2004年，扑克算法创始人托马斯·桑德霍尔姆（Tuomas Sandholm）坐在观众席中，被一位演讲者和他的演讲主题深深吸引。当时，哈佛大学经济学家艾尔·罗斯（Al Roth）正在法国马赛举行的博弈论学会世界大会上发表演讲。罗斯正在阐述肾脏移植网络在应对每位捐献者或接受者所面临的各种情况时所面临的挑战：血型、所在地、健康状况、年龄、亲属等等。

Sitting in an audience in 2004, Tuomas Sandholm, the creator of poker algorithms, found himself riveted by a speaker and his topic. Al Roth, a Harvard economist, was talking to the World Congress of the Game Theory Society in Marseille, France. Roth was explaining the challenges facing kidney transplant networks in dealing with the circumstances facing each donor or recipient: blood type, location, health, age, relatives, and so on.

在美国乃至全球，成千上万的人正等待器官移植，因此，最大限度地提高捐献者和患者之间的匹配率是器官移植系统面临的最大挑战。在过去的几十年里，用于尽可能多地为接受者提供器官的方法已经发生了无数次变化，但仍有数千个潜在的匹配者未能获得器官。造成这种情况的原因错综复杂，但并非无法解决。

With tens of thousands of people sitting on waiting lists in America and across the world, maximizing the number of matches between donors and patients is the biggest mission facing the transplant system. The methodology used to get organs to as many recipients as possible has changed countless times during the last few decades, but thousands of potential matches are still unmet. The reasons for that are complex and diverse—but not so complex that they can’t be fixed.

桑德霍姆听着罗斯的讲述，当罗斯开始讨论器官捐献网络如何尝试运用博弈论来增加年度移植数量时，他坐了起来。罗斯本人率先运用博弈论，将每年超过两万五千名美国医学院毕业生与医院进行住院医师培训的匹配。在1995年他的系统实施之前，美国的住院医师培训项目因几乎让所有人都不满而臭名昭著，从未能获得顶尖候选人的医院，到被迫与配偶分离或被调到所选专业实力较弱的医院的住院医师。

As Sandholm listened, he shifted in his seat when Roth began discussing how organ donor networks were experimenting with game theory to increase the numbers of transplants they made in a year. Roth himself pioneered the use of game theory to match up the more than twenty-five thousand annual U.S. medical school grads with hospitals for residencies. Before his system was implemented in 1995, the U.S. resident program was infamous for making nearly everybody unhappy, from hospitals that didn’t get their top candidates to residents who were torn away from their spouses or shifted to hospitals that were weak in their chosen specialty.

罗斯还创建了一个算法，根据学生的偏好、学校的严格程度、录取政策和地理位置，为纽约市即将毕业的八年级学生（这些学生可以就读七百多所不同的公立高中）匹配最合适的学校。在他的算法出现之前，匹配过程一片混乱。一位教育部官员将其比作中东混乱的集市。该计划效率低下，只有66%的学生选择加入；而现在，罗斯算法决定了纽约市93%八年级毕业生的未来。1

Roth also created an algorithm to match graduating New York City eighth graders, who can attend more than seven hundred different public high schools, with the school that’s the best fit according to the student’s preferences and the school’s rigor, acceptance policies, and location. Before his algorithm, the matching process was a mess. One Department of Education official compared it to a chaotic bazaar in the Middle East. The program was so ineffective that only 66 percent of students opted in; now the Roth algorithm decides the futures of 93 percent of the graduating eighth graders in New York City.1

在攻克高中难题之后，罗斯开始将博弈论应用于肾脏捐赠网络的难题——这是一项远为复杂的任务。器官移植链中的变化瞬息万变，从患者的病情、器官的可获得性，到部分参与者的后续行动意愿，无不如此。在马赛，罗斯解释了这些问题的快速发展如何影响他的团队工作。他告诉听众，随着移植候选人库的扩大，问题的复杂性也呈指数级增长。

Following his hack of high schools, Roth began work to apply game theory to the problems vexing kidney donor networks—a far more complicated task. Changes within an organ transplant chain can happen fast, from the condition of a patient and the availability of an organ to the willingness of some participants to follow through. In Marseille, Roth explained how the quick pace of the problems affected his team’s work. As the pool of transplant candidates grows larger, he told the audience, the complexity of the problem increases exponentially.

罗斯继续说着，桑德霍姆环顾四周，房间里大多坐满了经济学家。他开始觉得自己和其他人一样，都是解决这个问题的最佳人选。“我意识到，这不是一个经济学问题，”他说，“这是一个计算机科学问题。”

As Roth continued, Sandholm looked around the room, which was mostly full of economists. He started thinking that he was as good a candidate to solve this problem as anybody. “This wasn’t an economics problem, I realized,” he says. “This was a computer science problem.”

当疾病侵袭肾脏，导致肾脏衰竭时，患者面临两种选择：要么找到一个愿意捐献肾脏的人，这在很多情况下可以让患者过上相对正常的生活；要么，如果找不到捐献的肾脏，就接受透析治疗，即每周数次用机器过滤血液中多余的盐分和毒素，每次耗时四到五小时。第三个选择是死亡。超过2000万美国人患有慢性肾病，其中35万人定期接受透析治疗。2尽管美国每年在透析治疗上花费 400 亿美元，但每年仍有超过 20% 的美国透析患者死亡。3

When disease strikes at somebody’s kidneys, causing them to fail, the person is left with two options: either find a person willing to donate one of their kidneys, which allows patients to live a relatively normal life in many cases, or, if a donor kidney can’t be found, submit to dialysis, where a machine filters the blood of excess salts and toxins several times a week at four to five hours per session. The third option is death. More than 20 million Americans live with chronic kidney disease, and 350,000 undergo regular dialysis treatments.2 Despite the fact that the United States spends $40 billion a year on dialysis treatments, more than 20 percent of U.S. dialysis patients die every year.3

八万六千人正等待肾脏移植，这使得协助移植成为一项艰巨的任务。在美国每年约两万五千例移植手术中，超过60%的移植手术来自新近去世的捐献者。其余大部分移植手术来自与接受者有血缘关系的活体捐献者。

The fact that eighty-six thousand people sit on the kidney waiting list makes abetting transplants a weighty mission. Of the twenty-five thousand or so annual transplants in the United States, more than 60 percent of them begin with newly deceased donors. The majority of the rest come from live donors related to the recipients.

罗斯在 2004 年的演讲中重点介绍了配对配型技术的前景，当时这项技术每年只能完成几十例移植手术。配对配型是指患者有亲属或朋友愿意捐献肾脏，但由于某种原因（通常是血型不相容），患者的身体无法接受捐献者的肾脏。如果能找到第二对不相容的配对，即第二位捐献者与第一位患者匹配，而第一位捐献者与第二位患者匹配，那么就可以进行移植手术。然而，找到满足所有必要匹配要求的对子却并非易事。引入更多配对可以创造更多可用的匹配，至少在理论上是这样。但是，将数千对配对放在一起并试图有效地将它们分类却非常复杂。

In his 2004 speech, Roth spotlighted the promise of what’s known as pairs matching, which was only responsible for several dozen transplants a year at that time. Pairs matching happens when a patient has a relative or friend willing to donate but, for whatever reason, usually incompatible blood type, the patient’s body won’t accept the donor’s kidney. If a second incompatible pair can be found where the second donor matches the first patient and the first donor matches the second patient, then transplants can be made. Finding an opposite pair that satisfies all necessary matching requirements, however, is something of a long shot. Introducing more pairs to the mix creates more available matches, at least theoretically. But throwing thousands of pairs into a bucket and attempting to sort them out efficiently is complicated.

在艾尔·罗斯开始探索新的肾脏配型方法之前，人们只能用电子表格手工完成配型。如果匹配结果不明显，就无法进行配型。事实上，在罗斯的研究之前，美国根本没有任何国家级或地区性的肾脏配型库。罗斯开发了一个系统，可以自动找到从肾脏库中匹配肾脏的最高效方法，但该算法的处理能力有限，他在马赛的演讲台上感叹了这个问题。

Before Al Roth started tinkering with new methods for matching pairs, they were put together by hand with little more than a spreadsheet. If a match wasn’t patently obvious, it wasn’t made. Before Roth’s work, in fact, there were no national or regional pools for kidney matching anywhere in the United States. Roth developed a system that automatically found the most efficient way to put pairs from the pool together, but the algorithm was limited in the numbers it could handle, a problem he lamented at the lectern in Marseille.

桑德霍姆在罗斯演讲结束后找到了他，并主动提出为这个匹配项目提供帮助，他运用了罗斯在创建复杂的市场算法和世界上最先进的扑克机器人时学到的一些技巧。“像肾脏匹配池这样的项目所需的代码非常难写，”桑德霍姆解释道。“我花了22年的时间研究这些算法，才达到现在的水平。”

Sandholm tracked Roth down after his speech and offered his help on the matching project, using some of the tactics he’d picked up in creating complex market algorithms and the world’s most advanced poker bots. “The code needed for something like the kidney matching pool is very difficult to write,” Sandholm explains. “It had taken me twenty-two years of experience with these algorithms to get to this point.”

处理大量配对的难题之一是可能性的数量之巨，以及进行此类计算所需的计算机内存。每位候选人和捐赠者都携带着二十多项需要进行最佳匹配的参数，包括血型、体重指数、病毒史、捐献或接受左肾或右肾的意愿、年龄、血压、与候选人的关系、血液中的抗体类型，甚至他们愿意前往的地点以及匹配的总体难度（极其困难的匹配会获得额外优先权，因为他们应该在更容易匹配的候选人之前得到处理）。所有这些因素都使得计算机需要运行数百万种可能性才能找到最佳解决方案——而每次计算都比为棋盘创建解决方案树更为复杂。

One of the problems with crunching big pools of pairs was the sheer number of possibilities and the computer memory such a calculation needed. Each candidate and donor carry with them more than twenty parameters that need to be optimally matched, including blood type, body mass index, viral history, willingness to donate or accept a left or right kidney, age, blood pressure, relationship to candidate, types of antibodies in the blood, and even where they’re willing to travel and the difficulty of their match in general (acutely difficult matches are given extra precedence as they should be taken care of before more easily matched candidates). All of these factors make a computer run through millions of possibilities to find the best solution—and each calculation is more complicated than creating solution trees for a chessboard.

在桑多姆的研究之前，配对匹配算法无法扩展到数千人的牌池。但他编写了一种新算法，并对其进行了编码，使计算机能够在不耗尽内存的情况下处理海量计算。他借鉴了自己设计扑克机器人的方法，指示算法只记住最重要的部分，而不是全部。该算法可以在必要时近似地计算出空白。扩大牌池规模，并构建一个能够处理这一问题的机器人，将挽救更多生命，这才是关键所在。

Before Sandholm’s work, pairs matching couldn’t be scaled up to a pool of thousands. But he wrote a new algorithm and coded it in a way that allows the computer to process the giant calculations without exhausting its memory. He tapped methods he used in making his poker bot, instructing his algorithm only to remember the most important bits rather than all of them. The algorithm can approximate the blanks when necessary. Increasing the pool size, and building a bot that can handle it, will save more lives, which is the whole point.

由非营利组织“器官共享联合网络”（UNOS）运营的全国器官配对池于2010年底开始使用桑德霍姆的算法进行配对。桑德霍姆的算法每月对池子进行一次筛选，力求匹配数量最大化。UNOS于2011年底开始公布该池子，目标是使其数量达到桑德霍姆所说的“临界规模”。

A national pairs matching pool, run by the nonprofit United Network for Organ Sharing, began using Sandholm’s algorithm and taking pairs late in 2010. Once a month, Sandholm’s algorithm sorts through the pool, looking to make the maximum number of matches. UNOS started publicizing the pool in late 2011 with the goal of getting its numbers to what Sandholm calls “critical mass.”

随着越来越多的人注册加入UNOS配对库（该库也汇集了来自区域肾移植网络的参与者），该项目将变得越来越强大，最终达到至关重要的临界点，无论匹配困难还是容易匹配的候选人都有很大的机会延长生命。该库于2010年底开放时，只有140对配对参与，这意味着算法的第一次运行只产生了大约12对匹配。

As more people register for the UNOS pairs matching pool, which is also gathering participants from regional kidney transplant networks, the program will become increasingly powerful, leading it toward that all-important critical mass, where both hard-to-match and easy-to-match candidates stand a great chance of extending their lives. When the pool opened in late 2010, there were only 140 pairs participating, which led to only about a dozen matches from the first pass of the algorithm.

在规模较小的供体池中，由于血型、地理位置、免疫力缺乏或其他一系列因素，一次难以匹配的情况就可能让整个系统陷入瘫痪。这位难以匹配的患者可能会遇到一位配对的捐献者，其器官可以满足许多其他难以匹配的情况，但只有在患者也找到匹配的器官后才能使用。在只有几百对供体的小型供体池中，这种情况可能难以处理。但随着供体池规模扩大到超过一千名参与者——桑德霍姆设计的机器人最多可处理一万名供体——几乎总能找到一个合适的“拼图块”，让其他人能够加入进来。这就是桑德霍姆所说的“临界质量”。

In a small pool, one tough match—due to blood type, location, lack of immunity, or a bevy of other factors—can lock up the whole system. That hard-to-match patient may come with a paired donor whose organ would fill a number of other difficult matches, but can’t be used until the patient is also found a match. Such situations can prove intractable in small pools of just a few hundred pairs. But as the pool grows to include more than a thousand participants—Sandholm designed his bot to handle up to ten thousand—there’s almost always a puzzle piece that fits, allowing others to fit in behind it. That’s what Sandholm calls critical mass.

“托马斯的算法为这些难以匹配的患者找到了真正合适的肾脏，这种可能性给了他们活下去的理由。”负责 UNOS 配对程序的露丝安妮·汉托 (Ruthanne Hanto) 说道。

“Tuomas’s algorithm gives these tough matches real hope of finding that exact right kidney—and that possibility gives them a reason to live,” says Ruthanne Hanto, who runs the UNOS pairs matching program.

你的医生机器人

YOUR DOCTOR BOT

您是否希望有一位能够做到以下几点的医生：

Wouldn’t you like to have a doctor who will:

 

 

  • 始终方便且可用。
  • Always be convenient and available.
  • 了解自己的所有优点和缺点。
  • Know all of your strengths and weaknesses.
  • 了解您过去的状况可能预示的每一个风险因素。
  • Know every single risk factor your past conditions might signal.
  • 了解您的完整病史。
  • Know your complete medical history.
  • 了解您家族最近三代人的病史。
  • Know the medical history of the last three generations of your family.
  • 切勿粗心大意犯错或开错处方。
  • Never make a careless mistake or write an incorrect prescription.
  • 始终了解每一个新的治疗方法和医学发现。
  • Always be up to date on every new treatment and medical discovery.
  • 永远不要陷入坏习惯或困境。
  • Never fall into bad habits or ruts.
