  • 记住你的每一个基线测量值：脉搏、胆固醇、血压、体重、肺活量、骨密度和过去的伤害。
  • Know by heart each one of your baseline measurements: pulse, cholesterol, blood pressure, weight, lung capacity, bone density, and past injuries.
  • 时刻监视你。
  • Monitor you at all times.
  • 始终寻找问题的迹象，无论是心脏跳动、血压缓慢升高、胆固醇激增，甚至是呼出的空气中的微量变化，这些都可能预示着早期癌症。
  • Always be searching for the hint of a problem, be it a heart tick, a creeping blood pressure increase, a cholesterol surge, or even trace changes in the air you expel, which could indicate early-stage cancer.

没有哪个人类医生能够做到这些。算法可以，而且将会做到所有这些。在数量不多但不断增长的医院中，咨询算法是诊断任何入院患者时的首要任务。越来越多的证据支持算法在床边的应用；在标准流程中使用算法的医院并发症更少，初始诊断更准确，病死率更低，当然，成本也更低。

There exists no human doctor who can do these things. An algorithm can and will do all of them. In a small but growing number of hospitals, consulting an algorithm is task number one when diagnosing any admitted patients. The evidence in favor of algorithms at the bedside is piling up; the hospitals that use algorithms in their standard processes have fewer complications, more correct initial diagnoses, lower fatality rates, and, yes, lower costs.

当很明显机器人比之前的模型拯救了更多的生命并促成了更多的移植时，大多数公众可能愿意接受一种分配器官的算法。然而，当变化影响到自己的医生和常规医疗时，人们就不会那么乐观了。在医疗保健领域，即使是由错误信息、恐惧、贪婪或更糟糕的原因引起的抱怨也可能非常尖锐。想象一下，当一些保险公司建议用真正的医生代替体检，并由算法进行持续监控时，会引起怎样的狂热。算法必然会在某种程度上取代医生——这个前景并不像听起来那么可怕。然而，当谈到健康问题时，许多人的态度可以概括为：改变是坏的；没有改变是好的。

Most of the public would likely be willing to accept an algorithm that metes out organs when it’s clear that the bot saves many more lives and facilitates far more transplants than models that existed before. People will be less sanguine, however, when change affects their own doctor and regular medical treatments. In health care, the complaints, even when they’re fueled by misinformation, fear, greed, or worse, can be shrill. Imagine the fervor that will come when some insurers suggest replacing physicals by real live doctors with constant monitoring by an algorithm. Algorithms are bound to replace doctors on some level—a prospect that isn’t as scary as it sounds. When it comes to matters of health, though, many people’s attitudes can be summed up thusly: change is bad; no change is good.

尽管如此，人们对基于计算机算法的诊断和治疗的抵制是可以预见的。美国每年在医疗保健上的支出已达2.6万亿美元，占其GDP的18%，这一比例远高于我们的同类国家。这些国家人民不仅寿命更长，而且婴儿死亡率也低得多，而且通常在晚年都能享受到更美好的生活。4

Still, people’s resistance to computer-based algorithmic diagnoses and treatment is predictable. The United States already spends $2.6 trillion a year on health care, 18 percent of its GDP, a far higher percentage than our peer countries, where in every case people not only live longer but also suffer far lower infant mortality rates and generally enjoy better years at the end of their lives.4

医疗保健领域充斥着算法带来的轻松胜利。首先要改变的是我们分析检测结果的方式。从巴氏涂片到X光、核磁共振和CT扫描，各种检测的频率、复杂性和成本是过去二十年医疗保健成本激增的主要原因。当有人感觉不舒服去看医生时，无论他们的症状表明病情如何，他们通常都要接受一系列的检测。当这一系列检测结束后，通常还会进行另一项检测。即使有99.9%的可能性不需要进行这项检测，通常仍然需要进行。结果，对于那些进行检测的人来说，他们轻松获得了巨额收入——这体现了资本主义虽然对大多数经济体来说是一种有效的模式，但却不是一种管理医疗保健的有效方式。有大量的数据可以用来支持这一观点，但只需考虑一下，美国的平均预期寿命为 78 岁，与古巴相同，而古巴在医疗保健方面的人均支出不到美国的 10%，但取得的结果却大致相同。

Health care is full of easy wins for algorithms. The first thing to change will be how we analyze test results. The frequency, complexity, and costs of tests, from Pap smears to X-rays to MRIs to CT scans, have been among the major contributors to the explosion of health care costs during the last twenty years. When somebody shows up at the doctor not feeling well, they’re often subjected to a gauntlet of tests no matter what their symptoms indicate about their condition. When that flurry of tests is over, another one often follows. Even when there’s a 99.9 percent likelihood the test isn’t needed, it’s usually still mandated. The result, for those doing the testing, is an avalanche of easy revenue—thus exemplifying how capitalism, although it’s an effective paradigm for most of the economy, is not an efficient way to administer health care. A multitude of stats can be called on to support this, but simply consider that the United States’ average life expectancy of seventy-eight years is the same as that of Cuba, a country that spends less than 10 percent per capita of what the United States does on health care but achieves roughly the same result.

但这并非一场意识形态之争。这关乎算法如何改进美国现有的医疗体系——而算法最初将通过成为所有这些检测的默认扫描者、观察者和分析师来实现这一点。过去，你的结果需要放射科医生或病理学家付出高昂的代价才能得出，但未来算法就能做到。事实上，它会做得更好。

But this isn’t about an ideological battle. It is about algorithms bettering the system we have in the United States—and they will do that initially by becoming the default scanners, observers, and analysts of all of these tests. Where once your results required the expensive attention of a radiologist or a pathologist, in the future the attention of an algorithm will do just fine. It will, in fact, do better.

以巴氏涂片检查为例，它最初被称为巴氏涂片检查（以其希腊发明者乔治斯·帕帕尼古拉乌的名字命名）。自20世纪40年代首次推出以来，这项检查已使美国的宫颈癌死亡率降低了90%以上。5它会检查从女性宫颈抽取的一小块细胞样本的切片。切片首先交给细胞技术员，他们是经过专门训练的，专门做一件事：寻找细胞中可能表明癌症的异常迹象。然后，可疑的切片会被交给病理学家，病理学家是一名医学博士，年薪可能超过 30 万美元。现在有一些算法可以取代细胞技术员。更好的是（或者更糟的是，如果你是细胞技术员），这些算法通过扫描每张图像来寻找模拟已知在旧的分类图像中揭示癌症的视觉线索，从而帮助比人类竞争对手发现更多的癌症病例。医疗技术公司 BD（该公司制造了部分检测背后的设备）开展的一项研究中，实验室结合使用他们的算法和细胞技术员，发现了 86% 的癌症病例，而不使用算法进行扫描的实验室则发现了 79% 的癌症病例。6医学扫描中算法的日益普及将更早地发现更多问题，例如癌症，并最大限度地减少假阴性——此类扫描最令人担忧的问题。即使是渐进式的改进也能改变成千上万人的生活；仅在美国，每年进行的巴氏涂片检查就超过5500万次。7

Take the Pap test, originally called the Pap smear (named after its Greek inventor, Georgios Papanikolaou). The test has cut down on cervical cancer mortality rates in the United States by more than 90 percent since it was first introduced in the 1940s.5 It examines a slide of a small sample of cells drawn from a woman’s cervix. The slide first goes to a cytotechnologist, a person specially trained to do one thing: look for signs of abnormalities in the cells that may indicate cancer. Suspect slides are then passed to a pathologist, an MD who may earn more than $300,000 per year. There exist algorithms that can already replace the cytotechnologist. Even better (or worse, if you’re a cytotechnologist), the algorithms help find more instances of cancer than their human competitors by scanning each image for visual clues that mimic those known to reveal cancers in old cataloged images. In one study carried out by BD, a medical technology company that creates some of the equipment behind the testing, labs using their algorithm in tandem with a cytotechnologist spotted 86 percent of cancer instances versus 79 percent for those scanning without the algorithm.6 The rising use of algorithms in medical scanning will snare more problems, like cancer, earlier, and minimize false negatives, the scariest issue with such scans. Even incremental improvement would change thousands of lives; in the United States alone, more than fifty-five million Pap tests are carried out every year.7

在另一个案例中，算法在寻找所谓的肺结节（可能预示肺癌）方面优于单独的放射科医生。医生使用算法分析MDCT扫描（一种先进的X射线技术），在发现结节方面平均提高了16%。如果及早发现，监测结节可以挽救患者免于肺癌中晚期，这类患者的生存率不足15%。纽约州罗切斯特市伊丽莎白·温德乳腺诊所的另一项研究表明，使用算法作为诊断解释工具，可将乳腺癌乳房X光检查的假阴性率降低39%，这意味着通常被人类遗漏的癌症，算法能够以更高的概率发现。8斯坦福大学的研究表明，这种算法可以更早地发现乳腺癌，因此斯坦福大学的癌症研究所已经开发出一种算法，在放射科医生的指导下扫描每一次乳房 X 光检查。9

In another case, algorithms bettered lone radiologists in their search for what are called lung nodules, which can indicate lung cancer. Doctors using the algorithm to analyze their MDCT scans, an advanced form of X-ray, improved an average of 16 percent in spotting nodules, the monitoring of which, if caught early, can spare patients from the middle and late stages of lung cancer, for which the survival rates are less than 15 percent. In another study, from the Elizabeth Wende Breast Clinic in Rochester, New York, using algorithms as diagnostic interpreters was shown to decrease the incidence of false negatives in mammogram scans for breast cancer by 39 percent, meaning that cancers that are normally missed by humans are spotted at a far higher rate by algorithms.8 Stanford University’s Cancer Institute already has an algorithm scan every mammogram following a radiologist after Stanford studies indicated that it led to more early detections of breast cancer.9

减缓美国医疗保健检测成本失控的第一步是将一些检测分析结果发送给印度训练有素的医生。下一步，也是最终的答案，是将所有这项工作交给算法，这些算法一旦完善，将比印度、美国或其他任何地方的人工检测做得更好。

The first step in slowing out-of-control testing costs in U.S. health care was to ship some test analyses to well-trained doctors in India. The next—and final—answer will be turning all of this work over to algorithms that, when perfected, will do a better job than humans in India, America, or anywhere else.

那些负责阅读扫描、化验和患者元数据的人员的工作无疑岌岌可危。同样受到威胁的还有那些负责称量和发放药物的人员。城市地区的药剂师年薪可以超过13万美元。他们的工作压力很大，注重细节，而且不幸的是，他们的收入很容易被量化。这意味着这个行业亟待机器人入侵，而且迫在眉睫。2011年，加州大学旧金山分校开设了一家药房，里面除了一台机器人之外没有任何工作人员。瑞士物流公司Swisslog为加州大学旧金山分校制造了这台价值1500万美元的机器人。

The jobs for people reading scans, tests, and patient metadata are certainly endangered. Just as threatened as this workforce are the people who measure and dole out our medications. Pharmacists in urban areas can make more than $130,000 a year. Their job is stressful, detail-oriented, and can be, unfortunately for pharmacists, easily quantified. That means the profession begs for a bot invasion, and it’s imminent. In 2011, the University of California at San Francisco opened a pharmacy staffed by nobody except a single robot. A Swiss logistics firm, Swisslog, created the $15 million robot for UCSF.

这台机器直接从医生办公室和药房之间传输的电子信息中接收信息，它拥有灵巧的长臂，可以从装置内置的数千个药盒中抓取并包装药丸。该机器人接收所有关于患者的信息，包括他们的病情、过敏史以及他们可能正在服用的所有其他药物。机器人内部的算法会快速检查新处方是否存在药物冲突和并发症，确保不会发生有害的药物相互作用。加州大学旧金山分校这台机器中的算法无需花时间查阅最新的药理学信息；它们会通过制药公司发送的电子信息获取最新的药物信息，并立即吸收。与人类不同，这台机器不会忘记任何事情。这并不是说机器不会犯错——即使是编写得最好的程序也会出现错误。但错误也很容易修复，算法可以对负责配药的机器人进行并发测试，从而为机器人药剂师构建安全冗余。

The machine, which receives information straight from the electronic messages that already go between doctor’s offices and pharmacies, has long, dexterous arms that pluck and pack pills from thousands of bulk boxes that are built into the walls of the contraption. The bot receives all information regarding the patient, including their condition, any allergies, and all other medications they may be on. Algorithms within the bot quickly check for conflicts and complications with the new prescription, ensuring that there will be no detrimental drug interactions. The algorithms in the UCSF machine don’t need any time to read up on the latest in pharmacology; they get updated drug information through electronic messages from pharmaceutical companies and assimilate it immediately. The machine, unlike a human, forgets nothing. That’s not to say that a machine can’t make an error—bugs can affect the best-written programs. But bugs are also easily fixed and algorithms can run concurrent tests on the bot that doles out the drugs, building safety redundancy into the robot pharmacist.

旧金山的这台机器人目前已成功配药两百万张处方，且无一失误。药片与包装之间无需人工接触，彻底消除了污染的可能性。

The bot in San Francisco has now filled two million prescriptions without making a single mistake. And there’s no human contact between the pills and their packaging, eliminating the chance of contamination.

那么，与人类的竞争又如何呢？关于药房错误率的数据异常匮乏，现存的少数研究结果显示，错误率从令人震惊的4%到更可怕的10%不等。10不过，业内普遍接受的保守数字似乎是1%左右。美国药剂师协会对50家药店进行的一项全国性研究表明，平均错误率为1.7%。11所有这些数字都令人担忧。美国每年有37亿张处方需要配药，这意味着，即使按照最保守的计算方法，每年也有超过3700万张处方错误。美国药剂师协会估计，这个数字甚至更高，达到5150万张。

So how does the human competition fare? There’s a strange dearth of data on pharmacy error rates, and the few extant studies show results that span from the scary—a 4 percent error rate—to even scarier—10 percent error rates.10 It seems, however, that an accepted conservative number within the industry is about 1 percent. A national study of fifty pharmacies by the American Pharmacists Association showed that the average error rate is 1.7 percent.11 All of these numbers are scary. There are 3.7 billion prescriptions filled in the United States every year, which means, even by the most conservative of measurements, that there are more than 37 million prescription errors annually. The American Pharmacists Association estimated the number to be even higher, at 51.5 million.

这些错误对患者、我们的医疗系统以及参与制药流程的所有各方都造成了巨大的损失。全国范围内药剂师短缺的问题加剧了这一问题，导致他们工作过度、人手不足，进而引发更多错误。对于这一岗位，算法驱动的机器人的需求是不可否认的。挑选药丸、交叉检查药物相互作用以及确保数量和药物完全正确，这些都是算法驱动的机器人的专长。很少有任务能像算法驱动的机器人那样被量化。这个等式也有商业的一面。美国最大的连锁药店沃尔格林在 2006 年至 2007 年的十三个月内遭遇了四起涉及致命处方错误的陪审团诉讼，赔偿金额超过 6100 万美元。12如果沃尔格林能够从资产负债表中消除这些负债，情况会怎样？它可以，而且它会的。

The costs of these errors to patients, our health system, and all parties involved in the pharmaceutical process are dear. Pharmacists are not helped by the fact that there remains a shortage of them nationally, which leads to overworking, understaffing, and even more errors. The demand for an algorithm-powered robot in this role is undeniable. Picking out pills, cross-checking for drug interactions, and ensuring that quantities and medications are exactly right are skill’s made for algorithm-powered bots. Few tasks are so quantifiable. There’s a business side of this equation as well. Walgreens, the country’s largest pharmacy chain, had four jury-decided lawsuits involving fatal prescription errors brought against it during thirteen months in 2006 and 2007, with awards topping $61 million.12 What if Walgreens could eliminate such liabilities from its balance sheet? It can and it will.

但是那位医生的预约怎么办？

BUT WHAT ABOUT THAT DOCTOR’S APPOINTMENT?

维诺德·科斯拉（Vinod Khosla）是太阳微系统公司（Sun Microsystems）的联合创始人，也是一位极具先见之明的风险投资家。他和众多聪明人一样，相信算法将改善医疗保健。“最终，我们将不再需要普通医生，”科斯拉写道。他表示，算法将为90%到99%的医疗需求提供更优质、更经济的医疗服务。十三

Vinod Khosla, a cofounder of Sun Microsystems and as prescient a venture capital mind as exists, is one of the many bright people who believe that algorithms will make health care better. “Eventually, we won’t need the average doctor,” Khosla writes. Algorithms, he says, will provide much better and cheaper care for 90 to 99 percent of our medical needs.13

但也有一些令人信服的人士，例如哈佛大学医生、杰出的《纽约客》作家杰罗姆·格鲁普曼，对此持不同意见。格鲁普曼表示，依赖算法和循证医学是危险的，它会改变医生的思维方式，降低他们诊断这种已经愚弄了其他12位医生的怪病的效率。14

There are also compelling people such as Jerome Groopman, the Harvard doctor and splendid New Yorker writer, who disagree. Groopman says that relying on algorithms and evidence-based medicine is dangerous, that it alters how doctors think, making them less effective at diagnosing that odd malady that’s already fooled twelve other MDs.14

但很少有医生的问诊能像《豪斯医生》那样精彩纷呈。我们最灵活的诊断头脑完全可以应对看似棘手的病例，比如安妮·道奇。格鲁普曼告诉我们，在她痛苦的十五年里，数十位医生都对她真正的病情一无所知，最终一位富有洞察力的胃肠病专家救了她的命。道奇被诊断患有厌食症和贪食症，体重骤降至82磅后，医生建议她多吃谷物和碳水化合物来增重。这种建议让她难以忍受。最终，胃肠病专家迈伦·法尔查克博士正确地诊断出她患有乳糜泻，肠道无法正常处理麸质——小麦中的主要蛋白质之一。15

But few doctor visits unspool like an episode of House. There’s no reason why our most flexible diagnostic minds couldn’t be consulted on seemingly intractable cases, such as the one of Anne Dodge, who as Groopman tells us had her life saved by an insightful gastroenterologist after dozens of doctors whiffed on her real ailment during the course of a hellish fifteen years. Dodge, who had been diagnosed with anorexia and bulimia, had been told to eat grains and carbohydrates in order to pack on weight after she slipped to eighty-two pounds. This recommendation was killing her. Gastroenterologist Dr. Myron Falchuk finally correctly diagnosed her with celiac disease, wherein the intestines can’t properly process gluten, one of the main proteins in wheat.15

我们为什么要用法尔查克那样的头脑去处理那些他领域里的专家每天都要面对的例行程序、查询和案例呢？我们应该把棘手的案例留给法尔查克这样的高手，把剩下的——比如你上周得的感冒，或者去年的鼻窦炎——交给算法来处理。算法成本低廉、准确，而且每天都在变得越来越智能。

Why should we be taxing minds like that of Falchuk with routine procedures, queries, and cases that specialists in his realm face every day? We should save the tricky cases for solvers like Falchuk and give the rest—like the cold you had last week or that sinus infection from last year—to the algorithms. They’re cheap, accurate, and they get smarter every day.

许多医生对算法医学都有一定的了解。住院医生，甚至年纪稍长的医学博士，在评估新病人时，经常会查阅诊断小抄。但它们的实用性是有代价的；另一位医生兼作家、德克萨斯大学健康科学中心的医学教授弗雷德·赫伯特抱怨说，这些算法打印出来后会变得错综复杂，甚至会占据一整页纸。“它们有太多步骤，太多箭头指向太多方向，以至于我最终放弃了试图弄清楚所有事情，”他说。这个问题很容易解决，只需将所有这些信息都放到一个iPad应用程序中，该应用程序只需要求医生输入信息，而不是在打印的页面上向他展示整个操作的核心。但即使是这样的前景也没有给许多医生留下深刻的印象。赫伯特坚持认为，数学家是用来管理数字的，而医生是用来管理病人的。他认为，像管理数字一样管理病人是一种“令人遗憾的趋势”。16

Many doctors are familiar with algorithmic medicine to some extent. Residents and even older MDs often consult diagnostic cheat sheets when assessing a new patient. But their utility comes at a price; another doctor/writer, Fred Herbert, a professor of medicine at the University of Texas Health Science Center, complains that the algorithms, when printed out on paper, grow labyrinthine and can take up a whole page. “They have so many steps with so many arrows pointing in so many directions that I ultimately give up trying to figure everything out,” he says. That problem is easily fixed by sticking all of that information into an iPad app that only asks the doctor for inputs rather than showing him the guts of the entire operation on a printed page. But even that prospect doesn’t impress many doctors. Herbert maintains that mathematicians are for managing numbers and doctors are for managing patients. Managing patients like numbers, he says, is a “deplorable trend.”16

但越来越多的证据表明事实并非如此。犹他州的Intermountain医疗中心利用数据和算法提升了医院的诊疗水平，使其成为全球顶尖的康复中心之一。研究人员和医生甚至从瑞士远道而来，前来参观Intermountain医疗中心的诊疗方法。Intermountain医疗中心的负责人布伦特·詹姆斯博士在进入医学院之前，本科就读于犹他大学物理和计算机科学专业，这不足为奇。

But there’s accumulating proof that says otherwise. Intermountain Medical Center in Utah has used data and algorithms to improve that hospital’s performance and make it one of the preeminent healing centers in the world. Researchers and doctors come from as far as Switzerland to view the methods used at Intermountain. It should be no surprise that the man leading Intermountain’s charge, Dr. Brent James, spent his undergraduate years studying physics and computer science at the University of Utah before heading to medical school.

詹姆斯建立了一套系统，在制定患者治疗方案时，依靠数据而非医生的直觉。医院所做的一切都会被记录、分析和报告，以便日后通过算法进行检验，从呼吸机的设置到心脏病发作后的支架使用。詹姆斯利用Intermountain独有的数据，根据患者的实际情况，重新编写了医院的诊疗流程。算法会搜索收集到的既往病例数据，为Intermountain的医生提供未来诊断和治疗方案的信息。17

James has built a system of relying on data rather than mere doctor’s intuition when making decisions about how to treat patients. Everything the hospital does is charted, analyzed, and reported so it can later be examined by an algorithm, from ventilator settings to stent use after heart attacks. Using data produced only at Intermountain, James has been able to rewrite procedures the hospital follows derived from the predicament of the patient. Algorithms search the collected data of previous cases, informing doctors at Intermountain on future diagnoses and courses of treatment.17

其成果毋庸置疑：利用自身数据，Intermountain 医院将冠状动脉搭桥手术的死亡率降至 1.5%，而全国平均水平为 3%；肺炎患者的死亡率与全国平均水平相比降低了 40%；其早产婴儿比例远低于全国其他地区。美国早产趋势已得到充分证实；世界卫生组织的数据显示，过去 25 年间，早产率上升了 36%。但 Intermountain 医院的早产率实际上有所下降，这要归功于医院以数以万计的病例为基础，对病例进行分类、量化和分析后制定的治疗方案。总而言之，詹姆斯和 Intermountain 医院已提高 50 多种临床病症的成功率，这些病症占该院患者的一半以上。18詹姆斯的作品提出了一个问题：你想要一名医生吗？或者也许拥有一个机器人会更好？

The results are hard to argue with: using its own data, Intermountain has cut the death rate for coronary bypass surgery to 1.5 percent, compared with 3 percent nationally; it has reduced the death rate of pneumonia victims by 40 percent, compared with national numbers; and its percentage of infants delivered preterm is far below that of the rest of that country. The trend of more preterm deliveries in the United States is well documented; according to the World Health Organization, it has increased 36 percent during the last twenty-five years. But the rate at Intermountain has actually decreased thanks to the hospital’s treatment practices that have been informed by tens of thousands of cases it has categorized, quantified, and crunched. All told, James and Intermountain have increased successful outcomes for more than fifty clinical conditions, comprising more than half of the hospital’s patients.18 James’s work begs the question: do you want a doctor—or would you perhaps be better off with a bot?

“不要争论哲学，”詹姆斯在接受《纽约时报》采访时谈到科技怀疑论者时说道。“给我看看你们的死亡率，我就会相信你们。”19

“Don’t argue philosophy,” James said of technology doubters to the New York Times. “Show me your mortality rates, and then I’ll believe you.”19

这只是医院的治疗标准。预防性护理通常始于医生的办公室，但算法也可以提高那里的有效率。最终，算法将开始通过你的手机改善你的整体健康状况。2010年，全球最受尊敬的风险投资公司红杉资本投资了一家名为AirStrip的公司。该公司在2012年2月的另一轮融资后，已筹集超过3000万美元，旨在将实时患者数据直接提供给医生的iPhone、iPad和其他设备。接下来是家庭监控，其中一个应用程序将在家中和工作场所监控你，不断扫描你的生命体征并寻找早期疾病迹象。AirStrip家庭应用程序的早期版本将专注于改善充血性心力衰竭的治疗效果。根据美国国家心肺血液研究所的数据，这种疾病影响着美国600万人。20

And that’s just treatment standards at the hospital. Preventive care often starts in your physician’s office, but algorithms can improve efficacy rates there too. Eventually, algorithms will start improving your general health right from your mobile phone. In 2010, Sequoia Capital, the most revered venture capital firm in the world, invested in a company called AirStrip, which after another funding round in February 2012 has raised more than $30 million in its effort to provide real-time patient data straight to doctors’ iPhones, iPads, and other devices. Next up is home monitoring, wherein an app will monitor you at home and at work, constantly scanning your vitals and looking for early signs of trouble. Early versions of AirStrip’s home app will be focused on improving outcomes for congestive heart failure, which affects six million people in the United States, according to the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute.20

荷兰科技公司飞利浦（Philips）目前为iPhone或iPad开发了一款售价99美分的应用程序，该应用程序利用设备摄像头，对注视屏幕的用户进行多项重要测量。飞利浦的算法通过分析人脸图像像素中细微的颜色变化，可以精确计算出心率；为了确定用户的呼吸频率，该算法会观察用户的胸部运动。飞利浦表示，多年来他们一直在研发用于这项创新的先进算法，但直到2011年推出的iPad 2和iPhone 4S等新硬件，才使得该公司能够将这些算法应用于任何人，而且价格不到一美元。飞利浦和其他科技公司即将推出的应用程序将可以即时测量血压、体温、血氧水平以及脑震荡迹象。

The Dutch technology company Philips now makes a ninety-nine-cent app for your iPhone or iPad that takes several vital measurements of the person looking at the screen, using the device’s camera. Philips’s algorithms, by examining minuscule color changes in the image pixels of our faces, can figure heart rates to fine degrees of accuracy; to determine a user’s breathing rate, the algorithm watches his chest for movement. Philips says it has been working on the advanced algorithms for the innovation for years, but it was the new hardware in the form of the iPad 2 and the iPhone 4S, introduced in 2011, that allowed the company to put these algorithms to work, for anyone, for less than a dollar. Upcoming apps from Philips and other tech companies will allow for instant measurement of blood pressure, temperature, blood oxygenation levels, and signs of concussion.

将我们口袋里随身携带的设备提供的实时监测与对我们的DNA、基因以及我们天生易患疾病的详细了解结合起来，将成为我们这个时代医学领域的重大进步之一。DNA分析通常不是初级保健的常规步骤，因为它既耗时又昂贵，就像医学中的大多数事情一样。但随着旨在更快地绘制DNA图谱的算法投入使用，这种情况将会改变。有了你的基因及其变异，其他算法将把预防保健提升到一个新的水平。

Coupling real-time monitoring from devices we already carry around in our pockets with detailed knowledge of our DNA, our genes, and what diseases we’re naturally susceptible to will be one of the great medical steps forward of our time. DNA analysis isn’t usually a customary step of primary care because it’s time-consuming and expensive, just like most things in medicine. But this will change, as algorithms designed to map your DNA faster are put on the case. Armed with your genes and their variants, other algorithms will take preventive care to a new level.

以澳大利亚一家建筑公司的业务发展经理雷娜·贝茨为例。2006年，贝茨住院接受扁桃体切除术。手术进行得很顺利，医生和护士开始清理伤口，让她躺在手术台上休息。但她无法休息，也无法呼吸。贝茨是全球5%患有假性胆碱酯酶缺乏症的人之一，这种疾病使她更容易因手术中使用的麻醉药物而长时间瘫痪。当她在手术台上挣扎求生时，一名护士终于注意到了，于是团队用一根管子恢复了她的呼吸。但如果医院事先知道贝茨的情况，这起可能致命或导致严重脑损伤的事故本可以避免。21.有了23andMe这样的服务，我们中的许多人很快就能避免此类事件的发生。只需200美元，该公司就会通过邮件采集您的唾液样本，并返回一份详细的DNA分析报告。其算法可以分析出各种引人入胜的因素，从您的血统到您的健康风险以及对药物的潜在反应。诚然，一些医生和健康专家表示，23andMe的测试没有提供任何有用的信息，消费者应该省钱。包括纽约州在内的一些州已下令23andMe及类似服务机构必须获得州卫生部门的批准，宣布这些测试属于医疗用途，因此需要接受监管。23andMe表示，这种监管“极其家长式”，并补充说，人们有权了解自身基因信息。

Consider Renae Bates, a business development manager at an architecture firm in Australia. Bates was in the hospital for a tonsillectomy in 2006. The operation went smoothly and her doctors and nurses began to clean up, leaving her to rest on the operating table. But she couldn’t rest—she couldn’t breathe either. Bates is among the 5 percent of people in the world affected with pseudocholinesterase deficiency, which makes her more vulnerable to prolonged paralysis from anesthetic drugs used in operations. As she struggled for life on the operating table, one of the nurses finally noticed and the team restored her breathing with a tube. But had the hospital known Bates’s condition ahead of time, the incident, which could have easily killed her or resulted in serious brain damage, could have been avoided.21 Thanks to services like 23andMe, many of us will be able to head off such occurrences very soon. For $200, the company takes a saliva sample from you by mail and returns a detailed analysis of your DNA, its algorithm teasing out a variety of fascinating factors, from your ancestry to your health risks and potential reactions to medications. To be sure, some doctors and health experts say that 23andMe’s tests offer no useful information and that consumers should save their money. And some states, including New York, have ordered 23andMe and similar services to get approval from the state’s health department, declaring their tests to be medical and therefore open to regulation. Such regulation is “appallingly paternalistic,” says 23andMe, adding that people have a right to information contained within their own genes.

如今，这种基因组扫描既快捷又经济实惠，这在一定程度上要归功于尼克·帕特森 (Nick Patterson)。帕特森是一位华尔街黑客，在量化对冲基金文艺复兴科技公司 (Renaissance Technologies) 工作八年后，于 2001 年加入了哈佛大学和麻省理工学院的联合研究中心布罗德研究所 (Broad Institute)。文艺复兴科技公司通过整理数据和发现别人无法发现的模式来赚钱，帕特森在文艺复兴科技公司工作，这让帕特森成为了帮助布罗德研究所的最佳人选。当时，布罗德研究所正淹没在海量的 DNA 数据中，以至于那里的研究人员发现这些数据难以驾驭。仅仅对数百人的完整 DNA 基因组进行测序就能产生如此丰富的数据，以至于研究人员通常不会通过互联网将这些数据发送给其他人，因为这样的传输需要数周时间。相反，他们会通过联邦快递 (FedEx) 来回运送大容量硬盘。22

Such genomic scanning is now fast and affordable, thanks in part to Nick Patterson, a Wall Street hacker who after eight years at Renaissance Technologies, the quantitative hedge fund, joined up with the Broad Institute, a joint research center of Harvard and MIT, in 2001. Working at Renaissance, which makes money off of sorting data and spotting patterns that nobody else can, made Patterson the perfect person to help the Broad Institute, which was drowning in DNA data so deep that the researchers there found it to be unnavigable. The information from sequencing just hundreds of people’s complete DNA genomes produces data so copious that researchers usually don’t send it to others across the Internet because such a transfer would take weeks. Instead, they FedEx boxes of high-capacity hard drives back and forth.22

帕特森编写了算法，用于从DNA数据中查找、搜索和分类模式及关系，从而改变了我们分析DNA的速度。他的算法也揭示了本世纪进化史上的重大发现之一。几十年来，人们普遍认为人类和黑猩猩在某个时刻分道扬镳：我们走一条路，它们走另一条路。但在2006年，帕特森的算法发现，数百万年后，我们实际上与黑猩猩重新融合，杂交，然后再次彻底分离。这些算法还导致人们发现，不到十万年前，人类与尼安德特人曾杂交。这次幽会赋予了我们斯坦福大学免疫遗传学家彼得·帕勒姆所说的“杂种优势”，赋予了我们强大的免疫系统，使人类得以殖民世界。23

Patterson composed algorithms to find, search, and sort patterns and relationships from the DNA data, changing the speed at which we can analyze DNA. His algorithms also uncovered one of the larger discoveries in evolution during this century. For decades, it was popularly theorized that humans and chimpanzees parted ways at some point: we went one way, they went another. But in 2006, Patterson’s algorithms figured out that we actually got back together with chimps millions of years later, interbred, and then split again for good. The algorithms also led to the discovery that humans crossbred with Neanderthals less than one hundred thousand years ago. The tryst gave us what Peter Parham, an immunogeneticist at Stanford, calls “hybrid vigor,” endowing us with a powerful immune system that allowed humans to colonize the world.23

一代人之后，像帕特森这样的算法将扫描我们的DNA，告诉我们可能患上哪些疾病，甚至何时会患上。治疗这些疾病将由一台世人熟知的计算机来处理：IBM的沃森。

A generation from now, algorithms like Patterson’s will scan our DNA and tell us what diseases we’re likely to get and even when they may come. Treating those maladies will be handled by a computer the world knows well: IBM’s Watson.

当你因为健康问题去看医生时，你的预约通常是这样的：医生问一个问题，你回答；医生再问一个问题，你回答。这种模式一直持续到你的看护者能够弄清楚她认为的你的确切问题是什么。她根据你的​​回答做出诊断，这些回答会引导她在脑海中构建一棵可能性树。算法可以做同样的事情。事实上，大多数算法不会交谈；它们不会权衡可能影响你的状态、你的回答和你的疾病的因素和细微差别。但沃森和即将入侵我们医疗世界的新一代算法有所不同。它们配备了最新的语音识别功能，能够动态感知人类情感，而且随着面部阅读算法的进步，它们还能够读懂你眉间皱纹的真实含义。

When you head to the doctor’s office with a health quandary, your appointment usually goes something like this: Your doctor asks a question, you answer; your doctor asks another question, you answer. This pattern goes on until your caregiver can suss out what she thinks is your exact problem. She bases her diagnosis on your answers, which lead her through a tree of possibilities within her head. An algorithm can do the same thing. It’s also true that most algorithms don’t converse; they don’t weigh factors and nuances that may have affected your state, your answers, and your sickness. But Watson and the coming class of algorithms that will invade our medical world are different. They’re imbued with the latest speech recognition capabilities, a dynamic sense of human feelings, and, with the advancement of face-reading algorithms, the ability to read what the creases in your brow are truly saying.

Watson 会将这些能力与医生所能提供的最丰富的循证诊断结合起来。医生可能会在你走进房间时看到你的最初症状，并像任何人一样，认为这是最简单的解释，从而影响她的检查、提问和预后。Watson 不会受到任何影响。你对机器人问题的最初几个答案会在 Watson 的大脑中开启数千种可能性。它会进一步挖掘那些有助于它排除或缩小可能性的问题，直到最终给出答案或让你走上正轨，以便进行能够揭示答案的精确测试。没有随意的测试，没有直觉，只有数据输入和数据输出。Watson 不会错过这些罕见病例的线索，因为它不会偏向于依赖简单的答案。

Watson will knit these kinds of capabilities with as rich an evidence-based diagnosis as any doctor could muster. A doctor may witness your initial symptoms when you walk into the room and, as any human would, assume the easiest explanation, thus coloring her examination, her questions, and her prognosis. Watson is unaffected by any of this. Your first several answers to the bot’s questions open up thousands of possibilities within Watson’s brain. It digs further with the questions that help it best eliminate or narrow the possibilities until, finally, it can issue an answer or put you on track for the exact tests that will reveal the answer. No willy-nilly tests, no gut feelings, just data in, data out. Watson won’t miss clues on those rare cases because he’s simply not prejudiced to rely on the easy answers.

在《危险边缘！》（Jeopardy!）节目中获胜后不久，IBM 便开始与哥伦比亚大学的医生和研究人员合作，开发一款新的 Watson 系统，使其不再仅仅是医疗保健领域的一个新奇事物，而是一个真正的护理专家和诊断权威。2011 年 9 月，医疗保险巨头 WellPoint 宣布计划让 Watson 协助医生进行诊疗，提供宝贵且合法的二次诊疗意见。WellPoint 使用 Watson 的主要目的是节省成本，但在向 IBM 支付 Watson 的时间费用的同时，患者也能获得更准确的初步诊断。

Soon after its Jeopardy! triumph, IBM began working with doctors and researchers at Columbia University to develop a version of Watson that won’t be a mere novelty in health care but a true caregiver and diagnostic authority. In September 2011, the giant health insurer WellPoint announced plans to give Watson a job assisting doctors in their offices with diagnoses, providing a valuable and legitimate second opinion. WellPoint’s main purpose in using Watson is saving money, but in paying IBM for Watson’s time, patients also receive the benefit of more correct initial diagnoses.

哥伦比亚大学临床医学教授赫伯特·蔡斯 (Herbert Chase) 用他职业生涯早期遇到的一个棘手案例来测试沃森，当时他必须治疗一位三十五岁左右的女性，她抱怨自己力量下降、肌肉无力。24这位女士的血液检查结果显示磷酸盐水平低，而碱性磷酸酶（一种酶）的读数异常高。面对这些情况，沃森大胆推测，她最有可能的疾病是甲状旁腺功能亢进症或佝偻病。然而，仔细分析了检查结果后，沃森最终还是同意，应该对这位女士进行检查，看看她是不是患有一种非典型的佝偻病，这种佝偻病对维生素D治疗无效，而她正是这种佝偻病。

Herbert Chase, a clinical medicine professor at Columbia, tested Watson with a vexing case from earlier in his career when he had to treat a woman in her midthirties who complained of fleeting strength and limp muscles.24 The woman’s blood tests revealed low phosphate levels and strangely high readings of alkaline phosphatase, an enzyme. Queried with these conditions, Watson ventured that the most likely malady was either hyperparathyroidism or rickets. Crunching the test results did cause Watson to allow, however, that the woman should be checked for an atypical case of rickets that was resistant to treatment with vitamin D, which is exactly what she had.

Watson 只花了几秒钟就得出了这一结果。而对于最初负责这一病例的医生来说，这需要几天的时间。

Getting to that result took Watson a few seconds. For the doctors on the initial case, it took days.

7

7

人类的分类

CATEGORIZING HUMANKIND

我们每个人都有 自己的性格类型。在真正的专家观察下，我们每个人都能像动物园里的动物一样被分类、标记和编目。你是一只暴躁的猩猩，还是一只温顺的小鹿？你是诡计多端，还是像阿部一样诚实？技艺精湛的精神科医生只需与我们交谈，就能以惊人的速度解答这些问题。他们知道我们为什么工作，知道我们为什么争斗，也知道我们会与什么样的人相处。这种水平的诊断师在大多数精神科诊所并不常见；他们是稀缺人才。但是，如果他们的类型可以被机器模仿、复制，甚至增强呢？如果存在一套算法，可以识别我们的性格，了解我们的弱点，判断我们的想法，并预测我们的行为呢？如果我们创造出一台能够读懂我们心思的机器呢？

ALL OF US HAVE A personality type. All of us, when observed by a true expert, can be categorized, tagged, and cataloged like an animal in a zoo. Are you a volatile orangutan or a docile fawn? Do you operate with guile and trickery, or are you as honest as Abe? Psychiatrists with elite skills can, just by talking with us, answer these questions with surprising swiftness. They know why we work, they know why we fight, and they know the kinds of people with whom we will get along. Diagnosticians of this caliber don’t reside in most psychiatry practices; they’re a rare breed. But what if their type could be imitated, reproduced, and even enhanced by a machine? What if there existed a set of algorithms that could identify our character, know our weaknesses, determine our thoughts, and predict our actions? What if we created a machine that could read our minds?

这样的发展不仅会改变精神病学，还会改变各种商业、客户服务和招聘实践。如果在商务电话结束后，你可以咨询一个机器人，它会准确地告诉你通话过程以及对方对你提议的看法，那会怎样？销售电话将永远改变，糟糕的关系将更早结束，谈判也将变得简单——直到双方都使用沉着冷静的机器人来谈判。

Such a development would change not only psychiatry but also all manner of commerce, customer service, and hiring practices. What if, after a business call, you could consult a bot that told you exactly how the call went and what the other side thought of your proposal? Sales calls would never be the same, bad relationships would end earlier rather than later, and negotiations would be straightforward—until both sides employed unflappable bots to do their talking, that is.

这类技术将颠覆我们与他人的日常互动。这听起来可能遥不可及，但算法早已洞悉了我们许多人的心思，能够解析我们的性格，了解我们的动机。当机器人在观察我们时，我们很少会收到明确的警告；它悄无声息地潜入了我们的生活。虽然听起来可能令人毛骨悚然，但一个能够读懂你和你配偶的算法确实很有用。

Such technology will disrupt many of our day-to-day interactions with other people. It may sound like a far-off prospect, but algorithms have already figured many of us out, parsing our personalities and learning our motivations. We’re rarely given explicit warning when a bot is observing us; it’s something that’s crept into our lives with little fanfare. While it may sound creepy, an algorithm that can read you as well as your spouse can be useful.

我们几乎都曾被机器人读取过信息，尽管大多数人当时并没有意识到。你可能听过这样的话：“本次通话可能会被录音或监控，以用于质量和培训目的。” 无论是银行、信用卡、航空公司还是保险公司，当我们拨打客服电话，听到这句熟悉的话语时，我们其实是在允许算法介入监听。有人认为，这条信息只是为了防止主管或经理监听或稍后重播通话内容，这并非毫无道理。但在很多情况下，情况并非如此。

We’ve almost all been read by a bot, although most of us didn’t realize it at the time. You likely recognize these words: “This call may be recorded or monitored for quality and training purposes.” Whether it’s a bank, credit card, airline, or insurance company, when we dial up customer service and hear that familiar phrase, we’ve allowed an algorithm to drop in for a listen. It’s not unreasonable to believe that this message is merely served in case a supervisor or manager is listening in or may replay the call later. But in many cases, that’s not what’s happening.

实际情况是，一个机器人正在窃听你的通话。它会监听你的谈话，评估你的性格类型，并判断你打电话的原因。在某些情况下，机器人会在客服人员与你交谈时将这些信息传递给他们。最不可思议的是，它还能读懂你的想法。如何才能最快速、最经济地满足你的需求？一旦机器人了解你——它可以在三十秒甚至更短的时间内了解你——它会将你未来的通话转接给与你性格特征相同的客服人员。将呼叫者与错误的客服人员配对会增加发生激烈争吵的风险。将志同道合的客户和客服人员安排在一起，可以缩短通话时间，提高客户满意度，并为公司带来更多利润。

What is happening is that a bot is eavesdropping on your call. It listens to you talk, assesses your personality type, and determines why you’ve called. In some cases, the bot relays this information to the customer service agent as they talk to you. Most incredibly, the bot tries to read your mind. How can you be most quickly and cheaply satisfied? Once the bot gets to know you—it can figure you out in thirty seconds or less—it will route your future calls to agents who share your personality traits. Pairing callers with the wrong agents heightens the risk of a colossal argument. Putting like-minded customers and agents together results in shorter calls, higher customer satisfaction, and bigger profits for the company.

为了更好地理解这些机器人的工作原理和能力范围，了解它们的根源会有所帮助，这些根源可以追溯到美国国家航空航天局 (NASA)，以及华尔街。

To better understand how these bots work and the breadth of their abilities, it helps to understand their roots, which trace to NASA and, as usual, Wall Street.

选对人才：从运气到科学

PICKING THE RIGHT PEOPLE: FROM LUCK TO A SCIENCE

1970年4月11日，三名宇航员乘坐一枚363英尺高的土星五号登月火箭，火箭内充满了超低温氧气和氢气，燃烧后将把他们送出地球大气层。之后，他们将再次点燃助推器，离开地球轨道。这就是阿波罗13号。目的地：月球。

On April 11, 1970, three men sat in a 363-foot-tall Saturn V moon rocket filled with superchilled oxygen and hydrogen that, as it burned, would propel them up and out of the earth’s atmosphere. From there, they would again light their booster to leave earth’s orbit. This was Apollo 13. Destination: the moon.

第二天早上，宇航员们用无线电联系了任务控制中心。按照惯例，控制中心人员向宇航员们通报了当天的新闻。他的信息如下：首先是休斯顿的棒球比分，宇航员和控制中心大部分时间都待在那里：

The next morning the men radioed mission control. As was the custom, the mission control man fed the astronauts the news of the day. This was his message, starting with a baseball score from Houston, where the astronauts and mission control spent most of their time:

 

 

太空人队以8比7的战绩幸存下来……马尼拉和吕宋岛其他地区发生了地震。昨天见证了你们从科德角发射升空的西德总理威利·勃兰特和尼克松总统将完成一轮会谈。空中交通管制员仍在罢工，但你们会很高兴知道任务控制中心的管制员仍在工作。1

The Astros survived, 8 to 7. . . . They had earthquakes in Manila and other areas of the island of Luzon. West German Chancellor Willy Brandt, who witnessed your launch from the Cape yesterday, and President Nixon will complete a round of talks. The air traffic controllers are still out on strike, but you’ll be happy to know the controllers in Mission Control are still on the job.1

太空舱机组人员詹姆斯·洛弗尔 (James Lovell)、弗雷德·海斯 (Fred Haise) 和约翰·斯威格特 (John Swigert) 很欣赏他的幽默。后来，他们聊起报税的事（4 月 15 日即将到来），斯威格特想起自己当时为了赶任务做准备，竟然忘了报税。任务控制员们在笑声中答应帮他咨询延期报税事宜。

The capsule crew, James Lovell, Fred Haise, and John Swigert, appreciated the humor. Later in the conversation, a joke about filing taxes (April 15 was approaching) reminded Swigert that in the rush to get ready for the mission, he had forgotten to file. Through their laughter, the mission controllers promised to inquire about a tax extension for him.

在对航天器进行例行飞行中维护时，一个发生故障的恒温器向一个巨大的氧气罐中发出电弧，氧气罐立即点燃，引发爆炸，将飞船的一半炸入太空。

During routine midflight maintenance on the spacecraft, a malfunctioning thermostat sent an electrical arc into one of the giant tanks of oxygen, which ignited immediately, sparking an explosion that blew half of the ship into space.

指挥舰的氧气即将耗尽，船员们不得不撤退到唯一能去的地方：登月舱，一个永远无法到达预定目的地的飞行器。这艘着陆器的设计载客量仅为两人45小时，现在却要供三人生存近100小时。为了节省电池电量，船员们关闭了登月舱内的大部分电子设备，包括暖气系统。随着时间流逝，甚至几天过去，舱内温度接近冰点，船员们无法入睡，体力也随之下降。

The men were faced with a command ship quickly running out of oxygen. To survive, they retreated to the only spot they could: the lunar module, a vehicle that would never see its intended destination. The lander, designed to keep two people alive for only forty-five hours, would now have to sustain three men for nearly one hundred hours. To conserve enough battery power to survive, the men shut down most of the electronics in the lunar rig, including the heating. As the hours and then days wore on, the temperature approached freezing inside the ship, preventing sleep and sapping the men of energy.

休斯顿的任务控制中心引导宇航员们进行一项机动，利用月球引力作为弹弓，让飞船绕过月球背面，然后返回地球。宇航员们小心翼翼地推动登月舱的推进器，使飞船完美地对准了目标，以便完成机动。这堪称技术上的妙招。

Mission control in Houston guided the men into a maneuver that would swing their craft around the dark side of the moon and then back toward earth, using the moon’s gravitational pull as a slingshot. Gingerly nudging the lunar module’s thrusters, the men got their ship into perfect alignment for the maneuver. It was a technical masterstroke.

但这个小技巧只是休斯顿任务控制中心想出的众多绝妙工程改造之一。有一次，登月舱内的二氧化碳浓度上升到危险的高水平，因为额外宇航员的呼气超过了飞船上由氢氧化锂筒制成的二氧化碳洗涤器的容量。洗涤器当时已经用完了。如果不加以解决，宇航员们将会被自己的废气窒息而死。受损的服务舱也有自己的筒，但形状不同，装不下登月舱。任务控制中心指示宇航员们用飞船里的物品临时拼凑一个过滤盒来装其他筒：一个塑料袋、一本飞行计划书的封面和一卷灰色胶带。这个装置被连接到洗涤器的一根氧气软管上，奇迹般地起作用了。二氧化碳浓度迅速回落到非致命水平。2

But that trick was only one of many brilliant engineering adaptations conjured by mission control in Houston. At one point, the carbon dioxide levels in the lunar module grew dangerously high as the extra man’s exhalation overwhelmed the craft’s CO2 scrubbers, which were made from cartridges of lithium hydroxide. The cartridge supply had run out. Without a fix, the men would suffocate on their own exhaust. The damaged service module had cartridges of its own, but they were of a different shape and wouldn’t fit the lunar module. Mission control instructed the men to jury-rig a filter box to fit the other cartridges with items in the ship: a plastic bag, the cover of a flight plan book, and a roll of gray tape. The apparatus was attached to one of the scrubber’s oxygen hoses and, miraculously, worked. The CO2 dived back to nonlethal levels.2

两天后，他们终于在南太平洋溅落，这不仅证明了休斯顿团队以及宇航员们自身的实力。然而，同样令人惊叹的是这三名宇航员在重压之下展现出的韧性和凝聚力。在长达一百个小时的时间里，他们坐在一个仅供两人使用的狭小太空舱内，不断执行着一项又一项关键任务。面对如此严峻的条件，每个人的反应截然不同。有些人会收起情绪，冷静地完成眼前的任务，无论眼前的前景多么令人担忧。然而，我们中的很多人，即使是宇航员，也无法摆脱令人麻木的恐惧；面对可能出现的死亡，我们会退缩，我们会无所作为，或者我们会做出失去理智的行为。

That the men would splash down in the South Pacific two days later is a testament to the capabilities of the team in Houston as well as that of the astronauts themselves. Just as remarkable, however, was the resiliency and cohesion of the three-man crew under pressure. For one hundred hours, these men sat inside a tiny capsule designed for two, constantly performing one critical task after another. When subjected to such dire conditions, individuals react in acutely different ways. Some people tuck their emotions away and calmly go about the task at hand, no matter how foreboding the immediate future may appear. A good chunk of us, however, even astronauts, are unable to escape paralyzing fear; we recede, we do nothing, or we act irrationally when faced with the likely prospect of death.

很难预测一个人的反应。更难预测的是，在如此孤立的环境中，人们能否相处融洽、共同协作。阿波罗13号任务中，NASA有点幸运。其中一名机组人员斯威格特在发射前一天才加入任务。他是肯·马丁利的替补，后者在前一周接触了麻疹。三人几乎没有时间适应一起工作，就被绑在座椅上，送入外太空。但NASA对这三人将如何相处有所了解。近十年来，该太空计划一直在评估宇航员的性格兼容性。这项心理测量项目在引导美国在太空竞赛中领先于苏联方面发挥了至关重要的作用。

It’s difficult to predict how a person will react. Even harder to forecast is how well people will get along and function together when put into such isolated conditions. With Apollo 13, NASA got a little lucky. One of the crew members, Swigert, had only joined the mission a day before launch. He was a replacement for Ken Mattingly, who had been exposed to measles the previous week. The trio had little time to get used to working together before they were strapped into seats and blasted into outer space. But NASA did have some idea of how the three would mesh. The space program had been assessing the compatibility of astronauts’ personalities for nearly a decade. This psyche-measuring program played a crucial role in guiding the Americans ahead of the Soviets in the space race.

如果没有彻底彻底的心理评估，根本无法知道三个人在一个狭小的太空舱里会如何融合，更不用说在像登月这样艰巨的任务中了。NASA非常清楚，宇航员的匹配不当可能会危及任务，甚至危及机组人员的生命。这就是为什么几乎所有早期宇航员都是直接从军队中选拔出来的，因为候选人都经历过战斗、压力和死亡。同行和背景调查对候选人在战火中的性格至关重要，也是选拔过程中至关重要的环节。

Without thorough and exhaustive psychological assessments, there was no way to know how a three-man cocktail would mix in a tiny capsule, not to mention during missions as taxing as a lunar landing. NASA was more than aware that a bad match of astronauts could compromise a mission and even the lives of the crew. That’s one of the reasons why almost all of the early astronauts were plucked directly from the military, where the candidates had been exposed to combat, stress, and death. Peer and background checks on a candidate’s character under fire were paramount to the selection process.

即便如此，在阿波罗13号险些丧命之后，NASA仍然希望找到一种更好的方法，一种严格、绝对、精准的方法。因此，NASA在1971年着手创建一个全面的人员分类系统，以便了解哪些人能够很好地合作，哪些人一旦面临压力和人员的不合理组合就容易爆发。NASA需要一种方法来解读人们的思想，并预测他们的确切行动。NASA在20世纪70年代和80年代开发的系统，如今以机器人的形式存在，它们能够解读我们的性格、愿望和意图——而我们大多数人对此却浑然不觉。

Even so, after the close call of Apollo 13, NASA wanted a better method, something that would be rigid, absolute, and accurate. So in 1971 the agency set out to create a comprehensive system of categorizing people to the point of knowing who would work well together and who was liable to explode if exposed to the wrong mix of pressure and people. NASA needed a way to read people’s minds and predict their exact actions. The system the agency developed in the 1970s and 1980s lives on today in the form of bots that read our personalities, our wants, and our intentions—a fact of which most of us are oblivious.

美国宇航局在冷战时期开发了其人员评估算法。当时，组建比苏联宇航员队伍更优秀的宇航员队伍至关重要。苏联宇航员至少经历过两次因机组人员冲突而受损的任务。由于当时NASA没有高性能计算机和语音识别软件，因此性格评估只能在纸上进行。这些方法由当时NASA的首席精神病学家特里·麦奎尔精心编写。

NASA developed its people-assessing algorithms in the focused time of the Cold War, when creating better astronaut crews than the Soviets, who experienced at least two compromised missions due to crew conflict, was all that mattered. NASA didn’t have high-powered computers and speech-recognizing software, so personality assessments were carried out on paper. These methods were carefully scripted by NASA’s head psychiatrist at the time, Terry McGuire.

麦奎尔小时候就发现自己很擅长在欺凌者和他们内向的受害者之间充当调解人。“随着我的成长，我发现自己比大多数人对周围发生的情绪变化都更敏感，”他回忆道。他能够本能地感知到人们内心深处的痛苦、恐慌、恐惧和愤怒，甚至在清晰的信号尚未显现之前就被察觉。事实上，麦奎尔对人及其行为如此感兴趣，以至于他开始攀岩和登山，不仅因为他喜欢这项运动，还因为他能够观察到不同的人对恐惧、压力、痛苦和逆境的反应。“那是一个不可思议的实验室，”他说。

As a child, McGuire found that he had a talent for being a peacemaker between bullies and their introverted targets. “I knew as I was growing up that I was more sensitive than most of the guys to emotional things going on around me,” he remembers. He could innately sense suffering, panic, fear, and anger boiling in people before the clear signals had manifested. McGuire became so interested in people and their behavior, in fact, that he took up rock climbing and mountaineering not only because he enjoyed the sport but also because he was able to observe different people’s reactions to fear, stress, pain, and adversity. “It was an incredible laboratory,” he says.

1958年，美国空军聘请麦奎尔开发一种系统，用于预测士兵在危及生命的压力下的反应。时至今日，五角大楼每年都要执行数十次，甚至数百次的绝密任务。并非所有任务都像击毙本·拉登的那次突袭行动那样引人注目，但它们都需要在火力下毫不畏惧的士兵。有些平时看似意志坚强的士兵，在这种情况下却完全丧失了战斗力。而另一些人，有时是最不靠谱的士兵，则会变得冷酷无情、专注而致命。军方想知道，为什么有些人的表现比其他人好得多？更重要的是，我们如何提前知道他们是谁？

In 1958, the air force enlisted McGuire to develop systems that could predict soldiers’ reactions under life-threatening stress. To this day, the Pentagon runs dozens, if not hundreds, of top-secret missions every year. Not all of them are as high profile as the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, but they all require men who don’t flinch under fire. Some men who otherwise seem to have nerves of steel utterly fail in such circumstances. And others, sometimes the least likely of troops, turn emotionless, focused, and deadly. The military wanted to know, why do some guys do so much better than others? And, even more important, how do we know who they are ahead of time?

麦奎尔自称是“空军黑暗面的心理医生”。他拥有的实验室、仪器和资源比当时任何学术机构或医院都要先进。当时正值冷战时期，军队是世界科技的前沿阵地，而如今，这些技术都触手可及——这一切都是为了让他能够追寻自青少年时期就一直好奇的课题。

McGuire was to be the self-described “psychiatrist on the dark side of the air force.” The laboratories, instruments, and resources at his disposal were superior to any academic or hospital setting at the time. It was the Cold War; the military was the cutting edge for the world’s technology, and now it was at McGuire’s fingertips—all so he could follow a subject of curiosity that had been with him since adolescence.

麦奎尔坚持不懈，最终设计出一套长达三个小时的问题，专门用来向新兵提问。通过他们的回答，他有超过50%的概率——正如人们所期望的那样——了解一个人在极端情况下的性格特征。麦奎尔帮助一支又一支小队执行危险任务，而他们的目的永远保密。

McGuire dug in, and eventually developed a three-hour set of questions that he would deliver to new recruits. From their answers, he stood a better than 50 percent chance—as much as anybody had hoped for—of knowing a man’s makeup when he was placed under extreme circumstances. McGuire helped send team after team into dangerous missions, their purposes forever classified.

麦圭尔向上级提出了亲自随军执行任务的想法。他认为自己需要实战经验，才能知道该如何看待这些士兵。最终，他获得了许可，于是麦圭尔坐上了直升机，低空飞过越南丛林。一小队美军士兵被困在山顶上。他们的弹药即将耗尽；一旦最后一发炮弹落地，他们就会被蜂拥而至的敌军彻底击溃。

McGuire pitched to his superiors the idea of tagging along on a mission himself. He needed experience in the field, he reasoned, to know what to look for in these men. At some point, permission was granted and McGuire found himself in the back of a helicopter, flying low over the jungle in Vietnam. A small group of American soldiers had been pinned down on a mountaintop. They were running out of ammo; when their last shell hit the ground, they would be overwhelmed by teeming enemy forces.

补给小组在半夜飞行，车灯熄灭，直升机的爆炸声透过敞开的舱门抽打着他们的脸。当直升机接近山峰时，数百发曳光弹从丛林中呼啸而出，击中了直升机的金属机身。麦奎尔和机上的其他人没有还击；他们不想让枪口的爆炸暴露自己的位置。麦奎尔回忆说，这需要极大的克制力。他们降落在山上唯一的一块空地上，倾倒了大量弹药和炸药。“然后我们就赶紧离开了，”麦奎尔说。

The resupply team flew in the middle of the night, their lights off and the chopper blast whipping their faces through the open doors. As the helicopter approached the mountain, hundreds of tracer bullets zipped out of the jungle, pelting the craft’s metal hull. McGuire and the others aboard didn’t fire back; they didn’t want to betray their position with muzzle blasts. It took incredible restraint, McGuire recalls. They landed in the only open patch of ground on the mountain and dumped a big load of ammunition and explosives. “And then we got the hell out of there,” McGuire says.

通过实地调查，麦奎尔发现了一些迹象，表明哪些人能在压力下蓬勃发展，但他仍然觉得这种做法并非一门科学。有时，他仍然觉得自己只是在猜测。有时，他甚至会犯错。1971年，他的研究引起了美国国家航空航天局（NASA）的关注。NASA当时正开始引入科学家参与宇航员项目，想知道如何挑选他们。NASA希望对候选人进行评估，找出哪些宇航员能够更好地合作。此前，NASA的大部分宇航员都来自空军的试飞员项目。这些意志坚强的宇航员驾驶着美国最新、最不为人知、也最危险的飞机。

Through his investigations in the field, McGuire found indications of what kind of people thrive under pressure, but he still found the practice less than a science. At times, he still felt he was just guessing. Sometimes he was straight wrong. In 1971, his research attracted an interested party in NASA, which was beginning to introduce scientists into the astronaut program and it wanted to know how to pick them. It wanted to grade its candidate pool and figure out which of its astronauts would work best together. The agency had previously plucked most of its astronauts from the air force’s test pilot program. These were the steely men who flew the country’s newest, least known, and most dangerous aircraft.

试飞员在太空中不太可能崩溃。至于科学家，嗯，“NASA 根本不知道，”麦奎尔说。NASA 邀请他加入是因为它追求精准——也希望麦奎尔能够从五千多名科学家中筛选出人才。NASA 不仅需要知道谁能承受压力，还需要知道如何确定人们的适应性。有时压力无法击垮一个人，但加上与同伴的摩擦，可能会导致更严重的后果。

The test pilots were unlikely to crack while in space. As for the scientists, well, “NASA just had no idea,” McGuire says. NASA brought him on board because it wanted precision—and it wanted McGuire to vet a pool of more than five thousand scientists. It needed to know not only who would hold up under pressure but also how to determine people’s compatibilities. Sometimes stress couldn’t break people, but combined with friction with peers it could lead to worse fractures.

“他们让我做一些别人根本没做过的事情，”麦奎尔说。“他们想让我预测，如果候选人在150英里的高空听到舱门吱吱作响，他们会作何反应。”

“They were asking me to do things that people really hadn’t done,” McGuire says. “They wanted me to predict how candidates would respond if the hatch started to squeal when they were 150 miles up.”

麦奎尔有自己的方法，但他开始梳理其他人的研究，看看是否有人采取了他未曾想到的方法。当他发现一些有趣的发现时，他经常邀请精神病学家或研究人员到休斯顿的NASA，与他一起评估候选人并交流意见。有一次，他偶然发现了普渡大学心理学家泰比·卡勒的研究。

McGuire had his own methods, but he started combing through the others’ research to see if anybody else had taken an approach he hadn’t thought of. When he found something interesting, he often invited the psychiatrist or researcher to NASA in Houston to evaluate candidates with him and compare notes. At one point he came across the research of Taibi Kahler, a psychologist at Purdue University.

1971年，卡勒开发了一套方法，用于识别不同类型的人类沟通及其有效性。它将言语互动精简为一系列序列，这些序列可以通过说话模式和词汇选择来识别。每个序列都能在说话者口中清晰地识别出来。不同的序列组合可以表明说话者是投入、快乐、无聊、厌恶，还是对谈话对象感到反感。有了卡勒的系统，无需费力窥探对方的内心，也无需试图窥探对方的内心。评估一个人所需的所有信息都来自他的口中。

In 1971, Kahler developed a process to identify different kinds of human communication and their efficacy. It narrowed verbal interactions down to a number of sequences that were identified by speech patterns and word choice. Each sequence could be objectively identified as it tumbled out of the speaker’s mouth. Different combinations of sequences signaled whether the person was engaged, happy, bored, disgusted, or repulsed by their conversation partner and the subject. With Kahler’s system, there was no looking between the cracks or trying to peer into a subject’s soul. All of the information needed to assess a person came out of his or her mouth.

卡勒的体系建立在我们所说的词汇之上。我们的句子结构、我们选择的动词、谓语和代词，都体现了大多数人从童年时代就已形成的清晰特征。我们每天都会造句数百次甚至数千次。这个过程已经根深蒂固；我们无法轻易改变这些习惯，也无法学会完全不同的说话方式。对于拥有卡勒这种技能的人来说，我们无法掩饰自己的真实面貌。

Kahler built his system around the words that we speak. Our sentence structures, our chosen verbs, predicates, and pronouns all betray well-defined characteristics that most people have carried with them since childhood. Putting together sentences is something we do hundreds or thousands of times per day. The process becomes incredibly ingrained for us; we cannot, with the flip of a switch, break these habits or pick up completely different ways of speaking. To somebody with the skills of Kahler, we can’t disguise who we are.

卡勒根据清晰的言语模式将人进行线性划分的方法，使其自然而然地被编入算法，并最终被机器人所采用。长期以来，精神病学一直被认为是一个似乎不受技术进步影响的领域。但卡勒的方法——运用逻辑树和二元判定理论——或许已经证明了这种说法的谬误。

Kahler’s linear method of dividing people up according to clear patterns of speech made it a natural fit to be programmed into an algorithm and, eventually, a bot. Psychiatry has long been thought of as a field that would seem impervious to technological advances. But Kahler’s method—using the theory of logic trees and binary determination—may have proven this to be untrue.

1972年，麦圭尔认为卡勒的说法不准确，但他想亲眼看看这位教授的方法。于是，麦圭尔邀请卡勒来到NASA；这总归是好事——每年都有几十位心理评估医生来这里。卡勒与麦圭尔及其团队一起，对宇航员候选人进行面试和评判。候选人首先要回答一两个小时的标准问题，然后还要接受一系列他们根本无法准备的、紧张的提问和测试。对大多数候选人来说，成功通过这项严峻的考验是他们毕生的目标。这意味着他们能够承受NASA要求的压力——他们不会像其他许多候选人那样崩溃。

In 1972 McGuire didn’t think Kahler was right, but he wanted to see the professor’s methods for himself. So McGuire invited Kahler down to NASA; it couldn’t hurt—dozens of psyche-evaluating doctors passed through every year. Kahler sat in with McGuire and his team as they interviewed and judged astronaut candidates, who were run through an hour or two of standard queries before being subjected to an intense string of questions and tests for which they couldn’t possibly have prepared. Succeeding in this gauntlet represented a life’s goal to most of the candidates. It meant they could withstand the pressure NASA required—they wouldn’t break, like so many other candidates.

在候选人面试环节，NASA 的人会疯狂地记笔记，面试过程可能持续数小时。卡勒也负责做同样的评估，他会仔细观察候选人，同时在便笺簿上工工整整地做笔记。麦奎尔注意到，大约十分钟后，卡勒会突然放下铅笔。他已经看到了所有需要看到的东西。他对每个候选人都这样做。其他人会持续几个小时，但卡勒只是静静地坐着，双膝交叉，双手合十，便笺簿和铅笔一动不动。

The NASA people furiously scribbled notes during the candidates’ sessions, which could last for several hours. Kahler, tasked with making the same assessments, would carefully observe the subjects while taking his own notes in tidy fashion on a legal pad. McGuire noticed that after ten minutes or so, Kahler would abruptly put his pencil down. He’d seen all he needed to see. He did this for every single candidate. The others would carry on for hours, but Kahler just sat calmly, his knees crossed, his hands folded, and his pad and pencil motionless.

卡勒的方法看似草率，麦圭尔猜测这些方法最终会失效。但随着麦圭尔团队跟踪候选人的训练过程及其与他人的互动，卡勒的预测成真，包括预期的学员之间冲突。麦圭尔的评估，以及NASA其他所有人的评估，最终都回归了中庸（有对有错），但这位来自普渡大学的医生始终一针见血。不知何故，卡勒精辟的评估比麦圭尔——该领域的先驱——见过的任何其他方法都更有效。卡勒只需观察十五分钟，就能诊断出一个人的性格、气质和未来行为。

Kahler’s methods seemed hasty and McGuire guessed they would prove ineffective. But as McGuire’s team followed candidates through training and their interactions with others, Kahler’s predictions held true, including anticipated clashes among trainees. McGuire’s assessments, as well as those of everyone else at NASA, reverted to the mean (some right, some wrong), but the doctor from Purdue was consistently spot on. Somehow, Kahler’s pithy evaluations were more effective than anything else McGuire, a pioneer in this field, had seen. Kahler could diagnose a person’s character, fiber, and future actions by observing them for fifteen minutes.

卡勒的方法——更重要的是，他精准的观测结果——让麦圭尔和美国宇航局兴奋不已。但他能教会其他人进行同样的观测吗？答案是肯定的。于是，美国宇航局启动了一个项目，旨在确定代表美国执行太空任务的宇航员构成。这项科学——可以安全地称之为科学——将合适的科学家派往任务，并避免了人为灾难：外太空的叛乱。

Kahler’s methods—and more important, his accurate results—excited McGuire and NASA. But could he teach others to make the same observations he did? The answer was yes. Thus began a NASA project that would determine the makeup of the space-bound crews representing the United States of America. The science—and it can be safely called that—put the right scientists on missions and avoided human-made catastrophe: mutinies in the void of outer space.

当时可能发生叛变。美国宇航局定期监听苏联宇航员和地面控制人员之间的对话。卡勒回忆说，在20世纪70年代中期的一次任务中，太空舱里的两名宇航员显然相处不融洽。他们每天的太空任务包括采集同伴的血样。飞行途中，一名俄罗斯宇航员故意用力将针头刺入另一名宇航员的手部，以至于刺穿了骨头。随后发生了扭打，俄罗斯地面控制人员担心会发生太空谋杀。虽然无人死亡，但受感染宇航员的手部严重感染，肿成了一个充满脓液的巨大球状。为了保全他的生命，任务被迫中止，宇航员们返回地球。

Mutinies were a possibility. NASA regularly listened in on conversations between Soviet cosmonauts and their ground controllers. On one particular mission in the mid-1970s, Kahler recalls, it became clear that the two men in the capsule weren’t getting along. The men’s daily space tasks included taking blood samples from their partner. Halfway into the trip, one of the Russians purposefully drove the needle so hard into the other’s hand that it pierced bone. A scuffle erupted and Russian ground control operators worried about the possibility of a space homicide. Nobody died, but the afflicted man’s hand became hopelessly infected, swelling into a giant pus-filled ball. To preserve his life, the mission was aborted and the men returned to earth.

麦奎尔表示，NASA的许多任务中，类似灾难的发生比人们意识到的要近得多。为了避免这些灾难，他开始全神贯注地学习卡勒的方法。这位教授的系统——以及窃听机器人在你打电话时对你进行评估的略微修改的版本——将人们分为六类：

McGuire says such disasters were closer to happening on many NASA missions than people realize. To avoid them, he became a rapt student of Kahler’s methods. The professor’s system—and the slightly modified version with which eavesdropping bots evaluate you when you call—classifies people under six categories:

 

 

1. 情绪化的人。他们会先尝试建立关系，了解对方，然后再深入探讨当前问题。这类人占总人口的30%，其中女性占四分之三。紧张的局势会让这类人变得情绪化，反应过度。

1. Emotions-driven people. They try to form relationships and learn about the person they’re speaking with before diving into the issue at hand. Women comprise three-quarters of this group, which makes up 30 percent of the total population. Tight situations make this group dramatic and overreactive.

2. 以思考为本的人。这类人倾向于摒弃客套，直截了当地讲事实。他们大多数的决定都源于一种刻板的实用主义。在压力之下，他们往往会变得缺乏幽默感、迂腐且控制欲强。

2. Thoughts-based people. This group tends to do away with pleasantries and go straight for the facts. A rigid form of pragmatism drives most of the decisions they make. Under pressure, they tend to become humorless, pedantic, and controlling.

3. 行动驱动型的人。大多数二手车销售员都属于这类人。他们渴望进步和行动，哪怕只是一点点。他们总是在催促、激励，寻找突破口。这类人中的许多人很有魅力。压力会驱使行动驱动型的人做出非理性、冲动甚至报复的行为。

3. Actions-driven people. Most used-car salesmen would come under this umbrella. They crave progress and action, even in tiny chunks. They’re always pushing, prodding, and looking for an angle. Many in this group can be charming. Pressure can drive actions-driven people to irrational, impulsive, and vengeful behavior.

4. 反思型的人。这类人往往沉着冷静，想象力丰富。他们往往更注重未来发展，而非基于已有的事物。当这些人对某件事感兴趣时，他们可能会沉浸其中数小时，深入钻研新课题。然而，将这些知识运用到实际项目中却是一个弱点。

4. Reflections-driven people. This group can be calm and imaginative. They often think more about what could be rather than working with what already is. These people, when they’re interested in something, can drift off for hours while they dig into the new subject. Applying this knowledge to a real-world project, however, is a weakness.

5. 观点驱动型人格。这类人使用的语言充斥着命令式和绝对化。他们倾向于只看到事情的一面，即使有证据反驳，也会坚持自己的观点。超过70%的政客都是观点驱动型人格，但这类人只占总人口的10%。这类人也可能是不知疲倦的工作者，他们会坚持不懈地钻研问题，直到问题得到解决。在压力之下，他们的观点可能会成为弱点；他们会变得爱评判、多疑和敏感。

5. Opinions-driven people. The language used by this group is stocked with imperatives and absolutes. They tend to see one side of a situation and will stick to their views even when refuted with proof. More than 70 percent of politicians are opinions-driven people, but the group constitutes only 10 percent of the population as a whole. People from this group can also be tireless workers, who will persistently grind away on a problem until it is solved. Under pressure, their opinions can become weaknesses; they can grow judgmental, suspicious, and sensitive.

6.反应型人格。卡勒称这类人为“叛逆者”，但现代标准——以及构建人格解读机器人的标准——将他们称为“反应型人格”。这类人自发、富有创造力、爱玩。他们对事物反应强烈：“我喜欢这个！”或“这糟透了！”许多创新者都来自这一群体。在压力下，他们可能变得固执、消极、爱责怪。

6. Reactions-based people. Kahler called this group rebels, but the modern set of standards—and those on which personality-deciphering bots are built—refer to them as reactions people. This group is spontaneous, creative, and playful. They react strongly to things: “I love that!” or “That sucks!” Many innovators come from this group. Under pressure, they can be stubborn, negative, and blameful.

如果你觉得自己在上述多个类别中都找到了自己的影子，那你没错。我们的性格往往受这六种特质中的一种主导，但在其他五种特质中，我们拥有的比例各不相同。例如，唐纳德·特朗普无疑是一个行动型的人，但他的性格中很可能也存在着情感驱动的部分，而这部分并不体现在他的公众形象中。

If you think you spot shades of yourself in more than one of the categories above, you’re not mistaken. Our personalities tend to be dominated by one of the six traits, but we possess differing percentages of the other five. Donald Trump, for instance, is most certainly an actions-based person, but he likely has an emotions-driven piece of his personality that isn’t part of his public face.

作为NASA载人航天计划的决策者之一，麦奎尔成为了快速洞察人心的专家。他能在五分钟内判断出与他交谈的人的主导性格。思想型的人会提出很多问题；他们总是在收集数据。意见型的人会发布命令，看待事物非黑即白。他们很多陈述都以“我认为”开头，之后会将自己的“想法”当成事实。反应型的人喜欢用“是！”引导对话。随着时间的推移，麦奎尔逐渐了解了哪些性格的人容易在太空中发生冲突，哪些人根本不适合宇航员的世界。例如，反思型的人就不适合NASA。“这个项目里几乎没有这样的人，”麦奎尔说。

As one of NASA’s powerful people determining who would be part of its manned space program, McGuire became an expert at quickly reading people. He can tell within five minutes what personality is dominant in somebody he’s talking with. Strong thoughts-driven people issue a lot of questions; they’re always gathering data. Opinions-driven people issue edicts, see things in black and white. They start many statements with an “I think,” later treating their “thoughts” as facts. Reactions-based people like leading dialogues with a “Yes!” Over time, McGuire came to learn what kinds of personalities were likely to butt heads in space and which ones were simply unsuited for the astronaut world. Reflections-driven people, for instance, aren’t a good fit at NASA. “They’re virtually nonexistent in the program,” McGuire says.

人们的兼容性程度各不相同。我们都遇到过面包店里令人难以忍受的店员或脾气暴躁的咖啡师。但同样，其他人也可能不会对同一个人如此恼火。那是因为他们的性格更接近。NASA 把一个情绪型的人塞进三个主要以思想为主的人的飞船里是不明智的。或者，即使选择四个强有力的以思想为主的候选人也可能会带来麻烦。最好是混合其他人——比如一个以反应为主的人和一个以观点为主的人。这个小组的领导者很可能是一个以思想为主的人，但麦奎尔会确保他的性格包含其机组人员的主要特质；拥有这些特质将使他能够理解他的宇航员并更好地处理关系。

People have varying degrees of compatibility. All of us have met that insufferable clerk at the bakery or the ornery barista. But it’s also true that other people may not be so annoyed by the same person. That’s because their personalities offer a closer match. It would be unwise for NASA to stuff an emotions-driven person into craft with three largely thoughts-based people. Or even choosing four strong thoughts-based candidates could make for trouble. It’s best to mix in others—like a reactions-based person and an opinions-driven person. The leader of this group may well be a thoughts-based person, but McGuire would see to it that his personality included his crew’s primary traits; having those components would allow him to understand his astronauts and better manage relations.

太空中最高效的指挥官往往具备均衡的品质。虽然许多飞行员倾向于理性思考，但最优秀的飞行员也拥有感性和观点主导的良好性格。人们不喜欢向迂腐、缺乏同情心的工作狂汇报，但人们会向那些努力工作并对下属的工作和生活表现出真挚同理心的人汇报。

Some of the most effective commanders in space are those with well-balanced qualities. While many pilots tend to be thoughts-driven, the best ones also have good pieces of emotional- and opinion-driven personalities. People don’t like reporting to pedantic workaholics with no compassion, but they will fall in line under those who work hard and display genuine empathy for their subordinates’ jobs and lives.

“比如约翰·格伦，他坚如磐石，天哪，看到他因为别人的不幸而感动落泪，这表明敏感和坚韧是独立决定的，”麦奎尔解释道。

“John Glenn, for instance, who is steady as a rock, oh man—to see him moved to tears by the misfortunes of another person—that shows you that sensitivity and toughness are independently determined,” explains McGuire.

NASA 也希望地面任务控制中心能有稳定的人手。如果没有休斯顿屏幕前的那些足智多谋、沉着冷静的工作人员，阿波罗 13 号就不可能完成这趟不可思议的返回地球之旅。麦圭尔负责对太空舱宇航员以及那些坐在地球上的旋转椅上接二连三地抽着烟、帮助引导他们安全返回的宇航员进行精神评估。

NASA also wanted steady hands on the ground in mission control. Apollo 13 would never had made its unlikely journey back to earth without resourceful and unflappable people sitting at the screens in Houston. McGuire oversaw the psychiatric evaluations of both the space-bound men and those who, chain-smoking from their swivel chairs on earth, helped guide them to safety.

当麦奎尔发现宇航员之间可能爆发冲突时，他学会了如何提前采取行动。他经常会和他担心的宇航员坐下来，坦诚地告诉他们他预见到的情况。这种坦诚产生了奇效，因为两位宇航员都会竭尽全力保持友好而专业的人际关系；没有人愿意危及自己在项目中的地位。麦奎尔还会提醒任务指挥官注意潜在的问题，并告诉他如何化解太空中的冲突。

When McGuire saw potential eruptions between crewmates, he learned how to take action ahead of time. He’d often sit down with the astronauts he was worried about and tell them candidly what he saw coming. The honesty worked wonders as both crew members would go out of their way to keep their relations civil and professional; nobody wanted to jeopardize their standing in the program. McGuire would also alert the commander of the mission to be on the lookout for potential problems and tell him how to disarm ugly conflicts in space.

在他目睹的几十次发射任务中，麦奎尔预测其中六次会出现机组人员问题。其中五次，他的预测都正确。他回忆起在宇航员返回休斯顿后，在新闻发布会后，在走廊里碰到了一位名叫约翰的宇航员。麦奎尔担心约翰和他的一位航天飞机同伴会引发太空爆炸。近戰。

Of the several dozen operations he saw take off, McGuire predicted crew trouble on six of them. For five of those missions, he was right. He recalls catching an astronaut named John in the hallway following a press conference after his crew had returned to Houston. McGuire had been concerned about John and one of his fellow shuttle mates setting off a space melee.

“那么，那里的情况怎么样？”麦奎尔问道。

“So, how’d it go up there?” McGuire asked.

“哦，还不错，”约翰和蔼地回答。然后他眯起眼睛，皱起了眉头。“但再多一天——哪怕再多一天——我就会杀了他。”

“Oh, it was good,” replied John affably. Then his gaze narrowed and his eyebrows creased. “But one more day—just one more day—and I’d have killed him.”

麦奎尔相信了这一点。

McGuire believed it.

走出 NASA，走进我们的生活

OUT OF NASA AND INTO OUR LIVES

随着精神病学和人类行为学领域的其他人了解到NASA的成功，卡勒的方法也随之传播开来。很快，财富500强企业的CEO们纷纷向麦奎尔和卡勒寻求指导，学习如何更有效地领导员工并与员工建立联系。卡勒甚至在1992年总统竞选期间为比尔·克林顿的演讲和辩论做准备，指导这位未来的总统在与不同性格的人交往时应避免使用哪些词语和短语，以及如何应对广大温和的选民。克林顿或许天生善于沟通，但就连他也觉得这种练习很有帮助。

As other people in the psychiatry and human behavior methods learned of NASA’s success, Kahler’s methods spread. Soon Fortune 500 CEOs sought out McGuire and Kahler for tutoring on how they could lead more effectively and connect with their employees. Kahler even prepped Bill Clinton for his speeches and debates during the 1992 presidential race, coaching the future president on what words and phrases to avoid when courting individuals of varying personalities as well as how to handle addressing a wide, moderate electorate. Clinton may be a natural communicator, but even he found the exercise useful.

1992年10月的一场总统辩论片段清晰地展现了卡勒的演讲方式如何影响了克林顿的演讲。在市政厅辩论会上，老布什和克林顿都回答了一位心烦意乱的失业妇女的提问。这位妇女希望经济更加强劲，就业岗位更多。她情绪低落。布什热情洋溢地朗诵了一系列倡议，作为回应。然而，克林顿走到这位妇女面前，谈到他对阿肯色州失业人员的痛苦感同身受，他知道工厂经理的名字，知道他们以前的工作，他们孩子的名字，以及他们为什么如此努力工作。克林顿说他想投资美国，投资美国人民——这是一个模糊的说法，但却深深地打动了这位妇女、现场观众和电视观众。他以同理心对待她感性的性格，而不是像布什那样，用冷冰冰的算计来应对她。

A clip from one presidential debate in October 1992 clearly shows how Kahler’s methods affected Clinton’s delivery. In the town hall format, George H. W. Bush and Clinton both answer a question from a distraught unemployed woman who wants a stronger economy and more jobs. She is emotionally upset. Bush replies with a spirited recitation of initiatives. Clinton, though, walks over to the woman and talks about how he feels the pain of people who have been laid off in Arkansas, how he knows the plant managers by name, knows the jobs they used to do, the names of their children, and why they work so hard. Clinton says he wants to invest in America, in its people—a vague measure, but one that stirs the woman, the crowd, and the TV audience alike. He met her emotional personality with empathy rather than the cold calculus of a thoughts-based person as Bush had done.

克林顿竞选总统期间，卡勒的弟子之一、精神病学家赫奇斯·卡珀斯开始为电信技术公司（Telecom Technologies）担任顾问。这家硬件制造商希望改善其高管与办公室职员之间的关系。如今，卡珀斯是世界上最善于读人的人之一；只需三十分钟的聊天，他就能彻底了解一个人的性格。3. 1995年，辛普森案的辩护团队请他评估陪审员的性格。在电信公司工作期间，卡珀斯与凯利·康威（Kelly Conway）关系密切，后者最终升任首席执行官。两人共事的几年对康威来说是人生的成长期。他开始对美国国家航空航天局（NASA）建立的评估、解读和预测人格的理论和方法着迷。

About the time Clinton was running for president, one of Kahler’s disciples, Hedges Capers, a psychiatrist, started consulting for Telecom Technologies, a hardware maker that wanted better relations between its C-level executives and the cubicle-bound folk. Today Capers is one of the best readers of people in the world; he thoroughly knows a person’s personality after a thirty-minute chat.3 The O. J. Simpson defense team asked him to assess jurors’ personalities in its 1995 trial. Working with Telecom, Capers became close with Kelly Conway, who eventually rose to be CEO. The few years the two worked together were formative ones for Conway. He became engrossed with the theories and methods established at NASA for evaluating, reading, and predicting people.

康威最终离开电信公司，创办了eLoyalty，一家为拥有大型呼叫中心的公司提供咨询服务的公司。他把自己学到的关于人才评估的知识深藏心底。“我感觉这些知识总有一天会派上用场，”康威说。

Conway eventually left Telecom to found eLoyalty, a consultancy for companies with large call centers, and he buried away in his head what he’d learned about assessing people. “I had a feeling it would someday become really useful,” Conway says.

康威的eLoyalty发展迅速，业绩斐然；它最终上市，股票在纳斯达克交易。但康威并没有忘记NASA和Capers。4

Conway’s eLoyalty grew and did well; it eventually went public and its stock was traded on the Nasdaq. But Conway didn’t forget about NASA or Capers.4

人们的核心性格很少会改变。当一个人长期遭受虐待和压力时，也会有一些例外，但这些情况只是个例。随着年龄的增长，我们的词汇量可能会变得更加丰富多样，但我们说话的方式——也就是我们句子的结构——却始终如一。这些结构揭示了我们如何处理逻辑，以及在压力下如何行动的惊人线索。NASA正是利用了这一事实，远程入侵了人类大脑。

People’s core personalities rarely change. Exceptions happen when a person is exposed to long-term abuse and stress, but these cases are outliers. As we get older, our vocabulary may grow varied and dense, but the way in which we speak—the structure we lend to our sentences—remains the same. Those structures give away amazing clues as to how any of us process logic and act under pressure. By exploiting this fact, NASA had remotely hacked the human brain.

2000年，康威的eLoyalty开始被更擅长将呼叫中心人员迁移到海外的大型咨询公司抢占业务。在寻找其他发展eLoyalty的途径时，康威发现几乎没有哪条路没有被竞争对手堵死。呼叫中心软件业务的增长路径狭窄，需要一点一点地去争取。要想远远领先于其他竞争对手，唯一的办法就是创新，创造出其他公司无法提供的产品。

In 2000, Conway’s eLoyalty started losing business to larger consultancies with more expertise in moving some call center personnel offshore. As he looked for other ways to grow eLoyalty, Conway found few paths not already clogged with competitors. The business of call center software offered only small paths of growth that would have to be won inch by inch. The only way to leap far ahead of the pack would be to innovate, to create something that no other player could offer.

为 NASA 工作的想法在康威的脑海里萌芽。除了熟悉 NASA 的工作流程外，康威还精通另外两件事：他自己做的呼叫中心优化业务，以及作为纳斯达克一家公司的 CEO，他对华尔街最新、最牛逼的伎俩了如指掌。

The seed of NASA’s work had begun to bloom in Conway’s head. Along with the working of the space agency’s process, Conway knew two other things well: his own business of call center optimization and, as CEO of a Nasdaq company, the latest and greatest tricks being performed on Wall Street.

2000年，康威深知语音识别技术的巨大进步，于是他想到或许最终可以构建一个能够读心术的机器人。他的第一个电话就打给了卡珀斯。这位精神病学家仔细考虑了康威的方案，认为它不仅有价值，而且可以改变商业世界和心理学实践。

Knowing the strides made in speech recognition, in 2000 Conway thought that perhaps a mind-reading bot could be constructed after all. His first phone call went to Capers. The psychiatrist considered Conway’s pitch and thought not only that it had merit but also that it could change the world of business and the practice of psychology.

发明一款改变客户服务的产品本身就可能带来巨大的利润。客户服务行业规模远超大多数人的想象。例如，AT&T 的呼叫中心拥有 10 万个坐席，每年运营成本高达 40 亿美元。事实上，美国呼叫中心员工总数达 400 万，是美国第三大职业类别。在这个行业中，发明一款更优秀的工具每年可能带来数十亿美元的价值。

Inventing a product to change customer service could by itself prove immensely lucrative. The customer service industry is far larger than most people realize. AT&T, for instance, has 100,000 seats in its call centers and spends $4 billion a year to run them. The four million call center employees in the United States, in fact, represent the third-largest occupational category in the country. Inventing a better tool in this industry could be worth multiple billions of dollars every year.

多年来，构建一个能够量化语音并确定性格和思维的机器人一直是不可能的。当时的技术——软件和硬件——都还未成熟。语音识别软件——计算机捕捉并准确翻译人类言语的能力——几十年来一直被认为是徒劳的。当时存在的用于此目的的软件漏洞百出，而且往往极其不准确。但在20世纪90年代初，IBM研究中心的两位科学家开始深入研究计算机语音识别和翻译，而这个领域长期以来一直未能开发出足够强大的产品来应对日常情况。彼得·布朗和罗伯特·默瑟最初研究的是将一种语言翻译成另一种语言的程序，最早是从法语翻译成英语。在此之前，大多数致力于这个问题的黑客都精通两种语言，并编写了直接翻译单词的程序：英语中的火腿在法语中是jambon；奶酪当然是fromage；等等。但是，所有语言都充满了例外、奇怪的规则以及违反直觉的习语和短语，这严重影响了翻译算法的编写。需要解释的矛盾之处实在太多了。5

For years, constructing a bot that could quantify spoken words and determine personalities and thoughts was impossible. The technology—software and hardware—just wasn’t ready. Speech recognition software—the ability of computers to capture and translate exactly what humans say—was a lost cause for decades. The software that did exist for the purpose was buggy and often wildly inaccurate. But in the early 1990s, two scientists at IBM’s research center dove into computerized speech recognition and translation, a field that had long failed to produce anything robust enough to be used in everyday situations. Peter Brown and Robert Mercer started by working on programs that translated one language to another, starting with French to English. Most hackers working on the problem up to that point knew both languages and wrote programs that translated words directly: the English ham is, in French, jambon; cheese is, of course, fromage; and so on. But all languages are rife with exceptions, strange rules, and counterintuitive idioms and phrase that severely complicate writing translation algorithms. There are simply too many inconsistencies to account for.5

布朗和默瑟不懂法语，也不想学。他们没有手写数千个算法，而是将加拿大议会会议记录输入IBM工作站。由于加拿大有两种官方语言，这些记录（一年的记录就多达数百万字）同时提供英语和法语版本。他们创建了机器学习算法，从这两份文本中寻找模式。其他人曾试图用优雅的代码来重现不同语言的语法结构，以此来解决这个问题，而布朗和默瑟则使用“愚蠢”的软件和暴力破解。“只有这样，我们才有可能听到（marqué d'un asterisque/starred）的轻声呼唤，或（qui s'est fait bousculer/embattled）的低语，”布朗在总结他们研究的论文中写道。6

Brown and Mercer didn’t know French, nor did they care to learn it. Instead of writing thousands of algorithms by hand, they fed transcripts of Canadian parliament meetings into their IBM workstations. Because Canada has two official languages, the transcripts, which for a single year can number in the millions of words, are available in both English and French. The men created machine-learning algorithms to look for patterns in the twin texts. Where others had tried to solve the problem with elegant code that attempted to reproduce the grammatical structures of different languages, Brown and Mercer employed “dumb” software and brute force. “Only in this way can one hope to hear the quiet call of (marqué d’un asterisque/starred) or the whisper of (qui s’est fait bousculer/embattled),” wrote Brown in a paper summarizing their research.6

随后，布朗和默瑟建立了一套算法，试图根据前面的单词来预测接下来的单词。事实上，他们的技术非常具有革命性，它不仅改变了语音翻译软件，也改变了语音识别程序。最新最好的语音识别软件不是试图记住从说话者口中说出的每一个单词，而是寻找组合在一起有意义的单词串。这样，它就可以轻松区分are和our。Are you going to the mall today不会被误认为Our you going to the mall today，因为人们从来不会说our you going。就像我们学习语法规则一样，机器学习算法也是如此。这种方法构成了我们今天使用的语音识别程序的基础。

Brown and Mercer then built a set of algorithms that tried to anticipate what words would come next based on what preceded it. Their hack was so revolutionary, in fact, that it not only changed speech translation software, but also speech recognition programs. Instead of trying to nail each word as it comes out of the speaker’s mouth, the latest and best speech recognition software looks for strings of words that make sense together. That way, it has an easy time distinguishing are from our. Are you going to the mall today won’t be mistaken with Our you going to the mall today because, simply, people never say our you going. Just as we learn grammar rules, so the machine-learning algorithm did as well. This method forms the backbone of the speech recognition programs we use today.

布朗和默瑟的突破引起了华尔街的关注。1993年，他们离开IBM，加入对冲基金文艺复兴科技公司（Renaissance Technologies）。他们开发的语言算法也可以用来预测金融市场的短期趋势，而他们的算法版本也成为了文艺复兴科技公司旗下最佳基金的核心。在布朗和默瑟的推动下，文艺复兴科技公司的资产规模从1993年的2亿美元飙升至2001年的40亿美元。7语音识别算法在市场上的具体应用尚不清楚，这正是文艺复兴科技如此成功的原因。文艺复兴科技是华尔街最大的谜团，其吸引顶尖科学人才进入金融领域的本领无人能及，包括高盛。文艺复兴科技创始人、麻省理工学院毕业的数学家詹姆斯·西蒙斯在默瑟和布朗的帮助下成为亿万富翁后，于2009年退休，并任命他们为联席首席执行官。

Brown and Mercer’s breakthrough didn’t go unnoticed on Wall Street. They left IBM in 1993 for Renaissance Technologies, the hedge fund. Their work developing language algorithms could also be used to predict short-term trends in the financial markets, and versions of their algorithms became the core of Renaissance’s best funds. During a run powered by Brown and Mercer’s work, Renassiance went from $200 million in assets in 1993 to $4 billion in 2001.7 How the speech recognition algorithms are used in the markets isn’t exactly known, which is why Renaissance remains so successful. Renaissance is the largest enigma on Wall Street—and its knack for luring top science talent to finance is second to nobody, including Goldman. When James Simons, Renaissance’s MIT-educated mathematician founder, retired in 2009 after becoming a billionaire with the help of Mercer and Brown, he named them co-CEOs.

默瑟和布朗的研究成果意味着，到2001年，康威就能买到现成的软件，能够以相当高的准确度转录大多数对话。既然能够捕捉人们的话语，康威就需要构建算法机器人，将这些转录的话语运用到NASA的计算中。

The work of Mercer and Brown meant that by 2001, Conway could buy off-the-shelf software that could transcribe most conversations with a reasonable degree of accuracy. Now that he could capture people’s words, Conway needed to build algorithmic bots that could take those transcribed words and apply to them the calculus of NASA.

为了实现这一目标，康威着手开发一个算法库，涵盖所有可以想象到的词语序列或说话模式。一个人说的任何话都可以用来解读性格线索。例如，如果一个人在与客服代表的对话中，以提问和要求答案的方式开场，而没有寒暄和闲聊，那么他很可能是一个以思考为基础的人。他们可能会说：“您好，我的车需要换个消声器。2007 年款斯巴鲁傲虎的维修价格是多少？什么时候可以修？”这句话中的关键词是“需求”、“什么”、“何时”——打电话的人要求提供信息，并希望尽快得到答复。

To do this, Conway set out to develop a library of algorithms for every series of words or pattern of speech imaginable. Anything a person says can be read for personality clues. For instance, if a person opens the conversation with a customer service representative by asking questions and demanding answers, dispensing with pleasantries and chitchat, it’s likely they’re a thoughts-based person. They may say things like, Hi, my car needs a new muffler. What is your repair price for a 2007 Subaru Outback and when can you do the work? The keywords in this statement are needs, what, when—the caller is demanding information and he wants an answer as quickly as possible.

另一位来电者可能会打电话来，解释公司产品性能不佳给她带来的感受。她可能会说：“我气炸了——这根本行不通，我都不知道该怎么办了。我对贵公司和服务期待更高，现在却很失望。”这里的关键词是“气炸”、“失望”和“期待”。此外，来电者大量使用人称代词“我”，并随后用陈述句表达自己的感受，进一步表明她是一个情绪化的人。

Another caller might call and explain how the poor performance of the company’s product made her feel. This person might say, I’m exasperated—this doesn’t work and I’m just not sure what to do anymore. I expected more out of your company and your service. I’m disappointed. The keywords here are exasperated, disappointed, and expected. Also, the caller has further indicated that she is an emotions-based person by heavy use of the personal pronoun I, followed by declarative statements of feeling.

第一个打电话的人正在进行事实调查。用事实来回答他的答案，他很快就会满意。算法应该知道，闲聊会让他恼火。第二个打电话的人希望得到强烈的同理心和一般的交谈。道歉和真诚的理解会让她最满意。康威需要能够在几秒钟内理解这些事实的算法。
