The first caller was on a fact-finding mission. Meet his answers with facts and he will be quickly satisfied. Making small talk, the algorithms should know, would annoy him. The second caller wants a heavy dose of empathy and general conversation. She will be best satisfied by an apology and genuine understanding. Conway needed algorithms that would pick up on these facts in a matter of seconds.

康威不顾个性，他想要打造一个机器人，在来电者提出要求之前就能知道他们想要什么。例如，如果有人威胁要采取法律行动，康威希望主管能够立即知晓，尤其是对于像医疗保险公司这样的潜在客户来说，诉讼现象非常普遍，每年都会影响到公司的利润。任何能够阻止少数诉讼的自动化措施都价值数百万美元。康威深知，持续以正确的方式处理来电者可以提升公司的业绩，并建立忠诚的客户群。

Going past personalities, Conway wanted to build a bot that would know what callers wanted before they even asked for it. If a person threatened legal action, for instance, Conway wanted a supervisor to know immediately, especially for potential clients such as health insurers where litigation was a frequent enough phenomenon that it affected the bottom line every year. Any kind of automatic measure that could head off just a handful of lawsuits would be worth millions. Conway knew that handling callers the exact right way on a consistent basis could lift a company’s results and build a loyal customer base.

康威深知，打造一款革命性的产品可能带来巨大的回报，于是他试图改变这家上市公司的发展方向，这源于他预感和信念：某种东西可以读懂人心。然而，并非所有人都信服。康威告诉eLoyalty的首席律师罗伯特·沃特，他知道一个可以预测人类行为的心理模型。沃特差点儿笑了出来。“我说：‘好吧！我做了二十年的律师，没错，我也能预测人心——他们都是混蛋。’”

Knowing that creating a revolutionary product could result in a huge payoff, Conway looked to change the direction of his public company based on a hunch and the belief that something could be built to read people’s minds. Not everybody was convinced. Conway told Robert Wert, eLoyalty’s head lawyer, that he knew of a psychological model that could predict human behavior. Wert nearly guffawed. “I said, ‘Right! I’ve been a lawyer for twenty years and, yeah, I can predict humans too—they’re all assholes.’”

但当沃特遇到卡珀斯，亲眼见证了科学的成果后，他改变了想法。这位律师现在经营着卡勒的咨询公司。律师事务所每天付给沃特超过1万美元，让他指导合伙人如何从数量上解读人类。

But Wert was converted when he met Capers and saw the science in action. The lawyer now runs Kahler’s consultancy. Law firms pay Wert more than $10,000 a day to tutor their partners on how to decipher humans quantitatively.

康威想把人类从中剔除出去。康威认为，由于这是一种定量方法，因此可以构建能够读懂顾客想法的机器人。“我们正在对人类语言进行分类，”他说。

Conway wanted to take humans out of it. Because it was a quantitative method, it was possible, Conway figured, to build bots that could read customers’ minds. “We are categorizing the human language,” he says.

康威带着他的小团队继续开发他的算法库，使其逐步完善，最终投入使用。与此同时，他和卡佩斯一起出发，验证他的理论是否可行。他必须弄清楚，了解一个人的想法、了解他们的动机究竟有何真正优势，以及他的整个计划是否真的有用——前提是他能够成功。

With the small team he had, Conway kept working on his algorithm library, building it up to go live. At the same time, he set out with Capers to find out if his theories would even work. He had to know what the real advantages were of knowing a person’s thoughts, of knowing their motivations and whether this whole mission of his would prove useful—providing he could even pull it off.

康威说服全球无线运营商沃达丰，将12名客服代表的1500通电话录音交给他。每位客服代表都接听了超过100通电话，这使得康威能够了解每位代表在处理各种不同类型的来电者时的表现，从行动型到反思型。他还能了解每位沃达丰客服代表的性格，从而验证他的假设：性格相似的代表能更快地解决问题，减少愤怒挂断电话的顾客。

Conway talked Vodafone, the global wireless carrier, into turning over to him fifteen hundred phone call recordings for a group of twelve customer service agents. Having more than a hundred calls per agent allowed Conway to determine how each of them fared with all different types of callers, from actions-based people to reflections-based people. He could also figure out what kind of personality each of the Vodafone representatives possessed and therefore test his hypothesis that like personalities reach resolutions faster and leave fewer callers hanging up angry.

康威和卡珀斯分别监听了每一通电话，并对1500名来电者和客服人员的性格进行了分类。之后，他们计算了每通电话的通话时间，并将其归类为满意结果，或者在最糟糕的情况下，导致潜在客户流失。之后，两人将所有这些数据汇总到一个矩阵中，并检验了结果。

Conway and Capers listened to each call independently and classified the personalities of all fifteen hundred callers and the agents. They then timed each call and classified it as a happy conclusion or, in the worst case, a potential customer lost. The pair then put all of this data into a matrix and examined the results.

结果简直令人震惊。当呼叫者联系到性格与其本人相近的客服人员时，通话时间约为五分钟，问题解决率高达92%。无论以何种标准衡量，这都堪称高质量的客户服务。然而，当客户的电话转接给性格相反的客服人员时，差异却令人惊叹：通话时间仅需十分钟，问题解决率高达47%。这意味着，与呼叫者性格相匹配的客服人员的通话效率是其他通话的两倍。随着通话时间的大幅缩短，像AT&T这样的公司最终可以节省三分之一的呼叫中心成本——前提是Conway能够真正开发出实现这一目标所需的机器人。

The results were nothing short of astounding. When a caller reached a personality much like their own, calls lasted about five minutes and the problem was resolved 92 percent of the time. That’s high-quality customer service by any measure. When a customer’s call landed with an agent with an opposite personality, however, the difference was amazing: ten-minute calls and a 47 percent problem resolution rate. This meant that calls matching the personality of the caller with that of the agent were twice as effective as other calls. With drastically shorter call times, a company like AT&T could eventually eliminate a third of its call center costs—provided that Conway could actually build the kinds of bots necessary to make it possible.

事实证明，这完全有可能。然而，要将其变为现实，却是一个浩大的工程。为了构建必要的算法，康威不仅聘请了顶尖程序员，还“尽我所能地招募最聪明的人”。他发现，聘用最优秀的人才，然后对他们进行必要的培训，往往比仅仅聘用那些已经掌握了正确编程和逻辑技能的人更有效。这就好比选择迈克尔·乔丹加入你的腰旗橄榄球队，而不是一个高中时可能是全联盟外接手的人。当然，后者会接球，也懂得踢橄榄球，但一旦乔丹对比赛有了感觉，他与生俱来的运动天赋很可能会被他超越。

As it turned out, it was very possible. To make it reality, though, would prove to be a massive project. To build the algorithms necessary, Conway hired crack programmers along with “just the smartest people I could find.” He found that hiring the brightest talent and then training them on what he needed done was often more effective than simply hiring people who already had the correct programming and logic skills. It’s akin to picking Michael Jordan for your flag football team over somebody who may have been an all-conference wide receiver in high school. Sure, the second guy can catch and knows how to play football, but MJ’s natural athleticism will likely blow by him once he gets a feeling for the game.

为了打造一个能读心术的机器人，康威需要很多像迈克尔·乔丹那样的人才。他准备把eLoyalty核心业务呼叫中心管理的全部利润都投入到这个项目中，他认为这个项目能够改变世界，远不止于客户服务。凭借每年数千万美元的运营利润，康威在招募团队成员方面大手大脚。但当他真正要签下一支由超级明星组成的庞大团队时，他发现其他资金雄厚的追求者也在追逐他。事实上，其他追求者的资金实力与世界上任何一家都不相上下。康威的对手是华尔街的量化投资机器。

To create a mind-reading bot, Conway needed a lot of Michael Jordans. He was prepared to take all of the profits from eLoyalty’s core business of call center management and plow them into this project, something he felt could change the world far beyond customer service. With tens of millions of dollars in operating profits per year, Conway could afford to be generous in hiring his team. But when it came to actually signing a large team of superstars, he found that other well-financed suitors were wooing them too. The other suitors were, in fact, as well funded as any in the world. Conway had run right up against the Wall Street quant machine.

8

8

华尔街与硅谷

WALL STREET VERSUS SILICON VALLEY

一系列事件，全部 集中在2001年左右，导致交易公司的损益表大幅增加，并扩大了其熟练程序员的队伍。从这一时期开始，金融业的扩张是前所未有的，其动力来自两件事：蓬勃发展的房地产行业（华尔街参与了这一行业的创建）以及算法自营交易的兴起。

A COLLECTION OF EVENTS, ALL coalescing right around 2001, led to the fattening of trading houses’ income statements and the pools of adroit programmers they kept on staff. The expansion of the financial sector beginning in this period was unprecedented and fueled by two things: the booming housing sector (which Wall Street helped create) and the rise of algorithmic proprietary trading.

2000年，机器人交易量占美国股市总交易量的不到10%。华尔街巨头们深知机器人的存在，但当时的算法根本无法左右市场。机器人掌控着整个市场，引发像“闪电崩盘”那样的事件，这简直不可想象。2000年，控制交易大厅的是人，而不是计算机。纽约证券交易所几乎所有交易仍然由人工专家处理，这些专家拥有监管特定股票大部分交易的独特特权。在交易大厅，交易员下单的速度取决于专家及其助手的处理速度。整个系统完全由人工操控。掌控华尔街的仍然是交易大厅，而不是计算机主板或光纤线路中的脉冲光。彼得菲的系统和一代模仿者占领了纳斯达克，但纽约证券交易所仍然是一个喊口令胜过打字的地方，更不用说任何全自动系统了。

In 2000, bots accounted for less than 10 percent of all trading on U.S. stock markets. Big Wall Street players knew well of their existence, but the algorithms back then weren’t moving the market. The thought of them co-opting the entire works and sparking an event like that of the Flash Crash was inconceivable. In 2000, people controlled the pits, not computers. Almost all trades on the NYSE still traveled through the hands of a human specialist, who had the unique privilege of overseeing most of the trading on one particular equity. On the floor, traders could shoot orders only as quickly as the specialists and their minions could handle them. The system was entirely human. It was still the pits, not computer motherboards or the pulsing light in a fiber-optic line, that ran Wall Street. Peterffy’s system and a generation of copycats had taken over the Nasdaq, but the NYSE remained a place where yelling out orders trumped typing, let alone anything wholly automatic.

然而，这一切都在改变。电子交易网络的兴起，让像彼得菲这样的交易员/程序员更容易、更便宜地进入曾经被小圈子和少数精英控制的市场。稳定的网络连接、强大的台式电脑和一些编写精良的代码，可以让一位具备市场知识的程序员直接进入这个行业。

All of that was changing, however. The rise of the electronic trading networks made it easier and cheaper for trader/programmers like Peterffy to wade into markets once controlled by cliques and a select few. A solid network connection coupled with a powerful desktop computer and some well-written code could spring a programmer with market knowledge straight into the game.

除了更便捷的访问方式外，所谓的华尔街十进制化还为黑客提供了另一个巨大的赚钱机会。在十进制化之前，美国股市一直以美元的零头作为单位。例如，1997年之前，一只股票的最小波动幅度是八分之一，相当于12.5美分。后来，波动幅度减半为十六分之一，但这仍然意味着一只股票的最小价差至少为6.25美分。这个价差仍然足够大，足以让老牌经纪商和做市商，即使是那些在技术方面投资不足的，也能从中牟取暴利。他们只需以卖价卖出，以买价买入即可。使用零头保证了经纪商的利润，而牺牲了其他所有人，尤其是小投资者的利益。

In addition to greater access, the so-called decimalization of Wall Street gave hackers another huge opportunity to make money. Before decimalization, U.S. stock markets had always operated on fractions of a dollar. For instance, before 1997 the smallest increment a stock could move had been one-eighth, which is equal to 12.5 cents. The increment was then halved to one-sixteenth, but that still meant the minimum spread on a stock was at least 6.25 cents. This was still a large enough spread to keep the established brokers and market makers, even those who had underinvested in technology, raking in money. All they had to do was sell at the offer and buy at the bid. The use of fractions guaranteed brokers profits at the expense of everybody else, especially small investors.

2001年，美国证券交易委员会（SEC）强制所有市场改用小数，导致许多交易量大的股票的价差降至1美分。现在，仅仅成为拥有客户的做市商已不足以获得巨额收益。你需要交易量，大量的交易量。而实现交易量的唯一途径是：技术和懂得如何利用技术的人才。

In 2001, the Securities and Exchange Commission mandated that all markets switch to decimals, rendering the spreads in many heavy-volume stocks to one penny. Now just being a market maker with clients wasn’t enough to cinch up big earnings. You needed volume, lots of it. The only way to get it: technology and the brains that knew how to use it.

到2008年初，自动化机器人占据了美国股市所有交易的60%。金融行业用了七年时间，吸纳了所有技艺娴熟的应届毕业生工程师、物理学家以及那些对高薪和足以买下大多数美国人两套住房的奖金稍有兴趣的文艺复兴式人才。华尔街已经发展成为比半导体行业、大型制药公司或电信行业更大规模的数学、工程和科学毕业生招聘机构。正是在这种逆境中，康威花了近十年的时间努力招聘人才。

By early 2008, automated bots accounted for 60 percent of all U.S. stock market trades, and the financial industry had spent seven years sucking up every deft graduating engineer, physicist, and general Renaissance man who had even a mild attraction to a large starting salary and a bonus big enough to buy most Americans’ homes twice over. Wall Street had grown to become a larger hirer of math, engineering, and science graduates than the semiconductor industry, Big Pharma, or the telecommunications business. It was into this headwind that Conway tried to hire for the better part of a decade.

康威的 eLoyalty 公司位于芝加哥北部的森林湖，花了数十天时间在附近的西北大学和芝加哥大学招聘。康威会带着几名他最信任的员工出席招聘活动，并设立公司展位。但随着康威和 eLoyalty 在招聘领域的深入，他们发现自己被华尔街的招聘人员所困扰。高盛、摩根士丹利、花旗、瑞信等大公司在顶尖大学的招聘活动中无处不在。在大多数情况下，华尔街公司派出的是刚从学校毕业几年的初级员工。他们可以肤浅地谈论在他们公司工作是什么样的。他们不推销愿景，不推销挑战，不推销智力激励——他们没有真正的推销。高盛或摩根只需出现，他们的展位就会被围得水泄不通。

Conway’s eLoyalty, based north of Chicago in Lake Forest, spent dozens of days recruiting at nearby Northwestern University and the University of Chicago. Conway would show up at recruiting events with a few of his most trusted employees and set up his company booth. But as Conway and eLoyalty dug further into the recruiting game, they found themselves stymied by Wall Street’s recruiters. Goldman, Morgan Stanley, Citi, Credit Suisse, and the rest of their lot were omnipresent at top universities’ career events. In most cases, the Wall Street firms sent junior employees who had only been out of school a few years to such events. They could talk shallowly about what working at their companies was like. They didn’t pitch vision, they didn’t pitch challenge, they didn’t pitch intellectual stimulation—they didn’t really pitch. All Goldman or Morgan had to do was show up and their booths would be mobbed.

2001年至2008年这段时期，很可能将成为华尔街的巅峰。这些公司不仅创下了收入、利润和员工人数的新高，还获得了前所未有的广泛声誉和认可，而且很可能永远不会再有这样的成就。这正是康威所面临的挑战。

This period—2001 to 2008—will likely go down as Wall Street’s pinnacle. The firms enjoyed not only record revenues, profits, and head count, but also widespread prestige and acceptance on a level that they had never seen before and will likely never see again. This was what Conway was up against.

康威的确能找到几个人来应聘，但要找到最优秀的人才却很难。“如果候选人从未听说过你的公司，那么很难打败高盛，”他说。即使他能让候选人感兴趣，他的花费也会被财力雄厚的证券交易公司压垮。“我们薪水不错，但我们不能给一个刚毕业的大学生开20万美元，”他解释道。

Conway would get a few people trolling past, but getting a crack at the best people proved difficult. “It’s just really hard to beat out a Goldman Sachs when the candidate has never heard of your company,” he says. Even when he could get a candidate interested, he’d get outspent by trading houses’ deep pockets. “We pay well, but we can’t throw $200,000 at a fresh college graduate,” he reasons.

康威竭尽全力招募最优秀的人才。当他意识到公司位于郊区的森林湖（Lake Forest）总部可能会让那些想留在芝加哥的毕业生望而却步时，eLoyalty 便在芝加哥市中心的核心地段——租金最高的金融区——开设了一间大型办公室。他为推荐员工的员工提供现金奖励。康威不断招募新毕业生，希望找到一批才华横溢、志同道合的人，他们或许可以通过加入 eLoyalty 引领潮流。

Conway did everything possible to land the best minds. When he thought the company’s suburban headquarters in tony Lake Forest might be a turnoff to graduates looking to stay in the city, eLoyalty opened up a large office in the heart of Chicago’s downtown, right in the financial district where rents are highest. He rewarded employees with cash for hiring referrals. Conway kept pounding at new graduates, hoping to find a stream of bright, like-minded people who might start a trend by heading to eLoyalty.

康威试图缩短流程，引进顶尖院校、拥有语言学经验的MBA毕业生。他们当然能构思出他需要的算法。但这条路行不通。“我们付了过高的薪水，结果却发现他们工作能力不足，”康威说。这些MBA毕业生被细节、流程和指标所困扰。康威真正需要的是充满创造力的技术人员——拥有高容量的思维，能够快速构思问题，并找到独特而独特的解决方案。

Conway tried to short-circuit the process, bringing in MBA graduates from top schools with experience in linguistics. Surely they could conceive the algorithms he needed. But that route didn’t work. “We overpaid and it turned out they weren’t very good at their jobs,” Conway says. The MBAs got caught up on details, procedure, and metrics. What Conway really needed was technical people charged with creativity—high-capacity minds that could quickly conceive of problems and find unique and disparate ways of solving them.

eLoyalty 面临的一个典型（且巨大的）问题是：并非所有情绪型人都使用完全相同的说话模式。要想自动识别这些差异，并准确进行分类，需要开发成千上万种算法，识别所有情绪型人及其怪癖、意图和语言。只有拥有超强专注力和高度分析能力的人才能胜任这项任务。

A typical (and large) problem facing eLoyalty: Not every emotions-based person uses the exact same patterns of speech. Devising ways to automatically sniff out these differences and still categorize people correctly requires the creation of tens of thousands of algorithms capable of spotting all emotions-based people and their quirks, intentions, and language. Only people with a supreme capacity for focus and a highly analytical mind are up to the task.

康威在招聘这类人才方面确实取得了一些进展，尽管进展缓慢。候选人需要接受性格和智商测试。只有得分最高的人才会被考虑。eLoyalty 招聘的员工中，超过四分之一的人智商在全国排名前 1%。而这正是华尔街所珍视的候选人。正是这些人能够解读影响证券价格的十二个因素，并设计出能够以光速利用这些理论进行交易的算法。与高盛这样的蓝筹公司竞争，再加上即使是初级员工也要支付 40 万美元的薪水/奖金，这减缓了康威的招聘进度。

Conway did make some progress on hiring these kinds of people, albeit slowly. Prospects were given personality and IQ tests. Only the best scorers were considered. More than a quarter of all of eLoyalty’s hires are in the top 1 percent of IQs nationally. This is exactly the same candidate so cherished by Wall Street. It’s these people who can unravel the twelve things affecting a securities price and how to conceive of algorithms to trade on these theories at the speed of light. Competing against a blue-chip name like Goldman Sachs, plus salary/bonus compensation of $400,000 for even junior-level people, slowed Conway’s progress.

康威并非唯一一个在从华尔街的诱惑者手中抢夺人才的失败者。整个科技界都目睹了投资银行、贸易公司，以及如今新兴的精品高频交易公司，纷纷涌入精英大学，寻找人才。校园里的动态变化可谓不小。例如，从2000年到2006年，麻省理工学院毕业生前往华尔街的比例飙升了67%，当时该校超过四分之一的毕业生进入了金融业。1

Conway wasn’t alone in his losing battle to wrest talent from the temptress of Wall Street. The entire tech world watched as investment banks, trading houses, and now a new breed of company, the boutique high-speed trader, all swarmed elite universities in search of talent. The changing dynamic on campuses wasn’t a small one. For instance, the share of MIT graduates heading to Wall Street popped 67 percent from 2000 to 2006, when more than a quarter of all of the school’s graduates headed into finance.1

康威和其他科技界人士也不得不应对人才库急剧萎缩的局面。20世纪80年代，随着个人电脑的兴起，大量学生涌入计算机科学专业，该领域也因此蓬勃发展。计算机科学系规模迅速扩大，编程人才涌入经济的各个领域。但这一时期随着1988年的科技股崩盘而戛然而止，而这场崩盘的部分原因是1987年的股市灾难。此后近十年，计算机科学一直是大学里不受欢迎的专业。

Conway and the rest of the tech crowd also had to battle a drastically shrinking talent pool. The field had expanded in the 1980s, when, following the rise of the personal computer, students poured into computer science as a major. CS departments swelled and programming talent flowed to all corners of the economy. But that period ended abruptly with the tech crash of 1988, which was partially brought on by the 1987 stock market disaster. Following that, computer science remained an unpopular college major for almost ten years.

但随后，AOL、Netscape、eBay 和 Yahoo! 等巨头相继出现，一批新的百万富翁应运而生，计算机科学院校的入学人数也再次大幅增长。上世纪 90 年代末，我还是伊利诺伊大学的工程系学生时，学校正值校友成功的浪潮，其中包括马克·安德森（Netscape）、马克斯·列夫琴（PayPal），以及后来 YouTube 和 Yelp 的创始人。伊利诺伊大学的计算机科学楼曾是工程系最热闹的地方。学生们经常在毕业前前往硅谷，互联网泡沫的传说让整个工程系沸腾不已。即使是成绩平平的学生，似乎也能拿到签约奖金、股票期权，以及毕业后在互联网上获得荣耀的模糊保证。

But then came AOL, Netscape, eBay, and Yahoo! A new class of millionaire was born and computer science schools’ enrollments jumped again. When I was an engineering student at the University of Illinois in the late 1990s, the school was riding a wave of alumni successes, including those of Marc Andreessen (Netscape), Max Levchin (PayPal), and later the founders of YouTube and Yelp! The computer science building at U of I was the busiest place on the engineering quad. Students regularly departed for Silicon Valley before they graduated, and stories of dot-com gold kept the quad buzzing. Even mediocre students seemed to be snaring signing bonuses, stock options, and some fuzzy guarantee of Web glory upon graduation.

这个故事最初在全国几所大学里上演，随着科技热潮的升温及其影响波及全美，它的影响也愈演愈烈。1998年，选择计算机科学专业的大学新生人数开始迅速上升，当时计算机科学专业的学生仅占新生总数的1.5%。2002年，这一数字达到峰值3.5%，在短短五年内增长了一倍多。但互联网泡沫的破灭迅速缩水了人才库。到2007年底，这一数字已跌至1.5%以下。因此，华尔街继续招聘更多的程序员，尽管总体上可用的程序员数量已经减少——这加剧了像康威和eLoyalty这样的人才短缺。这种趋势变得如此明显，以至于教授们开始注意到了。

This story unfolded at a handful of campuses across the country and burgeoned larger as the tech boom grew hotter and its effects reached the whole of America. As a result, the number of college freshmen choosing computer science as a major began to rise quickly in 1998, when computer science majors comprised just 1.5 percent of incoming freshmen. In 2002, the number peaked at 3.5 percent, more than doubling in just five years. But the dot-com crash quickly shrank the pool. By the end of 2007, the numbers had sunk below 1.5 percent. So Wall Street continued to hire more programmers even with fewer of them available overall—compounding the shortage for people like Conway and eLoyalty. The trend became so pronounced that professors started to notice.

维韦克·瓦德瓦加入杜克大学，用他的话说，是想教工程专业的学生如何解决现实世界的问题，并让他们成为工程师——而不是华尔街的算法操纵者。当他发现大多数学生毕业后都成为了投资银行家或管理顾问时，他感到震惊和沮丧。“我的学生几乎没有一个真正成为工程师，”他说，“他们背负着巨额的学生贷款，而高盛提供的贷款额度是工程公司的两倍，他们又怎么可能成为工程师呢？”

Vivek Wadhwa joined the faculty at Duke University to, as he describes it, teach engineering students about solving the real world’s problems and to work as engineers—not algorithm jockeys on Wall Street. He was shocked and upset when the majority of his students became investment bankers or management consultants after they graduated. “Hardly any of my students actually became engineers,” he says. “And why would they, when they had huge student loans, and Goldman Sachs was offering them twice as much as engineering companies did?”

瓦德瓦本人也曾是华尔街的一名工程师，20世纪80年代末在瑞士信贷第一波士顿银行工作。他最终成为该银行信息服务部门的副总裁。在加入瑞士信贷之前，瓦德瓦曾在硅谷最初的创新者之一施乐公司工作，年薪4.7万美元。1986年，他在瑞士信贷第一波士顿银行工作的第一年，年薪16万美元。第二年，他赚了18万美元，第三年24万美元，第四年30万美元。这一切都发生在1990年之前。

Wadhwa was once an engineer on Wall Street himself, working for Credit Suisse First Boston in the late 1980s. He eventually became vice president of the bank’s information services. Before Credit Suisse, Wadhwa worked at one of Silicon Valley’s original innovators, Xerox, where he made $47,000 a year. His first year with CSFB, in 1986, he made $160,000. He made $180,000 in his second year, $240,000 in his third year, and $300,000 in his fourth year. This was all before 1990.

和许多学生一样，瓦德瓦原本打算在华尔街待几年，还清一些债务，然后继续前进。但他发现很难抽身。“这有点像有组织犯罪，”他说，“你永远都离不开它。”

Like many of his own students, Wadhwa figured he’d spend a few years on Wall Street, pay off some debts, and then move on. But he found it hard to pull away. “It gets to be kind of like organized crime,” he says. “You can never leave.”

瓦德瓦最终离开，创立了 Relativity Technologies，该公司开发软件帮助企业从旧代码库迁移到 C++ 和 Java 等新代码库。此后，他不仅在杜克大学任职，还在埃默里大学和斯坦福大学任职，成为科技教育领域的领军人物之一。

Wadhwa eventually got away and founded Relativity Technologies, which made software to help companies migrate from older code bases to newer ones such as C++ and Java. He has since become one of the leading voices of tech education from positions not only at Duke but also at Emory and Stanford.

作为杜克大学的一名新教员，瓦德瓦亲眼目睹他的许多最聪明的学生最终进入华尔街，发明了那些将世界推向经济崩溃边缘的工具——抵押债务凭证、高斯连接函数（一个被华尔街滥用的优秀公式）以及随时可能失控的交易算法。

As a new faculty member at Duke, Wadhwa watched as many of his brightest students ended up on Wall Street, conjuring up the very instruments that would lead the world to the brink of economic collapse—collateralized debt obligations, the Gaussian copula (a fine formula that was misused by the Street), and trading algorithms that could go wild at any moment.

那是2007年，股市达到历史最高点。金融公司吸金如吸尘机般迅速。为了确保自身在行业中的领先地位，这些金融公司需要两样东西：华盛顿的朋友和金钱能买到的顶尖量化人才。因此，他们不惜代价地买下了这些人才。面对这样的现实，康威几乎不可能以自己期望的速度扩张。

This was in 2007, the all-time height of the stock market. Financial-sector companies were pulling in cash like a vacuum sucks dust. To ensure their spot at the top of the heap, the finance firms needed two things: friends in Washington and the best quantitative brains money could buy. So in both cases they bought them. Going up against this reality, Conway had little chance of expanding with the speed he desired.

算法人才争夺战的兴衰

BOOM AND BUST OF THE ALGORITHMIC TALENT WAR

争夺最佳算法构建者的竞争延伸到了华尔街公司内部和公司之间。那些能够编写最优雅代码或构思出最巧妙算法的人，可以轻松地在德意志银行和骑士交易等公司之间来回穿梭。在这群人中，存在着一种超级玩家，他们的技能如此独特且宝贵，以至于年薪远超100万美元。

The competition for the best algorithm builders extended into and between Wall Street firms. People who could write the most elegant code or conceive of the most clever algorithms could easily shuttle back and forth between players such as Deutsche Bank and Knight Trading. Among this group there exists a level of superplayer, a quant whose skill is so unique and valuable as to command compensation well in excess of $1 million per year.

在某些情况下，报酬可能会高得多。米哈伊尔·马利舍夫是一位等离子体物理学家，也是肯·格里芬旗下以量化交易为中心的芝加哥对冲基金Citadel高频交易业务的幕后推手。2008年，他从Citadel获得了1.5亿美元的报酬。一年后，马利舍夫离开Citadel，创办了一家名为Teza Technologies的竞争公司。格里芬认为马利舍夫的专有代码被盗，于是起诉了他，最终赢得了巨额罚款，Teza的业务也因此遭到重创。2

In some cases, compensation can grow much larger. Mikhail Malyshev, a plasma physicist and the brains behind the high-frequency trading operation at Ken Griffin’s Citadel, the quant-centric Chicago hedge fund, was paid $150 million by Citadel in 2008. A year later Malyshev left to start up a competing firm he named Teza Technologies. Assuming he was being robbed of proprietary code, Griffin sued Malyshev, eventually winning a big fine and largely scuttling Teza’s business.2

像 Citadel 这样的雇主，虽然给量化人才开出了高额薪水，但也很容易招致人才叛逃。肯·格里芬 (Ken Griffin) 的公司另一位前金融工程师濮一浩 (Yihao Pu) 于 2011 年底因涉嫌在离职前窃取代码而被捕。濮一浩的回应是将自己的电脑扔进芝加哥郊外的一条河里。潜水员打捞出了这台电脑；里面藏有 Citadel 最重要的交易代码的构建模块。3

Employers like Citadel, while they pay incredible sums to their quantitative minds, are left vulnerable to defections. Ken Griffin’s firm had another one of its former financial engineers, Yihao Pu, arrested in late 2011 for allegedly pilfering code before he left. Pu responded by flinging his computer into a river outside of Chicago. Divers recovered the hardware; it contained building blocks of Citadel’s most important trading code.3

颓废的薪酬和招聘之争一直​​持续到2008年秋日，华尔街的一切都发生了改变。9月15日，国际顶级投资银行雷曼兄弟——一家雇佣了大批量化分析师的公司——申请破产。道琼斯指数在接下来的三周内下跌了3000点，华尔街的大多数精英公司濒临破产。美林证券被出售给美国银行，高盛从沃伦·巴菲特手中获得了50亿美元，贝尔斯登则永远消失了。

The decadent pay and hiring wars continued until, during the course of one fall day in 2008, everything changed for Wall Street. On September 15, Lehman Brothers, the international white-shoe investment bank—and a place that employed legions of quants—filed for bankruptcy. The Dow dropped 3,000 points in the next three weeks and most of Wall Street’s elite firms teetered near insolvency. Merrill Lynch sold itself to Bank of America, Goldman Sachs secured $5 billion from Warren Buffett, and Bear Stearns disappeared forever.

在不到一年的时间里——以雷曼兄弟公司破产为导火索——美国经济的重心永远地改变了。在此之前，金融业占 GDP 的比重一直在加速上升。即使在 20 世纪 60 年代，股市长期牛市，华尔街的工作开始获得一丝魅力的时候，金融业在 GDP 中的占比也不到 4%。1982 年，当量化分析师和程序员首次开始迁移到华尔街时，没有一家银行或金融公司进入道琼斯工业平均指数。一家也没有。但就在那时，华尔街开始大步前进。到 2008 年，就在雷曼兄弟破产之前，金融业占经济的比重超过了 8%——这个数字打破了所有平均值和历史。4那时，道琼斯指数中已有 5 家金融公司，其中之一的美国国际集团 (AIG) 要求政府提供 1500 亿美元的救助，这比新西兰、巴基斯坦、科威特和乌克兰等 200 多个国家的 GDP 总和还要高。5

In less than a year—sparked by the bankruptcy of one company, Lehman Brothers—the vector of the U.S. economy was changed forever. Before this event, the financial sector had been rising as a percentage of GDP at an accelerating rate. Even during the 1960s, a time in which the stock market romped on a long bull run and when Wall Street jobs began gaining a smidge of glamour, the financial sector accounted for less than 4 percent of GDP. In 1982, when quants and programmers first began migrating to Wall Street, not a single bank or financial company had infiltrated the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Not one. But that’s when Wall Street went on a tremendous roll. By 2008, just before the collapse of Lehman, the financial sector accounted for more than 8 percent of the economy—a number defying all averages and history.4 By then, the Dow Jones contained five financial companies, one of which, AIG, commanded a government bailout of $150 billion—bigger than the GDPs of more than two hundred countries, including New Zealand, Pakistan, Kuwait, and Ukraine.5

裁员潮像病毒一样席卷了华尔街。就连那些看似无所不能的量化分析师大军——那些银行和交易公司耗费了巨额精力和金钱才招来的宝贵员工——也都夹着纸箱离开了办公室。从2009年秋季的大部分时间到2009年，华尔街那些招聘数学、科学和工程专业人才最多的公司能否生存下来，一直都存在着巨大的不确定性。

Layoffs hit Wall Street like a virus. Even the seemingly impervious legions of quants, the precious employees who banks and trading houses had spent so much effort and money acquiring, left their offices with cardboard boxes under their arms. For much of the fall and well into 2009, there was genuine uncertainty as to whether Wall Street’s biggest hirers of math, science, and engineering majors would survive.

2008年秋天，康威和他eLoyalty团队像往常一样出现在芝加哥大学的招聘会上，但他立刻注意到了一些不同寻常的事情。“他们都走了，”他说。高盛、摩根大通，所有这些公司都消失了。这些公司不仅停止了招聘，还开始以前所未有的规模大幅削减员工人数。2008年，花旗集团裁员7.3万人；美林证券和美国银行裁员3.5万人；雷曼兄弟的2.3万人全部失业；贝尔斯登的9000名员工没有被摩根大通录用，摩根大通以极低的价格收购了这家投资银行，并在旗下又裁掉了1万人。

In the fall of 2008, when Conway and his crew from eLoyalty made their normal appearance at a University of Chicago recruiting event, he immediately noticed something different. “They were gone,” he says. Goldman, Morgan, all of them. They just disappeared. These companies had not only stopped hiring, they had also begun slashing payroll on a scale never before seen. In 2008, Citigroup cut seventy-three thousand people; Merrill Lynch and Bank of America dropped thirty-five thousand; all of Lehman’s twenty-three thousand people were left jobless; nine thousand of Bear Stearns’s employees weren’t picked up by J.P. Morgan, which bought the investment bank for a pittance and eliminated another ten thousand jobs within its own house.

康威的变化令人震惊。他曾经需要为每一次面试都与顶尖人才竞争，而现在，他拥有了一大批感兴趣的学生。对于曾经与华尔街争夺量化人才的其他经济领域来说，情况也是如此。

The difference for Conway was staggering. Where he once had to battle for each and every interview with a top-notch recruit, now he had a large pool of interested students. The same could be said for all other parts of the economy that once competed with Wall Street for bright quantitative minds.

“我们开始招募以前根本招不到的人才，”Redfin 的首席执行官格伦·凯尔曼回忆道。Redfin 是一家西雅图初创公司，致力于重塑房地产买卖模式，以低于正常的经纪人佣金和主导整个行业的勾结来削减佣金。多年来，凯尔曼一直大声哀叹，我们国家那么多最聪明的人被关在曼哈顿下城或芝加哥环区，用光纤电缆传输的代码片段互相争斗。“他们中的大多数人最终都落得如此下场，真是太疯狂了。想象一下，如果所有这些人才都被释放出来，我们会做什么，”他说。

“We started getting people that we would have never gotten before,” recalls Glenn Kelman, the CEO of Redfin, a Seattle startup that is trying to reshape how we buy and sell real estate, undercutting normal broker commissions and the collusion that dominates the industry. Kelman has lamented out loud for years that so many of our country’s smartest people were being locked up in lower Manhattan or Chicago’s Loop to battle each other with clips of code flowing through fiber-optic cable. “It’s insane that this is where most of them end up. Imagine what we could do if all that talent was freed,” he says.

对康威来说，他的人才确实得到了充分释放。在银行业崩溃后的两年里，eLoyalty 聘请了 60 名算法构建者，壮大了团队，以满足他远大的商业抱负。

For Conway, the talent had indeed been let loose. In the two years following the banking implosion, eLoyalty hired sixty algorithm builders, ramping up his team to fit his lofty business aspirations.

在康威打造个性感知机器人的十年间，eLoyalty 传统的呼叫中心管理工作支撑着公司持续运营。在此期间，这项传统业务占公司 9000 万美元年收入的 60% 甚至更多。这笔资金让康威构建了一个他认为对潜在竞争对手构成不可逾越的壁垒：一个包含两百万个算法的算法库，可以监听、学习并识别机器人听力范围内每个说话的人。康威的机器人如今已经分析了超过 7.5 亿次对话。存储这样的数据堪比谷歌。2011 年，eLoyalty 在明尼阿波利斯建成了一个新的数据中心，拥有一千台服务器，存储着 600 TB 的客户数据（美国国会图书馆的印刷品藏书也需要 10 TB 才能存储）。

During the decade that Conway has been building his personality-sensing bot, eLoyalty’s traditional call center management work kept the ship running. During this period, the legacy business comprised 60 percent or more of the company’s $90 million of annual revenues. It paid for Conway to construct what he views as an impossible barrier to wannabe competitors: a library of two million algorithms that listen, learn, and slot every person who speaks within earshot of the bot. Conway’s bots have now analyzed more than 750 million conversations. Storing such data is a Google-worthy task. In 2011 eLoyalty finished off a new data center in Minneapolis that houses a thousand servers containing six hundred terabytes of customer data (the Library of Congress’s print stash would require ten terabytes to store).

这些机器人的才能远不止解读人格、帮我们与志同道合的人建立联系。它们是反欺诈的利器，随着它们的普及，或许还能抑制全球身份盗窃的泛滥。每三千个客服电话中，就有一个是诈骗电话。在这些对话中，诈骗分子试图从客服人员那里榨取目标用户的个人信息。很多情况下，这些心怀叵测的窃贼只掌握目标用户的一项数据，例如姓名和地址。他们会致电数百家信用卡、银行和保险供应商，希望在通话过程中收集更多信息，最终找到一个可以操纵的账户，为自己牟利。这些电话通常会被转接到俄罗斯、东欧、爱尔兰和非洲的呼叫中心，这些中心专门从事信息和身份盗窃。诈骗电话通常可以通过连续错误回答安全问题，或者在大多数情况下，通过来电者突然挂断电话来识别。

The bots’ talents go beyond reading personalities and connecting us with like-minded people. They’re fraud busters, and as they spread, they may help dampen what has become a global identity theft epidemic. One out of three thousand customer service calls is fraudulent. In these conversations, fraudsters try to milk customer service agents for personal information belonging to a target. In many cases the aspiring thief will only have one piece of a person’s data, such as a name and address. They will make calls to hundreds of credit card, bank, and insurance vendors, hoping to gather more information as they go, and at some point hit upon an account they can manipulate for their own enrichment. These calls often get farmed out to call centers in Russia, Eastern Europe, Ireland, and Africa that are wholly dedicated to stealing information and identities. Fraudulent calls can often be spotted by a continuous string of wrong answers to security questions or, in most cases, the caller hanging up abruptly.

接线员通常会将这些电话标记为疑似诈骗电话，但由于这些电话通常带有伪装的来电显示，因此几乎无法阻止他们拨打数百甚至数千个电话。然而，eLoyalty 机器人的语音识别能力赋予了它们不可思议的反诈骗能力。人的声音就像指纹一样，具有独特的可辨性；它们无法轻易改变，而且它们的音色和声学特性虽然会随着时间的推移略有变化，但却保持着高度的一致性。Conway 的机器人会以电子方式记录并存储呼叫者的声音，并将其存储在主数据库中，并可以在诈骗者声音数据库中快速核对呼叫者的声音。接线员会立即在电脑屏幕上收到匹配通知，并告知该电话很可能是诈骗电话。这些骗子一如既往地试图开发语音合成器来破解 Conway 的工具，但 Conway 表示，他正在开发一种反制方法。

Operators will normally flag these calls as likely fraud attempts, but because the calls often carry disguised caller IDs, there’s little that can be done to prevent them from placing hundreds or even thousands of additional calls. The eLoyalty bots’ speech recognition capability gives them an uncanny ability to thwart fraud, however. People’s voices are as uniquely distinguishable as a human fingerprint; they can’t be easily changed, and their timbre and acoustics, while they change slightly over time, remain incredibly consistent. Conway’s bots electronically record and store their callers’ voices in a master database and can quickly check callers’ voices in the fraudster voice database. Operators are instantly notified on their computer screens of a match and the high likelihood that a call is fraudulent. The crooks, as is their wont, are trying to pioneer voice-altering synthesizers to crack Conway’s tool, but Conway is developing a counterhack, he says.

除了欺诈之外，机器人还在彻底改变恼人的电话销售业务。不同的性格需要不同的销售技巧。不要对那些以想法为主的人软话。要向他们灌输好处、事实、省钱的秘诀，并希望他们能做到。然而，一个以行动为主的人可能会被这样的推销所激励：“如果你现在购买，我还会免费赠送你一个小玩意儿！”对于电话销售员来说，诀窍在于知道该使用什么样的推销方式。培训电话销售员如何识别六种不同的性格，这不太可能是一场有利可图的赌博。但能够在正确的时机用正确的推销方式引导销售人员，却意义非凡。

Beyond fraud, the bots are revolutionizing the annoying business of telesales. Different kinds of personalities require different selling techniques. Don’t soft-talk a thoughts-based person. Feed these people the benefits, the facts, the savings, and hope the chips fall in the right spots. An actions-based person, however, may be well motivated by a pitch that emphasizes, “If you buy right now, I’ll also throw in a second thingamagadget for free!” The trick for the cold caller is knowing what kind of pitch to employ. Training telephone salespeople on the finer points of recognizing six different personalities isn’t likely to be a profitable gamble. But being able to direct salespeople with the right pitch at the right moment is valuable.

以沃达丰 (Vodafone) 为例，该公司也曾尝试利用美国国家航空航天局 (NASA) 开发、康威的 eLoyalty 团队完善的销售方法，充当销售宣传的试验田。这家电信公司的市场营销部门预先设定了接线员推销升级服务的顺序和方式。他们的方法和大多数方法一样，取得了一定的成功，但大多数电话仍然以失败告终。但沃达丰根据潜在客户的个性调整了其宣传和销售顺序。情感型客户会得到亲切的问候和一些有助于他们与亲朋好友保持良好联系的产品的贴心服务。其他性格类型的客户则获得了为他们量身定制的类似计划。结果：销售成功率提高了 8600%。

Consider the experience of Vodafone, which also offered to be the guinea pig for sales pitches based on the methods developed at NASA and perfected by Conway’s eLoyalty team. The telecom company’s marketing department had a predetermined order and way in which their operators were to sell upgrades. Their methods, like most, were moderately successful, but most calls still resulted in strikeouts. But then Vodafone altered its pitches and selling order based on the personality of the potential customer. Emotions-based people would be buttered up with chummy talk and products that offered to keep them in better touch with relatives and friends. Other personality types had similar plans tailored to them. The result: an 8,600 percent increase in sales success.

机器人在商业、服务甚至政治领域（比如自动拨号电话）的潜力显然非常巨大。康威认为这可能是一个价值数十亿美元的大生意。大公司开始看到康威产品的前景；美国几家最大的电信公司在其部分客服席位上使用了他的机器人。六大健康保险公司中有四家也已开始使用该机器人。康威的回报可能是巨大的。他为每个席位每月 175 美元的算法使用费收费，与大公司每个客服席位 5 万美元的总成本相比，这笔费用微不足道。如果像 AT&T 这样的公司将康威的机器人添加到其每个客服席位上，那么年销售额将达到 2 亿美元，是该公司目前销售额的两倍多。

The potential for bots in business, service, and even politics (think robocalls) is clearly huge. Conway believes it could be a multibillion-dollar business. Big companies are starting to see the promise of Conway’s offering; several of the largest telecom companies in the country use his bot in some of their customer service seats. Four of the six largest health insurance companies have started using the bot as well. The rewards for Conway could be enormous. He charges $175 per seat per month for access to his algorithms, a pittance compared to the total cost of $50,000 per customer service seat for big companies. If a company like AT&T were to add Conway’s bot to every one of its customer service chairs, the result would be $200 million in annual sales—more than double what his company pulls in right now.

如果像AT&T这样的公司真的开始将整个呼叫中心迁移到康威的软件（正如许多人现在正在考虑的那样），那么未来我们的许多对话都将由算法操控。如果康威的计划成功，我们可能会发现几乎每个商务电话都在与窃听机器人对话。既然机器人能够带来更高的满意度、更低的成本和更高的客户满意度，为什么还要让客户承受人类同胞反复无常的待遇呢？

If companies like AT&T do start switching over whole call centers to Conway’s software, as many are now contemplating, many of our conversations in the future will be directed by algorithms. If Conway’s plan is successful, we may find ourselves talking to eavesdropping bots on almost every business call. Why leave customers prone to the fickle treatment of their fellow humans when bots can secure more satisfaction, lower costs, and happier customers?

机器人对我们与人类同伴互动的影响远不止于电话交谈。卡珀斯是将这种方法介绍给康威的精神科医生，至今仍在日常工作中使用这些方法。他认为，这项科学在学校和医院等场所拥有更大的潜力，因为师生关系和护理人员与患者关系的有效性，很大程度上受到双方性格所产生的自然融洽或尖锐冲突的影响。机器人可以对患者进行两分钟的快速评估，并将他们与符合类似模式的护士和医生匹配，从而促进更好的沟通，并最终提供更好的护理。同样的道理也适用于课堂，尽管由于学校规模、班级学生人数等因素，这些关系可能更难管理。卡珀斯认为，很大一部分被诊断患有注意力缺陷多动障碍的儿童是反应型人格，他们所处的环境（大型学校）无法提供这类人所需的学习环境——更多的互动、刺激和直接指导。

The effect of bots on our interactions with fellow humans won’t end with phone conversations. Capers, the psychiatrist who introduced Conway to the methods and still works with them on a daily basis, believes that the science has bigger potential in places like schools and hospitals, where the efficacy of teacher-student and caregiver-patient relationships is acutely affected by the natural rapport or prickliness generated by the personalities on each side. Bots could perform quick two-minute assessments of patients and match them with nurses and doctors who fit similar molds, making for better communications and, ultimately, better care. The same thing can be said of the classroom, although those relationships can be harder to manage because of the size of schools, the number of students in a class, and so on. Capers believes that a large percentage of children diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder are reactions-based people placed in settings (large schools) that don’t provide the kind of learning environment—with more interaction, stimulation, and direct instruction—such personalities require.

康威正在探索所有这些途径。在他的机器人征服语音通信领域之后，他的下一个目标是电子邮件。拥有大客户的企业通常双方客户关系都超过三十人。所有这些人都会通过电子邮件、电话和即时消息进行交流。对康威来说，这些交流以及其中包含的文字、想法和信息都是情报。有了这些信息，他可以了解两家公司之间的关系状况。他可以识别出可能只有一方显而易见的紧张点、危及客户关系的业务部门，甚至账户续签的可能性。员工的姓名和他们在电子邮件中输入的实际内容对除了阅读邮件的机器人之外的所有人都是匿名的，这利用了超过十万种算法来解析电子邮件中双方之间的紧张、一致、满意和冲突等信息。康威的算法可以让人们随时了解两家公司之间关系的健康状况，在某些情况下，可以让高管注意到哪些举措损害了或帮助了他们与客户的良好关系。

Conway is looking at all of these avenues. His next target, after his bots conquer the world of voice communications, is e-mail. Businesses with large accounts often have client relationships more than thirty people deep on each side. All of these people trade e-mails, phone calls, and instant messages. To Conway, these exchanges and the words, thoughts, and messages they contain are intel. With it, he can derive the state of a relationship between two companies. He can identify tension points that may only be obvious to one side, business units that are endangering the client relationship, and even the odds that an account will be renewed. Employees’ names and the actual words they’ve typed within e-mails remain anonymous to all but the bot that reads them, putting to use more than 100,000 algorithms to parse e-mails for things like tension, agreement, happiness, and conflict between two parties. Conway’s algorithms provide a peek at the health of a relationship between two companies at any point, allowing executives to note, in some cases, what initiatives hurt or helped their goodwill with clients.

允许雇主（哪怕只是个机器人）查看员工的电子邮件，这听起来不像是大多数员工乐意接受的事情。我们不应忘记，全球最大的电子邮件平台之一——谷歌的Gmail，在搜索我们电子邮件中的关键词并投放相应的广告时，也做了同样的事情。不仅如此，还值得注意的是，法律允许雇主对员工的公司电子邮件账户做任何他们想做的事情——阅读、删除、转发、发布。在这个世界上，那些能够巧妙地设计和利用算法的人正在积累越来越多的权力，我们的未来似乎将充满机器人来评判我们、引导我们、衡量我们。

Allowing one’s e-mails to be surveyed by an employer—even just a bot—doesn’t sound like something most employees would happily accept. We shouldn’t forget that one of the largest e-mail platforms in the world, Google’s Gmail, does the same thing when it searches our e-mails for keywords and serves us corresponding ads. Not only that, but it’s also worth noting that the law allows employers to do anything they wish—read, delete, forward, publish—with their employees’ company e-mail accounts. In a world where an increasing amount of power is being accumulated by those who can fashion and leverage algorithms with skill and finesse, our future looks to be one filled with bots judging us, routing us, and measuring us.

康威的技术一旦盛行，理论上可以限制我们交谈的对象。或许我们只能与那些与我们性格类别相同的人互动。这样的事实意味着使用该软件的公司可以获得更好的盈利，但这对我们的文化和接纳他人的能力意味着什么呢？它可能不会影响这些方面；我们可以通过各种渠道接触到与我们自身不同的人和文化。但将康威机器人的强大功能与科技已经给我们带来的各种分类结合起来，问题就变得更加严重了。

Conway’s technology, were it to take over, could theoretically limit the kind of people we talk to. Perhaps we’d only be allowed to interact with those who share our personality category. Such a fact translates to a better bottom line for companies using the software, but what would it mean for our culture and our capacity to accept others? It may not affect any of these things; exposure to people and cultures unlike our own can be had through any number of conduits. But couple the power of Conway’s bots with the kinds of pigeonholing that technology has already brought to us, and the problem becomes more acute.

表面上看，这种情况听起来不错，但实际上它可能导致不宽容、极端主义和立法僵局。科技帮助我们构建了一个无需走出舒适区的世界，我们可以安坐于志同道合、灵魂相通、观点相投的舒适区。如果一个员工只与同类型的大脑打交道，他将如何应对一个情绪型的新同事？这位员工可能是这个国家最有才华的人之一，但如果他无法与不同性格的人有效沟通，他的职业发展前景将如何？与不同类型的人共事已经是我们日常生活中面临的最具挑战性的事情之一，但它也可能是最有回报的事情之一。康威的使命并没有让他明确反对这种关系，但随着机器人接管人类互动的不同途径，我们必须承认这可能会对我们的世界产生奇怪的副作用。

On the surface, such a condition may sound nice, but in reality it can lead to intolerance, extremism, and legislative stalemate. Technology has helped us build a world in which we needn’t travel beyond our own comfort zone, where we can settle into an easy chair of like minds, souls, and views. If, as a thoughts-based person, an employee is only ever subjected to other brains of the same type, how will he handle a new coworker who is an emotions-based person? This employee may be one of the most talented people in the country at his job, but if he is unable to effectively communicate with people of differing personalities, where will that leave him as a professional? Working with other types of people is already one of the more challenging things we face in day-to-day life, but it can also be one of the most rewarding. Conway’s mission hasn’t sent him explicitly angling against such relationships, but as the bots take over different paths of human interaction, we must acknowledge the possibility of strange side effects on our world.

9

9

华尔街的损失对我们其他人来说是一种收获

WALL STREET’S LOSS IS A GAIN FOR THE REST OF US

他们去硅谷

TO SILICON VALLEY THEY GO

一场金融灾难才将 人才从格林威治、曼哈顿下城、伦敦和芝加哥的牛市、熊市、交易员和量化分析师手中夺走。康威组建了一支由经验丰富的量化人才组成的新团队，科技界的其他领域也纷纷效仿。

IT TOOK A FINANCIAL CATASTROPHE to wrest the talent tide away from the bulls, bears, traders, and quants of Greenwich, lower Manhattan, London, and Chicago. As Conway built new teams with adept quantitative brains, so did the rest of the tech world.

经济领域人才流动的变化引起了不少人的关注。“这几乎是一夜之间发生的，真是令人惊讶，”杜克大学教授维韦克·瓦德瓦说道。他的学生对华尔街的态度在2008年秋季开始转变。更令人欣喜的是，从瓦德瓦的角度来看，他们对科技和工程的兴趣也随之升温。“我相信这正是这些学位的初衷，”他补充道。

The change in brain flow within the economy was noticeable to more than a few. “It was astonishing, what happened almost overnight,” says Vivek Wadhwa, the Duke professor. His students’ attitudes toward Wall Street began changing during the fall of 2008. Even better, from Wadhwa’s point of view, their interest in technology and engineering picked up. “I believe that was the point of these degrees in the first place,” he adds.

毫无疑问，金融业的崩溃改变了经济的走向。但正如任何伟大的故事一样，这个故事也有其他分支。2008年和2009年初华尔街的低谷或许是这出戏的主角，但还有其他更微妙的戏剧在上演。其中一出戏就没那么微妙了：Facebook。马克·扎克伯格于2004年初创办了Facebook，在撰写本文时，他的身价已超过250亿美元。与此同时，他的公司市值已飙升至1000亿美元以上。

There’s little doubt that the collapse of the financial industry changed the course of the economy. But just as with any great story, there are other branches of this tale. Wall Street’s nadir of 2008 and early 2009 may have been the main act onstage, but there were other, more subtle plays taking place. One wasn’t so subtle: Facebook. Mark Zuckerberg launched Facebook in early 2004, and he was at the time of this writing worth more than $25 billion. His company’s value, meanwhile, has soared past $100 billion.

扎克伯格的故事广为人知；使用 Facebook 的人并非技术宅或金融大鳄，而是极其普通的人，其中许多人沉迷于 Facebook 提供的持续更新、新闻和聊天。扎克伯格的故事似乎并非遥不可及；他显然很聪明，但依然保持着普通人的身份。我曾在一次活动中遇到他，当时他开着女友的讴歌掀背车——这辆车轻轻松松就有六年车龄了。相比之下，硅谷其他精英阶层的豪车数量之多，甚至很少有人能达到扎克伯格的 1%。因此，你会看到这样一个故事，无论大学黑客还是高中生，都会深受其影响。谁不想成为那样的人，在宿舍里打造下一个伟大的事业，并且始终脚踏实地？

Zuckerberg’s story is well known; the people who use Facebook aren’t tech nerds or finance guys—they’re exceedingly normal people, many of whom have become addicted to the constant updates, news, and chat that Facebook provides. Zuckerberg’s story seems attainable; he’s clearly smart, but he remains normal. I met him at an event to which he drove his girlfriend’s Acura hatchback—a vehicle that was easily six years old. Compare that with the glitzy car stables belonging to much of the rest of the Silicon Valley elite, few of whom have collected a fortune even 1 percent of Zuckerberg’s, and you’re left with a story that affects college hackers and high schoolers alike. Who wouldn’t want to be that guy, to build the next big thing from a dorm room and stay incredibly grounded throughout?

扎克伯格所需要的只是如何编写代码和如何构建算法的知识。电影《社交网络》是Facebook 崛起的缩影，其中的一个场景已深深印在数百万未来算法编写者、数学专业学生和程序员的脑海中：扎克伯格的角色向他的好友爱德华多·萨维林询问萨维林用来对国际象棋选手进行排名的算法。扎克伯格想用这个算法对哈佛大学的女生进行排名。萨维林在窗玻璃上潦草地写下了这个看起来很复杂的方程式，这时响起了一些时髦的音乐，扎克伯格点头说：“我们来写吧。” 随后，这两位哈佛男孩开始着手在六年内打造一家价值 1000 亿美元的公司。在窗户上潦草地写下算法的这一刻可能从未发生过—— 《社交网络》如果不是夸张的话就什么都不是——但对于许多精明的年轻黑客来说，这仍然是一个标志性的场景和创造的神话。

All Zuckerberg needed was the knowledge of how to code and how to construct an algorithm. A scene from the movie The Social Network, a profile of Facebook’s rise, has been singed into the brains of millions of future algorithm writers, math majors, and programmers: Zuckerberg’s character asks his buddy, Eduardo Saverin, for an algorithm Saverin used to rank chess players. Zuckerberg wanted to use the algorithm to rank girls at Harvard. Saverin scribbles the complex-looking equation onto a windowpane, some hipster music kicks in, and Zuckerberg nods: “Let’s write it.” The Harvard boys then set to work building a $100 billion company in six years. This moment, the scrawling of the algorithm on the window, may never have happened—The Social Network was nothing if not hyperbolic—but it’s still an iconic scene and a myth of creation for many savvy young hackers.

Facebook 在将人才从华尔街吸引到西海岸方面功不可没，但近年来许多其他成功案例的成就甚至超过了最伟大的金融工程师所能给出的任何答案。看看 Twitter、Groupon、Square、Dropbox、Zynga 和 YouTube 等等。此外，还有数十家公司，例如 Tellme Networks、Tacoda、Zimbra 等等，你可能从未听说过，但它们在被收购时的价格却高达 2.5 亿至 9 亿美元。大学生已经注意到了这一趋势，美国工程和计算机科学院校的入学人数在经历了多年的下滑之后终于开始回升。正如瓦德瓦所指出的，最优秀的学生不再执着于华尔街。

Facebook deserves more credit than any other company for helping to swing the momentum of minds from Wall Street to the West Coast, but many other success stories in recent years have beaten anything even the greatest financial engineer can offer. Look at Twitter, Groupon, Square, Dropbox, Zynga, and YouTube, among a bevy of others. Then there are dozens of names, such as Tellme Networks, Tacoda, Zimbra, and others, that you may never have heard of but that still fetched prices of $250 million to $900 million each when they were acquired. College students have noticed this trend, and the engineering and computer science schools of the country have seen their enrollment finally begin to tick up after years of decline. As Wadhwa noted, the best students are no longer fixated on Wall Street.

对于拥有多种选择的量化人才来说，他们在职业决策中始终面临的压力在于：我是应该接受华尔街那份稳赚不赔的薪水——起薪25万美元，外加或许同样丰厚的奖金——还是应该搬到一个配备啤酒机和乒乓球桌的办公室，挥杆打球，争取在科技行业永垂不朽？如今，即使是经验丰富的华尔街从业者，天平也正在向科技行业倾斜。

For quantitative minds with options, the tension within their career decisions has always been, do I take the guaranteed money on Wall Street—with starting salaries of $250,000 plus a bonus perhaps just as valuable—or do I move to an office with a kegerator and a ping-pong table while I swing for the fences of tech immortality? The scales are now tipping toward tech, even for experienced Wall Street hands.

普尼特·梅塔曾是花旗资本市场的技术高级副总裁，年薪约为 40 万美元。2010 年，31 岁的他放弃了华尔街的职业生涯，投身创业。“我曾经问过自己：我真的在这里创造了什么吗？”梅塔说。他解释说，华尔街存在的目的只有一个：介入每一笔金融交易。在花旗之前，梅塔曾在美林证券和摩根大通编写代码。在华尔街，他一直只是一个中间人，尽管收入不菲，但这曾让他夜不能寐。他开始从事一个业余项目，一款名为 MyCityWay 的应用程序，该应用程序可以帮助城市居民轻松导航餐馆、电影院、酒吧、交通等任何影响他们日常生活的地方。在为花旗编写代码达到极限后，梅塔辞职并无偿开发他的应用程序。他和他的联合创始人现在拥有50名员工，他们的应用程序已在70个城市上线，其中30个位于海外。他们已经筹集了600万美元的风险投资，梅塔说他每周都会和至少一位工程师交谈，他们表示再也不会回到华尔街了。

Puneet Mehta was a senior vice president of technology at Citi Capital Markets, a position that paid about $400,000 a year, when in 2010, at age thirty-one, he chucked his Wall Street career for startup life. “I used to ask myself: am I really building something here?” Mehta says. Wall Street, he explains, exists to do one thing: get in between every single financial transaction it can. Before Citi, Mehta wrote code at Merrill Lynch and J.P. Morgan. The fact that on Wall Street all he would ever be was a middleman, albeit a well-paid middleman, used to keep him up at night. He began working on a side project, an app called MyCityWay, which allows urban dwellers to easily navigate restaurants, movie theaters, bars, traffic—anything that affects their life every day. When he reached his limit of writing code for Citi, Mehta quit and worked unpaid on his app. He and his cofounders now have fifty employees and their app has been released in seventy cities, thirty of them overseas. They’ve raised $6 million in venture capital, and Mehta says he talks to at least one other engineer every week who says they’re never going back to Wall Street.

“以前招这些人很难，”他说，“现在他们愿意来了。”

“It used to be hard to hire these people,” he says. “Now they want to come.”

安德鲁·蒙塔伦蒂（Andrew Montalenti）本不必被赶出摩根士丹利。他在华尔街做了三年黑客，却一直想着：“我从来没想过自己是在解决真正的问题。” 2009年3月，他离开了摩根士丹利。

Andrew Montalenti didn’t need to be shoved out the door of Morgan Stanley. He just left in March of 2009 after spending three years as a hacker on Wall Street and thinking, “I never got the idea I was solving real problems.”

2006年，蒙塔伦蒂在纽约大学计算机科学专业读大四，当时他正值半毕业，于是接受了摩根大通的一份工作。这家投行给了他1万美元的签约奖金，并规定他9月份就可以开始工作。蒙塔伦蒂说，这让他更容易接受了这份工作。所有新员工都对用摩根大通的钱在夏天游历欧洲或南美、无忧无虑的想法爱不释手。这听起来还不错。蒙塔伦蒂终于开始工作时，22岁的他年薪已经达到10万美元。有一次，他环顾四周的同事，其中一些人比他大15到20岁，心想：“这不可能成为我毕生的事业。” 于是，他辞职并联合创办了Parse.ly，该公司的算法为出版网站（例如《大西洋月刊》和《美国新闻与世界报道》）提供细致入微的深度分析，这两家公司都是他们的客户。“我们帮助的是编辑和记者，”他说。 “我无法想象做其他任何事情。”

Montalenti accepted a job at Morgan in 2006 halfway through his senior year at NYU, where he majored in computer science. The investment bank gave him a $10,000 signing bonus and a September start date, which Montalenti says made taking the job that much easier. All of the new recruits fall in love with the idea of spending the summer traveling through Europe or South America on Morgan’s money, without a care in the world. It’s not a bad pitch. When he finally started his job, Montalenti was making $100,000 at twenty-two years of age. At some point he looked around at his colleagues, some of whom were fifteen to twenty years older than him, and said, “This can’t be my life’s work.” He quit and cofounded Parse.ly, whose algorithms put together nuanced and in-depth analytics for publishing Web sites like those for the Atlantic and U.S. News and World Report, both of which are clients. “We’re helping editors and journalists,” he says. “I can’t imagine doing anything else.”

杰弗里·哈默巴赫（Jeffrey Hammerbacher）面临的难题，与梅塔、蒙塔伦蒂以及成千上万其他工程师在毕业时面临的困境如出一辙。2005年，哈默巴赫即将从哈佛大学数学系毕业，却做出了一个看似轻而易举的决定：进军华尔街。

Jeffrey Hammerbacher faced exactly the conundrum that Mehta, Montalenti, and thousands of other engineers confront when graduating. Hammerbacher was finishing up at Harvard with a math degree in 2005 when he made what seemed to be the easy choice to head to Wall Street.

哈默巴赫在密歇根长大，父亲是通用汽车的流水线工人。高中时，他写诗技艺娴熟，投掷弧线球也足够灵巧，以至于密歇根大学想让他加入棒球队。但他最终选择了哈佛大学，一开始主修英语，后来顺利地转到了数学专业。大学生活对他来说并不那么有趣。哈默巴赫一度辍学回家，在通用汽车的一家装配厂工作，后来母亲的惊慌让他又回到了哈佛。

Hammerbacher grew up in Michigan, the son of a General Motors assembly line worker. As a high school student, he composed poetry with a deft touch and snapped off curveballs with enough guile that the University of Michigan wanted him for its baseball squad. But he picked Harvard, where he started as an English major, later hopscotching, without a hitch, to math. College had difficulty entertaining him. At one point, Hammerbacher dropped out and headed home to work in a GM assembly plant before his mother’s consternation propelled him back to Harvard.

毕业后，哈默巴赫的华尔街之路因女友已经搬到纽约而变得更加清晰。“每个人都知道华尔街需要量化人才——他们大量招募哈佛大学数学系的学生，”他解释道。

Upon graduation, Hammerbacher’s path to Wall Street was made even clearer by the fact that his girlfriend had already moved to New York. “Everybody knew that Wall Street needed quantitative people—they recruited the math department at Harvard heavily,” he explains.

哈默巴赫并不热衷于成为分析衍生品的量化分析师，编写下一个伟大的交易算法。所以，那年夏天，当他和女友在纽约团聚时，他计划秋季在纽约大学攻读数学博士学位。为了打发时间赚点钱，他在贝尔斯登公司做了暑期实习生。

Hammerbacher wasn’t keen on becoming some quant analyzing derivatives and writing the next great trading algorithm. So when he joined his girlfriend in the city that summer, he had plans to start a math PhD at NYU in the fall. To kill time and make some money, he took an internship at Bear Stearns for the summer.

正如华尔街经常发生的那样，一枚小小的金币就能带来更多回报，哈默巴赫放弃了攻读博士学位的计划，全职加入贝尔斯登。他发现自己置身于贝尔斯登量化抵押贷款机器的心脏地带，这台机器孜孜不倦地研究算法和数据，以支撑他们在房地产市场的众多仓位。房地产繁荣为整个华尔街带来了丰厚的利润，贝尔斯登热情地抓住了这个机会，组建了一小队编程工程师和数学专家，他们不断构建模型，而这些模型在大多数情况下仍然支持着那个如今我们才意识到是多么愚蠢的想法：从经纪人、银行和中间商那里购买更多抵押贷款。正如格雷戈里·扎克曼的《史上最伟大的交易》和迈克尔·刘易斯的《大空头》等书中所记载的那样，贝尔斯登购买的这些抵押贷款被切碎，与华尔街的明胶混合，重新包装成形状完美的楔形，可以轻松地出售给养老基金、外国银行以及毫无戒心的百万富翁和亿万富翁。

As happens so often on Wall Street, one little gold piece led to the promise of more, and Hammerbacher dropped his doctorate plans and signed on full-time with Bear. He found himself inside the churning heart of Bear’s quantitative mortgage machine that worked tirelessly on algorithms and data crunching to support their myriad positions in the housing market. The housing boom had proven fantastically lucrative for all of Wall Street, and Bear, seizing that opportunity with gusto, had a small army of programming engineers and math savants cranking away on models that in most cases continued to back the now-we-realize-how-stupid-it-was idea of buying more mortgages from brokers, banks, and middlemen. As has been well chronicled in books such as Gregory Zuckerman’s The Greatest Trade Ever and Michael Lewis’s The Big Short, these mortgages that Bear bought were chopped up, mixed with Wall Street’s version of gelatin, and repackaged into perfectly shaped wedges that could easily be sold to pension funds, foreign banks, and unsuspecting millionaires and billionaires.

哈默巴赫加入了贝尔斯登抵押贷款部门的量化分析师团队，通过随机微积分、回归模型和长期动态算法，帮助贝尔斯登找到了如何有效对冲房地产市场风险的方法。然而，短短九个月后，哈默巴赫就厌倦了这份工作，并于2006年离职。这一举动颇具先见之明，因为一年后，贝尔斯登的两只对冲基金开始显露出疲态，这两只基金深陷次贷市场，濒临破产。哈默巴赫离职仅仅24个月后，贝尔斯登就彻底倒闭了，公司资产以低价被抵押给摩根大通。

Hammerbacher joined the quants working the mortgage desk at Bear and helped figure out, through stochastic calculus, regression models, and long, dynamic algorithms, how to properly hedge Bear’s housing market risk. Hammerbacher tired of the game after a short nine months, however, and left in 2006. It was a prescient move, as Bear began showing weaknesses a year later as a pair of its hedge funds, heavily entrenched in the subprime mortgage market, began teetering toward insolvency. Bear would disappear altogether just twenty-four months after Hammerbacher quit, the firm’s assets hocked to J.P. Morgan at rummage sale prices.

贝尔的量化操作——其数学和编程工作被操纵，用于支持我们现在看到的巨额抵押贷款支持证券——让哈默巴赫心生厌恶。如果他不打算在学术界的结构化环境中继续深造，他肯定不想把时间浪费在这上面。

The gears of Bear’s quant operations, whose math and programming work had been manipulated into endorsing what, we now can see, was an insane volume of mortgage-backed securities, had turned Hammerbacher off. If he wasn’t going to pursue further learning within the structured setting of academia, he surely didn’t want to waste his time on this.

2006年春天，马克·扎克伯格通过一位哈佛朋友联系上了以数学天赋闻名的哈默巴赫。一周后，哈默巴赫搬到了加州。他是Facebook的早期员工——最早的百名员工之一——扎克伯格授予他“研究科学家”这个高大上的头衔。哈默巴赫的工作是运用数学和算法，分析人们如何使用Facebook，并按年龄、性别、地点和收入进行细分，以及Facebook为何在某些地方蓬勃发展，而在其他地方却惨败。哈默巴赫由此成为了Facebook的数据之王。

Through a Harvard friend in the spring of 2006, Mark Zuckerberg reached out to Hammerbacher, who was well known for his math prowess. A week later, Hammerbacher was relocating to California. He was an early employee at Facebook—one of the first hundred—and Zuckerberg gave him the fancy title of research scientist. It was Hammerbacher’s job to use math and algorithms to figure out how people were using Facebook, broken down by age, gender, location, and income, and why Facebook thrived in some places and flopped in others. Hammerbacher had been made king of Facebook’s data.

扎克伯格之所以聘请哈默巴赫，是因为该公司迫切需要处理那些即将超过其存储容量的海量数据。这家新兴公司知道这些数据很有价值，但却不知道该如何处理。近二十年来，华尔街早已知道如何处理如此海量的数据：存储、分类、细分，并寻找其中的模式、异常和趋势，从而从中获利。

Zuckerberg tapped Hammerbacher because the company was desperate to get a handle on the mounds of data that threatened to overtake its storage capacity. The nascent company knew the data was valuable, but it wasn’t sure what to do with it. Wall Street has known what to do with such quantities of data for nearly two decades: store it, sort it, chop it, and look for patterns, anomalies, and trends that can be ridden to profit.

尽管华尔街拥有强大的数据整理能力，但它从未面临过像哈默巴赫在西海岸那样巨大的数据压力。Facebook 的原始数据海量，让纽约证券交易所及其高频交易平台的庞大数据中心都黯然失色。Facebook 系统拥有近 10 亿用户，该公司为每个用户存储了多达一千页的数据，包括你使用的电脑类型、你的政治观点、你的恋爱关系、你的宗教信仰、上次居住地、信用卡信息、工作信息、收藏链接、家庭信息，以及数量最多的照片信息。1更不用说我们的浏览习惯或 Facebook 庞大的广告基础设施了。

For all of Wall Street’s data-sorting muscle, it’s never faced a mountain like that which confronted Hammerbacher on the West Coast. Facebook’s raw information piles make the grand datacenters of the NYSE and its high-frequency trading shops look quaint. For every one of the nearly one billion users in Facebook’s system, the company stores up to a thousand pages of data, including the type of computer you use, your political views, your love relationships, your religion, last location, credit cards, job, favorite links, family, and, most voluminously, your photos.1 That’s to say nothing of our browsing habits or Facebook’s vast advertisement infrastructure.

Facebook 的第一个数据中心位于俄勒冈州的普赖恩维尔，致力于为其用户提供服务。用户每天在 Facebook 上花费的时间总计超过一百亿分钟，每秒浏览一百五十万张照片，每天产生三十兆字节的数据。Facebook 在北卡罗来纳州还拥有两个庞大的数据中心，并且正在瑞典吕勒奥北极圈边缘建造另一个数据中心，这也是其在美国境外的第一个数据中心。寒冷的气候将有助于冷却数千个计算机处理器，并降低能源费用。这三座建筑计划于 2014 年投入使用，占地面积相当于十六个足球场。哈默巴赫在加入 Facebook 之前还只是华尔街量化投资机器中的一个齿轮，但现在他被派来驯服这个世界。

Facebook’s first data center, in Prineville, Oregon, helps serve its users, who collectively spend more than ten billion minutes on the site each day while consuming one and a half million photos each second and generating thirty terabytes of data daily. Facebook also has two mammoth datacenters in North Carolina and is beginning construction on yet another, its first outside the United States, on the edge of the Arctic Circle in Lulea, Sweden. The frigid climate will help cool the thousands of computer processors and keep energy bills down. The three buildings, scheduled to come online in 2014, will cover an area equal to sixteen football fields. This is the world that Hammerbacher, who shortly before arriving was just another cog in the Wall Street quant machine, was brought in to tame.

哈默巴赫把他在华尔街学到的一切带到了Facebook位于硅谷的办公室。他组建了一支由和他本人一样的精英组成的团队；其中一些人对华尔街感到厌倦，是从摩根士丹利、骑士交易公司和高盛等其他顶级公司挖来的。Facebook需要知道如何最好地组织其页面，如何保持人们的联系，以及最重要的是，如何尽可能地留住用户。“我在那里是为了回答这些高层次的问题，但他们当时还没有任何工具来做到这一点，”谈到自己的聘用时，哈默巴赫说道。2

Hammerbacher brought all that he learned on Wall Street to Facebook’s Silicon Valley offices. He built a team stocked with thoroughbreds much like himself; some of them, having grown fed up on Wall Street, were plucked from other gold-plated firms like Morgan Stanley, Knight Trading, and Goldman Sachs. Facebook needed to know how to best arrange its pages, how to keep people connected, and, most important, how to keep people on its site as much as possible. “I was there to answer these high level questions, and they didn’t have any tools to do that yet,” he said of his hiring.2

哈默巴赫开发的工具和算法至今仍在监控着每天每小时涌入Facebook的海量数据。Facebook之所以对网民如此“粘性”和难以抗拒，部分原因在于哈默巴赫构建了系统来追踪用户的鼠标点击、光标游走的位置，以及什么样的页面布局能够吸引最多人并停留最长时间。所有这些点击、眼球和光标数据都经过筛选和检验。那些被证明最有粘性的数据会被留下，其余的则被扔进了数字垃圾箱。

Hammerbacher built the tools and the algorithms that still monitor the unimaginable amount of data pouring into Facebook every hour of every day. Part of the reason that Facebook has proven so “sticky” and irresistible to Web surfers is because Hammerbacher built systems to track people’s mouse clicks, where their cursors stray, and what page arrangements hook the largest number of people for the longest amount of time. All of this click, eyeball, and cursor data gets strained, sifted, and examined. The stuff that proves stickiest stays; the rest goes into the digital dustbin.

Facebook 表示，其一半用户每天至少登录一次。除了电子邮件平台之外，没有任何平台能做到这一点。事实证明，这家社交网站如此容易让人上瘾，以至于网上流传着一个表情包，上面画着一个装满蓝色液体的透明注射器，并配上白色的 Facebook 标志。或许没有比这更好的比喻来形容当前互联网公司的蓬勃发展，以及它们如何巧妙地从如此众多的用户那里获取如此多的时间。拥有近乎数十亿的忠实用户，使得销售可以根据性别、收入、地理位置等因素进行定位的广告变得更加容易，也更加有利可图。

Facebook says half of its users log in at least once a day. Nothing outside of e-mail platforms can make similar claims. The social networking site has proven so addictive that a meme circulating the Web features a clear syringe filled with blue liquid and adorned with the white Facebook logo. There may not be a better metaphor to describe the current surge of Internet companies and their brilliance in commanding so much time from so many people. Having a nearly captive audience of billions makes it all the easier, and lucrative, to sell ads that can be targeted by sex, income, geography, and more.

Facebook 可以告知潜在客户其用户的倾向、人际关系、愿望和爱好。大多数网络公司给广告商提供的是钝棍，而 Facebook 给他们的是外科医生的手术刀。精准定位广告已成为 Facebook 业务的引擎——而这一切的实现都源于一位华尔街量化分析师从黑暗势力叛逃。哈默巴赫移居西方并非因为缺乏金钱、地位或自尊，而是出于无聊，以及一种总觉得应该有更重要的事情可以做的感觉。他完全认同 Facebook 连接世界的精神。但即使是这项工作，在他眼里也变得越来越不重要了。“我们这一代最聪明的人都在思考如何让人们点击广告，”他喜欢这么说。“这太糟糕了。”

Facebook can tell prospective clients its users’ tendencies, relationships, desires, and hobbies. Where most of the Web hands advertisers a blunt club, Facebook gives them a surgeon’s scalpel. Minutely targeted advertising has become the engine of Facebook’s business—and it became possible when a Wall Street quant defected from the dark side. Hammerbacher didn’t migrate west for lack of money, status, or pride, but out of boredom and a general feeling that there had to be something more important he could be doing. He bought fully into the Facebook ethos of connecting the world. But even this work became, in his eyes, less and less important. “The best minds of my generations are thinking about how to make people click ads,” he likes to say. “That sucks.”

在 Facebook 工作两年后，哈默巴赫离开了。如果我们假设扎克伯格的公司将硅谷的标准规则应用于所有员工福利方案——这是一个安全的假设——那么哈默巴赫需要在公司工作四年才能获得全部的既定权利。这意味着，到他离开时，他只积累了 Facebook 在他作为公司早期员工签约时分配给他的股份的一半。因此，哈默巴赫的辞职很可能让他留下了数千万美元的保证金。对此，他打趣道：“这简直是毁灭财富的恶劣行为。”3

After two years at Facebook, Hammerbacher left. If we’re to assume that Zuckerberg’s company applies the standard rules of the Valley to all of its employee benefits packages—a safe assumption—then Hammerbacher would need four years at the company to earn his full vesting rights. That means that by the time he left, he’d only accumulated half of the shares Facebook allotted to him when he signed on as one of the company’s early employees. So by quitting, Hammerbacher likely left behind tens of millions of dollars that were guaranteed to him. About that, he quipped, “An egregious act of wealth destruction.”3

作为全球最大用户群数据的整理者，哈默巴赫以黑客和数学天才而闻名。离开Facebook后，他毫不费力地在Accel Partners（一家硅谷精英风险投资公司，也是Facebook的早期投资者）找到了一份入驻企业家的职位。但一个月后，哈默巴赫就退出了风险投资圈。

As the guy who organized the data of the largest user base on the planet, Hammerbacher is a known quantity as a hacker and math mind. Following his Facebook exit, he had no problem finding a position as an entrepreneur-in-residence at Accel Partners, an elite Silicon Valley venture capital firm and an early investor in Facebook. But Hammerbacher quit the VC scene after a month.

在Facebook积累了一些财富和视野后，哈默巴赫退一步审视科技界。什么才能真正改变世界？他意识到，答案是一把通用的铲子，可以挖掘数字化和计算机化世界产生的海量数据：数据。哈默巴赫希望构建一种操作系统，用于整理和浏览网站、公用事业公司、生物研究人员和医疗保健提供商产生的错综复杂的数据集。顿悟后不久，他创立了Cloudera。哈默巴赫希望他的平台能够像游戏公司那样，帮助癌症研究人员确定如何通过适量的“购买”按钮来服务用户。硅谷认为他有所成就；哈默巴赫和Cloudera的其他创始人已经筹集了7600万美元的风险投资，对于一家如此年轻的软件公司来说，这是一个巨大的数字。

Having amassed some wealth and perspective at Facebook, Hammerbacher took a step back and surveyed the tech world. What could really, truly change the world? The answer, he realized, was a kind of general spade for digging through what the digital and computerized world produces in such copious quantities: data. Hammerbacher wanted to build a kind of operating system for sorting and swimming through labyrinthine sets of data produced by Web sites, utility companies, biology researchers, and health care providers. Shortly after having this epiphany, he founded Cloudera. Hammerbacher wants his platform to be as applicable for a cancer researcher as it is for a game company determining how to serve users with just the right amount of “buy” buttons. The Valley thinks he’s on to something; Hammerbacher and the rest of the Cloudera founders have raised $76 million in venture capital, an outsized number for a software company so young.

哈默巴赫是众多从曼哈顿下城迁至硅谷的创业者之一，他们致力于将华尔街式的数据融合融入我们的日常生活。投资银行和贸易公司已经学会了如何将数据矿山打造成抵御竞争的壁垒，如今，硅谷也正在建立类似的防御体系。“Facebook 掌握的关于你点击流的信息比你好友照片的信息还要多，”Redfin 首席执行官格伦·凯尔曼说道。“那些已经形成规模的网站正在学习如何超越其他所有网站，因为它们拥有可供优化的数据。”

Hammerbacher is one of a troupe that has shifted from lower Manhattan to Silicon Valley to help inject Wall Street–style data mashing into our everyday lives. Investment banks and trading houses learned to build their data mines into ramparts that can ward off competition, and now these kinds of defenses are being erected in Silicon Valley. “Facebook has more information about your clickstream than it does of photos of your friends,” says Glenn Kelman, Redfin’s CEO. “Web sites that have built scale are learning to dominate all others because they’re the ones with the data to optimize.”

Zynga 由马克·平卡斯 (Mark Pincus) 于 2007 年创立，旗下拥有风靡一时的游戏《FarmVille》。凭借《FarmVille》，Zynga 的市值已达 200 亿美元，用户超过 2 亿。4

Zynga, which makes the ubiquitous FarmVille game, was founded in 2007 by Mark Pincus. On the back of FarmVille, it has grown to be worth $20 billion, with more than 200 million users.4

Zynga 的数据堆栈如此厚实细致，以至于它已经开发出各种方法，能够以最恰当的方式刺激不同类型的用户，让他们掏钱。该公司每天收集大约 600 亿个数据点，知道哪些玩家最容易被十分钟的免费游戏吸引，然后被催促着掏出信用卡；哪些玩家可以被胁迫购买昂贵的虚拟附加组件，例如豪华拖拉机、谷仓和动物群。Zynga 的销售业绩及其数据储备就是明证。Kelman 计划为 Redfin 做同样的事情，Redfin 通过其网站（以及不收取佣金的经纪人）来协助大部分购房流程，而不是通过房地产经纪人，后者的唯一动机就是成交，无论交易好坏。Netflix 已经投入数百万美元来完善其推荐电影的算法。Kelman 指出，与分析影响购房的因素相比，分析决定一个人电影偏好的因素要容易得多。 “如果你看了一部烂电影，你就浪费了一个周五晚上，”他说，“如果你买错了房子，它会影响你的生活。”

Zynga’s data stack is so thick and detailed that it has developed methods of how to best prod and poke different kinds of users in just the right way to get them to open their wallets. The company collects some sixty billion data points every day and knows which players are best hooked with ten minutes of free play before being prodded for a credit card, and which ones can be coerced into buying expensive virtual add-ons like fancy tractors, barns, and animal herds. The proof is in Zynga’s sales and its data hoard. Kelman plans on doing the same thing for Redfin, which facilitates much of the house-buying process through its Web site (and agents that don’t work on commission) rather than through real estate agents whose only motivation is a sale, no matter how good or bad the deal. Netflix has spent millions honing its algorithms that recommend what movies people should watch. Kelman points out that sorting the factors determining a person’s preference of movie is easy when compared with sorting those affecting the purchase of a house. “If you watch a bad movie, you blew a Friday night,” he says. “If you buy the wrong house, it can affect your life.”

2012年初，Kelman刚刚成功招募五位常春藤盟校的量化黑客加入西雅图的Redfin。其中两位来自全球最大的对冲基金桥水基金。拒绝桥水基金的情况并不常见；在那里工作几年，你就很有可能成为百万富翁。或许，唯一比拒绝文艺复兴科技公司（Renaissance Technologies）的工作更疯狂的事情莫过于拒绝。这家位于长岛的公司拥有众多高水平的工程和物理学博士，其仰慕者们喜欢称其为“全球最佳物理系”。然而，在硅谷的创业加速器Y Combinator，我遇到了伊格纳西奥·塞耶（Ignacio Thayer），他除了拥有其他显著的成就外，还是我认识的唯一一位拒绝文艺复兴科技公司的人。塞耶在斯坦福大学攻读计算机科学博士学位时，曾接受这家对冲基金的面试并获得了录用。在此之前，他曾在谷歌从事统计翻译工作四年。塞耶放弃了对冲基金的资金，甚至完成了他的博士学位，创办了 ReadyForZero 网站，该网站通过使用机器人每月根据利率、余额和用户的行为历史指导用户应该首先偿还哪些债务，从而帮助消费者更快地偿还债务。

In early 2012, Kelman had just successfully recruited five Ivy League quant-hackers to join Redfin in Seattle. Two of them came from Bridgewater, the largest hedge fund in the world. Turning down Bridgewater is something that doesn’t often happen; a few years there and you have a very real chance to be a millionaire. The only thing crazier, perhaps, would be to turn down a job at Renaissance Technologies. The Long Island operation is so full of high-level engineering and physics PhDs that admirers like to call it the “best physics department in the world.” But at Y Combinator, the startup accelerator in Silicon Valley that continually draws in elite hacker talent, I met Ignacio Thayer, who, among other notable achievements, is the only person I’ve known to turn down Renaissance. Thayer had been a PhD candidate in computer science at Stanford when he interviewed with and was offered a job by the hedge fund. Before that, he had spent four years working on statistical translations for Google. Thayer eschewed hedge fund money and even finishing his PhD to start ReadyForZero, a Web site that helps consumers pay down their debts faster by employing bots that direct users, every month, on which debts should be paid first based on interest rates, balances, and the behavioral history of the user.

文艺复兴公司是金融界量化精英人才最集中的公司，如果员工在公司工作几年以上，几乎可以保证获得数百万甚至数千万美元的薪水。员工（而不是其他人）可以进入文艺复兴公司的大奖章基金，该基金自 20 世纪 90 年代初成立以来，收益高达 30% 甚至更高。大奖章基金采用算法交易数百万股股票，正如创始人吉姆·西蒙斯所说，“任何会动的东西”。按照它的历史速度，大奖章基金可以在短短二十年内将 10 万美元变成 2000 多万美元。当那些极其聪明、精于算计的人开始拒绝文艺复兴的财富，转而选择硅谷不确定的结果时，钟摆已经正式 100% 地摆离了华尔街。

An employee of Renaissance, the highest concentration of elite quantitative talent in the financial world, is virtually guaranteed several million dollars, if not tens of millions, if they stay on for more than a few years. Employees—and nobody else—get access to Renaissance’s Medallion Fund, which has famously racked up 30 percent or better gains since its inception in the early 1990s. The Medallion Fund employs algorithms trading millions of shares of, as founder Jim Simons puts it, “anything that moves.” At its historical pace the Medallion Fund would turn $100,000 into more than $20 million in just twenty years. When exceedingly smart, calculating people begin turning down Renaissance riches for undetermined outcomes in Silicon Valley, the pendulum has officially swung 100 percent away from Wall Street.

“以前，如果你上了哈佛或耶鲁，就想成为金融巨头，”凯尔曼说，“但现在每个人都想成为扎克伯格。”

“It used to be if you went to Harvard or Yale, you wanted to be a finance titan,” Kelman says. “But now everybody wants to be a Zuckerberg.”

华尔街造成的损害

THE DAMAGE WROUGHT BY WALL STREET

如果没有硅谷及其软件机器人，我们的经济会怎样？2008年至2011年的经济形势虽然糟糕，但如果没有硅谷持续不断的创新，情况会更加糟糕。如果华尔街没有长期吸纳我们国家如此多的技术人才——以及他们构建的算法——我们的情况可能会更好。

Where would our economy be without Silicon Valley and its software bots? As bad as the economy looked in 2008–2011, it would be far worse without the string of innovation that the Valley has continually dished out. We could likely even be better off had Wall Street not been sucking up so much of our country’s technical talent—and the algorithms they built—for so long.

考夫曼基金会2011年的一项研究揭示了20世纪80年代、90年代和21世纪初金融业蓬勃发展与理工科毕业生创业率下降之间的关系。事实上，自20世纪80年代初华尔街开始疯狂抢夺技术人才以来，经验丰富的工程师创业率下降了60%以上。5

A 2011 study by the Kaufmann Foundation draws a relationship between a burgeoning financial sector during the 1980s, 1990s, and 2000s and a drop in the rate at which science and engineering graduates become entrepreneurs. The rate among experienced engineers, in fact, dropped by more than 60 percent since the early 1980s, when Wall Street started snatching up technical minds as fast as it could.5

作者 Paul Kedrosky 和 ​​Dane Stangler 写道：

The authors, Paul Kedrosky and Dane Stangler, write:

 

 

金融服务业过去曾以聘用渴望成功、充满热情的年轻高中和大学毕业生为荣，并计划在销售、交易、研究和投资银行领域对他们进行在职培训。尽管这种做法仍在继续，只是数量有所减少，但现在的不同之处在于，该行业的大部分利润来自复杂产品的创造、销售和交易，例如在近期金融危机中扮演核心角色的担保债务凭证（CDO）。这些新产品需要大量的金融工程，通常需要招聘理科、工科、数学和物理专业的硕士和博士毕业生。他们的才能使他们非常适合设计这些复杂的金融工具，而他们的起薪往往是他们留在本专业领域、寻求更切实的社会效益工作的五倍甚至更多。

The financial services industry used to consider it a point of pride to hire hungry and eager young high school and college graduates, planning to train them on the job in sales, trading, research, and investment banking. While that practice continues, even if in smaller numbers, the difference now is that most of the industry’s profits come from the creation, sales, and trading of complex products, like the collateralized debt obligations (CDOs) that played a central role in the recent financial crisis. These new products require significant financial engineering, often entailing the recruitment of master’s- and doctoral-level new graduates of science, engineering, math, and physics programs. Their talents have made them well-suited to the design of these complex instruments, in return for which they often make starting salaries five times or more what their salaries would have been had they stayed in their own fields and pursued employment with more tangible societal benefits.

作者指出，世界上最重要的创新并非通常来自通用电气和微软这样的巨头。它们往往来自专注于某一领域的创业者，而这种专注的程度是大公司无法比拟的。大多数大公司认为，他们的时间最好花在提高现有产品和流程的效率上。一家市值1000亿美元的公司，仅仅将效率提高5%，就能带来50亿美元的额外收入；很少有新产品能带来同样的提升。正因如此，大公司往往会陷入过度管理、创新不足的陷阱。这正是初创企业如此重要的原因。

It’s not often that the most important innovations in the world come from the GEs and the Microsofts, the authors point out. They come from entrepreneurs who are focused on that one area with an intensity that bigger companies simply can’t bring. Most big firms see their time as best spent on making their current products and processes more efficient. Making a $100 billion company more efficient by just 5 percent could result in a $5 billion windfall to the bottom line; there are few new products that could ever create the same dent. Because of this fact, big companies tend to fall into traps of overmanaging and underinnovating. This is why startups are so important.

“初创公司擅长以更经济、更高效的方式攻克复杂问题，而大型成熟公司几乎无法想象这一点，”凯德罗斯基和斯坦格勒写道。“在当今最需要创业精神的领域，科学家和工程师对于创办公司或加入新公司至关重要。”

“Startup firms specialize—in a way that larger and more-established companies can barely contemplate—in attacking complex problems in cheaper and more efficient ways,” write Kedrosky and Stangler. “For the leading areas in need of entrepreneurship today, scientists and engineers are essential to start firms or join new companies.”

考夫曼报告的作者表示，好消息是，像伊格纳西奥·塞耶和杰弗里·哈默巴赫这样的人代表着一个将持续下去的更大趋势：“鉴于我们需要企业家将产品和服务推向市场，以帮助我们解决一些我们曾经面临的最困难和最复杂的社会问题，现在是进行变革的最佳时机。”

The good news is that people like Ignacio Thayer and Jeffrey Hammerbacher are part of a bigger trend that will continue, say the Kauffman report’s authors: “Given our need for entrepreneurs to bring products and services to a market that help us with some of the most difficult and complex societal problems we have ever faced, there could not be a more auspicious time for the change.”

硅谷一直是科技初创企业的发源地，其次是其他一些城市。在长期被忽视之后，纽约在2008年金融危机后一跃成为第二大科技初创企业。这是一个令人难以置信的转变——瓦德瓦表示，这绝非巧合。“2008年银行业衰退与此息息相关，”他解释道。“突然之间，科技人才涌入街头，还有所有通常会搬到纽约去华尔街工作的应届毕业生工程师。他们仍然会来，但他们没有去投资银行工作。”

Silicon Valley has always been ground zero for tech startups, followed by a basket of other cities. After long being an afterthought in the space, New York made a charge to the top of that second heap following the 2008 financial crash. It’s an incredible turnabout—one that’s no coincidence, says Wadhwa. “The 2008 banking dip has more than a little to do with that,” he explains. “All of sudden you had tech talent on the streets—plus all of the graduating engineers who would normally move to New York and work for Wall Street. They still came, but they didn’t go to work for the investment banks.”

我问了联合广场风险投资公司 (Union Square Ventures) 合伙人、纽约最知名的风险投资家弗雷德·威尔逊 (Fred Wilson)，他是否认为 2008 年华尔街崩盘直接点燃了如今纽约蓬勃发展的创业环境。威尔逊认为其中另有隐情。“创业生态系统的孕育期很长，”他说。“如今发生的事情的种子早在 1995 年至 1999 年就已播下。”

I asked Fred Wilson, a partner at Union Square Ventures and the most prominent venture capitalist in New York, if he thought the Wall Street collapse of 2008 directly kindled the now bustling startup scene in New York. Wilson thought there was more to it. “Startup ecosystems have long gestation periods,” he says. “The seeds of what is happening now were sown in 1995 to 1999.”

这两种假设或许都有一定道理。威尔逊和其他纽约风险投资家有权让人们知道，在当时还不流行推动纽约科技发展的时候，他们就推动了科技发展。如果没有他们，我们就不会谈论这件事。但显然，由于2008年华尔街的困境，成千上万拥有精英教育背景、充满进取心的工程师加入了这一行列，这并没有什么坏处。

There’s probably more than a little truth to both hypotheses. Wilson and the rest of the New York VC brood have a right to let people know they were pushing tech forward in New York when it wasn’t hip to do so. Without them, we wouldn’t be talking about this. But it clearly didn’t hurt that thousands of highly motivated engineers with elite educations dropped into the mix thanks to Wall Street’s misfortunes in 2008.

瓦德瓦还认为，2011年的“占领华尔街”运动给金融业的声誉蒙上了一层污点。Redfin的凯尔曼对此表示赞同，他表示，他过去招募的许多常春藤盟校理科专业学生现在都对华尔街失去了兴趣。

Wadhwa also credits the Occupy Wall Street movement of 2011 for adding a layer of grime to financial-sector prestige. Redfin’s Kelman agrees, saying that many of the Ivy League science majors he used to recruit have simply been turned off to Wall Street.

“在我教授的本科工程课上，人们对投资银行的愤怒显而易见，”瓦德瓦说道。但他仍然对华尔街卷土重来的能力心存疑虑，并指出他的许多学生毕业时都背负着六位数的债务，需要以某种方式偿还。为了解决这个难题，瓦德瓦提议设立一项国家捐赠基金来支付工程师的教育费用。从美国大学毕业并获得工程学位，你的债务很快就能还清。但瓦德瓦教授想补充一些警告：如果毕业生进入华尔街或金融业，债务仍由工程师承担。而那些进入真正的工程领域或尝试创业的人，债务将被免除。“争取这些奖学金的是美国最顶尖的人才，”他解释道。

“The rage that is brewing against investment banks is palpable in my undergraduate engineering classes,” Wadhwa says. But he remains leery of Wall Street’s capability to mount a comeback, pointing out that many of his students graduate with six-figure debts that need to get paid off somehow. To solve this conundrum, Wadhwa proposes a national endowment to pay for engineers’ educations. Graduate from an American university with an engineering degree and, presto, your debt gets paid off. But the professor would want to add a few caveats: If a graduate heads to Wall Street or into finance, the debt remains with the engineer. Those who head into true engineering fields or try their hand at a startup get their debts forgiven. “You’d be getting the cream of the crop in America to go after these scholarships,” he reasons.

无论有没有报酬，新毕业生的编程技能都在不断提升。这意味着更多的算法、更多的自动化，以及我们生活的更多变化。

Paid or not, the programming skill of new graduates continues to climb. That only means more algorithms, more automation, and more changes to our lives.

10

10

未来属于算法及其创造者

THE FUTURE BELONGS TO THE ALGORITHMS AND THEIR CREATORS
