在朋友圈里， 总是存在着等级制度。顶端坐着那些影响他人观点的有影响力的人，他们就是领导者。而坐在最后面的是追随者。在工作中或家庭中也是如此。有老板，也有平民。每个人都在某种程度上知道这一点，大多数人都知道自己的位置。但这种感觉是会腐化的。你可能觉得自己是个领导者，但实际上你是个走狗。你的朋友知道，你不知道。有些人凭借地位、金钱、外貌或纯粹的人气登上顶峰。这些人才是社会中真正拥有影响力的人。这些人的身份有时显而易见。但通常情况下，他们并不那么明显。

WITHIN GROUPS OF FRIENDS, THERE are always pecking orders. At the top sit the influential ones who shape the opinions of others, the leaders. At the back sit the followers. The same is true at work or within a family. There are bosses and there are plebes. Everybody knows this on some level and most people have a sense of where they think they fit. But that sense is corruptible. You may feel like a leader, but in fact you’re a lackey. Your friends know it, you don’t. Some people float to the top based on their position, their money, their looks, or just sheer popularity. These are the true wielders of influence in society. Who these people are can sometimes be obvious. But often it isn’t so apparent.

有一些方法可以发现这些。我们的说话方式表明了我们在等级制度中的位置。影响者很少改变他们的说话方式。然而，受影响的人往往会改变自己的说话方式，以更接近影响者的说话方式。这同样适用于电子邮件等书面交流。言语会暴露一个人是否有影响力。主导风格的人处于等级制度的顶端。语言风格更像他人的人则处于较低的位置。更具体地说，我们的等级可以通过我们如何使用冠词、助动词、连词和高频副词来确定。1这些语法细节构成了我们的风格，无论是在我们说话的方式，还是在我们说话的方式中。这些词在上一句中以粗体显示。

There exist ways to find such things out. How we speak indicates what spot we occupy in the pecking order. The influencers rarely change their speech patterns. Those being influenced, however, often alter their speech to be closer to that of the influencer. The same applies to written communication such as e-mail. Words betray one’s influence or lack thereof. He who dictates style is at the head of the pecking order. He who shapes his language more like the other is lower. More specifically, our hierarchy can be determined by how we use words that are articles, auxiliary verbs, conjunctions, and high-frequency adverbs.1 These crumbs of grammatical fodder are what make up our style, be it in the way we speak or in the way we talk. Such words are bolded in the previous sentence.

康奈尔大学计算机科学教授乔恩·克莱因伯格编写了一种算法，该算法根据我们的用词来判断谁是真正的影响者，即那些塑造观点、引领潮流、吸引他人注意力的人。这些人可以左右选举结果，也可以推动新产品的研发。该算法会监听对话，识别谁是真正的领导者，以及其他人如何运作。它对电子邮件字符串也同样有效。想象一下，如果该算法窃听了所有通过谷歌、雅虎或通用电气或高盛电子邮件服务器的通信，会发生什么。这些影响者可以立即被识别出来。一家公司如果确切地知道谁是影响者，就可以针对他们量身定制营销策略。在互联网上，影响者会成为横幅广告和文字广告的关注对象，而这些广告的价格在他们不知情的情况下远高于平均水平。公司可以使用所谓的浏览器cookie来跟踪、宣传和监视这些影响者。这些人是通往他人心灵的大门，营销界对此心知肚明。能够自动大规模地识别等级最高的人可能会为政治、管理、销售和营销带来新的方法。

Jon Kleinberg, a computer science professor at Cornell, wrote an algorithm that keys on our word use to determine who among us are real influencers, the people who shape opinions, drive trends, and command the attention of others. These people can decide elections or propel a new product. The algorithm listens in on conversations and identifies who is in charge and how the rest of the pecking order plays out. It also works well on e-mail strings. Imagine what would happen if this algorithm eavesdropped on all communications going through Google or Yahoo! or the e-mail servers of GE or Goldman Sachs. The influencers could immediately be identified. A company that knew exactly who influencers were could tailor their marketing toward them. On the Internet, influencers would be followed by banner and text ads for products that were, unbeknownst to them, priced much higher than average ads. Companies could use what are called browser cookies to track, advertise, and keep tabs on the influencers. These people are the gateways to others’ hearts and minds, and the marketing world knows it. Being able to identify pecking-order top dogs automatically on a wide scale could lead to new approaches in politics, management, sales, and marketing.

这种基于细微影响力线索进行排名的模型，与驱动谷歌 PageRank 算法的计算原理相同。PageRank 算法以谷歌联合创始人拉里·佩奇 (Larry Page) 的名字命名，将网络流量引导至那些在搜索主题上被认为具有权威性的网站。重要的网站被称为“枢纽”和“影响者”。谷歌会在其搜索结果中更加信任那些经常被有影响力的网站和“枢纽”链接的网站。如果这些网站普遍认为某个航班预订搜索引擎是最好的，同时又链接到它，那么这个网站就很有可能在谷歌的搜索结果中名列前茅。通过查看有影响力网站的链接，谷歌的算法可以快速确定用户可能输入的任何查询应该显示什么。对人类的排序也可以用同样的方式进行。早在克莱因伯格着手研究人类影响者之前，他在 20 世纪 90 年代的 IBM 公司就编写了一种创新的网络搜索算法。该算法在互联网上搜索他所谓的“枢纽”和“权威”——后来，这启发了谷歌的创始人也采取同样的策略。

This model of ranking things based on small clues of influence is the same calculus that drives PageRank, Google’s algorithm, named after cofounder Larry Page, which steers Web traffic to sites the Web regards as authoritative on the subject being searched. Important Web sites are called hubs and influencers. Google gives more credence in its search results to sites that are often linked to by influential sites and hubs. If these sites commonly refer to, say, a particular flight-booking search engine as the best one while concurrently linking to it, it’s likely that this Web site will rise to the top of Google’s results. By looking at where the influential sites link, Google’s algorithm can quickly determine what to show for any query a user might type in. Sorting humans can be done much the same way. Long before he tackled the subject of human influencers, Kleinberg wrote an innovative Web search algorithm while at IBM in the 1990s. It trawled the Internet looking for what he called hubs and authorities—later inspiring the Google founders to do the same thing.

将这种算法投入日常使用可能会让人有些害怕。如果Facebook在整个网站上都放弃它，根据人们在几百个朋友圈中的相对权力对他们进行排名，会怎么样？如果公司也这样做，根据谁已经控制着谁，而不是他们试图建立的那种精英管理程序来选择管理人员，会怎么样？有些事情最好还是不要说，无论是算法还是人类。但毫无疑问，这种对我们社会地位的量化衡量即将到来。克莱因伯格一发明这个算法，很可能就会有十家公司开始着手开发自己的算法。营销机构、广告商以及任何有兴趣争取社会上最重要人物的人都能赚到太多钱，所以这种情况不可能不发生。我们面临的未来是，这种严谨而冷酷的计算将不断在算法的手中进行。啄食顺序仅仅是个开始。

Putting this algorithm into everyday use could prove a bit scary. What if Facebook dropped it on its entire site, ranking people according to their relative power within their circle of several hundred friends? What if companies did this, choosing managers by who already controls whom rather than whatever meritocratic process they’ve tried to install? Some things are just better left unsaid, be it by an algorithm or a human. But such quantitative measurements of our places in society are undoubtedly coming. As soon as Kleinberg created this algorithm, there were likely ten companies setting out to make their own. There’s too much money to be made by marketing agencies, advertisers, and anybody interested in wooing the most important people in society for this not to happen. We face a future where rigorous and cold calculations such as this will constantly take place at the hands of algorithms. Pecking orders are just the beginning.

所有道路……

ALL ROADS . . .

如果你一直在追踪，就会发现算法已经控制了你的货币市场基金、股票和退休账户。它们很快就会决定你打电话的对象；它们会控制你收音机里播放的音乐；它们会决定你获得救命器官移植的机会；而对数百万人来说，算法或许将做出他们一生中最重要的决定：选择配偶。至少它们不会开车。

If you’re keeping track, algorithms already have control of your money market funds, your stocks, and your retirement accounts. They’ll soon decide who you talk to on phone calls; they will control the music that reaches your radio; they will decide your chances of getting lifesaving organ transplants; and for millions of people, algorithms will make perhaps the largest decision in their life: choosing a spouse. At least they don’t drive.

真的吗？2011 年夏天我搬到加州后，经常开车沿着硅谷 85 号公路和 280 号州际公路行驶。每周至少一次，我会和一些奇怪的丰田普锐斯并肩而行，这些车的车顶上装着巨大的旋转装置。车里总是至少有一个人，但他（总是一个男人）不把手放在方向盘上，也不会回应我们的嘘声或问题。原来，这些车是谷歌的。开它们的不是人，而是算法。车顶上那个旋转的东西是激光测距仪。2011 年有七辆普锐斯在路上行驶，它们还配备了 GPS 接收器、四个雷达、一个摄像头、一个位置估算器和一个内部运动传感器——所有这些都连接到一个主机器人上，由它来决定行驶速度、何时转弯以及何时停车。所有这些系统——多个雷达、摄像头和 GPS——共同提供了冗余。如果机器人从其中一个系统获取的数据与其他来源的数据大相径庭，则不同的数据将被忽略，从而防止汽车因为其中一个雷达被一群俯冲的鸟儿欺骗而突然停车或转向。

Or do they? After I relocated to California for the summer of 2011, I often found myself driving along Silicon Valley’s Highway 85 and Interstate 280. At least once a week, I would pull alongside strange Toyota Priuses affixed with large rotating doodads on their roofs. There was always at least one human in the car, but he (and it was always a he) didn’t have his hands on the wheel and wouldn’t respond to our catcalls or questions. These cars, it turns out, belong to Google. People don’t drive them, algorithms do. That swiveling thing on the roof is a laser rangefinder. The Priuses, seven of which were plying the roads in 2011, also sport GPS receivers, four radars, a video camera, a position estimator, and an internal motion sensor—all of which are wired into a master bot that makes decisions about how fast to go, when to turn, and when to stop. All of these systems together—the multiple radars, cameras, and GPS—provide redundancy. If the bot is getting data from one of them that wildly contradicts that being supplied by other sources, the variant data will be ignored, keeping the car from suddenly stopping or swerving because one radar was fooled by a swooping flock of birds.

谷歌汽车完全自动驾驶，无需人类乘客干预，迄今已行驶14万英里，未发生任何事故。2011年8月，一辆谷歌汽车发生了一起被广泛报道的撞车事故，当时车内有人在操控。谷歌宣称的使命是减少排放（机器人踩油门更平稳）、道路容量翻番（机器人对故障的反应时间比人类更短，因此它们可以更紧密地行驶），并将全球每年120万的交通死亡人数减少一半。如果算法成为驾驶员，那么几乎可以消除人为失误——美国每年3.3万条道路死亡事故中几乎全部是人为失误造成的。

Google’s cars, which drive utterly autonomously from their human passengers, have covered 140,000 miles so far without an accident. A widely reported crash involving a Google car in August 2011 occurred when the human inside the car had been at the controls. Google’s stated mission is to reduce emissions (bots are smoother on the gas pedal), double road capacity (bots need less time to react to trouble than do humans, so they can drive closer together), and cut in half the world’s 1.2 million traffic deaths per year. Human error, which leads to almost all of the thirty-three thousand deaths on U.S. roads every year, could be almost eliminated if algorithms were the drivers.

随着我们的世界从人类主导所有重要决策，转变为与算法共享决策，卓越智力的价值正以复合速度增长。如今，软件和计算机代码可以轻松放大一小部分充满活力的思维的力量，提升其对社会的潜在价值。正是这些思维正在改变地球上的生物，做出关键决策，从驾驶汽车到交易股票，再到选择公司中合适的人才，这些决策从人类手中转移到了机器人手中。

As our world shifts from one where humans have made all of the important decisions to one in which we share that role with algorithms, the value of superior intellect has increased at a compounding rate. Software and computer code can now easily amplify the power of a small group of dynamic minds, increasing their potential value to society. These are the minds that are changing life on earth, taking critical decisions, from driving cars to trading stocks to choosing what personalities belong in a company, out of the hands of humans and putting them into the hands of bots.

两个海岸的故事

A TALE OF TWO COASTS

杰弗里·哈默巴赫是量化人才离开华尔街稳定财富、投奔变幻莫测、精英至上的硅谷的故事中的关键人物之一。他象征着两个世界之间的所有差异。一边是利用机器人和算法分割次级抵押贷款，然后将其兜售给毫无戒心的德国银行，最终这些银行以极低的价格吞噬了这些债务——对此我深感抱歉！——并以极快的速度交易股票，这确实降低了交易成本，惠及了公众，但也让他们付出了更高的波动性和可能引发大规模混乱的代价。而另一边，硅谷，则利用类似的智慧和技术，创造出一款游戏，或许能让你每天花上十五分钟来娱乐一番。来自硅谷的优秀产品可以帮助你与亲戚保持联系，追溯家族起源，教你的女儿学习微积分，或者改善你与医疗保险公司的关系。这正是哈默巴赫所看到的，也是他创立Cloudera的原因。

Jeffrey Hammerbacher is one of the linchpins in the tale of quant talent drifting away from the steady riches of Wall Street for the unpredictable and meritocratic zone of Silicon Valley. He’s a symbol of all that’s different between the two worlds. One side uses bots and algorithms to chop up subprime mortgages and peddle them to unsuspecting German banks that end up eating the debt for pennies on the dollar—sorry about that!—and to trade stocks at fast speeds that do in fact benefit the public in lower transaction costs, but also cost them in the way of higher volatilities and the possibility of epic chaos. The other side, Silicon Valley, uses similar brains and technology to create a game that may keep you entertained for fifteen minutes a day. The best products from the Silicon Valley help you keep in touch with relatives, trace your family’s origins, teach your daughter calculus, or smooth your relationship with your health insurer. That’s what Hammerbacher saw and why he founded Cloudera.

当你问哈默巴赫，他认为哪个领域最有前景，最有可能被像他这样的人攻克，他只用两个词回答：“医学诊断”。医生们显然应该小心谨慎，但他们更应该警惕，因为我们这一代最聪明的人——像哈默巴赫这样的人——正在瞄准他们。随着他们的并发症发生率、检查结果以及他们的诊疗实践都受到由聪明工程师构建的算法的严格审查，他们面临的目标只会越来越大。医生不会消失，但那些想要在未来保住饭碗的人应该想方设法让自己变得卓越。机器人可以处理那些繁重的工作，那些我们普通医生该做的活儿。

When you ask Hammerbacher what he sees as the most promising field that could be hacked by people like himself, he responds with two words: “Medical diagnostics.” And clearly doctors should be watching their backs, but they should be extra vigilant knowing that the smartest guys of our generation—people like Hammerbacher—are gunning for them. The targets on their backs will only grow larger as their complication rates, their test results, and their practices are scrutinized by the unyielding eye of algorithms built by bright engineers. Doctors aren’t going away, but those who want to ensure their employment in the future should find ways to be exceptional. Bots can handle the grunt work, the work that falls to our average practitioners.

令许多人高兴，也令少数人懊恼的是，律师和其他人一样容易受到算法入侵的影响。任何大型诉讼中最昂贵的部分之一就是证据开示过程——收集和研究案件的所有相关文件。在公司法或涉及合同的诉讼案件中，可能需要阅读数百万页的文件。阅读者通常是律师助理或初级律师，他们每小时的费用通常在100美元以上，有时甚至高达200美元，本质上就是“眼睛”的服务。然而，“眼睛”可以是硬件，而“眼睛”背后的“大脑”可以是算法。 帕洛阿尔托一家名为Blackstone Discovery的公司以及其他一些公司正在用算法取代人工，这些算法的工作效率与人类一样高，而且通常更彻底。算法也更便宜。审阅120万份文件，这项任务曾经可能要花费500万美元甚至更多，现在只需10万美元。2这或许可以解释为什么2012年，美国大约有5.4万名通过律师资格考试的律师，却只有2.6万个工作岗位。这对于全国成千上万正在苦苦寻找工作的律师来说，可不是什么好消息。哦，抱歉，我们把这份工作交给了算法。算法不需要医疗保险，也不需要将来成为合伙人的承诺。

To the delight of many and the chagrin of a few, lawyers are as susceptible as anybody to an algorithm invasion. One of the most expensive parts of any large lawsuit is the process of discovery—collecting and studying all relevant documents in a case. In corporate law or contentious cases involving contracts, there can be millions of pages that need to be read. The readers are often paralegals or junior associates, either of whom will cost north of $100 or sometimes $200 an hour for, essentially, the service of their eyes. Eyes, though, can be hardware, and the brain behind the eyes can be an algorithm. A Palo Alto company called Blackstone Discovery, among others, is replacing people with algorithms that work just as efficiently, and often more thoroughly, than humans. Algorithms are cheaper too. Running through 1.2 million documents, a task that could once have cost $5 million or more, now costs only $100,000.2 Perhaps that helps explain why in 2012 there were only twenty-six thousand jobs waiting for the fifty-four thousand or so lawyers who pass bar exams in the United States. None of this is good news for the tens of thousands of lawyers in the country who now want for work. Oh, sorry, we gave that job to an algorithm. The algorithm does not require health insurance or the promise that it could make partner later.

医生、律师、精神科医生、卡车司机、音乐家——我们究竟会因为算法而失去多少工作？这会对我们的经济产生多大影响？麻省理工学院的两位经济学家埃里克·布林约尔松和安德鲁·P·迈克菲在一篇具有里程碑意义的论文中写道：“简而言之，许多工人正在输掉与机器的竞赛。”3麻省理工学院的两位教授警告说，中等收入群体、普通的白领会计师应该做好被取代的准备。

Doctors, lawyers, psychiatrists, truck drivers, musicians—just how many jobs might we lose to algorithms? How much will this affect our economy? In a landmark paper, two economists at MIT, Eric Brynjolfsson and Andrew P. McAfee, wrote, “Many workers, in short, are losing the race against the machine.”3 The median worker, the average white-collar accountant, the MIT pair warn, should prepare to be replaced.

学术界此前也曾做出过这样的预测。20世纪20年代和30年代，当机器开始接管制造业任务时，约翰·梅纳德·凯恩斯（John Maynard Keynes）就曾发出警告，称一种名为“技术性失业”的“新病症”即将出现。这种病症是指现有工作被取代的速度赶不上自动化取代的速度。4.凯恩斯的警告最终被证明是夸大其词，后来被人们认为是空穴来风。但或许他的理论只是早了90年而已。根据布林约尔松和迈克菲的研究，自2009年6月经济衰退结束以来，企业在技术和软件方面的支出增加了26%，但员工人数却丝毫没有增加。2011年，标准普尔500指数成分股公司的利润创下了近1万亿美元的纪录，而这一成就并不需要太多额外的人力就能实现。

Academics have made such predictions before. When machines began taking over manufacturing tasks in the 1920s and 1930s, John Maynard Keynes sounded the alarm for a “new disease” he termed “technological unemployment,” which happens when jobs can’t be replaced as fast as they’re eliminated by automation.4 Keynes’s warning was blown off as hyperbolic when it didn’t prove out. But perhaps his theory was simply ninety years early. Since the end of the recession in June 2009, according to Brynjolfsson and McAfee, corporations have spent 26 percent more on technology and software but haven’t raised their payrolls at all. In 2011, the S&P 500 logged record profits of nearly $1 trillion, a feat that didn’t take many extra people to pull off.

作家也难保。我家乡伊利诺伊州埃文斯顿的一家公司Narrative Science，已经为其机器人技术获得了600万美元的风险投资，这些机器人技术可以将原始数据转化为风格清晰、语法正确、构思巧妙的新闻报道。这家隶属于十大联盟（Big Ten Network）的体育网站利用这项技术，在比赛结束后一分钟内发布文章。它的算法会收集比赛数据，识别出比赛中最重要的部分，然后围绕这些关键时刻撰写报道，就像记者一样。算法甚至知道比赛中的哪个部分最适合用作“导语”。在威斯康星大学对阵内华达大学拉斯维加斯分校（UNLV）的一场橄榄球比赛第三节刚结束几秒钟，机器人就及时输出了一篇文章，开头是这样的：“威斯康星大学似乎已经占据了胜利的主动权，在第三节结束时以51比10领先。拉塞尔·威尔逊传球给雅各布·佩德森，完成8码达阵，将比分扳成44比3，威斯康星大学进一步扩大了领先优势。”5

Writers aren’t safe either. Narrative Science, a company in my hometown of Evanston, Illinois, has attracted $6 million of venture capital for its bots that transform raw stats into styled, grammatically correct, and clever news stories. The sports Web site belonging to the Big Ten Network uses the technology to post articles within a minute after a game is over. Its algorithms suck in the box score and identify the most important parts of the game and then write a story built around those moments, just as a journalist would. The algorithm even knows what piece of the game is the best candidate to use as the “lede.” An article duly punched out by the bot seconds after the third quarter of a Wisconsin-UNLV football game started like this: “Wisconsin appears to be in the driver’s seat en route to a win, as it leads 51–10 after the third quarter. Wisconsin added to its lead when Russell Wilson found Jacob Pedersen for an eight-yard touchdown to make the score 44–3.”5

那么教训是什么？与机器人友好相处。在这个经济时代，现在和将来最不可或缺的人，是那些能够构建、维护和改进代码和算法的人。在硅谷待一段时间，你总会听到大大小小的科技公司抱怨优秀工程师的匮乏。

So what’s the lesson? Get friendly with bots. The people who are and will remain most indispensable in this economy are those who can build, maintain, and improve upon code and algorithms. Spend any time in Silicon Valley and the one thing you will hear technology companies large and small complain about is the dearth of good engineers.

拥有编程技能的工程师并不想找工作。正因如此，公司将工程工作外包到印度、巴西和东欧等地。如果有更多合格的科学、数学和工程专业人才，经济就会为他们提供就业机会，而且这些工作不太可能消失。即使面对这一事实，我们每年仍有40%的潜在工程专业学生流失，他们转向其他通常对数学要求较低的专业。如果这听起来像是一个熟悉的话题，那确实如此。2011年，奥巴马总统呼吁美国每年新增一万名工程师，这是一个令人钦佩的目标。6我们已经取得了一些进展。让更多孩子在高中阶段对数学和科学产生兴趣并不是问题所在；全国许多学校都成功地推动了这一进程。

Engineers with programming skills do not want for work. It’s for this reason more than any other that companies outsource engineering work to places like India, Brazil, and Eastern Europe. If there were more qualified science, math, and engineering majors, the economy would have jobs for them, and those jobs are not likely going away. Even in the face of that fact, every year we continue to lose 40 percent of our prospective engineering majors to other, usually less math-intensive degrees. If this sounds like a familiar theme, it is. In 2011, President Obama called for the country to graduate ten thousand more engineers a year, an admirable goal.6 And we’ve made some progress. Getting more kids interested in math and science at the high school level isn’t the problem; there’s been a successful push in many schools across the country to do just that.

问题往往在于，孩子们上了大学后会遇到伊利诺伊大学香槟分校名誉工程学教授戴维·戈德堡所说的“数理死亡行军”，这通常包括三个学期无休止的化学、物理、数学、计算机科学，以及戈德堡博士所在学院的一系列理论与应用力学（TAM）课程。我自己也经历过戈德堡博士的严峻考验，我可以证明，大学期间会度过无数个不眠之夜，考试也很艰难，至少与一些人文学科学生选修的更容易转学的跨学科课程和专业相比是如此。话虽如此，完成四年的工程学学业并不需要天才；只需要在高中多加努力，打下良好的高等数学和科学基础。

The problem is often that kids get to college and run into what David Goldberg, an emeritus engineering professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, calls “the math-science death march,” usually consisting of three semesters of relentless chemistry, physics, math, computer science, and, at Dr. Goldberg’s school, a series of classes called theoretical and applied mechanics (TAM). Having run Dr. Goldberg’s gauntlet myself, I can attest to sleepless nights and difficult tests, at least compared to the more transferable interdisciplinary classes and majors some humanities students take. Having said that, getting through four years of engineering school doesn’t take genius; it just takes a little more work and a good base of upper-level math and science in high school.

不幸的是，问题在于，没有足够的美国孩子在进入大学之前打下高等数学的基础。包括文艺复兴科技公司创始人吉姆·西蒙斯在内的一些人表示，解决方案的一部分是聘请更多能够引领我们以算法为中心的未来的人才，并将他们安排到课堂上。人们只能教授自己理解的东西。然而，教学并非易事。谷歌工程师掌握的许多技能，并不能转移到一群难以驾驭的16岁孩子身上。我们应该寻找那些能够在这两个世界之间轻松自如地穿梭的特殊人才——从算法代码的堆积如山，到塑造下一代思维的高中。能够找到能够巧妙地将学生聚集在新的复杂学科上的技术人才实属难得。但每当这样的人才被发现并投入教育领域，即使需要花费更多资金，对社会和学生来说都是有益的。

The problem, unfortunately, is that not enough U.S. kids get that foundation of upper-level math before arriving at college. Some, including Renaissance Technology’s founder Jim Simons, say part of the solution would be to hire more of the types of minds that are responsible for our coming algorithm-centric future and put them in the classroom. People can only teach what they understand themselves. Teaching isn’t easy, however. Many of the skills a Google engineer holds do not transfer to unruly collections of sixteen-year-olds. We should seek out those special people who can comfortably go back and forth between these two worlds—from piles of algorithmic code to the high schools where the next generation of minds is being molded. Finding technical talent with the nuanced ability to rally students around new, complex subjects is a rare thing. But every time such talent can be spotted and placed into the educational field, even if it costs more money, it’s a win for society and for students.

那么，这是否意味着要为我们最优秀的量化人才创造另一个竞标者——学校？的确如此。这没关系——有很多潜在的量化人才，他们从未真正地在游戏中发挥过作用。聪明人并不短缺。然而，在量化领域受过教育的聪明人却很少。我们只需要扩大吸引人才的渠道。美国每所高中的每个学生都应该至少选修一门编程课。大多数学生会就此打住，转而去做其他事情。但即使只有5%的学生开始尝试编写自己的程序和算法，也会改变我们的教育体系和经济格局。想象一下，所有从未考虑过编程或量化领域的学生。对他们来说，数学是一种必须死记硬背才能通过考试或测验的死记硬背技能；他们从未看到数学正在改变我们世界的另一面。或者，当他们最终意识到这一点时，比如在大学里，他们的人生方向已经转向了另一个领域。编程和计算机科学课程不应该只局限于少数学生——这项技能，比其他任何技能都更重要，在本世纪至关重要。所有学生都应该获得这样的机会。

So does this mean creating yet another bidder—schools—for our best quantitative minds? It does. And that’s okay—there are a lot of potentially quantitatively minded people roaming around out there who have never given their brains a proper crack at the game. Smart people aren’t in short supply. Smart people educated in quantitative fields are, however. We just need to increase the size of the funnel that gets people there. Every single student at every high school in America should be required to take at least one programming class. Most students will stop there and move on to do something else. But even if just 5 percent of those students become engaged with the power of devising their own programs and algorithms, it will change the dynamic of our education system and our economy. Imagine all of the students who never give programming or quantitative fields a thought. Math, to them, is a rote skill that must be memorized so that a test or a quiz can be passed; they never see the other side of math that’s changing our world. Or when they finally do, perhaps in college, their life vector is already set toward another field. Programming and computer science classes shouldn’t be relegated to a niche group of students—this is the skill, more than any other, that will matter during this century. All students should get their chance.

未来五十年的经济将有两大增长引擎：医疗保健和科技。前者是建立在摇摇欲坠的根基和美国人口老龄化基础上的体系的产物。但科技为任何背景的人提供了获得技能的机会，使他们无论在经济景气还是低迷时期都能保住饭碗。对于少数愿意忽略风险、开辟自己道路的人来说，技术技能和设计创新算法的能力可以打开创业和创造力的大门。这扇门为任何想走进去的人敞开。成为技术高手并不意味着在标准化考试的数学和科学部分取得好成绩。这关乎实践。关乎投入时间学习流程。

There will be two large growth engines in the economy of the next fifty years: health care and tech. The former is the result of a system built on a shaky foundation and an aging U.S. population. But tech offers the opportunity for anybody from any background to attain skills that will keep them employed in good economies and bad ones. For a select few willing to ignore risks and carve their own path, technical skills and the ability to devise innovative algorithms can open the door to entrepreneurship and creativity. The door is open for anybody who wants to walk through it. Being a technical whiz isn’t about scoring well on the math and science sections of standardized tests. It’s about practice. It’s about putting in time to learn processes.

对于那些会写代码的人来说，未来将会有很多工作要做。如果你还能构思和编写复杂的算法，那就更好了——你或许就能统治世界了。当然，前提是机器人还没抢先一步。

There’s going to be a lot of work in the future for those who can write code. If you can also conceive and compose intricate algorithms, all the better—you may just be able to take over the world. That is, if a bot doesn’t do it first.

致谢

ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

一本书从开始到结束，变化之大令人惊叹。时间流逝，信息来源、顾问，甚至编辑，随着时间的流逝，在这个例子中，已经过去了两年，来来往往。当然，作者始终如一——我的经纪人，来自 Launch Books 的 David Fugate 也始终如一，他始终是我的首要支持者、拥护者和顾问。在我开始写第一本书的一年多前，我在网上偶然遇到了 David，这改变了我的职业生涯。尽管这是我的第二本书，但在出版行业，我仍然算得上是个菜鸟。而 David，简而言之，就是我能安然地继续做下去的原因。

It’s remarkable how much can change from when a book project starts to when it ends. Sources, advisers, and even editors shift into and then out of the picture as the months roll into, in this case, two years. The writer remains the same, of course—as did my agent, David Fugate of Launch Books, who, as always, remains my number one advocate, champion, and adviser. Meeting David randomly on the Web—more than a year before I began work on my first book—changed my career. Despite the fact that this is my second book, I remain something of a noob in the publishing business. And David, quite simply, is the reason I can safely carry on as a noob.

在一些可能为本书付费的人看到这些内容之前，许多人都仔细研读了这些内容。这个团队的负责人是我在企鹅出版社的编辑妮基·帕帕多普洛斯。妮基最初并不是本书的编辑，所以她对自己正在做的事情一无所知。但我很幸运。妮基是一位出色的编辑，她很快就帮助塑造了本书的叙事，删减了冗余内容，并找出了不足之处。由于她的努力，这本书变得更加出色。

A number of people pored over these pages before anybody who may have paid money for this book ever saw them. At the head of this group was Niki Papadopoulos, my editor at Penguin. Niki did not start as this book’s editor, so she had little idea what she was wading into. But I got lucky. Niki is a superb editor, and she quickly helped shape this book’s narrative, shave fat, and suss out weaknesses. The book is far stronger as a result of her work.

我的妻子莎拉一字不漏地读完了这本书——通常不止一遍——并努力去除掉那些令人尴尬的陈词滥调、语法错误和毫无意义的从句。生活的力量似乎常常合谋将许多个人、家庭和工作事件塞进同一个日历。我们去年的经历就证明了这一点。就在本书即将完成之际，莎拉生下了双胞胎女儿（你好，帕克和玛伦！），所以她工作时经常一个孩子躺在腿上，另一个孩子在她脚边，我们的儿子（你好，杰克！）则在后面的家具上荡来荡去。等到这本书付印时，莎拉已经重返工作岗位，并正式被载入“超级妈妈名人堂”。如果没有她，我在这个项目中可能会崩溃很多次。她是我工作和生活中的伙伴。

My wife, Sarah, read every word in this book—oftentimes more than once—and rid these pages of embarrassing clichés, grammar faux pas, and meaningless clauses. Life’s forces often seem to collude in pushing many personal, family, and work events onto the same calendar. The last year for us has proved this true. Sarah gave birth to twin girls (hi, Parker and Maren!) just as this book was getting wrapped up, so her work was often done with one baby in her lap, another at her feet, and our son (hi, Jack!) swinging from a piece of furniture in the background. By the time this book is in print, Sarah will be back at her job and duly enshrined into the Supermom Hall of Fame. Without her, I would have crumbled many times during this project. She is my partner in work and life.

马塞尔·帕卡特（Marcel Pacatte）是我西北大学的一位教授，他的学费物超所值，他至今仍孜孜不倦地为我提供批评和建议。他比任何人都先读完每一章，并提出真诚的评论，使手稿每次都得到改进。

Marcel Pacatte, one of my professors from Northwestern University who was worth the price of tuition, continues to be a tireless source of critiques and advice. He read every chapter before anybody else and offered honest commentary that improved the manuscript at each turn.

汤姆·彭宁顿，我在工程学院、滑雪、做披萨以及生活中的挚友，仅仅因为我的邀请，就放下了周末的一切，通读了这本书。他的反馈非常宝贵。

Tom Pennington, my trusty friend in engineering school, skiing, pizza making, and life, dropped everything on a weekend to read through the pages of this book just because I asked him to. His feedback was invaluable.

我的父母加里和珍妮特也在本书出版前读过部分内容，他们对我工作的热情永远激励着我。我的父亲是少数几个在读到本书第二章关于算法历史的大部分内容之前就已经了解的人之一。尽管如此，他还是给予了本书由衷的认可，这打消了我之前担心这一章会让人感到无聊的顾虑。他还设计了我的房子，对此我感激不尽，因此我在此表达我的谢意。

My parents, Gary and Janet, also read sections of this book before it reached others, and I will always be encouraged by their enthusiasm for my work. My father is one of the few people who may have known most of chapter 2’s content on the history of algorithms before reading it here. Nonetheless, he gave it a hearty stamp of approval, which quieted my worries that the chapter would bore people. He also designed my house, for which I can never thank him enough, so I do so here.

2011年5月之前，我并不认识兰迪·斯特罗斯，他是《纽约时报》的科技专栏作家，也是圣何塞州立大学的教授。但他却津津有味地阅读了本书的早期版本。他的反馈坦诚而详尽，而且非常有帮助。每当兰迪发现一组他觉得因为各种原因而严重错误的词语时，他就会轻轻地在文中加上“UGH”（呃）。兰迪的“UGH”改进了这本书，并帮助我继续我作为作家的艰难历程。

I didn’t know Randy Stross, a technology columnist at the New York Times and a professor at San Jose State University, before May 2011. But he took to reading an early version of this book with gusto. His feedback was frank and profuse—and incredibly helpful. When Randy ran across a set of words he felt to be egregiously wrong for any number of reasons, he would lightly embed this word in the text: “UGH.” Randy’s “UGHs” improved this book and helped me continue my jagged evolution as a writer.

托马斯·彼得菲（Thomas Peterffy）非常慷慨，不仅在康涅狄格州格林威治与我共度了十几个小时，还通过电话与我进行了交流。面对我的疑问，他总是彬彬有礼，他精彩的故事也让我重温了美国股市第一起大规模黑客攻击事件。

Thomas Peterffy was incredibly generous in spending more than a dozen hours with me in Greenwich, Connecticut, as well as on the phone. He was always a good sport when it came to my queries, and his colorful stories helped bring to life the first big hack of the U.S. stock markets.

Spread Networks 的创始人丹尼尔·斯皮维 (Daniel Spivey) 和大卫·巴克斯代尔 (David Barksdale) 很少接受采访。我很幸运地在全国范围内报道了他们的故事，但一周后，《华尔街日报》的一位竞争对手记者打电话给他们，他们却对这家报社无话可说。他们的故事和他们的项目至今仍令人难以置信，而且妙趣横生。我很感激他们，以及大卫的父亲吉姆·巴克斯代尔——一位无论如何都堪称科技界传奇人物——抽出时间告诉我他们是如何挖出这个秘密的。

Daniel Spivey and David Barksdale, the founders of Spread Networks, have given very few interviews to anybody. I was lucky enough to break their story nationally, and when, a week later, a competing reporter at the Wall Street Journal called them, they had nothing to say to the newspaper. Their story and their project remain almost unbelievable—and fun. I’m grateful that they, along with David’s father, Jim Barksdale, a technology legend by any measure, took the time to tell me how they dug their secret hole.

本·诺瓦克的故事是本书中最引人入胜的人物之一，他特意从新西兰抽出时间，通过几次Skype电话与我分享了这段经历。迈克·麦克里里，他的技术让诺瓦克的音乐广受欢迎，他慷慨地分享了公司的历史以及他自己的经历，其中不乏充满创意的创作。

Ben Novak has one of the most interesting stories in this book, and he took time from New Zealand to hop on a few Skype calls and tell me about it. Mike McCreary, whose technology made Novak’s music popular, was generous in providing the history of his company as well as his own history, which is dotted with inventive creations.

大卫·科普（David Cope）发明了能够模仿巴赫作曲风格的算法，他花了几个小时与我谈论他的工作。对于任何一位正在以门外汉的身份探索计算机科学领域，并想知道如何才能进入这个领域的人来说，科普的故事都极具启发性。他是一位音乐家和学者，在毫无经验的情况下，将自己打造成人工智能领域杰出的创造者之一。他的故事本身就可以写成一本书。

David Cope, the creator of algorithms that can mimic the composition style of Bach, took hours to speak with me about his work. For anybody who is looking into the world of computer science as an outsider and wondering what it would take to get inside, Cope’s tale is instructive. He was a musician and academic who, with zero experience, turned himself into one of the preeminent creators within the artificial intelligence community. His stories could constitute a book on their own.

杰森·布朗跟我讲述了他如何破解了四十年前披头士乐队的谜团。他向一位非音乐人解释了和弦的构造、声音的科学原理以及音乐背后的数学原理。他很有耐心，对此我深表感谢。

Jason Brown talked to me about how he cracked Beatles mysteries that were four decades old. He explained the construction of chords, the science of sound, and the math behind music to a nonmusician. He was patient, and I’m thankful for that.

布鲁斯·布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔（Bruce Bueno de Mesquita）笑声动人，而且善于解释他的博弈论系统如何比人类更有效地预测其他人未来最有可能做什么。在我采访他之后，他出现在了《科尔伯特报告》（The Colbert Report）节目中，这是该节目最搞笑的片段之一。我推荐你看看这个片段，或者布埃诺·德·梅斯基塔的TED演讲或他在《每日秀》（The Daily Show）上的表演，同样精彩。快速谷歌搜索一下就能找到所有这些内容。

Bruce Bueno de Mesquita has a wonderful laugh and a knack for explaining how his game theory systems can be more effective than humans when determining what, exactly, other humans are most likely to do in the future. After I interviewed him, he appeared on the The Colbert Report in one of that show’s more hilarious segments. I recommend watching that or, just as good, Bueno de Mesquita’s TED lecture or his appearance on The Daily Show. A quick Google search will reveal all of these items.

卡内基梅隆大学教授托马斯·桑德霍姆（Tuomas Sandholm）是全球最先进的博弈论算法创造者之一，享有盛誉。他基于这些理论创立了一家公司，雇佣了一百多人，后来又将其出售。如今，他找到了一种更好的方法来构建扑克游戏机器人，更重要的是，能够匹配器官捐献者。他的工作拯救了生命。他的日程安排很满，但他还是多次抽出时间与我进行长谈。

Carnegie Mellon professor Tuomas Sandholm has built a reputation as one of the most advanced creators of game theory algorithms in the world. He built a company on these theories to employ more than one hundred people, then sold it, and has now found a better way to build poker-playing bots and, more important, to match organ donors. His work saves lives. He maintains a busy schedule, but he took time to talk with me at length on multiple occasions.

特里·麦奎尔博士是我交谈过的最有趣的两三个人之一。几十年来，他一直担任美国国家航空航天局（NASA）的首席心理学家，为该机构的稳定发挥了重要作用。他曾被苏联突击队深入敌后追捕，也是约翰·格伦等人的密友。在我们如今所知的攀岩和登山装备出现之前，麦奎尔曾与世界级登山者一起攀登过北美一些最险峻的山峰。他关于我们思维方式以及言语如何泄露我们个性和真实意图的洞见，构成了我书中某一章节的基础，也构成了正在入侵所有人类交流媒介的一类新型算法的基础。

Dr. Terry McGuire is one of the two or three most interesting people I have ever spoken with. He was a stabilizing force at NASA for decades while serving as the agency’s main psychologist. He has been chased by Soviet commandos behind enemy lines and was a confidant to men like John Glenn. Before there was the equipment that we know today for rock climbing and mountaineering, McGuire scaled some of the thorniest peaks in North America with world-class climbers. His insights on how our minds work and the way in which words betray our personalities and true intentions form the basis of a chapter of my book and a new class of algorithms that is invading all mediums of human communication.

赫奇斯·卡珀斯对特里·麦奎尔也给出了同样的评价，而他对这个问题的深刻见解对我来说同样重要。他能如此迅速地从我的言谈中分析出我的性格，这让我惊叹不已。他对我自身性格倾向的分析相当准确。

Hedges Capers says the same about Terry McGuire, and his insights on the topic proved to be just as important for me. I marveled at how quickly he analyzed my own personality from the words I spoke. His analysis of my own tendencies as a person was quite accurate.

凯利·康威（Kelly Conway）曾多次与我共度数小时，详细阐述他的公司（当时名为 eLoyalty，现更名为 Mattersight Corporation）如何构建算法，用他的话来说，就是对人类语言进行分类。如今，康威的公司专注于这项使命。从公司在纳斯达克的股票价格来看，他的计划在经历了早期的波折后，进展非常顺利。康威是一位创新者，也是一位优秀的沟通者，我非常感谢他抽出时间与我交流。

Kelly Conway spent hours with me on more than one occasion to detail how his company—then called eLoyalty and now Mattersight Corporation—constructed algorithms to, as he says, categorize the human language. Conway’s company has now focused on this mission alone, and, by the looks of the value of his company’s shares on the Nasdaq, his plan is working out incredibly well after some rough waters early on. Conway is an innovator and an excellent communicator in his own right, and I’m indebted to him for the time he spent with me.

杜克大学教授维韦克·瓦德瓦总是乐于谈论华尔街与硅谷的对立——他从人才争夺战的双方汲取的观点，塑造了那一章。杰夫·哈默巴赫并非唯一一位从纽约叛逃到湾区的工程师，但他是其中最重要的一位。作为一家热门初创公司的创始人，他生活中的空闲时间不多，我感谢他给了我一些。Redfin 首席执行官格伦·凯尔曼也是如此，我多年前认识他，当时他的精辟建议帮助我写下了我的第一本书。他的想法对于正确描绘当今硅谷的景象至关重要。

Vivek Wadhwa, a professor at Duke University, was always up for a chat on Wall Street versus Silicon Valley—his views, gleaned from both sides of the talent war, helped shape that chapter. Jeff Hammerbacher isn’t the only engineer to defect from New York to the Bay Area, but he’s one of the most important. As the founder of a hot startup, he has few spare minutes in his life, and I thank him for giving some to me. The same can be said for Redfin CEO Glenn Kelman, whom I met years ago and whose pithy advice at that time helped convince me to write my first book. His thoughts were instrumental in painting the right picture of the Silicon Valley scene right now.

我研究这项工作所需的许多书籍，尤其是关于算法交易和金融的书籍，都非常昂贵。作为一名作家，我喜欢尽可能地买书，但这些为华尔街算法作家编写的书籍，很多都要花费一百美元甚至更多。幸运的是，我住在西北大学所在的城镇，那里巨大的图书馆收藏了我所寻找的每一本晦涩难懂的书籍。同样幸运的是，西北大学的校友可以完全使用其书库和资源，这为我提供了一个宽敞安静的工作室，无论早晚都开放，甚至在两个时间段都开放。在整理关于算法历史的章节时，我发现自己不得不寻找一些旧文献，这些文献通常已经绝版，很难找到。同样，西北大学拥有所有这些资料，我可以随意浏览。那里的图书管理员甚至免除了我几本书的高额滞纳金。谢谢。

Many of the books I needed for researching this work, especially the ones on algorithmic trading and finance, were quite expensive. As an author, I like to buy books whenever I can, but many of these volumes, put together for aspiring Wall Street algorithm writers, cost a hundred dollars or more. Luckily for me, I live in the same town as Northwestern University, where the huge library houses every single arcane book I’ve ever sought. Also luckily for me, Northwestern gives alumni full access to its stacks and resources, affording me a vast and quiet workshop that was open early, late, and at all hours in between. When putting together the chapter on the history of algorithms, I found myself seeking old texts, often out of print and hard to find. Again, Northwestern had all of these materials, and I was able to browse them at will. The librarians there even waived some hefty late fees I had accrued on several books. Thank you.

我开始写这本书，并大部分内容是在《福布斯》杂志担任撰稿人时写的。然而，当我完成的时候，我已经离开《福布斯》，创办了一家名为 Aisle50 的初创公司，为消费者提供食品杂货折扣。这对我来说是一次很大的改变，但我也欣然接受了。一路走来，我得到了很多人的帮助，其中最了不起的莫过于 Y Combinator 的投资者和顾问保罗·格雷厄姆和杰西卡·利文斯顿。他们在硅谷创造了一些特别的东西，而对于好奇的人来说，恰好有一本书与这本书同时出版，由同一家出版商出版，这是迄今为止关于 Y Combinator 的最佳编年史：兰迪·斯特罗斯的《发射台》。读一读吧。

I started this book and wrote much of it as a staff writer at Forbes magazine. By the time I finished, however, I had left Forbes to form a startup, Aisle50, which offers grocery discounts to consumers. It was quite a change for me but also one that I embraced. There have been many helping hands along the way, some of the most formidable ones coming from our investors and advisers at Y Combinator, Paul Graham and Jessica Livingston. They have built something special in Silicon Valley, and, for the curious, there happens to be a book being released at exactly the same time as this one, by the same publisher, that is the best chronicle ever put together on Y Combinator: Randy Stross’s The Launch Pad. Read it.

至于Aisle50，我对它寄予厚望，这要感谢我们精干的销售和工程团队，他们已经证明自己能够应对迄今为止我们面临的所有挑战，而且挑战有很多。最重要的是，我非常感谢我的联合创始人莱利·斯科特。除了你和配偶之间的关系之外，没有什么比你和联合创始人之间的关系更亲密了。我们一起生活，连续几个月每天工作15个小时，一起欢笑，甚至一起哭泣。莱利是一位不知疲倦的工作者，一位好丈夫、好父亲和好朋友——在生意场上，我最想和他共事。他是一个坚强的人，生活中不乏挑战，有些挑战他以雄心勃勃的姿态欣然接受，而有些挑战，包括最艰难的挑战，他却选择坦然面对。他以很少有人能拥有的力量应对人生的转折。这很鼓舞人心。

As for Aisle50, I have high hopes thanks to our crack sales and engineering teams, who have proven to be up to every challenge we faced so far, and there have been many. Most important, I’m grateful to Riley Scott, my cofounder. Other than the relationship you share with your spouse, there is none as intense as the relationship you share with your cofounder. We’ve lived together, worked together fifteen hours a day for months on end, laughed together, and even cried together. Riley is a tireless worker, a great husband, father, and friend—and there’s nobody with whom I’d rather be in business. He’s a strong person whose life has not been short on challenges, some of which he willingly courted as an ambitious person, and some of which, including the most harrowing, he did not. He has met the turns of life with a strength that few could have mustered. It’s inspiring.

笔记

NOTES

第一章：华尔街，第一张多米诺骨牌

CHAPTER 1: WALL STREET, THE FIRST DOMINO

1. Carolyn Cui，《从治愈到致富》，《亚洲华尔街日报》， 2010 年 4 月 27 日，第 A9 页。

1. Carolyn Cui, “From Healing to Making a Killing,” Wall Street Journal Asia, April 27, 2010, p. A9.

2. Suzanne McGee，《A Breed Apart》，《机构投资者》， 2005 年 11 月 10 日。

2. Suzanne McGee, “A Breed Apart,” Institutional Investor, November 10, 2005.

3. Joe Klein，《Sweet Sweetback 的华尔街之歌》，纽约， 1983 年 9 月 5 日，第 43 页。

3. Joe Klein, “Sweet Sweetback’s Wall Street Song,” New York, September 5, 1983, p. 43.

4. 同上。

4. Ibid.

5. 彼得菲仍然将其中一块石板放在他办公室的木制展示柜中。

5. Peterffy still keeps one of the tablets in a wooden display case in his office.

6. Thomas Bass，《预测者》（纽约：Henry Holt，1999 年），第 126 页。

6. Thomas Bass, The Predictors (New York: Henry Holt, 1999), p. 126.

7. Felix Salmon 和 Jon Stokes，《算法控制华尔街》，《连线》， 2010 年 12 月 27 日。

第二章：人类与算法简史

CHAPTER 2: A BRIEF HISTORY OF MAN AND ALGORITHMS

1. http://news.ycombinator.com。

1. http://news.ycombinator.com.

2. Jean-Luc Chabert 编，《算法史：从鹅卵石到微芯片》， Chris Weeks 译（柏林：Springer-Verlag，1999 年）。

2. Jean-Luc Chabert, ed., A History of Algorithms: From the Pebble to the Microchip, translated by Chris Weeks (Berlin: Springer-Verlag, 1999).

3. 作者本人在作为本科工程师的 C 语言编程课上就被分配了井字游戏机问题。

3. The author was assigned the tic-tac-toe machine problem himself as an undergraduate engineer in a C-language programming class.

4. Chabert，《算法史》。本导言部分主要参考了 Chabert 先生的著作。

4. Chabert, A History of Algorithms. This introductory section relies heavily on the work of Mr. Chabert.

5. 同上。

5. Ibid.

6. Godfried Toussaint，《欧几里得算法生成传统音乐节奏》（蒙特利尔：麦吉尔大学计算机科学学院，2005 年），http://cgm.cs.mcgill.ca/~godfried/publications/banff.pdf。

6. Godfried Toussaint, The Euclidean Algorithm Generates Traditional Musical Rhythms (Montreal: School of Computer Science, McGill University, 2005), http://cgm.cs.mcgill.ca/~godfried/publications/banff.pdf.

7. Midhat J. Gazale，《日晷：从法老到分形》（新泽西州普林斯顿：普林斯顿大学出版社，1999 年），第 33 页。

7. Midhat J. Gazale, Gnomon: From Pharaohs to Fractals (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 1999), p. 33.

8. Niall Ferguson，《货币的崛起》（纽约：企鹅出版社，2008年），第34页。

8. Niall Ferguson, The Ascent of Money (New York: Penguin, 2008), p. 34.

9. Henry Linger 编，《构建知识经济的基础设施》，第 12 届信息系统与发展国际会议论文集，澳大利亚墨尔本，2003 年（纽约：Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers，2004 年）。

9. Henry Linger, ed., Constructing the Infrastructure for the Knowledge Economy, Proceedings of the 12th International Conference on Information Systems and Development, Melbourne, Australia, 2003 (New York: Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers, 2004).

10. “苹果与黄金比例”，保罗·马丁博客， http://paulmmartinblog.wordpress.com/2011/07/18/apple-and-the-golden-ratio/。

10. “Apple and the Golden Ratio,” Paul Martin’s Blog, http://paulmmartinblog.wordpress.com/2011/07/18/apple-and-the-golden-ratio/.

11. 弗格森，《货币的崛起》，第34页。

11. Ferguson, The Ascent of Money, p. 34.

12. Dirk Struik，《数学简史》（纽约州米尼奥拉：多佛，1948 年），第 80 页。

12. Dirk Struik, A Concise History of Mathematics (Mineola, NY: Dover, 1948), p. 80.

13. David Berlinski，《算法的问世：从创意到计算机的300年历程》（纽约：Mariner，2001年），第 14 页。

13. David Berlinski, The Advent of the Algorithm: The 300-Year Journey from an Idea to the Computer (New York: Mariner, 2001), p. 14.

14. 同上，第 2 页。

14. Ibid., p. 2.

15. 伯特兰·罗素，《莱布尼茨哲学批判性阐释》（纽约：Cosimo Books，2008年），第192页。

15. Bertrand Russell, A Critical Exposition of the Philosophy of Leibniz (New York: Cosimo Books, 2008), p. 192.

16. Chabert，《算法史》，第 44 页。

12. Kevin McCoy, “Lawsuit: Walgreens Prescription Error Killed Man,” USA Today, November 2, 2007.

13. Vinod Khosla，“我们需要医生还是算法？” TechCrunch， 2012 年 1 月 10 日，http://techcrunch.com/2012/01/10/doctors-or-algorithms/。

13. Vinod Khosla, “Do We Need Doctors or Algorithms?” TechCrunch, January 10, 2012, http://techcrunch.com/2012/01/10/doctors-or-algorithms/.

14. Jerome Groopman，《医生如何思考》（纽约：霍顿·米夫林，2007 年）。

14. Jerome Groopman, How Doctors Think (New York: Houghton Mifflin, 2007).

15. 同上。

15. Ibid.

16. Fred Herbert，《回顾（和回顾）：一位老式医生的反思》（佐治亚州梅肯：默瑟大学出版社，2003 年），第 37 页。

16. Fred Herbert, Looking Back (and Forth): Reflections of an Old-fashioned Doctor (Macon, GA: Mercer University Press, 2003), p. 37.

17. David Leonhardt，《让医疗保健变得更好》，《纽约时报杂志》， 2009 年 11 月 3 日。

17. David Leonhardt, “Making Health Care Better,” New York Times Magazine, November 3, 2009.

18. 同上。

18. Ibid.

19. 同上。

19. Ibid.

20. “什么是心力衰竭？”美国国家心肺血液研究所，http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/health-topics/topics/hf/。

20. “What Is Heart Failure?” National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute, http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/health-topics/topics/hf/.

第七章：人类的分类

CHAPTER 7: CATEGORIZING HUMANKIND

1. Judy L. Hasday，《阿波罗 13 号任务》（纽约：切尔西出版社，2001 年），第 16 页。

1. Judy L. Hasday, The Apollo 13 Mission (New York: Chelsea House, 2001), p. 16.

2. 安德鲁·柴金（Andrew Chaikin），《月球上的人：阿波罗宇航员的航行》（纽约：企鹅出版社，1995 年）。

2. Andrew Chaikin, A Man on the Moon: The Voyages of the Apollo Astronauts (New York: Penguin, 1995).

3. 我和卡珀斯的第一次谈话持续了将近两个小时。谈话结束时，他向我介绍了我的性格。我发现，我最大的特点是思想驱动。我比较务实，通常基于事实做决定，但我不擅长授权，而且在压力下容易暴躁（后者对于作家或科技创业者来说可不是什么好品质）。我们刚开始聊天时，卡珀斯描述了这个理论是如何运作的，我跟着他点头。说实话，我当时还不太相信这个理论。他怎么可能仅凭我的言辞就能知道我的想法？我可能说一套，但实际意思却完全不同。

3. During my first conversation with Capers, which lasted almost two hours, he debriefed me on my own personality at the end of our talk. It turns out that the largest piece of my persona is thoughts-driven. I’m pragmatic and usually make decisions based on facts, but I also have a hard time delegating and can become irate under pressure (the latter part not being a fabulous trait for an author or a tech entrepreneur). When we first started chatting, Capers described how the theory worked, and I followed along, nodding. Truth be told, I wasn’t yet sold on this whole thing. How could he know what I was thinking based solely on my words? I could say one thing and mean something completely different.

有一次，我就是这么做的——我经常这么做。卡珀斯继续他早期的解释时，我经常点头回应，并说“有意思”。他后来告诉我，这句话清楚地表明我并没有留下什么印象，而且我仍在保留意见。“你的意思不是‘嘿，这很有趣’，”卡珀斯向我解释道。“你真正想说的是，‘嗯，我不太确定。’”

In one case, that’s what I did—it’s something I often do. As Capers continued his early explanations, I often responded with a nod and the reply of “interesting.” This utterance, he later told me, clearly signaled that I wasn’t impressed and that I was still withholding judgment. “You don’t actually mean, ‘Hey, that’s interesting,’” Capers explained to me. “What you’re really saying is, ‘Hmm, I’m not sure about that.’”

他一针见血。一个以思考为基础的人，如果回复简短，缺乏情感，通常只是在钓鱼，想了解更多信息。要么就是他们根本就不感兴趣。但卡珀斯说，当他开始跟我讲一些测试数据时，我一下子兴奋起来。“你说，‘哇，这太酷了’，”他回忆道。“当一个以思考为基础的人把副词和形容词，比如‘酷’，放在一起时，意思是你真的被打动了。”

He was spot on. A thoughts-based person who issues short replies with little emotion is often just trolling for more information. Either that or they’re totally uninterested. But Capers said I later perked up when he started telling me about some test statistics. “You said, ‘Wow, that’s really cool,’” he recounted. “When a thoughts-based person puts an adverb together with an adjective such as ‘cool,’ it means you’re truly impressed.”

确实如此。和所有人一样，我的性格在七八岁时就基本形成了。

Indeed I was. Just like everybody else, my personality had mostly been formed by the time I was seven or eight years old.

4. 卡珀斯本人也有一段有趣的经历，包括他曾在摇滚乐界的职业生涯。他是20世纪60年代至70年代摇滚乐队“Hedge and Donna”的成员之一，该乐队在十年间发行了六张唱片。他的演艺生涯也引领他进入了电影界；他主演了1974年的电影《乡巴佬约翰传奇》。当他在好莱坞的运气耗尽后，卡珀斯在学校完成了成为一名精神科医生所需的学业。他在圣地亚哥遇到了卡勒，在那里，他很快便掌握了卡勒、麦奎尔和美国国家航空航天局（NASA）共同创立的理论。

4. Capers has an interesting story himself, including a career stint in rock and roll. He was one-half of the 1960s–1970s rock group Hedge and Donna, who released six records during a ten-year stretch. His showbiz career also led him to the movies; he starred in 1974’s The Legend of Hillbilly John. When his Hollywood luck ran out, Capers spent the requisite years in school to become a psychiatrist. He met Kahler in San Diego, where he proved a quick learner of the theory Kahler, McGuire, and NASA had developed.

5. 塞巴斯蒂安·马拉比，《金钱胜过上帝：对冲基金与新精英的形成》（纽约：企鹅出版社，2010 年）。

5. Sebastian Mallaby, More Money Than God: Hedge Funds and the Making of a New Elite (New York: Penguin Press, 2010).

6. Peter Brown、Robert Mercer、Stephen Della Pietra 和 Vincent J. Della Pietra，《统计机器翻译的数学：参数估计》，《计算语言学杂志》 19，第 2 期（1993 年）：263-311。

6. Peter Brown, Robert Mercer, Stephen Della Pietra, and Vincent J. Della Pietra, “The Mathematics of Statistical Machine Translation: Parameter Estimation,” Journal of Computational Linguistics 19, no. 2 (1993): 263–311.

7. Ingfei Chen，《科学家在工作：尼克·帕特森》，《纽约时报》， 2006年12月12日。

7. Ingfei Chen, “Scientist at Work: Nick Patterson,” New York Times, December 12, 2006.

第八章：华尔街与硅谷

CHAPTER 8: WALL STREET VERSUS SILICON VALLEY

1. Rana Foroohar，《华尔街：助力经济复苏，还是扼杀经济复苏？》 ，《时代》杂志， 2011年4月4日。

1. Rana Foroohar, “Wall Street: Aiding the Economic Recovery, or Strangling It?” Time, April 4, 2011.

2. 在Teza组建团队期间，马雷舍夫招募了高盛的程序员谢尔盖·阿列尼科夫，并提出将阿列尼科夫40万美元的年薪翻三倍至120万美元。阿列尼科夫同意了，并迅速搬到了芝加哥。在Teza工作的第二天，阿列尼科夫因涉嫌窃取高盛的计算机代码而被捕。在高盛工作的最后三天，阿列尼科夫系统地将大量高盛的交易代码上传到德国的一台服务器。但高盛的技术安全部门发现了这一行为，并向联邦调查局报告了此事。2011年，阿列尼科夫被联邦法院判处八年监禁。然而，2012年2月，辩方辩称控方在本案中不公平地引用了《经济间谍法》，纽约一家美国上诉法院推翻了原判，阿列尼科夫因此获得了喘息的机会。

2. While building his team at Teza, Malyshev recruited a Goldman Sachs programmer, Sergey Aleynikov, by offering to triple his $400,000 salary to $1.2 million. Aleynikov agreed to come over and made a hasty move to Chicago. A day after he began working at Teza, Aleynikov was arrested on charges that he had stolen computer code from Goldman. During his last three days of work at Goldman, Aleynikov had systematically uploaded big chunks of Goldman’s trading code to a server in Germany. But Goldman’s tech security spotted the maneuver and alerted the FBI. In 2011, Aleynikov received an eight-year jail sentence from a federal court. In February 2012, however, he got a break as a U.S. appeals court in New York overturned the conviction after the defense argued that the prosecution had unfairly utilized the Economic Espionage Act in the case.

3. Jacob Bunge 和 Amy Or，《前 Citadel 员工因涉嫌窃取代码被捕》， 道琼斯通讯社，2011 年 10 月 13 日。

3. Jacob Bunge and Amy Or, “Ex-Citadel Employee Arrested for Allegedly Stealing Code,” Dow Jones Newswires, October 13, 2011.

4. 保罗·克鲁格曼，《市场奥秘》，《纽约时报》， 2009年3月26日。

4. Paul Krugman, “The Market Mystique,” New York Times, March 26, 2009.

5. 美国中央情报局世界概况，https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/。

5. The CIA World Factbook, https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/.

CHAPTER 9: WALL STREET’S LOSS IS A GAIN FOR THE REST OF US
